376 </a>

632 <path d="M19 8H5c-1.66 0-3 1.34-3 3v6h4v4h12v-4h4v-6c0-1.66-1.34-3-3-3zm-3 11H8v-5h8v5zm3-7c-.55 0-1-.45-1-1s.45-1 1-1 1 .45 1 1-.45 1-1 1zm-1-9H6v4h12V3z"/>

642 <a class="usa-button usa-button--unstyled" href="mailto:?subject=Information from the National Cancer Institute Web Site &body=I found this information on www.cancer.gov and I'd like to share it with you: https://www.cancer.gov/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq %0D%0A%0D%0A NCI's Web site, www.cancer.gov, provides accurate, up-to-date, comprehensive cancer information from the U.S. government's principal agency for cancer research. If you have questions or need additional information, we invite you to contact NCI's LiveHelp instant messaging service at https://livehelp.cancer.gov, or call the NCI's Contact Center 1-800-4-CANCER (1-800-422-6237) (toll-free from the United States).">

818<article>

819

820 <div class="resize-content">

821

822 <h1>

823Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment (PDQ®)–Health Professional Version</h1>

824

825 <div id="cgvBody">

826

827 <div class="summary-sections">

828

829 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

830

831 <h6>

832On This Page</h6>

833

834 <ul>

835

836 <li>

838General Information About Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)</a>

839</li>

840

841 <li>

843World Health Organization (WHO) Classification System for Childhood ALL</a>

844</li>

845

849</li>

854</li>

859</li>

860

861 <li>

864</li>

865

866 <li>

867<a href="#_727">

869</li>

870

899

900

901 <div class="accordion">

902

903

904

905 <section id="_1">

906

907 <h2>

908General Information About Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)</h2>

909

910 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

911<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

912<h6>

913In This Section</h6>

914<ul>

915<li>

916<a href="#_7_toc">

917Incidence</a>

918</li>

919<li>

920<a href="#_608_toc">

921Anatomy</a>

922</li>

923<li>

924<a href="#_2177_toc">

925Morphology</a>

926</li>

927<li>

928<a href="#_12_toc">

929Risk Factors for Developing ALL<ul>

930<li>

931<a href="#_62_toc">

932Down syndrome</a>

933</li>

934<li>

935<a href="#_67_toc">

936Low- and high-penetrance inherited genetic variants </a>

937</li>

938<li>

939<a href="#_1552_toc">

940Prenatal origin of childhood ALL</a>

941</li>

942</ul>

943</a>

944</li>

945<li>

946<a href="#_767_toc">

947Clinical Presentation</a>

948</li>

949<li>

950<a href="#_552_toc">

951Diagnosis</a>

952</li>

953<li>

954<a href="#_19_toc">

955Overall Prognosis</a>

956</li>

957<li>

958<a href="#_TrialSearch_1_sid_1_toc">

959Current Clinical Trials</a>

960</li>

961</ul>

962</nav>

963<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

964<a href="/types/leukemia/patient/child-all-treatment-pdq">

965Go to Patient Version</a>

966</div>

967<p id="_6" tabindex="-1">

968Cancer in children and adolescents is rare, although the overall incidence of childhood cancer, including ALL, has been slowly increasing since 1975.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9691</a>

970] Dramatic improvements in survival have been achieved in children and adolescents with cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9711</a>

972-<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9733</a>

974] Between 1975 and 2020, childhood cancer mortality decreased by more than 50%, although cancer remains the leading cause of death by disease past infancy among children in the United States.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9751</a>

976,<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9772</a>

978,<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

9794</a>

980,<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

9815</a>

982] For ALL, the 5-year survival rate increased over the same time, from 60% to approximately 90% for children younger than 15 years, and from 28% to more than 75% for adolescents aged 15 to 19 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9832</a>

984,<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9853</a>

986,<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

9876</a>

988] Childhood and adolescent cancer survivors require close monitoring because cancer therapy side effects may persist or develop months or years after treatment. For specific information about the incidence, type, and monitoring of late effects in childhood and adolescent cancer survivors, see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq">

989Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</a>

990.</p>

991<section id="_7">

992<h3 id="_7_toc">

993Incidence</h3>

994<p id="_10" tabindex="-1">

995ALL, the most common cancer diagnosed in children, represents approximately 25% of cancer diagnoses among children younger than 15 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

9967</a>

997] In the United States, ALL occurs at an annual rate of approximately 40 cases per 1 million people aged 0 to 14 years and approximately 21 cases per 1 million people aged 15 to 19 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9983</a>

999] There are approximately 3,100 children and adolescents younger than 20 years diagnosed with ALL each year in the United States.[<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

10008</a>

1001] Since 1975, there has been a gradual increase in the incidence of ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

10022</a>

1003,<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

10049</a>

1005]</p>

1006<p id="_61" tabindex="-1">

1007A sharp peak in ALL incidence is observed among children aged 1 to 4 years (81 cases per 1 million per year), with rates decreasing to 24 cases per 1 million by age 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

10083</a>

1009] The incidence of ALL among children aged 1 to 4 years is approximately fourfold greater than that for infants and for children aged 10 years and older.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

10103</a>

1011]</p>

1012<p id="_11" tabindex="-1">

1013 The incidence of ALL appears to be highest in American Indian or Alaska Native children and adolescents (65.9 cases per 1 million) and Hispanic children and adolescents (48 cases per 1 million).[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

10143</a>

1015,<a href="#cit/section_1.10">

101610</a>

1017,<a href="#cit/section_1.11">

101811</a>

1019] The incidence is substantially higher in White children than in Black children, with a twofold higher incidence of ALL from age 1 to 4 years in White children than in Black children.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

10203</a>

1021,<a href="#cit/section_1.10">

102210</a>

1023]</p>

1024</section>

1025<section id="_608">

1026<h3 id="_608_toc">

1027Anatomy</h3>

1028<p id="_609" tabindex="-1">

1029Childhood ALL originates in the T and B lymphoblasts in tissues with hematopoietic progenitor cells, such as the bone marrow and thymus (see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_610">

1030Figure 1</a>

1031). <figure id="figure_610" class="image-center">

1032<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/526538.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1033Enlarge</a>

1034<img id="_610" alt="Blood cell development; drawing shows the steps a blood stem cell goes through to become a red blood cell, platelet, or white blood cell. A myeloid stem cell becomes a red blood cell, a platelet, or a myeloblast, which then becomes a granulocyte (the types of granulocytes are eosinophils, basophils, and neutrophils). A lymphoid stem cell becomes a lymphoblast and then becomes a B-lymphocyte, T-lymphocyte, or natural killer cell." title="Blood cell development; drawing shows the steps a blood stem cell goes through to become a red blood cell, platelet, or white blood cell. A myeloid stem cell becomes a red blood cell, a platelet, or a myeloblast, which then becomes a granulocyte (the types of granulocytes are eosinophils, basophils, and neutrophils). A lymphoid stem cell becomes a lymphoblast and then becomes a B-lymphocyte, T-lymphocyte, or natural killer cell." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/526538-750.jpg">

1035<figcaption class="caption-container">

1036Figure 1. Blood cell development. Different blood and immune cell lineages, including T and B lymphocytes, differentiate from a common blood stem cell.</figcaption>

1037</figure>

1038</p>

1039<p id="_1438" tabindex="-1">

1040Marrow involvement of acute leukemia as seen by light microscopy is defined as follows:

1041

1042</p>

1043<div class="pdq-content-list">

1044<ul id="_1439">

1045<li>

1046M1: Fewer than 5% blast cells.</li>

1047<li>

1048M2: 5% to 25% blast cells.</li>

1049<li>

1050M3: Greater than 25% blast cells.</li>

1051</ul>

1052</div>

1053<p id="_1440" tabindex="-1">

1054Almost all patients with ALL present with an M3 marrow.

1055</p>

1056</section>

1057<section id="_2177">

1058<h3 id="_2177_toc">

1059Morphology</h3>

1060<p id="_496" tabindex="-1">

1061In the past, ALL lymphoblasts were classified using

1062the French-American-British (FAB) criteria as having L1, L2, or L3 morphology.[<a href="#cit/section_1.12">

106312</a>

1064] However, it is no longer used because of the lack of independent prognostic

1065significance and the subjective nature of this classification system. </p>

1066<p id="_593" tabindex="-1">

1067Most cases of ALL that show L3 morphology express surface immunoglobulin (Ig) and have a <em class="gene-name">

1068MYC</em>

1069 gene translocation identical to those seen in Burkitt lymphoma (i.e., t(8;14)(q24;q32), t(2;8)) that join <em class="gene-name">

1070MYC</em>

1071 to one of the Ig genes. Patients with this specific rare form of leukemia (mature B-cell or Burkitt leukemia) should be treated according to protocols for Burkitt lymphoma. For

1072more information about the treatment of mature B-cell lymphoma/leukemia and Burkitt lymphoma/leukemia, see <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/child-nhl-treatment-pdq">

1073Childhood Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment</a>

1074. Rarely, blasts with L1/L2 (not L3) morphology will express surface Ig.[<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

107513</a>

1076] These patients should be treated in the same way as patients with B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

107713</a>

1078]</p>

1079</section>

1080<section id="_12">

1081<h3 id="_12_toc">

1082Risk Factors for Developing ALL</h3>

1083<p id="_13" tabindex="-1">

1084Few factors associated with an increased risk of ALL have been identified. The primary accepted risk factors for ALL and associated genes (when relevant) include the following:</p>

1085<div class="pdq-content-list">

1086<ul id="_14">

1087<li>

1088Prenatal exposure to x-rays.</li>

1089<li>

1090Postnatal exposure to high doses of radiation (e.g., therapeutic radiation previously used for conditions such as tinea capitis and thymus enlargement).</li>

1091<li>

1092Previous treatment with chemotherapy.</li>

1093<li>

1094 Genetic conditions that include the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1095<ul id="_644" class="list-dash">

1096<li>

1097Down syndrome. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_62">

1098Down syndrome</a>

1099 section.</li>

1100<li>

1101Neurofibromatosis (<em class="gene-name">

1102NF1</em>

1103).[<a href="#cit/section_1.14">

110414</a>

1105]</li>

1106<li>

1107Bloom syndrome (<em class="gene-name">

1108BLM</em>

1109).[<a href="#cit/section_1.15">

111015</a>

1111]</li>

1112<li>

1113Fanconi anemia (multiple genes; ALL is observed much less frequently than acute myeloid leukemia [AML]).[<a href="#cit/section_1.16">

111416</a>

1115]</li>

1116<li>

1117Ataxia telangiectasia (<em class="gene-name">

1118ATM</em>

1119).[<a href="#cit/section_1.17">

112017</a>

1121]</li>

1122<li>

1123Li-Fraumeni syndrome (<em class="gene-name">

1124TP53</em>

1125).[<a href="#cit/section_1.18">

112618</a>

1127-<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

112820</a>

1129]</li>

1130<li>

1131Constitutional mismatch repair deficiency (biallelic mutation of <em class="gene-name">

1132MLH1</em>

1133, <em class="gene-name">

1134MSH2</em>

1135, <em class="gene-name">

1136MSH6</em>

1137, and <em class="gene-name">

1138PMS2</em>

1139).[<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

114021</a>

1141,<a href="#cit/section_1.22">

114222</a>

1143]</li>

1144</ul>

1145</div>

1146</li>

1147<li>

1148Low- and high-penetrance inherited genetic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_1.23">

114923</a>

1150] For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_67">

1151Low- and high-penetrance inherited genetic variants</a>

1152 section.</li>

1153<li>

1154Carriers of a constitutional Robertsonian translocation that involves chromosomes 15 and 21 and carriers of constitutional ring chromosome 21 are specifically and highly predisposed to developing intrachromosomal amplification of chromosome 21 (iAMP21) ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_1.24">

115524</a>

1156,<a href="#cit/section_1.25">

115725</a>

1158]</li>

1159</ul>

1160</div>

1161<section id="_62">

1162<h4 id="_62_toc">

1163Down syndrome</h4>

1164<p id="_63" tabindex="-1">

1165Children with Down syndrome have an increased risk of developing both ALL and AML,[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

116626</a>

1167-<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

116828</a>

1169] with a cumulative risk of developing leukemia of approximately 2.1% by age 5 years and 2.7% by age 30 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

117026</a>

1171,<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

117228</a>

1173] These rates represent a 20- to 30-fold increased risk of ALL and over 100-fold increased risk of AML for children with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.27">

117427</a>

1175,<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

117628</a>

1177]</p>

1178<p id="_66" tabindex="-1">

1179Approximately one-half to two-thirds of cases of acute leukemia in children with Down syndrome are ALL, and about 2% to 3% of childhood ALL cases occur in children with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.29">

118029</a>

1181-<a href="#cit/section_1.32">

118232</a>

1183] ALL in children with Down syndrome has an age distribution similar to that of ALL in children without Down syndrome, with a median age of 3 to 4 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.29">

118429</a>

1185,<a href="#cit/section_1.30">

118630</a>

1187] In contrast, the vast majority of cases of AML in children with Down syndrome occur before the age of 4 years (median age, 1 year).[<a href="#cit/section_1.33">

118833</a>

1189]</p>

1190<p id="_64" tabindex="-1">

1191Patients with ALL and Down syndrome have a lower incidence of both favorable (<em class="gene-name">

1192ETV6</em>

1193::<em class="gene-name">

1194RUNX1</em>

1195 fusion and hyperdiploidy [51&#8211;65 chromosomes]) and unfavorable (<em class="gene-name">

1196BCR</em>

1197::<em class="gene-name">

1198ABL1</em>

1199 or <em class="gene-name">

1200KMT2A</em>

1201::<em class="gene-name">

1202AFF1</em>

1203 fusions and hypodiploidy [&lt;44 chromosomes]) genomic alterations and a near absence of T-cell phenotype.[<a href="#cit/section_1.29">

120429</a>

1205-<a href="#cit/section_1.31">

120631</a>

1207,<a href="#cit/section_1.33">

120833</a>

1209,<a href="#cit/section_1.34">

121034</a>

1211]</p>

1212<p id="_1922" tabindex="-1">

1213Approximately 50% to 60% of cases of ALL in children with Down syndrome have genomic alterations affecting <em class="gene-name">

1214CRLF2</em>

1215 that generally result in overexpression of the protein produced by this gene, which dimerizes with the interleukin-7 receptor alpha to form the receptor for the cytokine thymic stromal lymphopoietin.[<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

121635</a>

1217-<a href="#cit/section_1.37">

121837</a>

1219] The <em class="gene-name">

1220P2RY8</em>

1221::<em class="gene-name">

1222CRLF2</em>

1223 fusion occurs much more commonly than the <em class="gene-name">

1224IGH</em>

1225::<em class="gene-name">

1226CRLF2</em>

1227 fusion in children with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.37">

122837</a>

1229,<a href="#cit/section_1.38">

123038</a>

1231] <em class="gene-name">

1232CRLF2</em>

1233 genomic alterations are observed at a much lower frequency (&lt;10%) in children with B-ALL who do not have Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.37">

123437</a>

1235,<a href="#cit/section_1.39">

123639</a>

1237,<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

123840</a>

1239] Based on the relatively small number of published series, it does not appear that genomic<em class="gene-name">

1240 CRLF2</em>

1241 aberrations in patients with Down syndrome and ALL have prognostic relevance, but more studies are needed to address this issue.[<a href="#cit/section_1.34">

124234</a>

1243,<a href="#cit/section_1.36">

124436</a>

1245] </p>

1246<p id="_65" tabindex="-1">

1247Approximately 20% of ALL cases arising in children with Down syndrome have somatically acquired <em class="gene-name">

1248JAK1</em>

1249 or <em class="gene-name">

1250JAK2</em>

1251 mutations,[<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

125235</a>

1253,<a href="#cit/section_1.36">

125436</a>

1255,<a href="#cit/section_1.41">

125641</a>

1257-<a href="#cit/section_1.43">

125843</a>

1259] a finding that is uncommon among younger children with ALL but that is observed in a subset of primarily older children and adolescents with high-risk B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_1.44">

126044</a>

1261] Almost all Down syndrome ALL cases with <em class="gene-name">

1262JAK</em>

1263 mutations also have <em class="gene-name">

1264CRLF2</em>

1265 genomic alterations.[<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

126635</a>

1267-<a href="#cit/section_1.37">

126837</a>

1269] Preliminary evidence suggests no correlation between <em class="gene-name">

1270JAK2</em>

1271 mutation status and 5-year event-free survival (EFS) in children with Down syndrome and ALL,[<a href="#cit/section_1.36">

127236</a>

1273,<a href="#cit/section_1.42">

127442</a>

1275] but more study is needed to address this issue.</p>

1276<p id="_2165" tabindex="-1">

1277A genome-wide association study found that four susceptibility loci associated with B-ALL in the non-Down syndrome population (<em class="gene-name">

1278IKZF1</em>

1279, <em class="gene-name">

1280CDKN2A</em>

1281, <em class="gene-name">

1282ARID5B</em>

1283, and <em class="gene-name">

1284GATA3</em>

1285) were also associated with susceptibility to ALL in children with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.45">

128645</a>

1287] <em class="gene-name">

1288CDKN2A</em>

1289 risk allele penetrance appeared to be higher for children with Down syndrome.</p>

1290<p id="_2249" tabindex="-1">

1291<em class="gene-name">

1292 IKZF1</em>

1293 gene deletions, observed in 20% to 35% of patients with Down syndrome and ALL, have been associated with a significantly worse outcome in this group of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_1.36">

129436</a>

1295,<a href="#cit/section_1.46">

129646</a>

1297,<a href="#cit/section_1.47">

129847</a>

1299]</p>

1300</section>

1301<section id="_67">

1302<h4 id="_67_toc">

1303Low- and high-penetrance inherited genetic variants </h4>

1304<p id="_68" tabindex="-1">

1305Genetic predisposition to ALL can be divided into several broad categories, as follows:</p>

1306<div class="pdq-content-list">

1307<ul id="_1847">

1308<li>

1309<strong>

1310Association with genetic syndromes.</strong>

1311 Increased risk can be associated with the genetic syndromes listed <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_644">

1312above</a>

1313 in which ALL is observed, although it is not the primary manifestation of the condition. </li>

1314<li>

1315<strong>

1316Common alleles.</strong>

1317 Another category for genetic predisposition includes common alleles with relatively small effect sizes that are identified by genome-wide association studies. Genome-wide association studies have identified a number of germline (inherited) genetic polymorphisms that are associated with the development of childhood ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_1.23">

131823</a>

1319] For example, the risk alleles of <em class="gene-name">

1320ARID5B</em>

1321 are associated with the development of hyperdiploid (51&#8211;65 chromosomes) B-ALL. <em class="gene-name">

1322ARID5B</em>

1323 is a gene that encodes a transcriptional factor important in embryonic development, cell type&#8211;specific gene expression, and cell growth regulation.[<a href="#cit/section_1.48">

132448</a>

1325,<a href="#cit/section_1.49">

132649</a>

1327] Other genes with polymorphisms associated with increased risk of ALL include <em class="gene-name">

1328GATA3</em>

1329,[<a href="#cit/section_1.50">

133050</a>

1331] <em class="gene-name">

1332IKZF1</em>

1333,[<a href="#cit/section_1.48">

133448</a>

1335,<a href="#cit/section_1.49">

133649</a>

1337,<a href="#cit/section_1.51">

133851</a>

1339] <em class="gene-name">

1340CDKN2A</em>

1341,[<a href="#cit/section_1.52">

134252</a>

1343] <em class="gene-name">

1344CDKN2B</em>

1345,[<a href="#cit/section_1.51">

134651</a>

1347,<a href="#cit/section_1.52">

134852</a>

1349] <em class="gene-name">

1350CEBPE</em>

1351,[<a href="#cit/section_1.48">

135248</a>

1353] <em class="gene-name">

1354PIP4K2A</em>

1355,[<a href="#cit/section_1.50">

135650</a>

1357,<a href="#cit/section_1.53">

135853</a>

1359] and <em class="gene-name">

1360TP63</em>

1361.[<a href="#cit/section_1.54">

136254</a>

1363]<p id="_2208" tabindex="-1">

1364Genetic risk factors for T-ALL share some overlap with the genetic risk factors for B-ALL, but unique risk factors also exist. A genome-wide association study identified a risk allele near <em class="gene-name">

1365USP7</em>

1366 that was associated with an increased risk of developing T-ALL (odds ratio, 1.44) but not B-ALL. The risk allele was shown to be associated with reduced <em class="gene-name">

1367USP7</em>

1368 transcription, which is consistent with the finding that somatic loss-of-function mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1369USP7</em>

1370 are observed in patients with T-ALL. <em class="gene-name">

1371USP7</em>

1372 germline and somatic mutations are generally mutually exclusive and are most commonly observed in T-ALL patients with <em class="gene-name">

1373TAL1</em>

1374 alterations.[<a href="#cit/section_1.55">

137555</a>

1376]</p>

1377<p id="_2250" tabindex="-1">

1378 Genetic risk factors that have similar impact for developing both B-ALL and T-ALL include <em class="gene-name">

1379CDKN2A</em>

1380, <em class="gene-name">

1381CDKN2B</em>

1382, and 8q24.21 (<em>

1383cis</em>

1384 distal enhancer region variants for <em class="gene-name">

1385MYC</em>

1386).[<a href="#cit/section_1.55">

138755</a>

1388]</p>

1389</li>

1390<li>

1391<strong>

1392Rare germline variants with high penetrance.</strong>

1393 Germline variants that cause pathogenic changes in genes associated with ALL and that are observed in kindreds with familial ALL (i.e., large effect sizes) comprise another category of genetic predisposition to ALL. Many of the genes associated with ALL risk play key roles in B-cell development (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

1394PAX5</em>

1395, <em class="gene-name">

1396ETV6</em>

1397, and <em class="gene-name">

1398IKZF1</em>

1399).[<a href="#cit/section_1.56">

140056</a>

1401]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1402<ul id="_2167">

1403<li>

1404<em class="gene-name">

1405<strong>

1406PAX5</strong>

1407</em>

1408. A germline variant in <em class="gene-name">

1409PAX5</em>

1410 that substitutes serine for glycine at amino acid 183 and that reduces <em class="gene-name">

1411PAX5</em>

1412 activity has been identified in several families that experienced multiple cases of ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_1.57">

141357</a>

1414,<a href="#cit/section_1.58">

141558</a>

1416]</li>

1417<li>

1418<em class="gene-name">

1419<strong>

1420ETV6</strong>

1421</em>

1422. Several germline <em class="gene-name">

1423ETV6</em>

1424 variants that lead to loss of ETV6 function have been identified in kindreds affected by both thrombocytopenia and ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

142559</a>

1426-<a href="#cit/section_1.63">

142763</a>

1428] Sequencing of <em class="gene-name">

1429ETV6</em>

1430 in remission (i.e., germline) specimens identified variants that were potentially related to ALL in approximately 1% of children with ALL that were evaluated.[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

143159</a>

1432] Most of the germline mutations (approximately 75%) were shown to be deleterious for <em class="gene-name">

1433ETV6</em>

1434 function, and 70% of cases with a deleterious germline <em class="gene-name">

1435ETV6</em>

1436 variant had a hyperdiploid karyotype. The remaining cases with a deleterious mutation had diploid ALL, with a transcriptional profile similar to that of cases with <em class="gene-name">

1437ETV6</em>

1438::<em class="gene-name">

1439RUNX1</em>

1440 fusion&#8211;positive ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_1.63">

144163</a>

1442]</li>

1443<li>

1444<em class="gene-name">

1445<strong>

1446TP53</strong>

1447</em>

1448. Pathogenic germline <em class="gene-name">

1449TP53</em>

1450 variants are associated with an increased risk of ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_1.64">

145164</a>

1452] A study of 3,801 children with ALL observed that 26 patients (0.7%) had a pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

1453TP53</em>

1454 germline variant, with an associated odds ratio of 5.2 for ALL development.[<a href="#cit/section_1.64">

145564</a>

1456] Compared with ALL in children with <em class="gene-name">

1457TP53</em>

1458 wild-type status or <em class="gene-name">

1459TP53</em>

1460 variants of unknown significance, ALL in children with pathogenic germline <em class="gene-name">

1461TP53</em>

1462 variants was associated with older age at diagnosis (15.5 years vs. 7.3 years), hypodiploidy (65% vs. 1%), inferior EFS and overall survival, and a higher risk of second cancers.</li>

1463<li>

1464<em class="gene-name">

1465<strong>

1466IKZF1</strong>

1467</em>

1468. Germline <em class="gene-name">

1469IKZF1</em>

1470 variants were identified in a kindred with familial ALL and in 43 of 4,963 (0.9%) children with sporadic ALL. Most (22 of 28) <em class="gene-name">

1471IKZF1</em>

1472 variants were shown to adversely affect <em class="gene-name">

1473IKZF1</em>

1474 gene function.[<a href="#cit/section_1.65">

147565</a>

1476] Germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

1477IKZF1</em>

1478 have been identified in hereditary hypogammaglobulinemia. In one series, 2 of 29 affected patients developed B-ALL during childhood.[<a href="#cit/section_1.66">

147966</a>

1480]</li>

1481</ul>

1482</div>

1483</li>

1484</ul>

1485</div>

1486</section>

1487<section id="_1552">

1488<h4 id="_1552_toc">

1489Prenatal origin of childhood ALL</h4>

1490<p id="_1553" tabindex="-1">

1491Development of ALL is a multistep process in most cases, with more than one genomic alteration required for frank leukemia to develop. In at least some cases of childhood ALL, the initial genomic alteration occurs in utero. Evidence to support this comes from the observation that the immunoglobulin or T-cell receptor antigen rearrangements that are unique to each patient&#8217;s leukemia cells can be detected in blood samples obtained at birth.[<a href="#cit/section_1.67">

149267</a>

1493,<a href="#cit/section_1.68">

149468</a>

1495] Similarly, in ALL characterized by specific chromosomal abnormalities, some patients have blood cells that carry at least one leukemic genomic abnormality at the time of birth, with additional cooperative genomic changes acquired postnatally.[<a href="#cit/section_1.67">

149667</a>

1497-<a href="#cit/section_1.69">

149869</a>

1499] Genomic studies of identical twins with concordant leukemia further support the prenatal origin of some leukemias.[<a href="#cit/section_1.67">

150067</a>

1501,<a href="#cit/section_1.70">

150270</a>

1503]</p>

1504<p id="_1554" tabindex="-1">

1505Evidence also exists that some children who never develop ALL are born with rare blood cells carrying a genomic alteration associated with ALL. Initial studies focused on the <em class="gene-name">

1506ETV6</em>

1507::<em class="gene-name">

1508RUNX1</em>

1509 translocation and used reverse transcriptase&#8211;polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to identify RNA transcripts indicating the presence of the gene fusion. For example, in one study, 1% of neonatal blood spots (Guthrie cards) tested positive for the <em class="gene-name">

1510ETV6</em>

1511::<em class="gene-name">

1512RUNX1</em>

1513 translocation.[<a href="#cit/section_1.71">

151471</a>

1515] While subsequent reports generally confirmed the presence of the <em class="gene-name">

1516ETV6</em>

1517::<em class="gene-name">

1518RUNX1</em>

1519 translocation at birth in some children, rates and extent of positivity varied widely.</p>

1520<p id="_2248" tabindex="-1">

1521 To more definitively address this question, a highly sensitive and specific DNA-based approach (genomic inverse PCR for exploration of ligated breakpoints) was applied to DNA from 1,000 cord blood specimens and found that 5% of specimens had the <em class="gene-name">

1522ETV6</em>

1523::<em class="gene-name">

1524RUNX1</em>

1525 translocation.[<a href="#cit/section_1.72">

152672</a>

1527] When the same method was applied to 340 cord blood specimens to detect the <em class="gene-name">

1528TCF3</em>

1529::<em class="gene-name">

1530PBX1</em>

1531 fusion, two cord specimens (0.6%) were positive for its presence.[<a href="#cit/section_1.73">

153273</a>

1533] For both <em class="gene-name">

1534ETV6</em>

1535::<em class="gene-name">

1536RUNX1</em>

1537 and <em class="gene-name">

1538TCF3</em>

1539::<em class="gene-name">

1540PBX1</em>

1541, the percentage of cord blood specimens positive for one of the translocations far exceeds the percentage of children who will develop either type of ALL (&lt;0.01%).</p>

1542</section>

1543</section>

1544<section id="_767">

1545<h3 id="_767_toc">

1546Clinical Presentation</h3>

1547<p id="_768" tabindex="-1">

1548The typical and atypical symptoms and clinical findings of childhood ALL have been published.[<a href="#cit/section_1.74">

154974</a>

1550-<a href="#cit/section_1.76">

155176</a>

1552]</p>

1553</section>

1554<section id="_552">

1555<h3 id="_552_toc">

1556Diagnosis</h3>

1557<p id="_553" tabindex="-1">

1558The evaluation needed to definitively diagnose childhood ALL has been published.[<a href="#cit/section_1.74">

155974</a>

1560-<a href="#cit/section_1.78">

156178</a>

1562]</p>

1563</section>

1564<section id="_19">

1565<h3 id="_19_toc">

1566Overall Prognosis</h3>

1567<p id="_20" tabindex="-1">

1568Among children with ALL, approximately 98% attain remission. Approximately 85% of patients aged 1 to 18 years with newly diagnosed ALL treated on current regimens are expected to be long-term event-free survivors, with more than 90% of patients alive at 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.79">

156979</a>

1570-<a href="#cit/section_1.82">

157182</a>

1572] Cytogenetic and genomic findings combined with minimal residual disease (MRD) results can define subsets of ALL with EFS rates exceeding 95% and, conversely, subsets with EFS rates of 50% or lower. For more information, see the sections on <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2077">

1573Cytogenetics/Genomics of Childhood ALL</a>

1574 and <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_580">

1575Prognostic Factors Affecting Risk-Based Treatment</a>

1576.</p>

1577<p id="_21" tabindex="-1">

1578Despite the treatment advances in childhood ALL, numerous important biological and therapeutic questions remain to be answered before the goal of curing every child with ALL with the least associated toxicity can be achieved. The systematic investigation of these issues requires large clinical trials, and the opportunity to participate in these trials is offered to most patients and families. </p>

1579<p id="_598" tabindex="-1">

1580Clinical trials for children and adolescents with ALL are generally designed to compare therapy that is currently accepted as standard with investigational regimens that seek to improve cure rates and/or decrease toxicity. In certain trials in which the cure rate for the patient group is very high, therapy reduction questions may be asked. Much of the progress made in identifying curative therapies for childhood ALL and other childhood cancers has been achieved through investigator-driven discovery and tested in carefully randomized, controlled, multi-institutional clinical trials. Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials">

1581NCI website</a>

1582.</p>

1583</section>

1584<section id="_TrialSearch_1_sid_1">

1585<h3 id="_TrialSearch_1_sid_1_toc">

1586Current Clinical Trials</h3>

1587<p id="_TrialSearch_1_22" tabindex="-1">

1588Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

1589advanced clinical trial search</a>

1590 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

1591General information</a>

1592 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

1593</section>

1594<h6 do-not-show="toc">

1595References</h6>

1596<ol>

1597<li id="section_1.1">

1598Smith MA, Altekruse SF, Adamson PC, et al.: Declining childhood and adolescent cancer mortality. Cancer 120 (16): 2497-506, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1599[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1600</li>

1601<li id="section_1.2">

1930 <section id="_2079">

1931

1932 <h2>

1933World Health Organization (WHO) Classification System for Childhood ALL</h2>

1934

1935 <div id="_section_2079" class="pdq-sections">

1936<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1937<h6>

1938In This Section</h6>

1939<ul>

1940<li>

1941<a href="#_2092_toc">

1942WHO 5th Edition Classification of B-Cell Lymphoblastic Leukemias/Lymphomas</a>

1943</li>

1944<li>

1945<a href="#_2093_toc">

1946WHO 5th Edition Classification of T-Lymphoblastic Leukemia/Lymphoma</a>

1947</li>

1948<li>

1949<a href="#_2083_toc">

19502016 WHO Classification of Acute Leukemias of Ambiguous Lineage</a>

1951</li>

1952</ul>

1953</nav>

1954<p id="_2080" tabindex="-1">

1955The 5th edition of the WHO Classification of Haematolymphoid Tumours lists the following entities for acute lymphoid leukemias:[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

19561</a>

1957]</p>

1958<section id="_2092">

1959<h3 id="_2092_toc">

1960WHO 5th Edition Classification of B-Cell Lymphoblastic Leukemias/Lymphomas</h3>

1961<div class="pdq-content-list">

1962<ul id="_2497">

1963<li>

1964B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma, not otherwise specified (NOS).</li>

1965<li>

1966B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with high hyperdiploidy.</li>

1967<li>

1968B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with iAMP21.</li>

1969<li>

1970B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

1971BCR</em>

1972::<em class="gene-name">

1973ABL1</em>

1974 fusion.</li>

1975<li>

1976B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

1977BCR</em>

1978::<em class="gene-name">

1979ABL1</em>

1980-like features.</li>

1981<li>

1982B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

1983KMT2A</em>

1984 rearrangement.</li>

1985<li>

1986B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

1987ETV6</em>

1988::<em class="gene-name">

1989RUNX1</em>

1990 fusion.</li>

1991<li>

1992B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

1993ETV6</em>

1994::<em class="gene-name">

1995RUNX1</em>

1996-like features.</li>

1997<li>

1998B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

1999TCF3</em>

2000::<em class="gene-name">

2001PBX1</em>

2002 fusion.</li>

2003<li>

2004B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2005IGH</em>

2006::<em class="gene-name">

2007IL3</em>

2008 fusion.</li>

2009<li>

2010B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2011TCF3</em>

2012::<em class="gene-name">

2013HLF</em>

2014 fusion.</li>

2015<li>

2016B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with other defined genetic abnormalities.</li>

2017</ul>

2018</div>

2019<p id="_2498" tabindex="-1">

2020The category of B-ALL with other defined genetic abnormalities includes potential novel entities, including B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

2021DUX4</em>

2022, <em class="gene-name">

2023MEF2D</em>

2024, <em class="gene-name">

2025ZNF384</em>

2026 or <em class="gene-name">

2027NUTM1</em>

2028 rearrangements; B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

2029IG</em>

2030::<em class="gene-name">

2031MYC</em>

2032 fusions; and B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

2033PAX5</em>

2034alt or PAX5 p.P80R (NP_057953.1) abnormalities.</p>

2035</section>

2036<section id="_2093">

2037<h3 id="_2093_toc">

2038WHO 5th Edition Classification of T-Lymphoblastic Leukemia/Lymphoma</h3>

2039<div class="pdq-content-list">

2040<ul id="_2082">

2041<li>

2042T-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma, NOS.</li>

2043<li>

2044Early T-precursor lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma.</li>

2045</ul>

2046</div>

2047</section>

2048<section id="_2083">

2049<h3 id="_2083_toc">

20502016 WHO Classification of Acute Leukemias of Ambiguous Lineage</h3>

2051<p id="_2084" tabindex="-1">

2052For acute leukemias of ambiguous lineage, the group of acute leukemias that have characteristics of both acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the WHO classification system is summarized in <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2090">

2053Table 1</a>

2054.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

20552</a>

2056,<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

20573</a>

2058] The criteria for lineage assignment for a diagnosis of mixed phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL) are provided in <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2091">

2059Table 2</a>

2060.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

20614</a>

2062]</p>

2063<table id="_2090" class="table-default expandable-container">

2064<caption>

2065Table 1. Acute Leukemias of Ambiguous Lineage According to the World Health Organization Classification of Tumors of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tissues<span class="sup">

2066a</span>

2067</caption>

2068<colgroup>

2069<col width="50.00%">

2070<col width="50.00%">

2071</colgroup>

2072<THead>

2073<tr>

2074<th>

2075Condition</th>

2076<th>

2077 Definition</th>

2078</tr>

2079</THead>

2080<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2081<tr>

2082<td colspan="2">

2083MPAL = mixed phenotype acute leukemia; NOS = not otherwise specified.</td>

2084</tr>

2085<tr>

2086<td colspan="2">

2087<span class="sup">

2088a</span>

2089Adapted from B&#233;n&#233; MC: Biphenotypic, bilineal, ambiguous or mixed lineage: strange leukemias! Haematologica 94 (7): 891-3, 2009.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

20902</a>

2091] Obtained from Haematologica/the Hematology Journal website <a href="http://www.haematologica.org" title="http://www.haematologica.org">

2092http://www.haematologica.org</a>

2093.</td>

2094</tr>

2095</TFoot>

2096<tbody>

2097<tr>

2098<td>

2099Acute undifferentiated leukemia

2100

2101

2102

2103

2104

2105</td>

2106<td>

2107Acute leukemia that does not express any marker considered specific for either lymphoid or myeloid lineage</td>

2108</tr>

2109<tr>

2110<td>

2111MPAL with <em class="gene-name">

2112BCR</em>

2113::<em class="gene-name">

2114ABL1</em>

2115 (t(9;22)(q34;q11.2))</td>

2116<td>

2117Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for mixed phenotype acute leukemia in which the blasts also have the (9;22) translocation or the <em class="gene-name">

2118BCR</em>

2119::<em class="gene-name">

2120ABL1</em>

2121 rearrangement</td>

2122</tr>

2123<tr>

2124<td>

2125MPAL with <em class="gene-name">

2126KMT2A</em>

2127 rearranged (t(v;11q23))</td>

2128<td>

2129Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for mixed phenotype acute leukemia in which the blasts also have a translocation involving the <em class="gene-name">

2130KMT2A</em>

2131 gene</td>

2132</tr>

2133<tr>

2134<td>

2135MPAL, B/myeloid, NOS

2136(B/M MPAL)</td>

2137<td>

2138Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for assignment to both B and myeloid lineage, in which the blasts lack genetic abnormalities involving <em class="gene-name">

2139BCR</em>

2140::<em class="gene-name">

2141ABL1</em>

2142 or <em class="gene-name">

2143KMT2A</em>

2144</td>

2145</tr>

2146<tr>

2147<td>

2148MPAL, T/myeloid, NOS (T/M MPAL)</td>

2149<td>

2150Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for assignment to both T and myeloid lineage, in which the blasts lack genetic abnormalities involving <em class="gene-name">

2151BCR</em>

2152::<em class="gene-name">

2153ABL1</em>

2154 or <em class="gene-name">

2155KMT2A</em>

2156</td>

2157</tr>

2158<tr>

2159<td>

2160MPAL, B/myeloid, NOS&#8212;rare types</td>

2161<td>

2162Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for assignment to both B and T lineage</td>

2163</tr>

2164<tr>

2165<td>

2166Other ambiguous lineage leukemias</td>

2167<td>

2168Natural killer&#8211;cell lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma</td>

2169</tr>

2170</tbody>

2171</table>

2172<table id="_2091" class="table-default expandable-container">

2173<caption>

2174Table 2. Lineage Assignment Criteria for Mixed Phenotype Acute Leukemia According to the 2016 Revision to the World Health Organization Classification of Myeloid Neoplasms and Acute Leukemia<span class="sup">

2175a</span>

2176</caption>

2177<colgroup>

2178<col width="50.00%">

2179<col width="50.00%">

2180</colgroup>

2181<THead>

2182<tr>

2183<th>

2184Lineage </th>

2185<th>

2186Criteria</th>

2187</tr>

2188</THead>

2189<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2190<tr>

2191<td colspan="2">

2192<span class="sup">

2193a</span>

2194Adapted from Arber et al.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

21954</a>

2196]</td>

2197</tr>

2198<tr>

2199<td colspan="2">

2200<span class="sup">

2201b</span>

2202Strong defined as equal to or brighter than the normal B or T cells in the sample.</td>

2203</tr>

2204</TFoot>

2205<tbody>

2206<tr>

2207<td>

2208<strong>

2209Myeloid lineage</strong>

2210</td>

2211<td>

2212Myeloperoxidase (flow cytometry, immunohistochemistry, or cytochemistry); <strong>

2213or</strong>

2214 monocytic differentiation (at least two of the following: nonspecific esterase cytochemistry, CD11c, CD14, CD64, lysozyme)</td>

2215</tr>

2216<tr>

2217<td>

2218<strong>

2219T lineage</strong>

2220</td>

2221<td>

2222Strong<span class="sup">

2223b</span>

2224 cytoplasmic CD3 (with antibodies to CD3 epsilon chain); <strong>

2225or</strong>

2226 surface CD3</td>

2227</tr>

2228<tr>

2229<td>

2230<strong>

2231B lineage</strong>

2232</td>

2233<td>

2234Strong<span class="sup">

2235b</span>

2236 CD19 with at least one of the following strongly expressed: CD79a, cytoplasmic CD22, or CD10; <strong>

2237or</strong>

2238 weak CD19 with at least two of the following strongly expressed: CD79a, cytoplasmic CD22, or CD10</td>

2239</tr>

2240</tbody>

2241</table>

2242<p id="_2086" tabindex="-1">

2243Leukemias of mixed phenotype may be seen in various presentations, including the following:</p>

2244<div class="pdq-content-list">

2245<ol id="_2087">

2246<li>

2247Bilineal leukemias in which there are two distinct populations of cells, usually one lymphoid and one myeloid.</li>

2248<li>

2249Biphenotypic leukemias in which individual blast cells display features of both lymphoid and myeloid lineage.</li>

2250</ol>

2251</div>

2252<p id="_2088" tabindex="-1">

2253Biphenotypic cases represent the majority of mixed phenotype leukemias.[<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

22545</a>

2255]

2256

2257Patients with B-myeloid biphenotypic leukemias lacking the <em class="gene-name">

2258ETV6</em>

2259::<em class="gene-name">

2260RUNX1</em>

2261 fusion have lower rates of complete remission (CR) and significantly worse event-free survival (EFS) rates compared with patients with B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

22625</a>

2263] Cases of MPAL (B/myeloid) that have <em class="gene-name">

2264ZNF384</em>

2265 gene fusions have been reported,[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

22666</a>

2267,<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

22687</a>

2269] and a genomic evaluation of MPAL found that <em class="gene-name">

2270ZNF384</em>

2271 gene fusions were present in approximately one-half of B/myeloid cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

22728</a>

2273]</p>

2274<p id="_2499" tabindex="-1">

2275Some studies suggest that patients with biphenotypic leukemia may fare better with a lymphoid, as opposed to a myeloid, treatment regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

22769</a>

2277-<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

227812</a>

2279]; [<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

228013</a>

2281][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2282Level of evidence C1</a>

2283] A large retrospective study from the international Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster group demonstrated that initial therapy with an ALL-type regimen was associated with a superior outcome compared with AML-type or combined ALL/AML regimens, particularly in cases with CD19 positivity or other lymphoid antigen expression. In this study, hematopoietic stem cell transplantation in first CR was not beneficial, with the possible exception of cases with morphological evidence of persistent marrow disease (&#8805;5% blasts) after the first month of treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

228412</a>

2285]</p>

2286<p id="_2089" tabindex="-1">

2287For more information about key clinical and biological characteristics, as well as the prognostic significance for these entities, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2077">

2288Cytogenetics/Genomics of Childhood ALL</a>

2289 section.</p>

2290</section>

2351 <section id="_2077">

2352

2353 <h2>

2354Cytogenetics/Genomics of Childhood ALL</h2>

2355

2356 <div id="_section_2077" class="pdq-sections">

2357<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

2358<h6>

2359In This Section</h6>

2360<ul>

2361<li>

2362<a href="#_sm_CDR0000779360_1916_toc">

2363Genomics of childhood ALL</a>

2364</li>

2365<li>

2366<a href="#_sm_CDR0000779360_1792_toc">

2367B-ALL cytogenetics/genomics</a>

2368</li>

2369<li>

2370<a href="#_sm_CDR0000779360_1838_toc">

2371T-ALL cytogenetics/genomics<ul>

2372<li>

2373<a href="#_sm_CDR0000779360_1850_toc">

2374Early T-cell precursor ALL cytogenetics/genomics</a>

2375</li>

2376</ul>

2377</a>

2378</li>

2379<li>

2380<a href="#_sm_CDR0000779360_1924_toc">

2381Mixed phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL) cytogenetics/genomics</a>

2382</li>

2383<li>

2384<a href="#_sm_CDR0000779360_1845_toc">

2385Gene polymorphisms in drug metabolic pathways</a>

2386</li>

2387</ul>

2388</nav>

2389<section id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1916">

2390<h3 id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1916_toc">

2391Genomics of childhood ALL</h3>

2392<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1906" tabindex="-1">

2393The genomics of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) has been extensively investigated, and multiple distinctive subtypes have been defined on the basis of cytogenetic and molecular characterizations, each with its own pattern of clinical and prognostic characteristics.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

23941</a>

2395] The discussion of the genomics of childhood ALL below is divided into three sections: the genomic alterations associated with B-ALL, followed by the genomic alterations associated with T-ALL and mixed phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL). Figures 2, 3, and 5

2396illustrate the distribution of B-ALL (stratified by National Cancer Institute [NCI] standard- and high-risk B-ALL) and T-ALL cases by cytogenetic/molecular subtypes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

23971</a>

2398] </p>

2399<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1966" tabindex="-1">

2400Throughout this section, the percentages of genomic subtypes from among all B-ALL and T-ALL cases are derived primarily from a report describing the genomic characterization of patients treated on several Children's Oncology Group (COG) and St. Jude Children's Research Hospital (SJCRH) clinical trials. Percentages by subtype are presented for NCI standard-risk and NCI high-risk patients with B-ALL (up to age 18 years).[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

24011</a>

2402]</p>

2403</section>

2404<section id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1792">

2405<h3 id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1792_toc">

2406B-ALL cytogenetics/genomics</h3>

2407<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1961" tabindex="-1">

2408B-ALL is typified by genomic alterations that include: 1) gene fusions that lead to aberrant activity of transcription factors, 2) chromosomal gains and losses (e.g., hyperdiploidy or hypodiploidy), and 3) alterations leading to activation of tyrosine kinase genes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

24091</a>

2410] Figures 2 and 3

2411illustrate the distribution of NCI standard-risk and high-risk B-ALL cases by 23 cytogenetic/molecular subtypes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

24121</a>

2413] The two most common subtypes (hyperdiploid and <em class="gene-name">

2414ETV6</em>

2415::<em class="gene-name">

2416RUNX1</em>

2417 fusion) together account for approximately 60% of NCI standard-risk B-ALL cases, but only approximately 25% of NCI high-risk cases. Most other subtypes are much less common, with most occurring at frequencies less than 2% to 3% of B-ALL cases. The molecular and clinical characteristics of some of the subtypes are discussed below. </p>

2418<figure id="figure_sm_CDR0000779360_1979" class="image-center">

2419<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/811447.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2420Enlarge</a>

2421<img id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1979" alt="Pie chart showing genomic subtypes and frequencies of NCI standard-risk B-ALL." title="Pie chart showing genomic subtypes and frequencies of NCI standard-risk B-ALL." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/811447-750.jpg">

2422<figcaption class="caption-container">

2423Figure 2. Genomic subtypes and frequencies of NCI standard-risk B-ALL. The figure represents data from 1,126 children diagnosed with NCI standard-risk B-ALL (aged 1&#8211;9 years and WBC &lt;50,000/&#181;L) and enrolled in St. Jude Children&#8217;s Research Hospital or Children&#8217;s Oncology Group clinical trials. Adapted from Supplemental Table 2 of Brady SW, Roberts KG, Gu Z, et al.: The genomic landscape of pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Nature Genetics 54: 1376-1389, 2022.</figcaption>

2424</figure>

2425<figure id="figure_sm_CDR0000779360_1980" class="image-center">

2426<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/811450.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2427Enlarge</a>

2428<img id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1980" alt="Pie chart showing genomic subtypes and frequencies of NCI high-risk B-ALL." title="Pie chart showing genomic subtypes and frequencies of NCI high-risk B-ALL." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/811450-750.jpg">

2429<figcaption class="caption-container">

2430Figure 3. Genomic subtypes and frequencies of NCI high-risk B-ALL. The figure represents data from 1,084 children diagnosed with NCI high-risk B-ALL (aged 1&#8211;18 years and WBC &gt;50,000/&#181;L) and enrolled in St. Jude Children&#8217;s Research Hospital or Children&#8217;s Oncology Group clinical trials. Adapted from Supplemental Table 2 of Brady SW, Roberts KG, Gu Z, et al.: The genomic landscape of pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Nature Genetics 54: 1376-1389, 2022.</figcaption>

2431</figure>

2432<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1907" tabindex="-1">

2433The genomic landscape of B-ALL is characterized by a range of genomic alterations that disrupt normal B-cell development and, in some cases, by mutations in genes that provide a proliferation signal (e.g., activating mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2434RAS</em>

2435 family genes or mutations/translocations leading to kinase pathway signaling). Genomic alterations leading to blockage of B-cell development include translocations (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

2436TCF3</em>

2437::<em class="gene-name">

2438PBX1</em>

2439 and <em class="gene-name">

2440ETV6</em>

2441::<em class="gene-name">

2442RUNX1</em>

2443 fusions), point mutations (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

2444IKZF1</em>

2445 and <em class="gene-name">

2446PAX5</em>

2447), and intragenic/intergenic deletions (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

2448IKZF1</em>

2449, <em class="gene-name">

2450PAX5</em>

2451, <em class="gene-name">

2452EBF</em>

2453, and <em class="gene-name">

2454ERG</em>

2455).[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

24562</a>

2457]</p>

2458<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1908" tabindex="-1">

2459The genomic alterations in B-ALL tend not to occur at random, but rather to cluster within subtypes that can be delineated by biological characteristics such as their gene expression profiles. Cases with recurring chromosomal translocations (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

2460TCF3</em>

2461::<em class="gene-name">

2462PBX1</em>

2463 and <em class="gene-name">

2464ETV6</em>

2465::<em class="gene-name">

2466RUNX1</em>

2467 fusions and <em class="gene-name">

2468KMT2A</em>

2469-rearranged ALL) have distinctive biological features and illustrate this point, as do the examples below of specific genomic alterations within unique biological subtypes:</p>

2470<div class="pdq-content-list">

2471<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1909">

2472<li>

2473<em class="gene-name">

2474IKZF1</em>

2475 deletions and mutations are most commonly observed within cases of <em class="gene-name">

2476BCR</em>

2477::<em class="gene-name">

2478ABL1</em>

2479 ALL and <em class="gene-name">

2480BCR</em>

2481::<em class="gene-name">

2482ABL1</em>

2483-like ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

24843</a>

2485,<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

24864</a>

2487]</li>

2488<li>

2489Intragenic <em class="gene-name">

2490ERG</em>

2491 deletions occur within a distinctive subtype characterized by gene rearrangements involving <em class="gene-name">

2492DUX4</em>

2493.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

24945</a>

2495,<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

24966</a>

2497]</li>

2498<li>

2499<em class="gene-name">

2500TP53</em>

2501 mutations, often germline, occur at high frequency in patients with low hypodiploid ALL with 32 to 39 chromosomes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

25027</a>

2503] <em class="gene-name">

2504TP53</em>

2505 mutations are uncommon in other patients with B-ALL.</li>

2506</ul>

2507</div>

2508<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1910" tabindex="-1">

2509Activating point mutations in kinase genes are uncommon in high-risk B-ALL. <em class="gene-name">

2510JAK</em>

2511 genes are the primary kinases that are found to be mutated. These mutations are generally observed in patients with <em class="gene-name">

2512BCR</em>

2513::<em class="gene-name">

2514ABL1</em>

2515-like ALL that have <em class="gene-name">

2516CRLF2</em>

2517 abnormalities, although <em class="gene-name">

2518JAK2</em>

2519 mutations are also observed in approximately 15% of children with Down syndrome and ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

25204</a>

2521,<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

25228</a>

2523,<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

25249</a>

2525] Several kinase genes and cytokine receptor genes are activated by translocations, as described below in the discussion of <em class="gene-name">

2526BCR</em>

2527::<em class="gene-name">

2528ABL1</em>

2529 ALL and <em class="gene-name">

2530BCR</em>

2531::<em class="gene-name">

2532ABL1</em>

2533-like ALL. <em class="gene-name">

2534FLT3</em>

2535 mutations occur in a minority of cases (approximately 10%) of hyperdiploid ALL and <em class="gene-name">

2536KMT2A</em>

2537-rearranged ALL, and are rare in other subtypes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

253810</a>

2539]</p>

2540<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1911" tabindex="-1">

2541Understanding of the genomics of B-ALL at relapse is less advanced than the understanding of ALL genomics at diagnosis. Childhood ALL is often polyclonal at diagnosis and under the selective influence of therapy, some clones may be extinguished and new clones with distinctive genomic profiles may arise.[<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

254211</a>

2543] However, molecular subtype&#8211;defining lesions such as translocations and aneuploidy are almost always retained at relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

25441</a>

2545,<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

254611</a>

2547] Of particular importance are new mutations that arise at relapse that may be selected by specific components of therapy. As an example, mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2548NT5C2</em>

2549 are not found at diagnosis, whereas specific mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2550NT5C2</em>

2551 were observed in 7 of 44 (16%) and 9 of 20 (45%) cases of B-ALL with early relapse that were evaluated for this mutation in two studies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

255211</a>

2553,<a href="#cit/section_3.12">

255412</a>

2555] <em class="gene-name">

2556NT5C2</em>

2557 mutations are uncommon in patients with late relapse, and they appear to induce resistance to mercaptopurine and thioguanine.[<a href="#cit/section_3.12">

255812</a>

2559] Another gene that is found mutated only at relapse is <em class="gene-name">

2560PRSP1</em>

2561, a gene involved in purine biosynthesis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.13">

256213</a>

2563] Mutations were observed in 13.0% of a Chinese cohort and 2.7% of a German cohort, and were observed in patients with on-treatment relapses. The <em class="gene-name">

2564PRSP1</em>

2565 mutations observed in relapsed cases induce resistance to thiopurines in leukemia cell lines. <em class="gene-name">

2566CREBBP</em>

2567 mutations are also enriched at relapse and appear to be associated with increased resistance to glucocorticoids.[<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

256811</a>

2569,<a href="#cit/section_3.14">

257014</a>

2571] With increased understanding of the genomics of relapse, it may be possible to tailor upfront therapy to avoid relapse or detect resistance-inducing mutations early and intervene before a frank relapse.</p>

2572<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_512" tabindex="-1">

2573A number of recurrent chromosomal abnormalities have been shown to have prognostic significance, especially in B-ALL. Some chromosomal alterations are associated with more favorable outcomes, such as favorable trisomies (51&#8211;65 chromosomes) and the <em class="gene-name">

2574ETV6</em>

2575::<em class="gene-name">

2576RUNX1</em>

2577 fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.15">

257815</a>

2579][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2580Level of evidence B4</a>

2581] Other alterations historically have been associated with a poorer prognosis, including the <em class="gene-name">

2582BCR</em>

2583::<em class="gene-name">

2584ABL1</em>

2585 fusion (Philadelphia chromosome&#8211;positive [Ph+]; t(9;22)(q34;q11.2)), rearrangements of the <em class="gene-name">

2586KMT2A</em>

2587 gene, hypodiploidy, and intrachromosomal amplification of the <em class="gene-name">

2588RUNX1</em>

2589 gene (iAMP21).[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

259016</a>

2591]</p>

2592<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1809" tabindex="-1">

2593In recognition of the clinical significance of many of these genomic alterations, the 5th edition revision of the World Health Organization Classification of Haematolymphoid Tumours lists the following entities for B-ALL:[<a href="#cit/section_3.17">

259417</a>

2595]</p>

2596<div class="pdq-content-list">

2597<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1957">

2598<li>

2599B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma, NOS.</li>

2600<li>

2601B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with high hyperdiploidy.</li>

2602<li>

2603B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with hypodiploidy.</li>

2604<li>

2605B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with iAMP21.</li>

2606<li>

2607B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2608BCR</em>

2609::<em class="gene-name">

2610ABL1</em>

2611 fusion.</li>

2612<li>

2613B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2614BCR</em>

2615::<em class="gene-name">

2616ABL1</em>

2617-like features.</li>

2618<li>

2619B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2620KMT2A</em>

2621 rearrangement.</li>

2622<li>

2623B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2624ETV6</em>

2625::<em class="gene-name">

2626RUNX1</em>

2627 fusion.</li>

2628<li>

2629B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2630ETV6</em>

2631::<em class="gene-name">

2632RUNX1</em>

2633-like features.</li>

2634<li>

2635B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2636TCF3</em>

2637::<em class="gene-name">

2638PBX1</em>

2639 fusion.</li>

2640<li>

2641B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2642IGH</em>

2643::<em class="gene-name">

2644IL3</em>

2645 fusion.</li>

2646<li>

2647B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with <em class="gene-name">

2648TCF3</em>

2649::<em class="gene-name">

2650HLF</em>

2651 fusion.</li>

2652<li>

2653B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with other defined genetic abnormalities.</li>

2654</ul>

2655</div>

2656<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1958" tabindex="-1">

2657The category of B-ALL with other defined genetic abnormalities includes potential novel entities, including B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

2658DUX4</em>

2659, <em class="gene-name">

2660MEF2D</em>

2661, <em class="gene-name">

2662ZNF384</em>

2663 or <em class="gene-name">

2664NUTM1</em>

2665 rearrangements; B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

2666IG</em>

2667::<em class="gene-name">

2668MYC</em>

2669 fusions; and B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

2670PAX5</em>

2671alt or PAX5 p.P80R (NP_057953.1) abnormalities.</p>

2672<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1811" tabindex="-1">

2673These and other chromosomal and genomic abnormalities for childhood ALL are described below.</p>

2674<div class="pdq-content-list">

2675<ol id="_sm_CDR0000779360_639">

2676<li>

2677<strong>

2678Chromosome number.</strong>

2679<div class="pdq-content-list">

2680<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_703">

2681<li>

2682<strong>

2683High hyperdiploidy (51&#8211;65 chromosomes).</strong>

2684<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_669" tabindex="-1">

2685High hyperdiploidy, defined as 51 to 65 chromosomes per cell or a DNA index greater than 1.16, occurs in approximately 33% of NCI standard-risk and 14% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

26861</a>

2687,<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

268818</a>

2689]

2690Hyperdiploidy can be evaluated by measuring the DNA content of cells (DNA

2691index) or by karyotyping. In cases with a normal karyotype or in which standard cytogenetic analysis was unsuccessful, interphase fluorescence <em>

2692in situ</em>

2693 hybridization (FISH) may detect hidden hyperdiploidy.</p>

2694<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1934" tabindex="-1">

2695 High hyperdiploidy generally occurs in cases with

2696clinically favorable prognostic factors (patients aged 1 to &lt;10 years with a low white blood cell [WBC] count) and is an independent favorable prognostic factor.[<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

269718</a>

2698-<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

269920</a>

2700] Within the hyperdiploid range of 51 to 65 chromosomes, patients with higher modal numbers (58&#8211;66) appeared to have a better prognosis in one study.[<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

270120</a>

2702] Hyperdiploid leukemia cells are particularly susceptible to undergoing apoptosis and accumulate higher levels of methotrexate and its active polyglutamate metabolites,[<a href="#cit/section_3.21">

270321</a>

2704] which may explain the favorable outcome commonly observed in these cases.</p>

2705<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_670" tabindex="-1">

2706While the overall outcome of patients with high hyperdiploidy is considered to be favorable, factors such as age, WBC count, specific trisomies, and early response to treatment have been shown to modify its prognostic significance.[<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

270722</a>

2708,<a href="#cit/section_3.23">

270923</a>

2710]</p>

2711<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1967" tabindex="-1">

2712Multiple reports have described the prognostic significance of specific chromosome trisomies among children with hyperdiploid B-ALL.</p>

2713<div class="pdq-content-list">

2714<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1968">

2715<li>

2716A study combining experience from the Children's Cancer Group and the Pediatric Oncology Group (POG) found that patients with trisomies of chromosomes 4, 10, and 17 (triple trisomies) have a particularly favorable outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.24">

271724</a>

2718]; [<a href="#cit/section_3.15">

271915</a>

2720][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2721Level of evidence B4</a>

2722] </li>

2723<li>

2724A report using POG data found that NCI standard-risk patients with trisomies of 4 and 10, without regard to chromosome 17 status, have an excellent prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.25">

272525</a>

2726] COG protocols currently use double trisomies of chromosomes 4 and 10 to define favorable hyperdiploidy. </li>

2727<li>

2728A retrospective analysis evaluated patients treated on two consecutive UKALL trials to identify and validate a profile to predict outcome in high hyperdiploid B-ALL. The investigators defined a good-risk group (approximately 80% of high hyperdiploidy patients) that was associated with a more favorable prognosis. Good-risk patients had either trisomies of both chromosomes 17 and 18 or trisomy of one of these two chromosomes along with absence of trisomies of chromosomes 5 and 20. All other patients were defined as poor risk and had a less favorable outcome. End-induction MRD and copy number alterations (such as <em class="gene-name">

2729IKZF1</em>

2730 deletion) were prognostically significant within each hyperdiploid risk group.[<a href="#cit/section_3.26">

273126</a>

2732]</li>

2733</ul>

2734</div>

2735 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_517" tabindex="-1">

2736Chromosomal translocations may be seen with high hyperdiploidy, and in those cases, patients are more appropriately risk-classified on the basis of the prognostic significance of the translocation. For instance, in one study, 8% of patients with the <em class="gene-name">

2737BCR</em>

2738::<em class="gene-name">

2739ABL1</em>

2740 fusion also had high hyperdiploidy,[<a href="#cit/section_3.27">

274127</a>

2742] and the outcome of these patients (treated without tyrosine kinase inhibitors) was inferior to that observed in non-<em class="gene-name">

2743BCR</em>

2744::<em class="gene-name">

2745ABL1</em>

2746 high hyperdiploid patients.</p>

2747<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_518" tabindex="-1">

2748Certain patients with hyperdiploid ALL may have a hypodiploid clone that has doubled (masked hypodiploidy).[<a href="#cit/section_3.28">

274928</a>

2750] Molecular technologies, such as single nucleotide polymorphism microarrays to detect widespread loss of heterozygosity, can be used to identify patients with masked hypodiploidy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.28">

275128</a>

2752] These cases may be interpretable based on the pattern of gains and losses of specific chromosomes (hyperdiploidy with two and four copies of chromosomes rather than three copies). These patients have an unfavorable outcome, similar to those with hypodiploidy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

275329</a>

2754]</p>

2755<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_519" tabindex="-1">

2756Near triploidy (68&#8211;80 chromosomes) and near tetraploidy (&gt;80 chromosomes) are much less common and appear to be biologically distinct from high hyperdiploidy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

275730</a>

2758] Unlike high hyperdiploidy, a high proportion of near tetraploid cases harbor a cryptic <em class="gene-name">

2759ETV6</em>

2760::<em class="gene-name">

2761RUNX1</em>

2762 fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

276330</a>

2764-<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

276532</a>

2766] Near triploidy and tetraploidy were previously thought to be associated with an unfavorable prognosis, but later studies suggest that this may not be the case.[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

276730</a>

2768,<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

276932</a>

2770]</p>

2771<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1770" tabindex="-1">

2772The genomic landscape of hyperdiploid ALL is characterized by mutations in genes of the receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK)/RAS pathway in approximately one-half of cases. Genes encoding histone modifiers are also present in a recurring manner in a minority of cases. Analysis of mutation profiles demonstrates that chromosomal gains are early events in the pathogenesis of hyperdiploid ALL and may occur <em>

2773in utero</em>

2774, while mutations in RTK/RAS pathway genes are late events in leukemogenesis and are often subclonal.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

27751</a>

2776,<a href="#cit/section_3.33">

277733</a>

2778]</p>

2779</li>

2780<li>

2781<strong>

2782Hypodiploidy (&lt;44 chromosomes).</strong>

2783 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_671" tabindex="-1">

2784B-ALL cases with fewer than the normal number of chromosomes have been subdivided in various ways, with one report stratifying on the basis of modal chromosome number into the following four groups:[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

278529</a>

2786] </p>

2787<div class="pdq-content-list">

2788<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1594">

2789<li>

2790Near-haploid: 24 to 29 chromosomes (n = 46). </li>

2791<li>

2792Low-hypodiploid: 33 to 39 chromosomes (n = 26). </li>

2793<li>

2794High-hypodiploid: 40 to 43 chromosomes (n = 13). </li>

2795<li>

2796Near-diploid: 44 chromosomes (n = 54).</li>

2797</ul>

2798</div>

2799<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1969" tabindex="-1">

2800Near-haploid cases represent approximately 2% of NCI standard-risk and 2% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

28011</a>

2802]</p>

2803<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1970" tabindex="-1">

2804Low-hypodiploid cases represent approximately 0.5% of NCI standard-risk and 2.6% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

28051</a>

2806]</p>

2807<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1595" tabindex="-1">

2808Most patients with hypodiploidy are in the near-haploid and low-hypodiploid groups, and both of these groups have an elevated risk of treatment failure compared with nonhypodiploid cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

280929</a>

2810,<a href="#cit/section_3.34">

281134</a>

2812] Patients with fewer than 44 chromosomes have a worse outcome than do patients with 44 or 45 chromosomes in their leukemic cells.[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

281329</a>

2814] A number of studies have shown that patients with high minimal residual disease (MRD) (&#8805;0.01%) after induction do very poorly, with 5-year event-free survival (EFS) rates ranging from 25% to 47%. Although hypodiploid patients with low MRD after induction fare better (5-year EFS rates, 64%&#8211;75%), their outcomes are still inferior to most children with other types of ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.35">

281535</a>

2816-<a href="#cit/section_3.37">

281737</a>

2818]</p>

2819 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1550" tabindex="-1">

2820The recurring genomic alterations of near-haploid and low-hypodiploid ALL appear to be distinctive from each other and from other types of ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

28217</a>

2822] In near-haploid ALL, alterations targeting RTK signaling, RAS signaling, and <em class="gene-name">

2823IKZF3</em>

2824 are common.[<a href="#cit/section_3.38">

282538</a>

2826] In low-hypodiploid ALL, genetic alterations involving <em class="gene-name">

2827TP53</em>

2828, <em class="gene-name">

2829RB1</em>

2830, and <em class="gene-name">

2831IKZF2</em>

2832 are common. Importantly, the <em class="gene-name">

2833TP53</em>

2834 alterations observed in low-hypodiploid ALL are also present in nontumor cells in approximately 40% of cases, suggesting that these mutations are germline and that low-hypodiploid ALL represents, in some cases, a manifestation of Li-Fraumeni syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

28357</a>

2836] Approximately two-thirds of patients with ALL and germline pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

2837TP53</em>

2838 variants have hypodiploid ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

283939</a>

2840]</p>

2841</li>

2842</ul>

2843</div>

2844</li>

2845<li>

2846<strong>

2847Chromosomal translocations and gains/deletions of chromosomal segments.</strong>

2848<div class="pdq-content-list">

2849<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_672">

2850<li>

2851<strong>

2852<em class="gene-name">

2853ETV6</em>

2854::<em class="gene-name">

2855RUNX1</em>

2856 fusion (t(12;21)(p13.2;q22.1)).</strong>

2857 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_711" tabindex="-1">

2858Fusion of the <em class="gene-name">

2859ETV6</em>

2860 gene on

2861chromosome 12 to the <em class="gene-name">

2862RUNX1</em>

2863 gene on chromosome 21 is present in approximately 27% of NCI standard-risk and 10% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

28641</a>

2865,<a href="#cit/section_3.31">

286631</a>

2867] </p>

2868<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1971" tabindex="-1">

2869The <em class="gene-name">

2870ETV6</em>

2871::<em class="gene-name">

2872RUNX1</em>

2873 fusion produces a cryptic translocation that is detected by methods such as FISH, rather than conventional cytogenetics, and it occurs most commonly in children aged 2 to 9 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.40">

287440</a>

2875,<a href="#cit/section_3.41">

287641</a>

2877] Hispanic children with ALL have a lower incidence of <em class="gene-name">

2878ETV6</em>

2879::<em class="gene-name">

2880RUNX1</em>

2881 fusions than do White children.[<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

288242</a>

2883]</p>

2884<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_714" tabindex="-1">

2885Reports generally indicate favorable EFS and overall survival (OS) rates in children with the <em class="gene-name">

2886ETV6</em>

2887::<em class="gene-name">

2888RUNX1</em>

2889 fusion; however, the prognostic impact of this genetic feature is modified by the following factors:[<a href="#cit/section_3.43">

289043</a>

2891-<a href="#cit/section_3.47">

289247</a>

2893]; [<a href="#cit/section_3.15">

289415</a>

2895][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2896Level of evidence B4</a>

2897]</p>

2898<div class="pdq-content-list">

2899<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_709" class="list-dash">

2900<li>

2901Early response to treatment.</li>

2902<li>

2903NCI risk category (age and WBC count at diagnosis).</li>

2904<li>

2905Treatment regimen.</li>

2906</ul>

2907</div>

2908 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_715" tabindex="-1">

2909In one study of the treatment of newly diagnosed children with ALL, multivariate analysis of prognostic factors found age and leukocyte count, but not <em class="gene-name">

2910ETV6</em>

2911::<em class="gene-name">

2912RUNX1</em>

2913 fusion status, to be independent prognostic factors.[<a href="#cit/section_3.43">

291443</a>

2915] However, another large trial only enrolled patients classified as having favorable-risk B-ALL, with low-risk clinical features, either trisomies of 4, 10, and 17 or <em class="gene-name">

2916ETV6</em>

2917::<em class="gene-name">

2918RUNX1</em>

2919 fusion, and end induction MRD less than 0.01%. Patients had a 5-year continuous complete remission rate of 93.7% and a 6-year OS rate of 98.2% for patients with <em class="gene-name">

2920ETV6</em>

2921::<em class="gene-name">

2922RUNX1</em>

2923.[<a href="#cit/section_3.15">

292415</a>

2925] It does not appear that the presence of secondary cytogenetic abnormalities, such as deletion of <em class="gene-name">

2926ETV6</em>

2927 (12p) or <em class="gene-name">

2928CDKN2A/B</em>

2929 (9p), impacts the outcome of patients with the <em class="gene-name">

2930ETV6</em>

2931::<em class="gene-name">

2932RUNX1</em>

2933 fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.47">

293447</a>

2935,<a href="#cit/section_3.48">

293648</a>

2937]</p>

2938<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1935" tabindex="-1">

2939 There is a higher frequency of late relapses in patients with <em class="gene-name">

2940ETV6</em>

2941::<em class="gene-name">

2942RUNX1</em>

2943 fusions compared with other relapsed B-ALL patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.43">

294443</a>

2945,<a href="#cit/section_3.49">

294649</a>

2947] Patients with the <em class="gene-name">

2948ETV6</em>

2949::<em class="gene-name">

2950RUNX1</em>

2951 fusion who relapse seem to have a better outcome than other relapse patients,[<a href="#cit/section_3.50">

295250</a>

2953] with an especially favorable prognosis for patients who relapse more than 36 months from diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.51">

295451</a>

2955] Some relapses in patients with <em class="gene-name">

2956ETV6</em>

2957::<em class="gene-name">

2958RUNX1</em>

2959 fusions may represent a new independent second hit in a persistent preleukemic clone (with the first hit being the <em class="gene-name">

2960ETV6</em>

2961::<em class="gene-name">

2962RUNX1</em>

2963 translocation).[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

296452</a>

2965,<a href="#cit/section_3.53">

296653</a>

2967]</p>

2968</li>

2969<li>

2970<strong>

2971<em class="gene-name">

2972BCR</em>

2973::<em class="gene-name">

2974ABL1</em>

2975 fusion (t(9;22)(q34.1;q11.2); Ph+).</strong>

2976<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_673" tabindex="-1">

2977 The <em class="gene-name">

2978BCR</em>

2979::<em class="gene-name">

2980ABL1</em>

2981 fusion leads to production of a BCR::ABL1 fusion protein with tyrosine kinase activity (see Figure 4).[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

29821</a>

2983] The <em class="gene-name">

2984BCR</em>

2985::<em class="gene-name">

2986ABL1</em>

2987 fusion occurs in approximately 2% of NCI standard-risk and 5% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

29881</a>

2989]<figure id="figure_sm_CDR0000779360_611" class="image-center">

2990<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/533336.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2991Enlarge</a>

2992<img id="_sm_CDR0000779360_611" alt="Philadelphia chromosome; three-panel drawing shows a piece of chromosome 9 and a piece of chromosome 22 breaking off and trading places, creating a changed chromosome 22 called the Philadelphia chromosome. In the left panel, the drawing shows a normal chromosome 9 with the ABL gene and a normal chromosome 22 with the BCR gene. In the center panel, the drawing shows part of the ABL gene breaking off from chromosome 9 and a piece of chromosome 22 breaking off, below the BCR gene.
