In the right panel, the drawing shows chromosome 9 with the piece from chromosome 22 attached. It also shows a shortened version of chromosome 22 with the piece from chromosome 9 containing part of the ABL gene attached. The ABL gene joins to the BCR gene on chromosome 22 to form the BCR::ABL fusion gene. The changed chromosome 22 with the BCR::ABL fusion gene on it is called the Philadelphia chromosome." title="Philadelphia chromosome; three-panel drawing shows a piece of chromosome 9 and a piece of chromosome 22 breaking off and trading places, creating a changed chromosome 22 called the Philadelphia chromosome. In the left panel, the drawing shows a normal chromosome 9 with the ABL gene and a normal chromosome 22 with the BCR gene. In the center panel, the drawing shows part of the ABL gene breaking off from chromosome 9 and a piece of chromosome 22 breaking off, below the BCR gene. In the right panel, the drawing shows chromosome 9 with the piece from chromosome 22 attached. It also shows a shortened version of chromosome 22 with the piece from chromosome 9 containing part of the ABL gene attached. The ABL gene joins to the BCR gene on chromosome 22 to form the BCR::ABL fusion gene. The changed chromosome 22 with the BCR::ABL fusion gene on it is called the Philadelphia chromosome." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/533336-750.jpg">

2993<figcaption class="caption-container">

2994Figure 4. The Philadelphia chromosome is a translocation between the <em class="gene-name">

2995ABL1</em>

2996 oncogene (on the long arm of chromosome 9) and the <em class="gene-name">

2997BCR</em>

2998 gene (on the long arm of chromosome 22), resulting in the fusion gene <em class="gene-name">

2999BCR</em>

3000::<em class="gene-name">

3001ABL1</em>

3002. <em class="gene-name">

3003BCR</em>

3004::<em class="gene-name">

3005ABL1</em>

3006 encodes an oncogenic protein with tyrosine kinase activity.</figcaption>

3007</figure>

3008</p>

3009<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_674" tabindex="-1">

3010This subtype of ALL is more common in older children with B-ALL and high WBC counts, with the incidence of the <em class="gene-name">

3011BCR</em>

3012::<em class="gene-name">

3013ABL1</em>

3014 fusions increasing to about 25% in young adults with ALL.</p>

3015<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_675" tabindex="-1">

3016Historically, the <em class="gene-name">

3017BCR</em>

3018::<em class="gene-name">

3019ABL1</em>

3020 fusion was associated with an extremely poor prognosis (especially in those who presented with a high WBC count or had a slow early response to initial therapy), and its presence had been considered an indication for allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) in patients in first remission.[<a href="#cit/section_3.27">

302127</a>

3022,<a href="#cit/section_3.54">

302354</a>

3024-<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

302556</a>

3026] Inhibitors of the BCR::ABL1 tyrosine kinase, such as imatinib mesylate, are effective in patients with <em class="gene-name">

3027BCR</em>

3028::<em class="gene-name">

3029ABL1</em>

3030 ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.57">

303157</a>

3032] A study by the Children's Oncology Group (COG), which used intensive chemotherapy and concurrent imatinib mesylate given daily, demonstrated a 5-year EFS rate of 70% (&#177; 12%), which was superior to the EFS rate of historical controls in the pre-tyrosine kinase inhibitor (imatinib mesylate) era. This result eliminated the recommendation of HSCT for patients with a good early response to chemotherapy using a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.[<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

303358</a>

3034,<a href="#cit/section_3.59">

303559</a>

3036] </p>

3037</li>

3038<li>

3039<strong>

3040<em class="gene-name">

3041KMT2A</em>

3042-rearranged ALL (t(v;11q23.3)).</strong>

3043<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_676" tabindex="-1">

3044Rearrangements involving the <em class="gene-name">

3045KMT2A</em>

3046 gene with more than 100 translocation partner genes result in the production of fusion oncoproteins. <em class="gene-name">

3047KMT2A</em>

3048 gene rearrangements occur in up to 80% of infants with ALL. Beyond infancy, approximately 1% of NCI standard-risk and 4% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases have <em class="gene-name">

3049KMT2A</em>

3050 rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

30511</a>

3052]

3053</p>

3054<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1972" tabindex="-1">

3055These rearrangements are generally associated with an increased risk of treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_3.60">

305660</a>

3057-<a href="#cit/section_3.63">

305863</a>

3059] The <em class="gene-name">

3060KMT2A</em>

3061::<em class="gene-name">

3062AFF1</em>

3063 fusion (t(4;11)(q21;q23)) is the most common rearrangement involving

3064the <em class="gene-name">

3065KMT2A</em>

3066 gene in children with ALL and occurs in approximately 1% to 2% of childhood ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

306761</a>

3068,<a href="#cit/section_3.64">

306964</a>

3070]</p>

3071<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_677" tabindex="-1">

3072Patients with <em class="gene-name">

3073KMT2A</em>

3074::<em class="gene-name">

3075AFF1</em>

3076 fusions are usually infants with high WBC counts. These patients are more likely than other children with ALL to have central nervous system (CNS) disease and to

3077have a poor response to initial therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.65">

307865</a>

3079] While both infants and adults

3080with the <em class="gene-name">

3081KMT2A</em>

3082::<em class="gene-name">

3083AFF1</em>

3084 fusion are at high risk of treatment failure, children with the

3085<em class="gene-name">

3086KMT2A</em>

3087::<em class="gene-name">

3088AFF1</em>

3089 fusion appear to have a better outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.60">

309060</a>

3091,<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

309261</a>

3093,<a href="#cit/section_3.66">

309466</a>

3095] Irrespective of the type of <em class="gene-name">

3096KMT2A</em>

3097 gene rearrangement, infants with leukemia cells that have <em class="gene-name">

3098KMT2A</em>

3099 gene rearrangements have a worse treatment outcome than older patients whose leukemia cells have a <em class="gene-name">

3100KMT2A</em>

3101 gene rearrangement.[<a href="#cit/section_3.60">

310260</a>

3103,<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

310461</a>

3105]</p>

3106<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1936" tabindex="-1">

3107 Whole-genome sequencing has determined that cases of infant ALL with <em class="gene-name">

3108KMT2A</em>

3109 gene rearrangements have few additional genomic alterations, none of which have clear clinical significance.[<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

311010</a>

3111] Deletion of the <em class="gene-name">

3112KMT2A</em>

3113 gene has not been associated with an adverse prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.67">

311467</a>

3115] </p>

3116<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_678" tabindex="-1">

3117Of interest, the <em class="gene-name">

3118KMT2A</em>

3119::<em class="gene-name">

3120MLLT1</em>

3121 fusion (t(11;19)(q23;p13.3)) occurs in approximately 1% of ALL cases and occurs in both early B-lineage

3122ALL and T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.68">

312368</a>

3124] Outcome for infants with the <em class="gene-name">

3125KMT2A</em>

3126::<em class="gene-name">

3127MLLT1</em>

3128 fusion is poor, but outcome

3129appears relatively favorable in older children with T-ALL and the <em class="gene-name">

3130KMT2A</em>

3131::<em class="gene-name">

3132MLLT1</em>

3133 fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.68">

313468</a>

3135]</p>

3136</li>

3137<li>

3138<strong>

3139<em class="gene-name">

3140TCF3</em>

3141::<em class="gene-name">

3142PBX1</em>

3143 fusion (t(1;19)(q23;p13.3)) and <em class="gene-name">

3144TCF3</em>

3145::<em class="gene-name">

3146HLF</em>

3147 fusion (t(17;19)(q22;p13)).</strong>

3148<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_679" tabindex="-1">

3149Fusion of the <em class="gene-name">

3150TCF3</em>

3151 gene on

3152chromosome 19 to the <em class="gene-name">

3153PBX1</em>

3154 gene on chromosome

31551 is present in approximately 4% of NCI standard-risk and 5% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

31561</a>

3157,<a href="#cit/section_3.69">

315869</a>

3159,<a href="#cit/section_3.70">

316070</a>

3161] The <em class="gene-name">

3162TCF3</em>

3163::<em class="gene-name">

3164PBX1</em>

3165 fusion may occur as either a balanced translocation or as an

3166unbalanced translocation and is the primary recurring genomic alteration of the pre-B&#8211;ALL immunophenotype (cytoplasmic immunoglobulin positive).[<a href="#cit/section_3.71">

316771</a>

3168] Black children are relatively more likely than White children to have pre-B&#8211;ALL with the <em class="gene-name">

3169TCF3</em>

3170::<em class="gene-name">

3171PBX1</em>

3172 fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.72">

317372</a>

3174] </p>

3175<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_680" tabindex="-1">

3176The <em class="gene-name">

3177TCF3</em>

3178::<em class="gene-name">

3179PBX1</em>

3180 fusion had been associated with inferior outcome in the context of antimetabolite-based therapy,[<a href="#cit/section_3.73">

318173</a>

3182] but the adverse prognostic significance was largely negated by more aggressive multiagent therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.70">

318370</a>

3184,<a href="#cit/section_3.74">

318574</a>

3186] More specifically, in a trial conducted by St. Jude Children's Research Hospital (SJCRH) in which all patients were treated without cranial radiation, patients with the <em class="gene-name">

3187TCF3</em>

3188::<em class="gene-name">

3189PBX1</em>

3190 fusion had an overall outcome comparable to children lacking this translocation, but with a higher risk of CNS relapse and a lower rate of bone marrow relapse, suggesting that more intensive CNS therapy may be needed for these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.75">

319175</a>

3192,<a href="#cit/section_3.76">

319376</a>

3194]</p>

3195<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1793" tabindex="-1">

3196The <em class="gene-name">

3197TCF3</em>

3198::<em class="gene-name">

3199HLF</em>

3200 fusion occurs in less than 1% of pediatric ALL cases. ALL with the <em class="gene-name">

3201TCF3</em>

3202::<em class="gene-name">

3203HLF</em>

3204 fusion is associated with disseminated intravascular coagulation and hypercalcemia at diagnosis. Outcome is very poor for children with the <em class="gene-name">

3205TCF3</em>

3206::<em class="gene-name">

3207HLF</em>

3208 fusion, with a literature review noting mortality for 20 of 21 cases reported.[<a href="#cit/section_3.77">

320977</a>

3210] In addition to the <em class="gene-name">

3211TCF3</em>

3212::<em class="gene-name">

3213HLF</em>

3214 fusion, the genomic landscape of this ALL subtype was characterized by deletions in genes involved in B-cell development (<em class="gene-name">

3215PAX5</em>

3216, <em class="gene-name">

3217BTG1</em>

3218, and <em class="gene-name">

3219VPREB1</em>

3220) and by mutations in RAS pathway genes (<em class="gene-name">

3221NRAS</em>

3222, <em class="gene-name">

3223KRAS</em>

3224, and <em class="gene-name">

3225PTPN11</em>

3226).[<a href="#cit/section_3.71">

322771</a>

3228]</p>

3229</li>

3230<li>

3231<strong>

3232<em class="gene-name">

3233DUX4</em>

3234-rearranged ALL with frequent <em class="gene-name">

3235ERG</em>

3236 deletions.</strong>

3237<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1812" tabindex="-1">

3238Approximately 3% of NCI standard-risk and 6% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL patients have a rearrangement involving <em class="gene-name">

3239DUX4</em>

3240 that leads to its overexpression.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

32411</a>

3242,<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

32435</a>

3244,<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

32456</a>

3246] East Asian ancestry was linked to an increased prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

3247DUX4</em>

3248-rearranged ALL (favorable).[<a href="#cit/section_3.78">

324978</a>

3250] The most common rearrangement produces <em class="gene-name">

3251IGH</em>

3252::<em class="gene-name">

3253DUX4</em>

3254 fusions, with <em class="gene-name">

3255ERG</em>

3256::<em class="gene-name">

3257DUX4</em>

3258 fusions also observed.[<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

325979</a>

3260] <em class="gene-name">

3261DUX4</em>

3262-rearranged cases show a distinctive gene expression pattern that was initially identified as being associated with focal deletions in <em class="gene-name">

3263ERG</em>

3264,[<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

326579</a>

3266-<a href="#cit/section_3.82">

326782</a>

3268] and one-half to more than two-thirds of these cases have focal intragenic deletions involving <em class="gene-name">

3269ERG</em>

3270 that are not observed in other ALL subtypes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

32715</a>

3272,<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

327379</a>

3274] <em class="gene-name">

3275ERG</em>

3276 deletions often appear to be clonal, but using sensitive detection methodology, it appears that most cases are polyclonal.[<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

327779</a>

3278] <em class="gene-name">

3279IKZF1</em>

3280 alterations are observed in 20% to 40% of <em class="gene-name">

3281DUX4</em>

3282-rearranged ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

32835</a>

3284,<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

32856</a>

3286] </p>

3287<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1918" tabindex="-1">

3288<em class="gene-name">

3289ERG</em>

3290 deletion connotes an excellent prognosis, with OS rates exceeding 90%. Even when the <em class="gene-name">

3291IZKF1</em>

3292 deletion is present, prognosis remains highly favorable.[<a href="#cit/section_3.80">

329380</a>

3294-<a href="#cit/section_3.83">

329583</a>

3296] While patients with <em class="gene-name">

3297DUX4</em>

3298-rearranged ALL have an overall favorable prognosis, there is uncertainty as to whether this applies to both <em class="gene-name">

3299ERG</em>

3300-deleted and <em class="gene-name">

3301ERG</em>

3302-intact cases. In a study of 50 patients with <em class="gene-name">

3303DUX4</em>

3304-rearranged ALL, patients with an <em class="gene-name">

3305ERG</em>

3306 deletion detected by genomic polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (n = 33) had a more favorable EFS rate of approximately 90% than did patients with intact <em class="gene-name">

3307ERG</em>

3308 (n = 17), with an EFS rate of approximately 70%.[<a href="#cit/section_3.81">

330981</a>

3310]</p>

3311</li>

3312<li>

3313<strong>

3314<em class="gene-name">

3315MEF2D</em>

3316-rearranged ALL.</strong>

3317<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1829" tabindex="-1">

3318Gene fusions involving <em class="gene-name">

3319MEF2D</em>

3320, a transcription factor that is expressed during B-cell development, are observed in approximately 0.3% of NCI standard-risk and 3% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

33211</a>

3322,<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

332384</a>

3324,<a href="#cit/section_3.85">

332585</a>

3326] </p>

3327<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1973" tabindex="-1">

3328Although multiple fusion partners may occur, most cases involve <em class="gene-name">

3329BCL9</em>

3330, which is located on chromosome 1q21, as is <em class="gene-name">

3331MEF2D</em>

3332.[<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

333384</a>

3334,<a href="#cit/section_3.86">

333586</a>

3336] The interstitial deletion producing the <em class="gene-name">

3337MEF2D</em>

3338::<em class="gene-name">

3339BCL9</em>

3340 fusion is too small to be detected by conventional cytogenetic methods. Cases with <em class="gene-name">

3341MEF2D</em>

3342 gene fusions show a distinctive gene expression profile, except for rare cases with <em class="gene-name">

3343MEF2D</em>

3344::<em class="gene-name">

3345CSFR1</em>

3346 that have a <em class="gene-name">

3347BCR</em>

3348::<em class="gene-name">

3349ABL1</em>

3350-like gene expression profile.[<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

335184</a>

3352,<a href="#cit/section_3.87">

335387</a>

3354]</p>

3355 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1937" tabindex="-1">

3356 The median age at diagnosis for cases of <em class="gene-name">

3357MEF2D</em>

3358-rearranged ALL in studies that included both adult and pediatric patients was 12 to 14 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

335984</a>

3360,<a href="#cit/section_3.85">

336185</a>

3362] For 22 children with <em class="gene-name">

3363MEF2D</em>

3364-rearranged ALL enrolled in a high-risk ALL clinical trial, the 5-year EFS rate was 72% (standard error, &#177; 10%), which was inferior to that for other patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

336584</a>

3366]</p>

3367</li>

3368<li>

3369<strong>

3370<em class="gene-name">

3371ZNF384</em>

3372-rearranged ALL.</strong>

3373<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1830" tabindex="-1">

3374<em class="gene-name">

3375ZNF384</em>

3376 is a transcription factor that is rearranged in approximately 0.3% of NCI standard-risk and 2.7% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

33771</a>

3378,<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

337984</a>

3380,<a href="#cit/section_3.88">

338188</a>

3382,<a href="#cit/section_3.89">

338389</a>

3384]</p>

3385<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1974" tabindex="-1">

3386 East Asian ancestry was associated with an increased prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

3387ZNF384</em>

3388.[<a href="#cit/section_3.78">

338978</a>

3390] Multiple fusion partners for <em class="gene-name">

3391ZNF384</em>

3392 have been reported, including <em class="gene-name">

3393ARID1B</em>

3394, <em class="gene-name">

3395CREBBP</em>

3396, <em class="gene-name">

3397EP300</em>

3398, <em class="gene-name">

3399SMARCA2</em>

3400, <em class="gene-name">

3401TAF15</em>

3402, and <em class="gene-name">

3403TCF3</em>

3404. Regardless of the fusion partner, <em class="gene-name">

3405ZNF384</em>

3406-rearranged ALL cases show a distinctive gene expression profile.[<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

340784</a>

3408,<a href="#cit/section_3.88">

340988</a>

3410,<a href="#cit/section_3.89">

341189</a>

3412] <em class="gene-name">

3413ZNF384</em>

3414 rearrangement does not appear to confer independent prognostic significance.[<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

341584</a>

3416,<a href="#cit/section_3.88">

341788</a>

3418,<a href="#cit/section_3.89">

341989</a>

3420] However, within the subset of patients with <em class="gene-name">

3421ZNF384</em>

3422 rearrangements, patients with <em class="gene-name">

3423EP300</em>

3424::<em class="gene-name">

3425ZNF384</em>

3426 fusions have lower relapse rates than patients with other <em class="gene-name">

3427ZNF384</em>

3428 fusion partners.[<a href="#cit/section_3.90">

342990</a>

3430] The immunophenotype of B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

3431ZNF384</em>

3432 rearrangement is characterized by weak or negative CD10 expression, with expression of CD13 and/or CD33 commonly observed.[<a href="#cit/section_3.88">

343388</a>

3434,<a href="#cit/section_3.89">

343589</a>

3436] Cases of mixed phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL) (B/myeloid) that have <em class="gene-name">

3437ZNF384</em>

3438 gene fusions have been reported,[<a href="#cit/section_3.91">

343991</a>

3440,<a href="#cit/section_3.92">

344192</a>

3442] and a genomic evaluation of MPAL found that <em class="gene-name">

3443ZNF384</em>

3444 gene fusions were present in approximately one-half of B/myeloid cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

344593</a>

3446]</p>

3447</li>

3448<li>

3449<strong>

3450<em class="gene-name">

3451NUTM1</em>

3452-rearranged B-ALL.</strong>

3453<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1952" tabindex="-1">

3454<em class="gene-name">

3455NUTM1</em>

3456-rearranged B-ALL is most commonly observed in infants, representing 3% to 5% of overall cases of B-ALL in this age group and approximately 20% of infant B-ALL cases lacking the <em class="gene-name">

3457KMT2A</em>

3458 rearrangement.[<a href="#cit/section_3.94">

345994</a>

3460] The frequency of <em class="gene-name">

3461NUTM1</em>

3462 rearrangement is lower in children after infancy (&lt;1% of cases).[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

34631</a>

3464,<a href="#cit/section_3.94">

346594</a>

3466]</p>

3467<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1975" tabindex="-1">

3468 The <em class="gene-name">

3469NUTM1</em>

3470 gene is located on chromosome 15q14, and some cases of B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

3471NUTM1</em>

3472 rearrangements show chromosome 15q aberrations, but other cases are cryptic and have no cytogenetic abnormalities.[<a href="#cit/section_3.95">

347395</a>

3474] RNA sequencing, as well as break-apart FISH, can be used to detect the presence of the <em class="gene-name">

3475NUTM1</em>

3476 rearrangement.[<a href="#cit/section_3.94">

347794</a>

3478]</p>

3479<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1953" tabindex="-1">

3480The <em class="gene-name">

3481NUTM1</em>

3482 rearrangement appears to be associated with a favorable outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.94">

348394</a>

3484,<a href="#cit/section_3.96">

348596</a>

3486] Among 35 infants with <em class="gene-name">

3487NUTM1</em>

3488-rearranged B-ALL who were treated on Interfant protocols, all patients achieved remission and no relapses were observed.[<a href="#cit/section_3.94">

348994</a>

3490] For the 32 children older than 12 months with <em class="gene-name">

3491NUTM1</em>

3492-rearranged B-ALL, the 4-year EFS and OS rates were 92% and 100%, respectively. </p>

3493</li>

3494<li>

3495<strong>

3496<em class="gene-name">

3497IGH</em>

3498::<em class="gene-name">

3499IL3</em>

3500 fusion (t(5;14)(q31.1;q32.3)).</strong>

3501<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1813" tabindex="-1">

3502This entity is included in the 2016 revision of the World Health Organization (WHO) classification of tumors of the hematopoietic and lymphoid tissues.[<a href="#cit/section_3.97">

350397</a>

3504] The finding of t(5;14)(q31.1;q32.3) in patients with ALL and hypereosinophilia in the 1980s was followed by the identification of the <em class="gene-name">

3505IGH</em>

3506::<em class="gene-name">

3507IL3</em>

3508 fusion as the underlying genetic basis for the condition.[<a href="#cit/section_3.98">

350998</a>

3510,<a href="#cit/section_3.99">

351199</a>

3512] The joining of the <em class="gene-name">

3513IGH</em>

3514 locus to the promoter region of the <em class="gene-name">

3515IL3</em>

3516 gene leads to dysregulation of <em class="gene-name">

3517IL3</em>

3518 expression.[<a href="#cit/section_3.100">

3519100</a>

3520] Cytogenetic abnormalities in children with ALL and eosinophilia are variable, with only a subset resulting from the <em class="gene-name">

3521IGH</em>

3522::<em class="gene-name">

3523IL3</em>

3524 fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.101">

3525101</a>

3526] </p>

3527<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1822" tabindex="-1">

3528The number of cases of <em class="gene-name">

3529IGH</em>

3530::<em class="gene-name">

3531IL3</em>

3532 ALL described in the published literature is too small to assess the prognostic significance of the <em class="gene-name">

3533IGH</em>

3534::<em class="gene-name">

3535IL3</em>

3536 fusion. Diagnosis of cases of <em class="gene-name">

3537IGH</em>

3538::<em class="gene-name">

3539IL3</em>

3540 ALL may be delayed because the ALL clone in the bone marrow may be small, and because it can present with hypereosinophilia in the absence of cytopenias and circulating blasts.[<a href="#cit/section_3.97">

354197</a>

3542]</p>

3543</li>

3544<li>

3545<strong>

3546Intrachromosomal amplification of chromosome 21 (iAMP21).</strong>

3547 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1814" tabindex="-1">

3548iAMP21 is generally diagnosed using FISH and is defined by the presence of greater than or equal to five RUNX1 signals per cell (or &#8805;3 extra copies of <em class="gene-name">

3549RUNX1</em>

3550 on a single abnormal chromosome).[<a href="#cit/section_3.97">

355197</a>

3552] It occurs in approximately 5% of NCI standard-risk and 7% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

35531</a>

3554]</p>

3555<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1976" tabindex="-1">

3556iAMP21 is associated with older age (median, approximately 10 years), presenting WBC count of less than 50 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

35579</span>

3558/L, a slight female preponderance, and high end-induction MRD.[<a href="#cit/section_3.102">

3559102</a>

3560-<a href="#cit/section_3.104">

3561104</a>

3562] Analysis of mutational signatures indicates that gene amplifications in iAMP21 occur later in leukemogenesis, which is in contrast to those of hyperdiploid ALL that can arise early in life and even <em>

3563in utero</em>

3564.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

35651</a>

3566]</p>

3567 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1823" tabindex="-1">

3568The United Kingdom Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (UKALL) clinical trials group initially reported that the presence of iAMP21 conferred a poor prognosis in patients treated in the MRC ALL 97/99 trial (5-year EFS rate, 29%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

356916</a>

3570] In their subsequent trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00222612">

3571UKALL2003 [NCT00222612]</a>

3572), patients with iAMP21 were assigned to a more intensive chemotherapy regimen and had a markedly better outcome (5-year EFS rate, 78%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.103">

3573103</a>

3574] Similarly, the COG has reported that iAMP21 was associated with a significantly inferior outcome in NCI standard-risk patients (4-year EFS rate, 73% for iAMP21 vs. 92% in others), but not in NCI high-risk patients (4-year EFS rate, 73% vs. 80%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.102">

3575102</a>

3576] On multivariate analysis, iAMP21 was an independent predictor of inferior outcome only in NCI standard-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.102">

3577102</a>

3578] The results of the UKALL2003 and COG studies suggest that treatment of iAMP21 patients with high-risk chemotherapy regimens abrogates its adverse prognostic significance and obviates the need for HSCT in first remission.[<a href="#cit/section_3.104">

3579104</a>

3580]</p>

3581</li>

3582<li>

3583<strong>

3584<em class="gene-name">

3585PAX5</em>

3586 alterations.</strong>

3587<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1919" tabindex="-1">

3588Gene expression analysis identified two distinctive ALL subsets with <em class="gene-name">

3589PAX5</em>

3590 genomic alterations, called <em class="gene-name">

3591PAX5</em>

3592alt and PAX5 p.P80R (NP_057953.1).[<a href="#cit/section_3.105">

3593105</a>

3594] The alterations in the <em class="gene-name">

3595PAX5</em>

3596alt subtype included rearrangements, sequence mutations, and focal intragenic amplifications.</p>

3597<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1920" tabindex="-1">

3598<strong>

3599<em class="gene-name">

3600PAX5</em>

3601alt. </strong>

3602<em class="gene-name">

3603PAX5</em>

3604 rearrangements have been reported to represent approximately 3% of NCI standard-risk and 11% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

36051</a>

3606] More than 20 partner genes for <em class="gene-name">

3607PAX5</em>

3608 have been described,[<a href="#cit/section_3.105">

3609105</a>

3610] with <em class="gene-name">

3611PAX5</em>

3612::<em class="gene-name">

3613ETV6</em>

3614, the primary genomic alteration in dic(9;12)(p13;p13),[<a href="#cit/section_3.106">

3615106</a>

3616] being the most common gene fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.105">

3617105</a>

3618] </p>

3619<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1831" tabindex="-1">

3620Intragenic amplification of <em class="gene-name">

3621PAX5</em>

3622 was identified in approximately 1% of B-ALL cases, and it was usually detected in cases lacking known leukemia-driver genomic alterations.[<a href="#cit/section_3.107">

3623107</a>

3624] Cases with <em class="gene-name">

3625PAX5</em>

3626 amplification show male predominance (66%), with most (55%) having NCI high-risk status. For a cohort of patients with <em class="gene-name">

3627PAX5</em>

3628 amplification diagnosed between 1993 and 2015, the 5-year EFS rate was 49% (95% confidence interval [CI], 36%&#8211;61%), and the OS rate was 67% (95% CI, 54%&#8211;77%), suggesting a relatively poor prognosis for patients with this B-ALL subtype.</p>

3629<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1921" tabindex="-1">

3630<strong>

3631PAX5 p.P80R (NP_057953.1). </strong>

3632PAX5 with a p.P80R mutation shows a gene expression profile distinctive from that of other cases with <em class="gene-name">

3633PAX5</em>

3634 alterations.[<a href="#cit/section_3.105">

3635105</a>

3636] Cases with PAX5 p.P80R represent approximately 0.3% of NCI standard-risk and 1.8% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

36371</a>

3638] PAX5 p.P80R B-ALL appears to occur more frequently in the adolescent and young adult (AYA) and adult populations (3.1% and 4.2%, respectively).[<a href="#cit/section_3.105">

3639105</a>

3640] </p>

3641<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1955" tabindex="-1">

3642Outcome for the pediatric patients with PAX5 p.P80R and <em class="gene-name">

3643PAX5</em>

3644alt treated in a COG clinical trial appears to be intermediate (5-year EFS rate, approximately 75%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.105">

3645105</a>

3646] <em class="gene-name">

3647PAX5</em>

3648alt rearrangements have also been detected in infant patients with ALL, with a reported outcome similar to <em class="gene-name">

3649KMT2A</em>

3650-rearranged infant ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.96">

365196</a>

3652]</p>

3653</li>

3654<li>

3655<strong>

3656<em class="gene-name">

3657BCR</em>

3658::<em class="gene-name">

3659ABL1</em>

3660-like (Ph-like).</strong>

3661 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1816" tabindex="-1">

3662<em class="gene-name">

3663BCR</em>

3664::<em class="gene-name">

3665ABL1</em>

3666-negative patients with a gene expression profile similar to <em class="gene-name">

3667BCR</em>

3668::<em class="gene-name">

3669ABL1</em>

3670-positive patients have been referred to as Ph-like,[<a href="#cit/section_3.108">

3671108</a>

3672-<a href="#cit/section_3.110">

3673110</a>

3674] and are now referred to as <em class="gene-name">

3675BCR</em>

3676::<em class="gene-name">

3677ABL1</em>

3678-like.[<a href="#cit/section_3.17">

367917</a>

3680] This occurs in 10% to 20% of pediatric B-ALL patients, increasing in frequency with age, and has been associated with an

3681<em class="gene-name">

3682IKZF1</em>

3683 deletion or mutation.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

36841</a>

3685,<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

36868</a>

3687,<a href="#cit/section_3.108">

3688108</a>

3689,<a href="#cit/section_3.109">

3690109</a>

3691,<a href="#cit/section_3.111">

3692111</a>

3693,<a href="#cit/section_3.112">

3694112</a>

3695] </p>

3696<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1861" tabindex="-1">

3697Retrospective analyses have indicated that patients with <em class="gene-name">

3698BCR</em>

3699::<em class="gene-name">

3700ABL1</em>

3701-like ALL have a poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

37024</a>

3703,<a href="#cit/section_3.108">

3704108</a>

3705] In one series, the 5-year EFS rate for NCI high-risk children and adolescents with <em class="gene-name">

3706BCR</em>

3707::<em class="gene-name">

3708ABL1</em>

3709-like ALL was 58% and 41%, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

37104</a>

3711] While it is more frequent in older and higher-risk patients, the <em class="gene-name">

3712BCR</em>

3713::<em class="gene-name">

3714ABL1</em>

3715-like subtype has also been identified in NCI standard-risk patients. In a COG study, 13.6% of 1,023 NCI standard-risk B-ALL patients were found to have <em class="gene-name">

3716BCR</em>

3717::<em class="gene-name">

3718ABL1</em>

3719-like ALL; these patients had an inferior EFS rate compared with non&#8211;<em class="gene-name">

3720BCR</em>

3721::<em class="gene-name">

3722ABL1</em>

3723-like standard-risk patients (82% vs. 91%), although no difference in OS rate (93% vs. 96%) was noted.[<a href="#cit/section_3.113">

3724113</a>

3725] In one study of 40 <em class="gene-name">

3726BCR</em>

3727::<em class="gene-name">

3728ABL1</em>

3729-like patients, the adverse prognostic significance of this subtype appeared to be abrogated when patients were treated with risk-directed therapy on the basis of MRD levels.[<a href="#cit/section_3.114">

3730114</a>

3731]</p>

3732 <p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1709" tabindex="-1">

3733The hallmark of <em class="gene-name">

3734BCR</em>

3735::<em class="gene-name">

3736ABL1</em>

3737-like ALL is activated kinase signaling, with approximately 35% to 50% containing <em class="gene-name">

3738CRLF2</em>

3739 genomic alterations [<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

37401</a>

3741,<a href="#cit/section_3.110">

3742110</a>

3743,<a href="#cit/section_3.115">

3744115</a>

3745] and half of those cases containing concomitant <em class="gene-name">

3746JAK</em>

3747 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_3.116">

3748116</a>

3749] </p>

3750<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1794" tabindex="-1">

3751Many of the remaining cases of <em class="gene-name">

3752BCR</em>

3753::<em class="gene-name">

3754ABL1</em>

3755-like ALL have been noted to have a series of translocations involving tyrosine-kinase encoding ABL-class fusion genes, including <em class="gene-name">

3756ABL1</em>

3757, <em class="gene-name">

3758ABL2</em>

3759, <em class="gene-name">

3760CSF1R</em>

3761, and <em class="gene-name">

3762PDGFRB</em>

3763.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

37644</a>

3765,<a href="#cit/section_3.111">

3766111</a>

3767,<a href="#cit/section_3.117">

3768117</a>

3769] Fusion proteins from these gene combinations have been noted in some cases to be transformative and have responded to tyrosine kinase inhibitors both <em>

3770in vitro</em>

3771 and <em>

3772in vivo</em>

3773,[<a href="#cit/section_3.111">

3774111</a>

3775] suggesting potential therapeutic strategies for these patients.</p>

3776<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1977" tabindex="-1">

3777<em class="gene-name">

3778BCR</em>

3779::<em class="gene-name">

3780ABL1</em>

3781-like ALL cases with non-<em class="gene-name">

3782CRLF2</em>

3783 genomic alterations represent approximately 3% of NCI standard-risk and 8% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

37841</a>

3785] In a retrospective study of 122 pediatric patients (aged 1&#8211;18 years) with ABL-class fusions (all treated without tyrosine kinase inhibitors), the 5-year EFS rate was 59%, and the OS rate was 76%.[<a href="#cit/section_3.118">

3786118</a>

3787]</p>

3788<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1818" tabindex="-1">

3789Approximately 9% of <em class="gene-name">

3790BCR</em>

3791::<em class="gene-name">

3792ABL1</em>

3793-like ALL cases result from rearrangements that lead to overexpression of a truncated erythropoietin receptor (EPOR).[<a href="#cit/section_3.119">

3794119</a>

3795] The C-terminal region of the receptor that is lost is the region that is mutated in primary familial congenital polycythemia and that controls stability of the EPOR. The portion of the EPOR remaining is sufficient for JAK-STAT activation and for driving leukemia development. Point mutations in kinase genes, aside from those in <em class="gene-name">

3796JAK1</em>

3797 and <em class="gene-name">

3798JAK2</em>

3799, are uncommon in patients with <em class="gene-name">

3800BCR</em>

3801::<em class="gene-name">

3802ABL1</em>

3803-like ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

38048</a>

3805]</p>

3806<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1817" tabindex="-1">

3807<em class="gene-name">

3808<strong>

3809CRLF2. </strong>

3810</em>

3811Genomic alterations in <em class="gene-name">

3812CRLF2</em>

3813, a cytokine receptor gene located on the pseudoautosomal regions of the sex chromosomes, have been identified in 5% to 10% of cases of B-ALL. These alterations represent approximately 50% of cases of <em class="gene-name">

3814BCR</em>

3815::<em class="gene-name">

3816ABL1</em>

3817-like ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.120">

3818120</a>

3819-<a href="#cit/section_3.122">

3820122</a>

3821] The chromosomal abnormalities that commonly lead to <em class="gene-name">

3822CRLF2</em>

3823 overexpression include translocations of the <em class="gene-name">

3824IGH</em>

3825 locus (chromosome 14) to <em class="gene-name">

3826CRLF2</em>

3827 and interstitial deletions in pseudoautosomal regions of the sex chromosomes, resulting in a <em class="gene-name">

3828P2RY8</em>

3829::<em class="gene-name">

3830CRLF2</em>

3831 fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

38328</a>

3833,<a href="#cit/section_3.115">

3834115</a>

3835,<a href="#cit/section_3.120">

3836120</a>

3837,<a href="#cit/section_3.121">

3838121</a>

3839] These two genomic alterations are associated with distinctive clinical and biological characteristics. </p>

3840<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1978" tabindex="-1">

3841<em class="gene-name">

3842BCR</em>

3843::<em class="gene-name">

3844ABL1</em>

3845-like B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

3846CRLF2</em>

3847 genomic alterations is observed in approximately 2% of NCI standard-risk and 5% of NCI high-risk pediatric B-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

38481</a>

3849]</p>

3850<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1959" tabindex="-1">

3851ALL with genomic alterations in <em class="gene-name">

3852CRLF2</em>

3853 occurs at a higher incidence in children with Hispanic or Latino genetic ancestry [<a href="#cit/section_3.115">

3854115</a>

3855,<a href="#cit/section_3.123">

3856123</a>

3857] and American Indian genetic ancestry.[<a href="#cit/section_3.78">

385878</a>

3859] In a study of 205 children with high-risk B-ALL, 18 of 51 (35.3%) Hispanic or Latino patients had <em class="gene-name">

3860CRLF2</em>

3861 rearrangements, compared with 11 of 154 (7.1%) cases of other declared ethnicity.[<a href="#cit/section_3.115">

3862115</a>

3863] In a second study, only the frequency of <em class="gene-name">

3864IGH</em>

3865::<em class="gene-name">

3866CRLF2</em>

3867 fusions was increased in Hispanic or Latino children compared with non-Hispanic or non-Latino children with B-ALL (12% vs. 2.7%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.123">

3868123</a>

3869] In this study, the percentage of B-ALL with <em class="gene-name">

3870P2RY8</em>

3871::<em class="gene-name">

3872CRLF2</em>

3873 fusions was approximately 6% and was not affected by ethnicity. </p>

3874<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1938" tabindex="-1">

3875 The <em class="gene-name">

3876P2RY8</em>

3877::<em class="gene-name">

3878CRLF2</em>

3879 fusion is observed in 70% to 75% of pediatric patients with <em class="gene-name">

3880CRLF2</em>

3881 genomic alterations, and it occurs in younger patients (median age, approximately 4 years vs. 14 years for patients with <em class="gene-name">

3882IGH</em>

3883::<em class="gene-name">

3884CRLF2</em>

3885).[<a href="#cit/section_3.124">

3886124</a>

3887,<a href="#cit/section_3.125">

3888125</a>

3889] <em class="gene-name">

3890P2RY8</em>

3891::<em class="gene-name">

3892CRLF2</em>

3893 occurs not infrequently with established chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., hyperdiploidy, iAMP21, dic(9;20)), while <em class="gene-name">

3894IGH</em>

3895::<em class="gene-name">

3896CRLF2</em>

3897 is generally mutually exclusive with known cytogenetic subgroups. <em class="gene-name">

3898CRLF2</em>

3899 genomic alterations are observed in approximately 60% of patients with Down syndrome and ALL, with <em class="gene-name">

3900P2RY8</em>

3901::<em class="gene-name">

3902CRLF2</em>

3903 fusions being more common than <em class="gene-name">

3904IGH</em>

3905::<em class="gene-name">

3906CRLF2</em>

3907 (approximately 80% vs. 20%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.121">

3908121</a>

3909,<a href="#cit/section_3.124">

3910124</a>

3911]</p>

3912<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1923" tabindex="-1">

3913<em class="gene-name">

3914IGH</em>

3915::<em class="gene-name">

3916CRLF2</em>

3917 and <em class="gene-name">

3918P2RY8</em>

3919::<em class="gene-name">

3920CRLF2</em>

3921 commonly occur as an early event in B-ALL development and show clonal prevalence.[<a href="#cit/section_3.126">

3922126</a>

3923] However, in some cases they appear to be a late event and show subclonal prevalence.[<a href="#cit/section_3.126">

3924126</a>

3925] Loss of the <em class="gene-name">

3926CRLF2</em>

3927 genomic abnormality in some cases at relapse confirms the subclonal nature of the alteration in these cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.124">

3928124</a>

3929,<a href="#cit/section_3.127">

3930127</a>

3931]</p>

3932<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1922" tabindex="-1">

3933<em class="gene-name">

3934CRLF2</em>

3935 abnormalities are strongly associated with the presence of <em class="gene-name">

3936IKZF1</em>

3937 deletions. Deletions of <em class="gene-name">

3938IKZF1</em>

3939 are more common in cases with <em class="gene-name">

3940IGH</em>

3941::<em class="gene-name">

3942CRLF2</em>

3943 fusions than in cases with <em class="gene-name">

3944P2RY8</em>

3945::<em class="gene-name">

3946CRLF2</em>

3947 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_3.125">

3948125</a>

3949] Other recurring genomic alterations found in association with <em class="gene-name">

3950CRLF2</em>

3951 alterations include deletions in genes associated with B-cell differentiation (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

3952PAX5</em>

3953, <em class="gene-name">

3954BTG1</em>

3955, <em class="gene-name">

3956EBF1</em>

3957, etc.) and cell cycle control (<em class="gene-name">

3958CDKN2A</em>

3959), as well as genomic alterations activating JAK-STAT pathway signaling (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

3960IL7R</em>

3961 and <em class="gene-name">

3962JAK</em>

3963 mutations).[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

39644</a>

3965,<a href="#cit/section_3.115">

3966115</a>

3967,<a href="#cit/section_3.116">

3968116</a>

3969,<a href="#cit/section_3.121">

3970121</a>

3971,<a href="#cit/section_3.128">

3972128</a>

3973] </p>

3974<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1626" tabindex="-1">

3975Although the results of several retrospective studies suggest that <em class="gene-name">

3976CRLF2</em>

3977 abnormalities may have adverse prognostic significance in univariate analyses, most do not find this abnormality to be an independent predictor of outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.115">

3978115</a>

3979,<a href="#cit/section_3.120">

3980120</a>

3981,<a href="#cit/section_3.121">

3982121</a>

3983,<a href="#cit/section_3.129">

3984129</a>

3985,<a href="#cit/section_3.130">

3986130</a>

3987] For example, in a large European study, increased expression of <em class="gene-name">

3988CRLF2</em>

3989 was not associated with unfavorable outcome in multivariate analysis, while <em class="gene-name">

3990IKZF1</em>

3991 deletion and <em class="gene-name">

3992BCR</em>

3993::<em class="gene-name">

3994ABL1</em>

3995-like expression signatures were associated with unfavorable outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.112">

3996112</a>

3997] Controversy exists about whether the prognostic significance of <em class="gene-name">

3998CRLF2</em>

3999 abnormalities should be analyzed on the basis of <em class="gene-name">

4000CRLF2</em>

4001 overexpression or on the presence of <em class="gene-name">

4002CRLF2</em>

4003 genomic alterations.[<a href="#cit/section_3.129">

4004129</a>

4005,<a href="#cit/section_3.130">

4006130</a>

4007]</p>

4008</li>

4009<li>

4010<strong>

4011<em class="gene-name">

4012IKZF1</em>

4013 deletions.</strong>

4014<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1832" tabindex="-1">

4015<em class="gene-name">

4016IKZF1</em>

4017 deletions, including deletions of the entire gene and deletions of specific exons, are present in approximately 15% of B-ALL cases. Less commonly, <em class="gene-name">

4018IKZF1</em>

4019 can be inactivated by deleterious point mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_3.109">

4020109</a>

4021]</p>

4022<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1939" tabindex="-1">

4023 Cases with <em class="gene-name">

4024IKZF1</em>

4025 deletions tend to occur in older children, have a higher WBC count at diagnosis, and are therefore more common in NCI high-risk patients than in NCI standard-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

40262</a>

4027,<a href="#cit/section_3.109">

4028109</a>

4029,<a href="#cit/section_3.128">

4030128</a>

4031,<a href="#cit/section_3.131">

4032131</a>

4033] A high proportion of <em class="gene-name">

4034BCR</em>

4035::<em class="gene-name">

4036ABL1</em>

4037-positive cases have a deletion of <em class="gene-name">

4038IKZF1</em>

4039,[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

40403</a>

4041,<a href="#cit/section_3.128">

4042128</a>

4043] and ALL arising in children with Down syndrome appears to have elevated rates of <em class="gene-name">

4044IKZF1</em>

4045 deletions.[<a href="#cit/section_3.132">

4046132</a>

4047] <em class="gene-name">

4048IKZF1</em>

4049 deletions are also common in cases with <em class="gene-name">

4050CRLF2</em>

4051 genomic alterations and in <em class="gene-name">

4052BCR</em>

4053::<em class="gene-name">

4054ABL1</em>

4055-like ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.80">

405680</a>

4057,<a href="#cit/section_3.108">

4058108</a>

4059,<a href="#cit/section_3.128">

4060128</a>

4061]</p>

4062<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1833" tabindex="-1">

4063Multiple reports have documented the adverse prognostic significance of an <em class="gene-name">

4064IKZF1</em>

4065 deletion, and most studies have reported that this deletion is an independent predictor of poor outcome in multivariate analyses.[<a href="#cit/section_3.80">

406680</a>

4067,<a href="#cit/section_3.108">

4068108</a>

4069,<a href="#cit/section_3.109">

4070109</a>

4071,<a href="#cit/section_3.112">

4072112</a>

4073,<a href="#cit/section_3.128">

4074128</a>

4075,<a href="#cit/section_3.133">

4076133</a>

4077-<a href="#cit/section_3.139">

4078139</a>

4079]; [<a href="#cit/section_3.140">

4080140</a>

4081][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4082Level of evidence B4</a>

4083] However, the prognostic significance of <em class="gene-name">

4084IKZF1</em>

4085 may not apply equally across ALL biological subtypes, as illustrated by the apparent lack of prognostic significance in patients with <em class="gene-name">

4086ERG</em>

4087 deletions.[<a href="#cit/section_3.80">

408880</a>

4089-<a href="#cit/section_3.82">

409082</a>

4091] Similarly, the prognostic significance of the <em class="gene-name">

4092IKZF1</em>

4093 deletion also appeared to be minimized in a cohort of COG patients with <em class="gene-name">

4094DUX4</em>

4095-rearranged ALL and with <em class="gene-name">

4096ERG</em>

4097 transcriptional dysregulation that frequently occurred by <em class="gene-name">

4098ERG</em>

4099 deletion.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

41006</a>

4101] The Associazione Italiana di Ematologia e Oncologia Pediatrica&#8211;Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster group reported that <em class="gene-name">

4102IKZF1</em>

4103 deletions were significant adverse prognostic factors only in B-ALL patients with high end-induction MRD and in whom co-occurrence of deletions of <em class="gene-name">

4104CDKN2A</em>

4105, <em class="gene-name">

4106CDKN2B</em>

4107, <em class="gene-name">

4108PAX5</em>

4109, or <em class="gene-name">

4110PAR1</em>

4111 (in the absence of <em class="gene-name">

4112ERG</em>

4113 deletion) were identified.[<a href="#cit/section_3.141">

4114141</a>

4115] The poor prognosis associated with <em class="gene-name">

4116IKZF1</em>

4117 alterations appears to be enhanced by the concomitant finding of deletion of 22q11.22. In a study of 1,310 patients with B-ALL, approximately one-half of the patients with <em class="gene-name">

4118IKZF1</em>

4119 alterations also had deletion of 22q11.22. The 5-year EFS rate was 43.3% for those with both abnormalities, compared with 68.5% for patients with <em class="gene-name">

4120IKZF1</em>

4121 alterations and wild-type 22q11.22 (<em>

4122P</em>

4123 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_3.142">

4124142</a>

4125]</p>

4126<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1855" tabindex="-1">

4127There are few published results of changing therapy on the basis of <em class="gene-name">

4128IKZF1</em>

4129 gene status. The Malaysia-Singapore group published results of two consecutive trials. In the first trial (MS2003), <em class="gene-name">

4130IKZF1</em>

4131 status was not considered in risk stratification, while in the subsequent trial (MS2010), <em class="gene-name">

4132IKZF1</em>

4133-deleted patients were excluded from the standard-risk group. Thus, more <em class="gene-name">

4134IKZF1</em>

4135-deleted patients in the MS2010 trial received intensified therapy. Patients with <em class="gene-name">

4136IKZF1</em>

4137-deleted ALL had improved outcomes in MS2010 compared with patients in MS2003, but interpretation of this observation is limited by other changes in risk stratification and therapeutic differences between the two trials.[<a href="#cit/section_3.143">

4138143</a>

4139][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4140Level of evidence B4</a>

4141]</p>

4142</li>

4143<li>

4144<strong>

4145<em class="gene-name">

4146MYC</em>

4147-rearranged ALL (8q24).</strong>

4148<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1956" tabindex="-1">

4149<em class="gene-name">

4150MYC</em>

4151 gene rearrangements are a rare but recurrent finding in pediatric patients with B-ALL. Patients with rearrangements of the <em class="gene-name">

4152MYC</em>

4153 gene and the <em class="gene-name">

4154IGH2</em>

4155, <em class="gene-name">

4156IGK</em>

4157, and <em class="gene-name">

4158IGL</em>

4159 genes at 14q32, 2p12, and 22q11.2, respectively, have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_3.144">

4160144</a>

4161-<a href="#cit/section_3.146">

4162146</a>

4163] The lymphoblasts typically exhibit a precursor B-cell immunophenotype, with a French-American-British (FAB) L2 or L3 morphology, with no expression of surface immunoglobulin and kappa or lambda light chains. Concurrent <em class="gene-name">

4164MYC</em>

4165 gene rearrangements have been observed along with additional cytogenetic rearrangements such as <em class="gene-name">

4166IGH</em>

4167::<em class="gene-name">

4168BCL2</em>

4169 or <em class="gene-name">

4170KMT2A</em>

4171.[<a href="#cit/section_3.146">

4172146</a>

4173] Patients reported in the literature have been variably treated with ALL therapy or with mature B leukemia/lymphoma treatment protocols, and the optimal treatment for this patient group remains uncertain.[<a href="#cit/section_3.146">

4174146</a>

4175]</p>

4176</li>

4177</ul>

4178</div>

4179</li>

4180</ol>

4181</div>

4182</section>

4183<section id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1838">

4184<h3 id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1838_toc">

4185T-ALL cytogenetics/genomics</h3>

4186<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1914" tabindex="-1">

4187 T-ALL is characterized by genomic alterations leading to activation of transcriptional programs related to T-cell development and by a high frequency of cases (approximately 60%) with mutations in <em class="gene-name">

4188NOTCH1</em>

4189 and/or <em class="gene-name">

4190FBXW7</em>

4191 that result in activation of the NOTCH1 pathway.[<a href="#cit/section_3.147">

4192147</a>

4193] Cytogenetic abnormalities common in B-ALL (e.g., hyperdiploidy, 51&#8211;65 chromosomes) are

4194 rare in T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.148">

4195148</a>

4196,<a href="#cit/section_3.149">

4197149</a>

4198]</p>

4199<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1960" tabindex="-1">

4200In Figure 5 below, pediatric T-ALL cases are divided into 10 molecular subtypes based on their RNA expression and gene mutation status. These cases were derived from patients enrolled in SJCRH and COG clinical trials.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

42011</a>

4202] Each subtype is associated with dysregulation of specific genes involved in T-cell development. Within a subtype, multiple mechanisms may drive expression of the dysregulated gene. For example, for the largest subtype, <em class="gene-name">

4203TAL1</em>

4204, overexpression of TAL1 can result from the <em class="gene-name">

4205STIL</em>

4206::<em class="gene-name">

4207TAL1</em>

4208 fusion and a noncoding insertion mutation upstream of the TAL1 locus that creates a <em class="gene-name">

4209MYB</em>

4210-binding site.[<a href="#cit/section_3.147">

4211147</a>

4212,<a href="#cit/section_3.150">

4213150</a>

4214] As another example, within the HOXA group, overexpression of <em class="gene-name">

4215HOXA9</em>

4216 can result from multiple gene fusions, including <em class="gene-name">

4217KMT2A</em>

4218 rearrangements, <em class="gene-name">

4219MLLT10</em>

4220 rearrangements, and <em class="gene-name">

4221SET</em>

4222::<em class="gene-name">

4223NUP214</em>

4224 fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

42251</a>

4226,<a href="#cit/section_3.147">

4227147</a>

4228,<a href="#cit/section_3.151">

4229151</a>

4230] In contrast to the molecular subtypes of B-ALL, the molecular subtypes of T-ALL are not used to define treatment interventions based on their prognostic significance or therapeutic implications.</p>

4231<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1964" tabindex="-1">

4232<figure id="figure_sm_CDR0000779360_1965" class="image-center">

4233<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/810691.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

4234Enlarge</a>

4235<img id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1965" alt="Figure showing genomic subtypes of T-ALL." title="Figure showing genomic subtypes of T-ALL." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/810691-750.jpg">

4236<figcaption class="caption-container">

4237Figure 5. Genomic subtypes of T-ALL. The figure represents data from 466 children, adolescents, and young adults diagnosed with T-ALL and enrolled in St. Jude Children&#8217;s Research Hospital or Children&#8217;s Oncology Group clinical trials.

4238Adapted from Brady SW, Roberts KG, Gu Z, et al.: The genomic landscape of pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Nature Genetics 54: 1376-1389, 2022.</figcaption>

4239</figure>

4240</p>

4241<div class="pdq-content-list">

4242<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1940">

4243<li>

4244<strong>

4245Notch pathway signaling.</strong>

4246<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1843" tabindex="-1">

4247Notch pathway signaling is commonly activated by <em class="gene-name">

4248NOTCH1</em>

4249 and <em class="gene-name">

4250FBXW7</em>

4251 gene mutations in T-ALL, and these are the most commonly mutated genes in pediatric T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.147">

4252147</a>

4253,<a href="#cit/section_3.152">

4254152</a>

4255] <em class="gene-name">

4256NOTCH1</em>

4257-activating gene mutations occur in approximately 50% to 60% of T-ALL cases, and <em class="gene-name">

4258FBXW7</em>

4259-inactivating gene mutations occur in approximately 15% of cases. Approximately 60% of T-ALL cases have Notch pathway activation by mutations in at least one of these genes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.153">

4260153</a>

4261,<a href="#cit/section_3.154">

4262154</a>

4263]</p>

4264<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1844" tabindex="-1">

4265The prognostic significance of <em class="gene-name">

4266NOTCH1</em>

4267 and <em class="gene-name">

4268FBXW7</em>

4269 mutations may be modulated by genomic alterations in RAS and PTEN. The French Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia Study Group (FRALLE) and the Group for Research on Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia reported that patients having mutated <em class="gene-name">

4270NOTCH1</em>

4271 or <em class="gene-name">

4272FBXW7</em>

4273 and wild-type <em class="gene-name">

4274PTEN</em>

4275 and <em class="gene-name">

4276RAS</em>

4277 constituted a favorable-risk group (i.e., low-risk group), while patients with <em class="gene-name">

4278PTEN</em>

4279 or <em class="gene-name">

4280RAS</em>

4281 mutations, regardless of <em class="gene-name">

4282NOTCH1</em>

4283 and <em class="gene-name">

4284FBXW7</em>

4285 status, have a significantly higher risk of treatment failure (i.e., high-risk group).[<a href="#cit/section_3.155">

4286155</a>

4287,<a href="#cit/section_3.156">

4288156</a>

4289] In the FRALLE study, the 5-year disease-free survival rate was 88% for the genetic low-risk group of patients and 60% for the genetic high-risk group of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_3.155">

4290155</a>

4291] However, using the same criteria to define the genetic risk group, the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute consortium was unable to replicate these results. They reported a 5-year EFS rate of 86% for genetic low-risk patients and 79% for the genetic high-risk patients, a difference that was not statistically significant (<em>

4292P</em>

4293 = .26).[<a href="#cit/section_3.154">

4294154</a>

4295]</p>

4296</li>

4297<li>

4298<strong>

4299Chromosomal translocations.</strong>

4300<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1840" tabindex="-1">

4301Multiple chromosomal translocations have been identified in T-ALL that lead to deregulated expression of the target genes. These chromosome rearrangements fuse genes encoding transcription factors (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

4302TAL1</em>

4303, <em class="gene-name">

4304TAL2</em>

4305, <em class="gene-name">

4306LMO1</em>

4307, <em class="gene-name">

4308LMO2</em>

4309, <em class="gene-name">

4310LYL1</em>

4311, <em class="gene-name">

4312TLX1</em>

4313, <em class="gene-name">

4314TLX3</em>

4315, <em class="gene-name">

4316NKX2-I</em>

4317, <em class="gene-name">

4318HOXA</em>

4319, and <em class="gene-name">

4320MYB</em>

4321) to one of the T-cell receptor loci (or to other genes) and result in deregulated expression of these transcription factors in leukemia cells.[<a href="#cit/section_3.147">

4322147</a>

4323,<a href="#cit/section_3.148">

4324148</a>

4325,<a href="#cit/section_3.157">

4326157</a>

4327-<a href="#cit/section_3.161">

4328161</a>

4329] These translocations are often not apparent by examining a standard karyotype, but can be identified using more sensitive screening techniques, including FISH or PCR.[<a href="#cit/section_3.148">

4330148</a>

4331] Mutations in a noncoding region near the <em class="gene-name">

4332TAL1</em>

4333 gene that produce a super-enhancer upstream of <em class="gene-name">

4334TAL1</em>

4335 represent nontranslocation genomic alterations that can also activate <em class="gene-name">

4336TAL1</em>

4337 transcription to induce T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.150">

4338150</a>

4339]</p>

4340<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1841" tabindex="-1">

4341Translocations resulting in chimeric fusion proteins are also observed in T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.155">

4342155</a>

4343]</p>

4344<div class="pdq-content-list">

4345<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1842">

4346<li>

4347A <em class="gene-name">

4348NUP214</em>

4349::<em class="gene-name">

4350ABL1</em>

4351 fusion has been noted in 4% to 6% of T-ALL cases and is observed in both adults and children, with a male predominance.[<a href="#cit/section_3.162">

4352162</a>

4353-<a href="#cit/section_3.164">

4354164</a>

4355] The fusion is cytogenetically cryptic and is seen in FISH on amplified episomes or, more rarely, as a small homogeneous staining region.[<a href="#cit/section_3.164">

4356164</a>

4357] T-ALL may also uncommonly show ABL1 fusion proteins with other gene partners (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

4358ETV6</em>

4359, <em class="gene-name">

4360BCR</em>

4361, and <em class="gene-name">

4362EML1</em>

4363).[<a href="#cit/section_3.164">

4364164</a>

4365] ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors, such as imatinib or dasatinib, may demonstrate therapeutic benefits in this T-ALL subtype,[<a href="#cit/section_3.162">

4366162</a>

4367,<a href="#cit/section_3.163">

4368163</a>

4369,<a href="#cit/section_3.165">

4370165</a>

4371] although clinical experience with this strategy is very limited.[<a href="#cit/section_3.166">

4372166</a>

4373-<a href="#cit/section_3.168">

4374168</a>

4375]</li>

4376<li>

4377Gene fusions involving <em class="gene-name">

4378SPI1</em>

4379 (encoding the transcription factor PU.1) were reported in 4% of Japanese children with T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.169">

4380169</a>

4381] Fusion partners included <em class="gene-name">

4382STMN1</em>

4383 and <em class="gene-name">

4384TCF7</em>

4385. T-ALL cases with <em class="gene-name">

4386SPI1</em>

4387 fusions had a particularly poor prognosis; six of seven affected individuals died within 3 years of diagnosis of early relapse.</li>

4388<li>

4389Other recurring gene fusions in T-ALL patients include those involving <em class="gene-name">

4390MLLT10</em>

4391, <em class="gene-name">

4392KMT2A</em>

4393, <em class="gene-name">

4394NUP214</em>

4395, and <em class="gene-name">

4396NUP98</em>

4397.[<a href="#cit/section_3.147">

4398147</a>

4399,<a href="#cit/section_3.151">

4400151</a>

4401]</li>

4402</ul>

4403</div>

4404</li>

4405</ul>

4406</div>

4407<section id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1850">

4408<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1850_toc">

4409Early T-cell precursor ALL cytogenetics/genomics</h4>

4410<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1851" tabindex="-1">

4411Detailed molecular characterization of early T-cell precursor ALL showed this entity to be highly heterogeneous at the molecular level, with no single gene affected by mutation or copy number alteration in more than one-third of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.170">

4412170</a>

4413] Compared with other T-ALL cases, the early T-cell precursor group had a lower rate of <em class="gene-name">

4414NOTCH1</em>

4415 mutations and significantly higher frequencies of alterations in genes regulating cytokine receptors and RAS signaling, hematopoietic development, and histone modification. The transcriptional profile of early T-cell precursor ALL shows similarities to that of normal hematopoietic stem cells and myeloid leukemia stem cells.[<a href="#cit/section_3.170">

4416170</a>

4417]</p>

4418<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1852" tabindex="-1">

4419Studies have found that the absence of biallelic deletion of the TCR-gamma locus (ABD), as detected by comparative genomic hybridization and/or quantitative DNA-PCR, was associated with early treatment failure in patients with T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.171">

4420171</a>

4421,<a href="#cit/section_3.172">

4422172</a>

4423] ABD is characteristic of early thymic precursor cells, and many of the T-ALL patients with ABD have an immunophenotype consistent with the diagnosis of early T-cell precursor phenotype.</p>

4424</section>

4425</section>

4426<section id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1924">

4427<h3 id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1924_toc">

4428Mixed phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL) cytogenetics/genomics</h3>

4429<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1925" tabindex="-1">

4430For acute leukemias of ambiguous lineage, the WHO classification system is summarized in Table 3.[<a href="#cit/section_3.173">

4431173</a>

4432,<a href="#cit/section_3.174">

4433174</a>

4434] The criteria for lineage assignment for a diagnosis of MPAL are provided in Table 4.[<a href="#cit/section_3.97">

443597</a>

4436]</p>

4437<table id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1930" class="table-default expandable-container">

4438<caption>

4439Table 3. Acute Leukemias of Ambiguous Lineage According to the World Health Organization Classification of Tumors of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tissues<span class="sup">

4440a</span>

4441</caption>

4442<colgroup>

4443<col width="50.00%">

4444<col width="50.00%">

4445</colgroup>

4446<THead>

4447<tr>

4448<th>

4449Condition</th>

4450<th>

4451 Definition</th>

4452</tr>

4453</THead>

4454<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

4455<tr>

4456<td colspan="2">

4457MPAL = mixed phenotype acute leukemia; NOS = not otherwise specified.</td>

4458</tr>

4459<tr>

4460<td colspan="2">

4461<span class="sup">

4462a</span>

4463Adapted from B&#233;n&#233; MC: Biphenotypic, bilineal, ambiguous or mixed lineage: strange leukemias! Haematologica 94 (7): 891-3, 2009.[<a href="#cit/section_3.173">

4464173</a>

4465] Obtained from Haematologica/the Hematology Journal website <a href="http://www.haematologica.org" title="http://www.haematologica.org">

4466http://www.haematologica.org</a>

4467.</td>

4468</tr>

4469</TFoot>

4470<tbody>

4471<tr>

4472<td>

4473Acute undifferentiated leukemia

4474

4475

4476

4477

4478

4479</td>

4480<td>

4481Acute leukemia that does not express any marker considered specific for either lymphoid or myeloid lineage</td>

4482</tr>

4483<tr>

4484<td>

4485MPAL with <em class="gene-name">

4486BCR</em>

4487::<em class="gene-name">

4488ABL1</em>

4489 (t(9;22)(q34;q11.2))</td>

4490<td>

4491Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for MPAL in which the blasts also have the (9;22) translocation or the <em class="gene-name">

4492BCR</em>

4493::<em class="gene-name">

4494ABL1</em>

4495 rearrangement</td>

4496</tr>

4497<tr>

4498<td>

4499MPAL with <em class="gene-name">

4500KMT2A</em>

4501 (t(v;11q23))</td>

4502<td>

4503Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for MPAL in which the blasts also have a translocation involving the <em class="gene-name">

4504KMT2A</em>

4505 gene</td>

4506</tr>

4507<tr>

4508<td>

4509MPAL, B/myeloid, NOS

4510(B/M MPAL)</td>

4511<td>

4512Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for assignment to both B and myeloid lineage, in which the blasts lack genetic abnormalities involving <em class="gene-name">

4513BCR</em>

4514::<em class="gene-name">

4515ABL1</em>

4516 or <em class="gene-name">

4517KMT2A</em>

4518</td>

4519</tr>

4520<tr>

4521<td>

4522MPAL, T/myeloid, NOS (T/M MPAL)</td>

4523<td>

4524Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for assignment to both T and myeloid lineage, in which the blasts lack genetic abnormalities involving <em class="gene-name">

4525BCR</em>

4526::<em class="gene-name">

4527ABL1</em>

4528 or <em class="gene-name">

4529KMT2A</em>

4530</td>

4531</tr>

4532<tr>

4533<td>

4534MPAL, B/myeloid, NOS&#8212;rare types</td>

4535<td>

4536Acute leukemia meeting the diagnostic criteria for assignment to both B and T lineage</td>

4537</tr>

4538<tr>

4539<td>

4540Other ambiguous lineage leukemias</td>

4541<td>

4542Natural killer&#8211;cell lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma</td>

4543</tr>

4544</tbody>

4545</table>

4546<table id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1931" class="table-default expandable-container">

4547<caption>

4548Table 4. Lineage Assignment Criteria for Mixed Phenotype Acute Leukemia According to the 2016 Revision to the World Health Organization Classification of Myeloid Neoplasms and Acute Leukemia<span class="sup">

4549a</span>

4550</caption>

4551<colgroup>

4552<col width="50.00%">

4553<col width="50.00%">

4554</colgroup>

4555<THead>

4556<tr>

4557<th>

4558Lineage </th>

4559<th>

4560Criteria</th>

4561</tr>

4562</THead>

4563<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

4564<tr>

4565<td colspan="2">

4566<span class="sup">

4567a</span>

4568Adapted from Arber et al.[<a href="#cit/section_3.97">

456997</a>

4570]</td>

4571</tr>

4572<tr>

4573<td colspan="2">

4574<span class="sup">

4575b</span>

4576Strong defined as equal to or brighter than the normal B or T cells in the sample.</td>

4577</tr>

4578</TFoot>

4579<tbody>

4580<tr>

4581<td>

4582<strong>

4583Myeloid lineage</strong>

4584</td>

4585<td>

4586Myeloperoxidase (flow cytometry, immunohistochemistry, or cytochemistry); <strong>

4587or</strong>

4588 monocytic differentiation (at least two of the following: nonspecific esterase cytochemistry, CD11c, CD14, CD64, lysozyme)</td>

4589</tr>

4590<tr>

4591<td>

4592<strong>

4593T lineage</strong>

4594</td>

4595<td>

4596Strong<span class="sup">

4597b</span>

4598 cytoplasmic CD3 (with antibodies to CD3 epsilon chain); <strong>

4599or</strong>

4600 surface CD3</td>

4601</tr>

4602<tr>

4603<td>

4604<strong>

4605B lineage</strong>

4606</td>

4607<td>

4608Strong<span class="sup">

4609b</span>

4610 CD19 with at least one of the following strongly expressed: CD79a, cytoplasmic CD22, or CD10; <strong>

4611or</strong>

4612 weak CD19 with at least two of the following strongly expressed: CD79a, cytoplasmic CD22, or CD10</td>

4613</tr>

4614</tbody>

4615</table>

4616<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1926" tabindex="-1">

4617

4618 The classification system for MPAL includes two entities that are defined by their primary molecular alteration: MPAL with <em class="gene-name">

4619BCR</em>

4620::<em class="gene-name">

4621ABL1</em>

4622 translocation and MPAL with <em class="gene-name">

4623KMT2A</em>

4624 rearrangement. The genomic alterations associated with the MPAL, B/myeloid, NOS (B/M MPAL) and MPAL, T/myeloid, NOS (T/M MPAL) entities are distinctive, as described below:</p>

4625<div class="pdq-content-list">

4626<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1927">

4627<li>

4628<strong>

4629B/M MPAL.</strong>

4630<div class="pdq-content-list">

4631<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1928">

4632<li>

4633Among 115 MPAL cases for which genomic characterization was performed, 35 (30%) were B/M MPAL. There were an additional 16 MPAL cases (14%) with <em class="gene-name">

4634KMT2A</em>

4635 rearrangements, 15 of whom showed a B/myeloid immunophenotype. </li>

4636<li>

4637Approximately one-half of B/M MPAL cases had rearrangements of <em class="gene-name">

4638ZNF384</em>

4639 with recurrent fusion partners, including <em class="gene-name">

4640TCF3</em>

4641 and <em class="gene-name">

4642EP300</em>

4643. These cases had gene expression profiles indistinguishable from B-ALL cases with <em class="gene-name">

4644ZNF384</em>

4645 rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

464693</a>

4647]</li>

4648<li>

4649Approximately two-thirds of B/M MPAL cases had RAS pathway alterations, with <em class="gene-name">

4650NRAS</em>

4651 and <em class="gene-name">

4652PTPN11</em>

4653 being the most commonly altered genes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

465493</a>

4655]</li>

4656<li>

4657Genes encoding epigenetic regulators (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

4658MLLT3</em>

4659, <em class="gene-name">

4660KDM6A</em>

4661, <em class="gene-name">

4662EP300</em>

4663, and <em class="gene-name">

4664CREBBP</em>

4665) are mutated in approximately two-thirds of B/M MPAL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

466693</a>

4667]</li>

4668</ul>

4669</div>

4670</li>

4671<li>

4672<strong>

4673T/M MPAL.</strong>

4674<div class="pdq-content-list">

4675<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1929">

4676<li>

4677Among 115 MPAL cases for which genomic characterization was performed, 49 (43%) were T/M MPAL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

467893</a>

4679] The genomic features of the T/M MPAL cases shared commonalities with those of early T-cell precursor (ETP) ALL, suggesting that T/M MPAL and ETP ALL are similar entities along the spectrum of immature leukemias.</li>

4680<li>

4681Compared with T-ALL, T/M MPAL showed a lower rate of alterations in the core T-ALL transcription factors (<em class="gene-name">

4682TAL1</em>

4683, <em class="gene-name">

4684TAL2</em>

4685, <em class="gene-name">

4686TLX1</em>

4687, <em class="gene-name">

4688TLX3</em>

4689, <em class="gene-name">

4690LMO1</em>

4691, <em class="gene-name">

4692LMO2</em>

4693, <em class="gene-name">

4694NKX2-1</em>

4695, <em class="gene-name">

4696HOXA10</em>

4697, and <em class="gene-name">

4698LYL1</em>

4699) (63% vs. 16%, respectively).[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

470093</a>

4701] A similar lower rate was also observed for ETP ALL.</li>

4702<li>

4703<em class="gene-name">

4704CDKN2A</em>

4705, <em class="gene-name">

4706CDKN2B</em>

4707, and <em class="gene-name">

4708NOTCH1</em>

4709 mutations, which are present in approximately two-thirds of T-ALL cases, were much less common in T/M MPAL cases. By contrast, <em class="gene-name">

4710WT1</em>

4711 mutations occurred in approximately 40% of T/M MPAL, but in less than 10% of T-ALL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

471293</a>

4713]</li>

4714<li>

4715RAS and JAK-STAT pathway mutations were common in the T/M MPAL and ETP ALL cases, while the PI3K signaling pathway is more commonly altered in T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

471693</a>

4717] For T/M MPAL, the most commonly mutated signaling pathway gene was <em class="gene-name">

4718FLT3</em>

4719 (43% of cases). <em class="gene-name">

4720FLT3</em>

4721 mutations tended to be mutually exclusive with RAS pathway mutations. </li>

4722<li>

4723Genes encoding epigenetic regulators (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

4724EZH2</em>

4725 and <em class="gene-name">

4726PHF6</em>

4727) were mutated in approximately two-thirds of T/M MPAL cases.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

472893</a>

4729]</li>

4730</ul>

4731</div>

4732</li>

4733</ul>

4734</div>

4735</section>

4736<section id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1845">

4737<h3 id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1845_toc">

4738Gene polymorphisms in drug metabolic pathways</h3>

4739<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1846" tabindex="-1">

4740A number of polymorphisms of genes involved in the metabolism of chemotherapeutic agents have been reported to have prognostic significance in childhood ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_3.175">

4741175</a>

4742-<a href="#cit/section_3.177">

4743177</a>

4744]</p>

4745<div class="pdq-content-list">

4746<ul id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1941">

4747<li>

4748<strong>

4749<em class="gene-name">

4750TPMT</em>

4751.</strong>

4752<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1942" tabindex="-1">

4753Patients with mutant phenotypes of <em class="gene-name">

4754TPMT</em>

4755 (a gene involved in the metabolism of thiopurines such as mercaptopurine) appear to have more favorable outcomes,[<a href="#cit/section_3.178">

4756178</a>

4757] although such patients may also be at higher risk of developing significant treatment-related toxicities, including myelosuppression, infection, and second malignancies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.179">

4758179</a>

4759,<a href="#cit/section_3.180">

4760180</a>

4761] Patients with homozygosity for <em class="gene-name">

4762TPMT</em>

4763 variants associated with low enzymatic activity tolerate only very low doses of mercaptopurine (approximately 10% of the standard dose) and are treated with reduced doses of mercaptopurine to avoid excessive toxicity. Patients who are heterozygous for this mutant enzyme gene generally tolerate mercaptopurine without serious toxicity, but they do require more frequent dose reductions for hematologic toxicity than do patients who are homozygous for the normal allele.[<a href="#cit/section_3.181">

4764181</a>

4765,<a href="#cit/section_3.182">

4766182</a>

4767]</p>

4768</li>

4769<li>

4770<strong>

4771<em class="gene-name">

4772NUDT15</em>

4773.</strong>

4774<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1943" tabindex="-1">

4775Germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

4776NUDT15</em>

4777 that reduce or abolish activity of this enzyme also lead to diminished tolerance to thiopurines.[<a href="#cit/section_3.181">

4778181</a>

4779,<a href="#cit/section_3.183">

4780183</a>

4781] The <em class="gene-name">

4782NUDT15</em>

4783 variants are most common in East Asian and Hispanic patients, and they are rare in European and African patients. Patients homozygous for the risk variants tolerate only very low doses of mercaptopurine, while patients heterozygous for the risk alleles tolerate lower doses than do patients homozygous for the wild-type allele (approximately 25% dose reduction on average), but there is broad overlap in tolerated doses between the two groups.[<a href="#cit/section_3.181">

4784181</a>

4785,<a href="#cit/section_3.184">

4786184</a>

4787]</p>

4788</li>

4789<li>

4790<strong>

4791CEP72.</strong>

4792<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1944" tabindex="-1">

4793Gene polymorphisms may also affect the expression of proteins that play central roles in the cellular effects of anticancer drugs. As an example, patients who are homozygous for a polymorphism in the promoter region of CEP72 (a centrosomal protein involved in microtubule formation) are at increased risk of vincristine neurotoxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_3.185">

4794185</a>

4795]</p>

4796</li>

4797<li>

4798<strong>

4799Single nucleotide polymorphisms.</strong>

4800<p id="_sm_CDR0000779360_1945" tabindex="-1">

4801Genome-wide polymorphism analysis has identified specific single nucleotide polymorphisms associated with high end-induction MRD and risk of relapse. Polymorphisms

4802of interleukin-15, as well as genes associated with the metabolism of etoposide and methotrexate, were significantly associated with treatment response in two large cohorts of ALL patients treated on SJCRH and COG protocols.[<a href="#cit/section_3.186">

4803186</a>

4804] Polymorphic variants involving the reduced folate carrier and methotrexate metabolism have been linked to toxicity and outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.187">

4805187</a>

4806,<a href="#cit/section_3.188">

4807188</a>

4808] While these associations suggest that individual variations in drug metabolism can affect outcome, few studies have

4809attempted to adjust for these variations. It is unknown whether individualized dose modification on the basis of these findings will improve outcomes.</p>

4810</li>

4811</ul>

4812</div>

4813</section>

4855[PUBMED Abstract]</a>
