JAMA 313 (8): 815-23, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25710658&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25710658&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5551[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5552</li>

5553<li id="section_3.186">

5554Yang JJ, Cheng C, Yang W, et al.: Genome-wide interrogation of germline genetic variation associated with treatment response in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia. JAMA 301 (4): 393-403, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19176441&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19176441&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5555[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5556</li>

5557<li id="section_3.187">

5558Gregers J, Christensen IJ, Dalhoff K, et al.: The association of reduced folate carrier 80G&gt;A polymorphism to outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia interacts with chromosome 21 copy number. Blood 115 (23): 4671-7, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20335220&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20335220&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5559[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5560</li>

5561<li id="section_3.188">

5562Radtke S, Zolk O, Renner B, et al.: Germline genetic variations in methotrexate candidate genes are associated with pharmacokinetics, toxicity, and outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Blood 121 (26): 5145-53, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23652803&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23652803&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5563[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5564</li>

5565</ol>

5566</div>

5567

5568 </section>

5569

5570

5571

5572 <section id="_22">

5573

5574 <h2>

5575Risk-Based Treatment Assignment</h2>

5576

5577 <div id="_section_22" class="pdq-sections">

5578<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

5579<h6>

5580In This Section</h6>

5581<ul>

5582<li>

5583<a href="#_645_toc">

5584Introduction to Risk-Based Treatment</a>

5585</li>

5586<li>

5587<a href="#_580_toc">

5588Prognostic Factors Affecting Risk-Based Treatment<ul>

5589<li>

5590<a href="#_554_toc">

5591Patient and clinical disease characteristics </a>

5592</li>

5593<li>

5594<a href="#_494_toc">

5595Leukemic characteristics</a>

5596</li>

5597<li>

5598<a href="#_526_toc">

5599Response to initial treatment</a>

5600</li>

5601</ul>

5602</a>

5603</li>

5604<li>

5605<a href="#_537_toc">

5606Prognostic (Risk) Groups<ul>

5607<li>

5608<a href="#_605_toc">

5609Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) risk groups </a>

5610</li>

5611<li>

5612<a href="#_687_toc">

5613Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (BFM) risk groups </a>

5614</li>

5615<li>

5616<a href="#_543_toc">

5617Prognostic (risk) groups under clinical evaluation</a>

5618</li>

5619</ul>

5620</a>

5621</li>

5622<li>

5623<a href="#_TrialSearch_22_sid_4_toc">

5624Current Clinical Trials</a>

5625</li>

5626</ul>

5627</nav>

5628<section id="_645">

5629<h3 id="_645_toc">

5630Introduction to Risk-Based Treatment</h3>

5631<p id="_646" tabindex="-1">

5632Children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) are usually treated according to risk groups defined by both clinical and laboratory features. The intensity of treatment required for cure varies substantially among subsets of children with ALL. Risk-based treatment assignment is used in children with ALL so that patients with favorable clinical and biological features who are likely to have a very good outcome with modest therapy can be spared more intensive and toxic treatment, while a more aggressive, potentially more toxic therapeutic approach is reserved for patients with a lower probability of long-term survival.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

56331</a>

5634,<a href="#cit/section_4.2">

56352</a>

5636]</p>

5637<p id="_594" tabindex="-1">

5638Certain ALL study groups, such as the Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG), use a more- or less-intensive induction regimen based on a subset of pretreatment factors, while other groups give a similar induction regimen to all patients.</p>

5639<p id="_2251" tabindex="-1">

5640Factors used by the COG to determine the intensity of induction include the following:</p>

5641<div class="pdq-content-list">

5642<ul id="_2252">

5643<li>

5644Immunophenotype.</li>

5645<li>

5646 The presence or absence of extramedullary disease.</li>

5647<li>

5648 Steroid pretreatment.</li>

5649<li>

5650 The presence or absence of Down syndrome.</li>

5651<li>

5652The National Cancer Institute (NCI) risk group classification.</li>

5653</ul>

5654</div>

5655<p id="_2253" tabindex="-1">

5656The NCI risk group classification for B-ALL stratifies risk according to age and white blood cell (WBC) count, as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

56573</a>

5658] </p>

5659<div class="pdq-content-list">

5660<ul id="_764">

5661<li>

5662Standard risk: WBC count less than 50,000/&#956;L <strong>

5663and</strong>

5664 age 1 to younger than 10 years.</li>

5665<li>

5666High risk: WBC count 50,000/&#956;L or greater <strong>

5667and/or</strong>

5668 age 10 years or older.</li>

5669</ul>

5670</div>

5671<p id="_765" tabindex="-1">

5672All study groups modify the intensity of postinduction therapy on the basis of a variety of prognostic factors, including NCI risk group, immunophenotype, early response determinations, and cytogenetics and genomic alterations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

56734</a>

5674] Detection of the <em class="gene-name">

5675BCR</em>

5676::<em class="gene-name">

5677ABL1</em>

5678 fusion (i.e., <em class="gene-name">

5679BCR</em>

5680::<em class="gene-name">

5681ABL1</em>

5682-positive ALL) leads to immediate changes in induction therapy, including the addition of a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, such as imatinib or dasatinib.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

56835</a>

5684]</p>

5685<p id="_24" tabindex="-1">

5686Risk-based treatment assignment requires the availability of prognostic factors that reliably predict outcome. For children with ALL, a number of factors have demonstrated prognostic value, some of which are described below.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

56876</a>

5688] Factors affecting prognosis are grouped into the following three categories:

5689</p>

5690<div class="pdq-content-list">

5691<ul id="_726">

5692<li>

5693<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_554">

5694Patient and clinical disease characteristics.</a>

5695</li>

5696<li>

5697<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_494">

5698Leukemic characteristics.</a>

5699</li>

5700<li>

5701<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_526">

5702 Response to initial treatment.</a>

5703</li>

5704</ul>

5705</div>

5706<p id="_26" tabindex="-1">

5707As in any discussion of prognostic factors, the relative order of significance and the interrelationship of the variables are often treatment dependent and require multivariate analysis to determine which factors operate independently as prognostic variables. Because prognostic factors are treatment dependent, improvements in therapy may diminish or abrogate the significance of any of these prognostic factors.</p>

5708<p id="_27" tabindex="-1">

5709A subset of the prognostic and clinical factors discussed below is used for the initial stratification of children with ALL for treatment assignment. For brief descriptions of the prognostic groupings currently applied in ongoing clinical trials in the United States, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_543">

5710Prognostic (risk) groups under clinical evaluation</a>

5711 section.</p>

5712<p id="_582" tabindex="-1">

5713For information about important prognostic factors at relapse, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1206">

5714Prognostic Factors After First Relapse of Childhood ALL</a>

5715 section.</p>

5716</section>

5717<section id="_580">

5718<h3 id="_580_toc">

5719Prognostic Factors Affecting Risk-Based Treatment</h3>

5720<section id="_554">

5721<h4 id="_554_toc">

5722Patient and clinical disease characteristics </h4>

5723<p id="_647" tabindex="-1">

5724Patient and clinical disease characteristics affecting prognosis include the following: </p>

5725<div class="pdq-content-list">

5726<ol id="_648">

5727<li>

5728<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1304">

5729Age at diagnosis</a>

5730.</li>

5731<li>

5732<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1306">

5733WBC count at diagnosis</a>

5734.</li>

5735<li>

5736<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1307">

5737Central nervous system (CNS) involvement at diagnosis</a>

5738.</li>

5739<li>

5740<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1308">

5741Testicular involvement at diagnosis</a>

5742.</li>

5743<li>

5744<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1309">

5745Down syndrome (trisomy 21)</a>

5746.</li>

5747<li>

5748<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1310">

5749Sex</a>

5750.</li>

5751<li>

5752<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1311">

5753Race and ethnicity</a>

5754.</li>

5755<li>

5756<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1738">

5757Weight at diagnosis and during treatment</a>

5758.</li>

5759</ol>

5760</div>

5761<section id="_1304">

5762<h5 id="_1304_toc">

5763Age at diagnosis</h5>

5764<p id="_700" tabindex="-1">

5765Age at diagnosis has strong prognostic significance in patients with B-ALL,

5766reflecting the different underlying biology of ALL in different age groups.[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

57677</a>

5768] Age at diagnosis is not prognostically relevant in T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

57698</a>

5770]</p>

5771<div class="pdq-content-list">

5772<ol id="_1305">

5773<li>

5774<strong>

5775Infants (younger than 1 year).</strong>

5776<p id="_701" tabindex="-1">

5777Infants with ALL have a particularly high risk of treatment failure. Treatment failure is most common in the following groups:</p>

5778<div class="pdq-content-list">

5779<ul id="_650">

5780<li>

5781Infants younger than 6 months (with an even poorer prognosis for those aged &#8804;90 days).[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

57829</a>

5783-<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

578413</a>

5785]</li>

5786<li>

5787Infants with extremely high presenting leukocyte counts (&gt;200,000&#8211;300,000 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

57889</span>

5789/L).[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

579010</a>

5791]</li>

5792<li>

5793Infants with a poor response to a prednisone prophase.[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

579410</a>

5795]</li>

5796<li>

5797Infants with a <em class="gene-name">

5798KMT2A</em>

5799 gene rearrangement.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

58009</a>

5801-<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

580212</a>

5803]</li>

5804</ul>

5805</div>

5806<p id="_712" tabindex="-1">

5807Up to 80% of infants with ALL have a translocation of 11q23 with numerous chromosome partners generating a <em class="gene-name">

5808KMT2A</em>

5809 gene rearrangement.[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

581010</a>

5811,<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

581212</a>

5813,<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

581414</a>

5815,<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

581615</a>

5817] The most common rearrangement is <em class="gene-name">

5818KMT2A</em>

5819::<em class="gene-name">

5820AFF1</em>

5821 (t(4;11)(q21;q23)), but <em class="gene-name">

5822KMT2A</em>

5823 rearrangements with many other translocation partners are observed. Infants with leukemia and <em class="gene-name">

5824KMT2A</em>

5825 rearrangements typically have very high WBC counts and an increased incidence of CNS involvement. Event-free survival (EFS) and overall survival (OS) rates are poor. The 5-year EFS and OS rates are 35% to 40% for infants with <em class="gene-name">

5826KMT2A</em>

5827-rearranged ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

582810</a>

5829-<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

583012</a>

5831]</p>

5832<p id="_1851" tabindex="-1">

5833The frequency of <em class="gene-name">

5834KMT2A</em>

5835 gene rearrangements is extremely high in infants younger than 6 months. From 6 months to 1 year, the incidence of <em class="gene-name">

5836KMT2A</em>

5837 rearrangements decreases but remains significantly higher than that observed in older children.[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

583810</a>

5839,<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

584016</a>

5841] Blasts from infants with <em class="gene-name">

5842KMT2A</em>

5843 rearrangements are often CD10 negative and express high levels of <em class="gene-name">

5844FLT3</em>

5845.[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

584610</a>

5847,<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

584811</a>

5849,<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

585015</a>

5851,<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

585217</a>

5853] Conversely, infants whose leukemic cells show a germline <em class="gene-name">

5854KMT2A</em>

5855 gene configuration frequently present with CD10-positive precursor-B immunophenotype. These infants have a significantly better outcome than do infants with ALL characterized by <em class="gene-name">

5856KMT2A</em>

5857 rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

585810</a>

5859,<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

586011</a>

5861,<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

586215</a>

5863,<a href="#cit/section_4.18">

586418</a>

5865] </p>

5866<p id="_2500" tabindex="-1">

5867Black infants with ALL are significantly less likely to have <em class="gene-name">

5868KMT2A</em>

5869 rearrangements than White infants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

587016</a>

5871]</p>

5872<p id="_2501" tabindex="-1">

5873A comparison of the landscape of somatic mutations in infants and older children with <em class="gene-name">

5874KMT2A</em>

5875-rearranged ALL revealed significant differences between the two groups. This result suggests distinctive age-related biological behaviors for <em class="gene-name">

5876KMT2A</em>

5877-rearranged ALL that may relate to the significantly poorer outcome for infants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

587819</a>

5879,<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

588020</a>

5881]</p>

5882<p id="_1887" tabindex="-1">

5883For more information about infants with

5884ALL, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1152">

5885Infants With ALL</a>

5886 section.</p>

5887</li>

5888<li>

5889<strong>

5890Young children (aged 1 to &lt;10 years).</strong>

5891<p id="_603" tabindex="-1">

5892Young children (aged 1 to &lt;10 years) with B-ALL have a better disease-free survival (DFS) rate than older children, adolescents, and infants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

58933</a>

5894,<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

58957</a>

5896,<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

589721</a>

5898-<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

589923</a>

5900] The improved prognosis in young children is at least partly explained by the more frequent occurrence of favorable cytogenetic features in the leukemic blasts, including hyperdiploidy with 51 to 65 chromosomes and/or favorable chromosome trisomies, or the <em class="gene-name">

5901ETV6</em>

5902::<em class="gene-name">

5903RUNX1</em>

5904 fusion (t(12;21)(p13;q22), previously known as the <em class="gene-name">

5905TEL</em>

5906::<em class="gene-name">

5907AML1</em>

5908 translocation).[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

59097</a>

5910,<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

591124</a>

5912,<a href="#cit/section_4.25">

591325</a>

5914]</p>

5915</li>

5916<li>

5917<strong>

5918Adolescents and young adults (aged &#8805;10 years).</strong>

5919<p id="_599" tabindex="-1">

5920In general, the outcome of patients with B-ALL aged 10 years and older is inferior to that of patients aged 1 to younger than 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.26">

592126</a>

5922] Patients aged 10 to 15 years fare better than those who are aged 16 to 21 years at diagnosis who were treated with pediatric regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

59238</a>

5924] However, the outcome for older adolescents has improved significantly over time.[<a href="#cit/section_4.27">

592527</a>

5926-<a href="#cit/section_4.29">

592729</a>

5928] Five-year survival

5929rates for adolescents aged 15 to 19 years increased from 36% (1975&#8211;1984) to 78% (2011&#8211;2017).[<a href="#cit/section_4.30">

593030</a>

5931-<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

593233</a>

5933]</p>

5934<p id="_1897" tabindex="-1">

5935Multiple retrospective studies have established that adolescents aged 16 to 21 years have a better outcome when treated on pediatric versus adult protocols.[<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

593634</a>

5937-<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

593836</a>

5939] For more information about adolescents with

5940ALL, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1141">

5941Postinduction Treatment for Specific ALL Subgroups</a>

5942 section.</p>

5943</li>

5944</ol>

5945</div>

5946</section>

5947<section id="_1306">

5948<h5 id="_1306_toc">

5949WBC count at diagnosis</h5>

5950<p id="_558" tabindex="-1">

5951A

5952WBC count of 50,000/&#181;L is generally used as an operational cut point between

5953better and poorer prognosis,[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

59543</a>

5955] although the relationship between WBC count and

5956prognosis is a continuous function rather than a step function. Patients with B-ALL and high WBC counts at diagnosis have an increased risk of treatment failure compared with patients with low initial WBC counts.[<a href="#cit/section_4.37">

595737</a>

5958]

5959

5960 </p>

5961<p id="_612" tabindex="-1">

5962 The median WBC count at diagnosis is much higher for T-ALL (&gt;50,000/&#181;L) than for B-ALL (&lt;10,000/&#181;L), and there is no consistent effect of WBC count at diagnosis on prognosis for T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.37">

596337</a>

5964-<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

596545</a>

5966]

5967 </p>

5968</section>

5969<section id="_1307">

5970<h5 id="_1307_toc">

5971CNS involvement at diagnosis</h5>

5972<p id="_559" tabindex="-1">

5973The presence or absence of CNS leukemia at diagnosis has prognostic significance in both patients with B-ALL and T-ALL. Patients who have a nontraumatic diagnostic lumbar puncture may be placed into one of three categories according to the number of WBC/&#181;L and the presence or absence of blasts on cytospin as follows: </p>

5974<div class="pdq-content-list">

5975<ul id="_560">

5976<li>

5977<strong>

5978CNS1: </strong>

5979 Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that is cytospin negative for blasts regardless of WBC count.</li>

5980<li>

5981<strong>

5982 CNS2: </strong>

5983 CSF with fewer than 5 WBC/&#181;L and cytospin positive for blasts.</li>

5984<li>

5985<strong>

5986CNS3 (CNS disease): </strong>

5987 CSF with 5 or more WBC/&#181;L and cytospin positive for blasts or clinical signs of CNS leukemia (i.e., facial nerve palsy, brain/eye involvement, or hypothalamic syndrome).</li>

5988</ul>

5989</div>

5990<p id="_561" tabindex="-1">

5991Children with ALL who present with CNS3 disease at diagnosis are at a higher risk of treatment failure (both within the CNS and systemically) than are patients who are classified as CNS1 or CNS2.[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

599246</a>

5993,<a href="#cit/section_4.47">

599447</a>

5995] Some studies have reported increased risk of CNS relapse and/or inferior EFS in CNS2 patients, compared with CNS1 patients,[<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

599648</a>

5997,<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

599849</a>

5999] while others have not.[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

600046</a>

6001,<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

600250</a>

6003-<a href="#cit/section_4.52">

600452</a>

6005]</p>

6006<p id="_1555" tabindex="-1">

6007A traumatic lumbar puncture (&#8805;10 erythrocytes/&#181;L) that includes blasts at diagnosis has also been associated with increased risk of CNS relapse and overall poorer outcome in some studies,[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

600846</a>

6009,<a href="#cit/section_4.51">

601051</a>

6011,<a href="#cit/section_4.53">

601253</a>

6013] but not others.[<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

601449</a>

6015,<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

601650</a>

6017,<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

601854</a>

6019] Patients with CNS2, CNS3, or traumatic lumbar puncture have a higher frequency of unfavorable prognostic characteristics than those with CNS1, including significantly higher WBC counts at diagnosis, older age at diagnosis, an increased frequency of the T-ALL phenotype, and <em class="gene-name">

6020KMT2A</em>

6021 gene rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

602246</a>

6023,<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

602450</a>

6025,<a href="#cit/section_4.51">

602651</a>

6027]</p>

6028<p id="_1572" tabindex="-1">

6029Most clinical trial groups have approached the treatment of CNS2 and traumatic lumbar puncture patients by using more intensive therapy, primarily additional doses of intrathecal therapy during induction.[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

603046</a>

6031,<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

603255</a>

6033,<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

603456</a>

6035]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

603650</a>

6037][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6038Level of evidence B4</a>

6039]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.57">

604057</a>

6041][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6042Level of evidence A1</a>

6043] </p>

6044<p id="_585" tabindex="-1">

6045To determine whether a patient with a traumatic lumbar puncture (with blasts) should be treated as CNS3, the COG uses an algorithm relating the WBC and red blood cell counts in the spinal fluid and the peripheral blood.[<a href="#cit/section_4.58">

604658</a>

6047]</p>

6048</section>

6049<section id="_1308">

6050<h5 id="_1308_toc">

6051Testicular involvement at diagnosis</h5>

6052<p id="_562" tabindex="-1">

6053Overt testicular involvement at the time of diagnosis occurs in approximately 2% of males,[<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

605459</a>

6055,<a href="#cit/section_4.60">

605660</a>

6057] with a higher frequency in patients with T-ALL than in patients with B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.60">

605860</a>

6059] </p>

6060<p id="_586" tabindex="-1">

6061In early ALL trials, testicular involvement at diagnosis was an adverse prognostic factor. With more aggressive initial therapy, however, it does not appear to have prognostic significance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

606259</a>

6063,<a href="#cit/section_4.60">

606460</a>

6065] For example, a European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer trial (EORTC-58881) reported no adverse prognostic significance for overt testicular involvement at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.60">

606660</a>

6067]</p>

6068<p id="_588" tabindex="-1">

6069The role of radiation therapy for testicular involvement is unclear. A study from St. Jude Children's Research Hospital (SJCRH) suggests that a good outcome can be achieved with aggressive conventional chemotherapy without radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

607059</a>

6071] The COG has also adopted this strategy for boys with testicular involvement that resolves completely by the end of induction therapy. The COG considers patients with testicular involvement to be high risk regardless of other presenting features, but most other large clinical trial groups in the United States and Europe do not consider testicular disease to be a high-risk feature.</p>

6072</section>

6073<section id="_1309">

6074<h5 id="_1309_toc">

6075Down syndrome (trisomy 21)</h5>

6076<p id="_590" tabindex="-1">

6077Outcomes in children with Down syndrome and ALL have often been reported as somewhat inferior to outcomes in children without Down syndrome,[<a href="#cit/section_4.61">

607861</a>

6079-<a href="#cit/section_4.65">

608065</a>

6081] although on some studies, patients with Down syndrome appeared to fare as well as those without Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.66">

608266</a>

6083,<a href="#cit/section_4.67">

608467</a>

6085] The lower EFS and OS of children with Down syndrome appear to be related to

6086increased frequency of treatment-related mortality, as well as higher rates of induction failure and relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_4.61">

608761</a>

6088-<a href="#cit/section_4.64">

608964</a>

6090,<a href="#cit/section_4.68">

609168</a>

6092,<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

609369</a>

6094] The inferior anti-leukemic outcome may be due, in part, to the decreased prevalence of favorable biological features such as <em class="gene-name">

6095ETV6</em>

6096::<em class="gene-name">

6097RUNX1</em>

6098 or hyperdiploidy (51&#8211;65 chromosomes) with trisomies of chromosomes 4 and 10 in Down syndrome ALL patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.68">

609968</a>

6100,<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

610169</a>

6102]</p>

6103<div class="pdq-content-list">

6104<ul id="_1911">

6105<li>

6106In a large retrospective study that included 653 patients with Down syndrome and ALL, patients with Down syndrome had a lower complete remission (CR) rate (97% vs. 99%, <em>

6107P</em>

6108 &lt; .001), higher cumulative incidence of relapse (26% vs. 15%, <em>

6109P</em>

6110 &lt; .001) and higher treatment-related mortality (7% vs. &lt; 1%, <em>

6111P</em>

6112 &lt; .001) compared with patients without Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

611369</a>

6114] Among the patients with Down syndrome, age younger than 6 years, WBC count of less than 10,000/&#181;L, and the presence of the <em class="gene-name">

6115ETV6</em>

6116::<em class="gene-name">

6117RUNX1</em>

6118 fusion (observed in 8% of patients) were independent predictors of favorable EFS.</li>

6119<li>

6120In a report from the COG, among patients with B-ALL who lacked <em class="gene-name">

6121KMT2A</em>

6122 rearrangements, <em class="gene-name">

6123BCR</em>

6124::<em class="gene-name">

6125ABL1</em>

6126, <em class="gene-name">

6127ETV6</em>

6128::<em class="gene-name">

6129RUNX1</em>

6130, and hyperdiploidy with trisomies of chromosomes 4 and 10, the EFS and OS rates were similar in children with and without Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.68">

613168</a>

6132]</li>

6133<li>

6134Certain genomic abnormalities, such as<em class="gene-name">

6135 IKZF1</em>

6136 deletions, <em class="gene-name">

6137CRLF2</em>

6138 aberrations, and <em class="gene-name">

6139JAK</em>

6140 mutations, are seen more frequently in ALL arising in children with Down syndrome than in those without Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.70">

614170</a>

6142-<a href="#cit/section_4.74">

614374</a>

6144] Studies of children with Down syndrome and ALL suggest that the presence of <em class="gene-name">

6145IKZF1</em>

6146 deletions (but not <em class="gene-name">

6147CRLF2</em>

6148 aberrations or <em class="gene-name">

6149JAK</em>

6150 mutations) is associated with an inferior prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

615169</a>

6152,<a href="#cit/section_4.74">

615374</a>

6154,<a href="#cit/section_4.75">

615575</a>

6156]</li>

6157</ul>

6158</div>

6159</section>

6160<section id="_1310">

6161<h5 id="_1310_toc">

6162Sex</h5>

6163<p id="_492" tabindex="-1">

6164 In some studies, the prognosis for girls with ALL is slightly better than it is for

6165boys with ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.76">

616676</a>

6167-<a href="#cit/section_4.78">

616878</a>

6169] One reason is the

6170occurrence of testicular relapses among boys, but boys also appear to be at

6171increased risk of bone marrow and CNS relapse for reasons that are not well

6172understood.[<a href="#cit/section_4.76">

617376</a>

6174-<a href="#cit/section_4.78">

617578</a>

6176] While some reports describe outcomes for boys as closely approaching those of girls,[<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

617723</a>

6178,<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

617955</a>

6180,<a href="#cit/section_4.79">

618179</a>

6182] larger clinical trial experiences and national data continue to show somewhat lower survival rates for boys.[<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

618322</a>

6184,<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

618533</a>

6186,<a href="#cit/section_4.80">

618780</a>

6188,<a href="#cit/section_4.81">

618981</a>

6190]</p>

6191</section>

6192<section id="_1311">

6193<h5 id="_1311_toc">

6194Race and ethnicity</h5>

6195<p id="_493" tabindex="-1">

6196Over the last several decades in the United States, survival rates in Black and Hispanic children with ALL have been somewhat lower than

6197the rates in White children with ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.82">

619882</a>

6199-<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

620085</a>

6201]</p>

6202<p id="_1898" tabindex="-1">

6203The following factors associated with race and ethnicity influence survival:</p>

6204<div class="pdq-content-list">

6205<ul id="_1899">

6206<li>

6207<strong>

6208ALL subtype.</strong>

6209 The reason for better outcomes

6210in White and Asian children than in Black and Hispanic children is at least partially explained by the different spectrum of ALL subtypes. For example, Black children have a higher relative incidence of T-ALL, lower rates of favorable genetic subtypes of B-ALL, and higher rates of the <em class="gene-name">

6211TFC3</em>

6212::<em class="gene-name">

6213PBX1</em>

6214 (t(1;19)) translocation. Hispanic and Latino children have a higher frequency of <em class="gene-name">

6215CRLF2</em>

6216 rearrangements and <em class="gene-name">

6217IKZF1</em>

6218 deletions.[<a href="#cit/section_4.86">

621986</a>

6220-<a href="#cit/section_4.88">

622188</a>

6222] </li>

6223<li>

6224<strong>

6225Treatment adherence.</strong>

6226 Differences in outcome may also be related to treatment adherence, as illustrated by a study of adherence to oral mercaptopurine (6-MP) in maintenance therapy. In the first report from the study, there was an increased risk of relapse in Hispanic children compared with non-Hispanic White children, depending on the level of adherence, even when adjusting for other known variables. However, even with adherence rates of 90% or more, Hispanic children continued to demonstrate increased rates of relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_4.89">

622789</a>

6228] In the second report from the study, adherence rates were shown to be significantly lower in Asian American and African American patients than in non-Hispanic White patients. A greater percentage of patients in these ethnic groups had adherence rates of less than 90%, which was associated with a 3.9-fold increased risk of relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_4.90">

622990</a>

6230]</li>

6231<li>

6232<strong>

6233Ancestry-related genomic variations.</strong>

6234 Ancestry-related genomic variations may also contribute to racial and ethnic disparities in both the incidence and outcome of ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.91">

623591</a>

6236] For example, the differential presence of specific host polymorphisms in different racial and ethnic groups may contribute to outcome disparities, as illustrated by the occurrence of single nucleotide polymorphisms in the <em class="gene-name">

6237ARID5B</em>

6238 gene that occur more frequently among Hispanic patients and are linked to both ALL susceptibility and to relapse hazard.[<a href="#cit/section_4.92">

623992</a>

6240] In a genome-wide association study (GWAS), the <em class="gene-name">

6241GATA3</em>

6242 variant, rs3824662, was associated with an increased risk of developing <em class="gene-name">

6243BCR</em>

6244::<em class="gene-name">

6245ABL1</em>

6246-like (Ph-like) ALL. Patients with this variant were at increased risk of high MRD at end-induction and at greater risk of relapse. The rs3824662 risk allele is associated with Native American genetic ancestry. The risk allele frequency was 52% in Guatemalan patients, 40% in U.S. Hispanic patients, and 14% in patients of European descent.[<a href="#cit/section_4.93">

624793</a>

6248]</li>

6249</ul>

6250</div>

6251</section>

6252<section id="_1738">

6253<h5 id="_1738_toc">

6254Weight at diagnosis and during treatment</h5>

6255<p id="_1753" tabindex="-1">

6256Studies of the impact of obesity on the outcome of ALL have had variable results. In most of these studies, obesity is defined as weight above the 95th percentile for age and height.</p>

6257<div class="pdq-content-list">

6258<ul id="_1900">

6259<li>

6260Three studies did not demonstrate an independent effect of obesity on EFS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.94">

626194</a>

6262][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6263Level of evidence B4</a>

6264]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.95">

626595</a>

6266,<a href="#cit/section_4.96">

626796</a>

6268][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6269Level of evidence C2</a>

6270]</li>

6271<li>

6272Two studies showed obesity to be an independent prognostic factor only in patients older than 10 years or in patients with intermediate-risk or high-risk disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.97">

627397</a>

6274,<a href="#cit/section_4.98">

627598</a>

6276][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6277Level of evidence C2</a>

6278]</li>

6279<li>

6280The COG reported on the impact of obesity on outcome in 2,008 children, 14% of whom were obese, who were enrolled on a high-risk ALL trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002812">

6281CCG-1961 [NCT00002812]</a>

6282).[<a href="#cit/section_4.99">

628399</a>

6284][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6285Level of evidence B4</a>

6286] Obesity was found to be an independent variable for inferior outcome compared with nonobese patients (5-year EFS rates, 64% vs. 74%; <em>

6287P</em>

6288 = .002). However, obese patients at diagnosis who then lost weight during the premaintenance period of treatment had outcomes similar to patients with normal weight at diagnosis.</li>

6289<li>

6290In a retrospective study of patients treated at a single institution, obesity at diagnosis was linked to an increased risk of having MRD at the end of induction and an inferior EFS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.100">

6291100</a>

6292][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6293Level of evidence C2</a>

6294]</li>

6295<li>

6296In a different retrospective study of 373 patients treated at a single institution, body mass index (BMI) at diagnosis was not associated with MRD at days 19 and 46, cumulative incidence of relapse, or EFS. OS was lower in patients with a high BMI, primarily resulting from treatment-related mortality and inferior salvage after relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_4.101">

6297101</a>

6298][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6299Level of evidence C1</a>

6300]</li>

6301<li>

6302In one study, obesity at diagnosis was associated with increased toxicity and truncated administration of asparaginase, especially in older children and adolescents.[<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

6303102</a>

6304] </li>

6305</ul>

6306</div>

6307<p id="_1792" tabindex="-1">

6308In a study of 762 pediatric patients with ALL (aged 2&#8211;17 years), the Dutch Childhood Oncology Group found that those who were underweight at diagnosis (defined as BMI standard deviation score &lt; -1.8; 8% of the population) had an almost twofold higher risk of relapse compared with patients who were not underweight (after adjusting for risk group and age), although this did not result in a difference in EFS or OS. Patients with a decrease in BMI during the first 32 weeks of treatment had similar rates of relapse as other patients, but had significantly worse OS, primarily because of poorer salvage rates after relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_4.103">

6309103</a>

6310]</p>

6311</section>

6312</section>

6313<section id="_494">

6314<h4 id="_494_toc">

6315Leukemic characteristics</h4>

6316<p id="_654" tabindex="-1">

6317Leukemic cell characteristics affecting prognosis include the following:</p>

6318<div class="pdq-content-list">

6319<ol id="_655">

6320<li>

6321<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1313">

6322Immunophenotype</a>

6323.</li>

6324<li>

6325<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1314">

6326Cytogenetics/genomic alterations</a>

6327.</li>

6328</ol>

6329</div>

6330<section id="_1313">

6331<h5 id="_1313_toc">

6332Immunophenotype</h5>

6333<p id="_497" tabindex="-1">

6334The 2016 revision to the World Health Organization (WHO) classification of myeloid neoplasms and acute leukemia classifies ALL as either B-lymphoblastic leukemia or T-lymphoblastic leukemia, with further subdivisions based on molecular characteristics.[<a href="#cit/section_4.104">

6335104</a>

6336,<a href="#cit/section_4.105">

6337105</a>

6338] For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_552">

6339Diagnosis</a>

6340 section.</p>

6341<p id="_657" tabindex="-1">

6342Either B- or T-lymphoblastic leukemia can coexpress myeloid antigens. These cases need to be distinguished from leukemia of ambiguous lineage.</p>

6343<div class="pdq-content-list">

6344<ol id="_633">

6345<li>

6346<strong>

6347 B-ALL (WHO B-lymphoblastic leukemia).</strong>

6348<p id="_658" tabindex="-1">

6349Before 2008, the WHO classified B-lymphoblastic leukemia as precursor B-lymphoblastic leukemia, and this terminology is still frequently used in the literature of childhood ALL to distinguish it from mature B-cell ALL. Mature B-cell ALL is now termed Burkitt leukemia and requires different treatment than has been given for B-ALL (precursor B-cell ALL).</p>

6350 <p id="_659" tabindex="-1">

6351B-ALL, defined by the expression

6352of CD19, HLA-DR, cytoplasmic CD79a, and other B-cell&#8211;associated antigens, accounts for

635380% to 85% of childhood ALL. Approximately 90% of B-ALL cases express the CD10 surface antigen (formerly known as common ALL antigen). Absence of CD10 is often associated with <em class="gene-name">

6354KMT2A</em>

6355 rearrangements, particularly t(4;11)(q21;q23), and a poor outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

635610</a>

6357,<a href="#cit/section_4.106">

6358106</a>

6359] It is not clear whether CD10 negativity has any independent prognostic significance in the absence of a <em class="gene-name">

6360KMT2A</em>

6361 gene rearrangement.[<a href="#cit/section_4.107">

6362107</a>

6363]</p>

6364<p id="_500" tabindex="-1">

6365The major immunophenotypic subtypes of B-ALL are as follows:</p>

6366<div class="pdq-content-list">

6367<ul id="_660">

6368<li>

6369Common B-ALL (CD10 positive and no surface or cytoplasmic immunoglobulin [Ig]).<p id="_661" tabindex="-1">

6370Approximately three-quarters of patients with B-ALL have the common precursor B-cell immunophenotype and have the best prognosis. Patients with favorable cytogenetics almost always show a common precursor B-cell immunophenotype.</p>

6371</li>

6372<li>

6373Pro-B ALL (CD10 negative and no surface or cytoplasmic Ig).<p id="_662" tabindex="-1">

6374Approximately 5% of patients have the pro-B immunophenotype. Pro-B is the most common immunophenotype seen in infants and is often associated with <em class="gene-name">

6375KMT2A</em>

6376 gene rearrangements.</p>

6377</li>

6378<li>

6379Pre-B ALL (presence of

6380cytoplasmic Ig).<p id="_637" tabindex="-1">

6381The leukemic cells of patients with pre-B ALL contain cytoplasmic Ig, and 25% of patients with pre-B ALL have the t(1;19)(q21;p13) translocation with the <em class="gene-name">

6382TCF3</em>

6383::<em class="gene-name">

6384PBX1</em>

6385 fusion.[<a href="#cit/section_4.108">

6386108</a>

6387,<a href="#cit/section_4.109">

6388109</a>

6389]</p>

6390<p id="_505" tabindex="-1">

6391Approximately 3% of patients have transitional pre-B ALL with expression of surface Ig heavy chain in the absence of Ig light chain expression, <em class="gene-name">

6392MYC</em>

6393 gene involvement, and L3 morphology. Patients with this phenotype respond well to therapy used for B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.110">

6394110</a>

6395]</p>

6396</li>

6397<li>

6398Mature B-ALL (Burkitt lymphoma/leukemia).<p id="_2192" tabindex="-1">

6399Approximately 2% of patients

6400present with mature B-cell leukemia (surface Ig expression, generally with French-American-British criteria L3

6401morphology and an 8q24 translocation involving <em class="gene-name">

6402MYC</em>

6403), also called Burkitt leukemia. The treatment for mature B-cell ALL is based on therapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is completely different from the treatment for B-ALL. Rare cases of mature B-cell leukemia that lack surface Ig but

6404 have L3 morphology with <em class="gene-name">

6405MYC</em>

6406 gene translocations should also be treated as mature B-cell leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_4.110">

6407110</a>

6408] For more information about the

6409treatment of children with mature B-cell lymphoma/leukemia and Burkitt lymphoma/leukemia, see <a href="/types/lymphoma/hp/child-nhl-treatment-pdq">

6410Childhood Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment</a>

6411.</p>

6412<p id="_2193" tabindex="-1">

6413A small number of cases of <em class="gene-name">

6414IG</em>

6415::<em class="gene-name">

6416MYC</em>

6417-translocated leukemias with precursor B-cell immunophenotype (e.g., absence of CD20 expression and surface Ig expression) have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

6418111</a>

6419] These cases presented in both children and adults. Like Burkitt lymphoma/leukemia, they had a male predominance and most patients showed L3 morphology. The cases lacked mutations in genes recurrently altered in Burkitt lymphoma (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

6420ID3</em>

6421, <em class="gene-name">

6422CCND3</em>

6423, or <em class="gene-name">

6424MYC</em>

6425), whereas mutations in RAS genes (frequently altered in B-ALL) were common. The clinical significance and optimal therapy of <em class="gene-name">

6426IG</em>

6427::<em class="gene-name">

6428MYC</em>

6429&#8211;translocated leukemias with precursor B-cell phenotype and molecular characteristics requires further study. </p>

6430</li>

6431</ul>

6432</div>

6433 </li>

6434<li>

6435<strong>

6436T-ALL.</strong>

6437<p id="_663" tabindex="-1">

6438T-ALL is defined by expression of the

6439T-cell&#8211;associated antigens (cytoplasmic CD3, with CD7 plus CD2 or CD5) on leukemic blasts. T-ALL is frequently associated

6440with a constellation of clinical features, including the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

644121</a>

6442,<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

644339</a>

6444,<a href="#cit/section_4.79">

644579</a>

6446]</p>

6447<div class="pdq-content-list">

6448<ul id="_664">

6449<li>

6450Male sex.</li>

6451<li>

6452Older age.</li>

6453<li>

6454 Leukocytosis.</li>

6455<li>

6456Mediastinal mass.</li>

6457</ul>

6458</div>

6459<p id="_665" tabindex="-1">

6460While not true historically, with appropriately intensive

6461therapy, children with T-ALL now have an outcome approaching that of

6462children with B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

646321</a>

6464,<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

646539</a>

6466,<a href="#cit/section_4.42">

646742</a>

6468,<a href="#cit/section_4.43">

646943</a>

6470,<a href="#cit/section_4.79">

647179</a>

6472,<a href="#cit/section_4.112">

6473112</a>

6474]</p>

6475<p id="_507" tabindex="-1">

6476There are few commonly accepted prognostic factors for patients with T-ALL. Conflicting data exist regarding the prognostic significance of presenting leukocyte counts in T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.38">

647738</a>

6478-<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

647945</a>

6480,<a href="#cit/section_4.113">

6481113</a>

6482] The presence or absence of a mediastinal mass at diagnosis has no prognostic significance. In patients with a mediastinal mass, the rate of regression of the mass lacks prognostic significance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.114">

6483114</a>

6484]</p>

6485<p id="_1556" tabindex="-1">

6486<strong>

6487Early T-cell precursor (ETP) ALL.</strong>

6488</p>

6489<p id="_708" tabindex="-1">

6490ETP ALL, a distinct subset of childhood T-ALL, was initially defined by identifying T-ALL cases with gene expression profiles highly related to expression profiles for normal early T-cell precursors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

6491115</a>

6492] The subset of T-ALL cases identified by these analyses represented 13% of all cases, and they were characterized by a distinctive immunophenotype (CD1a and CD8 negativity, with weak expression of CD5 and coexpression of stem cell or myeloid markers). </p>

6493<p id="_1888" tabindex="-1">

6494Initial reports describing ETP ALL suggested that this subset of patients has a poorer prognosis than other patients with T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

6495115</a>

6496-<a href="#cit/section_4.117">

6497117</a>

6498] In addition, some studies have reported that these patients have a slower early response and higher frequency of induction failure.[<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

649945</a>

6500] Other studies have observed a more favorable outcome for patients with ETP ALL, including one study from the U.K. Medical Research Council that showed that the ETP ALL subgroup of patients had nonsignificantly inferior 5-year EFS rates compared with non-ETP patients (76% vs. 84%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.118">

6501118</a>

6502] Similarly, in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00408005">

6503AALL0434 [NCT00408005]</a>

6504 trial, ETP status did not have a statistically significant impact on DFS (hazard ratio, 0.99; 95% CI, 0.59&#8211;1.67; <em>

6505P</em>

6506 = .981) on multivariable analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.119">

6507119</a>

6508,<a href="#cit/section_4.120">

6509120</a>

6510] Further study in additional patient cohorts is needed to firmly establish the prognostic significance of early T-cell precursor ALL, but most ALL treatment groups do not change patient treatment on the basis of early T-cell precursor status.</p>

6511</li>

6512<li>

6513<strong>

6514 Myeloid antigen expression.</strong>

6515<p id="_710" tabindex="-1">

6516Up to one-third of childhood ALL patients have leukemia

6517cells that express myeloid-associated surface antigens. Myeloid-associated antigen expression

6518appears to be associated with specific ALL subgroups, notably those with <em class="gene-name">

6519KMT2A</em>

6520 rearrangements, <em class="gene-name">

6521ETV6</em>

6522::<em class="gene-name">

6523RUNX1</em>

6524, and <em class="gene-name">

6525BCR</em>

6526::<em class="gene-name">

6527ABL1</em>

6528.[<a href="#cit/section_4.121">

6529121</a>

6530-<a href="#cit/section_4.123">

6531123</a>

6532] Patients with B-ALL who have gene rearrangements involving <em class="gene-name">

6533ZNF384</em>

6534 also commonly show myeloid antigen expression.[<a href="#cit/section_4.124">

6535124</a>

6536,<a href="#cit/section_4.125">

6537125</a>

6538] No independent adverse prognostic significance exists for

6539myeloid-surface antigen expression.[<a href="#cit/section_4.121">

6540121</a>

6541,<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

6542122</a>

6543]</p>

6544 <p id="_1412" tabindex="-1">

6545 For information about leukemia of ambiguous lineage, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2083">

65462016 WHO Classification of Acute Leukemias of Ambiguous Lineage</a>

6547 section.</p>

6548</li>

6549</ol>

6550</div>

6551</section>

6552<section id="_1314">

6553<h5 id="_1314_toc">

6554Cytogenetics/genomic alterations</h5>

6555<p id="_2078" tabindex="-1">

6556For information about B-ALL and T-ALL cytogenetics/genomics

6557and gene polymorphisms in drug metabolic pathways, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2077">

6558Cytogenetics/Genomics of Childhood ALL</a>

6559 section.</p>

6560</section>

6561</section>

6562<section id="_526">

6563<h4 id="_526_toc">

6564Response to initial treatment</h4>

6565<p id="_527" tabindex="-1">

6566The rapidity with which leukemia cells are eliminated after initiation of

6567treatment and the level of residual disease at the end of induction are associated with long-term outcome. Because treatment response is influenced by the drug sensitivity of leukemic cells and host pharmacodynamics and pharmacogenomics,[<a href="#cit/section_4.126">

6568126</a>

6569] early response has strong prognostic significance. Various ways of evaluating the

6570leukemia cell response to treatment have been used, including the following:

6571</p>

6572<div class="pdq-content-list">

6573<ol id="_1416">

6574<li>

6575<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1315">

6576MRD determination in bone marrow at the end of induction and end of consolidation</a>

6577.</li>

6578<li>

6579<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1316">

6580Day 7 and day 14 bone marrow responses</a>

6581.</li>

6582<li>

6583<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1317">

6584Peripheral blood response to steroid prophase</a>

6585.</li>

6586<li>

6587<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1318">

6588Peripheral blood response to multiagent induction therapy</a>

6589.</li>

6590<li>

6591<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1557">

6592Peripheral blood MRD before end of induction (day 8, day 15)</a>

6593.</li>

6594<li>

6595<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1319">

6596Persistent leukemia at the end of induction (induction failure)</a>

6597.</li>

6598</ol>

6599</div>

6600<section id="_1315">

6601<h5 id="_1315_toc">

6602MRD determination in bone marrow at the end of induction and end of consolidation</h5>

6603<p id="_532" tabindex="-1">

6604Morphological assessment of residual leukemia in blood or bone marrow is often difficult and is relatively insensitive. Traditionally, a cutoff of 5% blasts in the bone marrow (detected by light microscopy) has been used to determine remission status. This corresponds to a level of 1 in 20 malignant cells. To detect lower levels of leukemic cells in either blood or marrow, specialized techniques are required. Such techniques include polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays, which determine unique Ig/T-cell receptor gene rearrangements and fusion transcripts produced by chromosome translocations, or flow cytometric assays, which detect leukemia-specific immunophenotypes. With these techniques, detection of as few as 1 leukemia cell in 100,000 normal cells is possible, and MRD at the level of 1 in 10,000 cells (1 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

6605-4</span>

6606 or 0.01%) can be detected routinely.[<a href="#cit/section_4.127">

6607127</a>

6608] Newer techniques involving high-throughput sequencing (HTS) of Ig/T-cell receptor gene rearrangements can increase sensitivity of MRD detection to 1 in 1 million cells (1 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

6609-6</span>

6610 or 0.0001%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

6611128</a>

6612]</p>

6613<p id="_533" tabindex="-1">

6614Multiple studies have demonstrated that end-induction MRD is an important, independent predictor of outcome in children and adolescents with B-lineage ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.129">

6615129</a>

6616-<a href="#cit/section_4.131">

6617131</a>

6618] MRD response discriminates outcome in subsets of patients defined by age, leukocyte count, and cytogenetic abnormalities.[<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

6619132</a>

6620] In general, patients with higher levels of end-induction MRD have a poorer prognosis than do those with lower or undetectable levels.[<a href="#cit/section_4.127">

6621127</a>

6622,<a href="#cit/section_4.129">

6623129</a>

6624-<a href="#cit/section_4.131">

6625131</a>

6626] However, the absolute risk of relapse associated with specific MRD levels varies by genetic subtype. For example, at any given level of detectable end-induction MRD, patients with favorable cytogenetics, such as <em class="gene-name">

6627ETV6</em>

6628::<em class="gene-name">

6629RUNX1</em>

6630 or high hyperdiploidy, have a lower absolute risk of subsequent relapse than do other patients, while patients with high-risk cytogenetics have a higher absolute risk of subsequent relapse than do other patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.133">

6631133</a>

6632] This observation may have important implications when MRD is used to develop risk classification plans.</p>

6633<p id="_1901" tabindex="-1">

6634End-induction MRD is used by almost all groups as a factor in determining the intensity of postinduction treatment. Patients found to have higher MRD levels (typically &gt;0.1% to 0.01%) are allocated to more intensive therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_4.127">

6635127</a>

6636,<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

6637130</a>

6638,<a href="#cit/section_4.134">

6639134</a>

6640]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.135">

6641135</a>

6642][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6643Level of evidence B4</a>

6644]</p>

6645<p id="_2059" tabindex="-1">

6646A study of 619 children with ALL compared the prognostic utility of MRD by flow cytometry with the more sensitive HTS assay. Using an end-induction MRD cut point level of 0.01%, HTS identified approximately 30% more cases as positive (i.e., &gt;0.01%). Patients identified as positive by HTS but negative by flow cytometry had an intermediate prognosis, compared with patients categorized as either positive or negative by both methods. Patients meeting the criteria for standard-risk ALL with undetectable MRD by HTS had an especially good prognosis (5-year EFS rate, 98.1%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

6647128</a>

6648]</p>

6649<p id="_1783" tabindex="-1">

6650MRD levels obtained 10 to 12 weeks after the start of treatment (end-consolidation) have also been shown to be prognostically important. Patients with high levels of MRD at this time point have a significantly inferior EFS compared with other patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.131">

6651131</a>

6652,<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

6653132</a>

6654,<a href="#cit/section_4.136">

6655136</a>

6656]</p>

6657<div class="pdq-content-list">

6658<ul id="_1784">

6659<li>

6660<strong>

6661B-ALL.</strong>

6662 For patients with B-ALL, evaluating MRD at two time points (end-induction and end-consolidation) can identify the following three prognostically distinct patient subsets:[<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

6663132</a>

6664]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6665<ol id="_1785">

6666<li>

6667Low or undetectable end-induction MRD: Best prognosis.</li>

6668<li>

6669High end-induction MRD but low or negative end-consolidation MRD: Intermediate prognosis.</li>

6670<li>

6671High end-consolidation MRD (week 10&#8211;12 of therapy): Worst prognosis. The prognostic impact of end-consolidation MRD is modulated by NCI risk criteria. NCI high-risk patients with high end-consolidation MRD have DFS rates lower than NCI standard-risk patients who have similar MRD levels at this time point.[<a href="#cit/section_4.136">

6672136</a>

6673]</li>

6674</ol>

6675</div>

6676</li>

6677<li>

6678<strong>

6679T-ALL.</strong>

6680 There are fewer studies documenting the prognostic significance of MRD in patients with T-ALL. The United Kingdom Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (UKALL) group reported that T-ALL patients with nondetectable end-induction MRD had excellent outcomes, while those with very high MRD levels (&gt;5%) at the end of induction had a poor prognosis. However, for all other T-ALL patients, an association between end-induction MRD level and relapse risk was not found.[<a href="#cit/section_4.133">

6681133</a>

6682] The Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (DFCI) ALL consortium also reported that T-ALL patients with very low end-induction MRD (&lt;10<span class="sup">

6683-4</span>

6684) had a very favorable outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

668545</a>

6686]<p id="_2254" tabindex="-1">

6687Another study also indicated that MRD at a later time point may be more prognostically significant in T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

6688137</a>

6689] In the Associazione Italiana di Ematologia e Oncologia Pediatrica (AIEOP) <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00430118">

6690ALL-BFM-2000 (NCT00430118)</a>

6691 trial, MRD status at day 78 (week 12) was the most important predictor for relapse in patients with T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

6692137</a>

6693] Patients with detectable MRD at end-induction who had negative MRD by day 78 generally had a favorable prognosis, similar to that of patients who achieved MRD-negativity at the earlier end-induction time point.[<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

6694137</a>

6695] The COG AALL1231 study confirmed the prognostic significance of end-consolidation marrow MRD for patients with T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.138">

6696138</a>

6697]</p>

6698</li>

6699</ul>

6700</div>

6701<p id="_534" tabindex="-1">

6702MRD measurements, in conjunction with other presenting features, have also been used to identify subsets of patients with an extremely low risk of relapse. The COG reported a very favorable prognosis (5-year EFS rate, 97% &#177; 1%) for patients with precursor B-cell phenotype, NCI standard risk age/leukocyte count, CNS1 status, and favorable cytogenetic abnormalities (either high hyperdiploidy with favorable trisomies or the <em class="gene-name">

6703ETV6</em>

6704::<em class="gene-name">

6705RUNX1</em>

6706 fusion) who had less than 0.01% MRD levels at both day 8 (from peripheral blood) and end-induction (from bone marrow).[<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

6707130</a>

6708] The excellent outcomes in patients with low MRD at the end of induction were sustained for more than 10 years from diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.139">

6709139</a>

6710]</p>

6711<p id="_1679" tabindex="-1">

6712Modifying therapy on the basis of MRD determination has been shown to improve outcome. </p>

6713<div class="pdq-content-list">

6714<ul id="_1925">

6715<li>

6716The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00222612">

6717UKALL2003 (NCT00222612)</a>

6718 study demonstrated that reduction of therapy (i.e., one rather than two courses of delayed intensification) did not adversely impact outcome in non-high&#8211;risk patients with favorable end-induction MRD.[<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

671922</a>

6720][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6721Level of evidence B1</a>

6722] In a randomized controlled trial, the UKALL2003 study also demonstrated improved EFS for standard-risk and intermediate-risk patients who received augmented therapy if end-induction MRD was greater than 0.01% (5-year EFS rates, 89.6% for augmented therapy vs. 82.8% for standard therapy).[<a href="#cit/section_4.140">

6723140</a>

6724]</li>

6725<li>

6726The Dutch ALL10 trial stratified patients into the following three risk groups on the basis of MRD after the first month of treatment and after the second cycle of chemotherapy:[<a href="#cit/section_4.141">

6727141</a>

6728][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6729Level of evidence B4</a>

6730]

6731<div class="pdq-content-list">

6732<ul id="_1926">

6733<li>

6734Standard risk (low MRD after the first month of treatment).</li>

6735<li>

6736Moderate risk (high MRD after the first month of treatment, low MRD after the second cycle of chemotherapy).</li>

6737<li>

6738High risk (high MRD after the second cycle of chemotherapy).</li>

6739</ul>

6740</div>

6741<p id="_1927" tabindex="-1">

6742Compared with previous trials conducted by the same group, therapy was less intensive for standard-risk patients but more intensive for moderate-risk and high-risk patients. The overall 5-year EFS rate (87%) and OS rate (92%) were superior to the previous Dutch studies.</p>

6743</li>

6744<li>

6745In the DFCI ALL Consortium 05-001 trial, B-ALL patients with high end-induction MRD (defined as &#8805;1 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

6746-3</span>

6747) were classified as very high risk regardless of other presenting characteristics. These patients received an intensified cytotoxic chemotherapy backbone. The 5-year DFS rate for these patients was 77%, significantly better than outcome for such patients on previous trials, when end-induction MRD was not used to stratify therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

67488</a>

6749]</li>

6750</ul>

6751</div>

6752</section>

6753<section id="_1316">

6754<h5 id="_1316_toc">

6755Day 7 and day 14 bone marrow responses</h5>

6756<p id="_134" tabindex="-1">

6757Patients who have a rapid reduction

6758in leukemia cells to less than 5% in their bone marrow within 7 or 14 days after the

6759initiation of multiagent chemotherapy have a more favorable prognosis than patients who have slower clearance of leukemia cells from the bone marrow.[<a href="#cit/section_4.142">

6760142</a>

6761] MRD assessments at the end of induction therapy have generally replaced day 7 and day 14 morphological assessments as response to therapy prognostic indicators because the latter lose their prognostic significance in multivariate analysis once MRD is included in the analyses.[<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

6762130</a>

6763,<a href="#cit/section_4.143">

6764143</a>

6765] </p>

6766</section>

6767<section id="_1317">

6768<h5 id="_1317_toc">

6769Peripheral blood response to steroid prophase</h5>

6770<p id="_529" tabindex="-1">

6771Patients with a reduction in

6772peripheral blast count to less than 1,000/&#181;L after a 7-day induction prophase

6773with prednisone and one dose of intrathecal methotrexate (a good prednisone

6774response) have a more favorable prognosis than patients whose peripheral blast

6775counts remain above 1,000/&#181;L (a poor prednisone response).[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

677621</a>

6777] Poor prednisone response is observed in fewer than 10% of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

677821</a>

6779,<a href="#cit/section_4.144">

6780144</a>

6781] Treatment

6782stratification for protocols of the Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (BFM) clinical trials group historically were partially based

6783on early response to the 7-day prednisone prophase (administered immediately before the initiation of multiagent remission induction). The current trial being conducted by that group still uses prednisone response to risk-stratify patients with T-ALL but not B-ALL.</p>

6784</section>

6785<section id="_1318">

6786<h5 id="_1318_toc">

6787Peripheral blood response to multiagent induction therapy</h5>

6788<p id="_530" tabindex="-1">

6789Patients with

6790persistent circulating leukemia cells at 7 to 10 days after the initiation of

6791multiagent chemotherapy are at increased risk of relapse, compared with patients

6792who have clearance of peripheral blasts within 1 week of therapy

6793initiation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.145">

6794145</a>

6795] Rate of clearance of peripheral blasts has been found to be

6796of prognostic significance in both T-cell and B-lineage ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.145">

6797145</a>

6798]</p>

6799</section>

6800<section id="_1557">

6801<h5 id="_1557_toc">

6802Peripheral blood MRD before end of induction (day 8, day 15)</h5>

6803<p id="_1563" tabindex="-1">

6804MRD measured in peripheral blood obtained 1 week after the initiation of multiagent induction chemotherapy has also been evaluated as an early response-to-therapy prognostic factor.</p>

6805<div class="pdq-content-list">

6806<ul id="_1902">

6807<li>

6808In a COG study involving nearly 2,000 children with ALL, the presence of MRD in the peripheral blood at day 8 was associated with adverse prognosis. Increasing MRD levels were associated with a progressively poorer outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

6809130</a>

6810]</li>

6811<li>

6812In multivariate analysis, end induction-therapy MRD was the most powerful prognostic factor, but day 8 peripheral blood MRD maintained its prognostic significance, as did NCI risk group and the presence of favorable trisomies. A smaller study assessed the prognostic significance of peripheral blood MRD at day 15 after 1 week of a steroid prophase and 1 week of multiagent induction therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.146">

6813146</a>

6814] This study also observed multivariate significance for peripheral blood MRD levels after 1 week of multiagent induction therapy. </li>

6815</ul>

6816</div>

6817<p id="_1903" tabindex="-1">

6818Both studies identified a group of patients who achieved low MRD levels after 1 week of multiagent induction therapy who had a low rate of subsequent treatment failure.</p>

6819</section>

6820<section id="_1319">

6821<h5 id="_1319_toc">

6822Persistent leukemia at the end of induction (induction failure)</h5>

6823<p id="_531" tabindex="-1">

6824The vast majority of children with ALL achieve complete morphological remission by the end of the first month of treatment. The presence of greater than 5% lymphoblasts by morphological assessment at the end of the induction phase is observed in 1% to 2% of children with ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

682522</a>

6826,<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

682723</a>

6828,<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

6829147</a>

6830-<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

6831149</a>

6832] </p>

6833<p id="_1904" tabindex="-1">

6834Features associated with a higher risk of induction failure include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

6835149</a>

6836-<a href="#cit/section_4.151">

6837151</a>

6838]</p>

6839<div class="pdq-content-list">

6840<ul id="_682">

6841<li>

6842T-cell phenotype.</li>

6843<li>

6844Higher WBC at diagnosis for patients with B-ALL.</li>

6845<li>

6846Older age.</li>

6847<li>

6848Unfavorable biology.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6849<ul id="_2255">

6850<li>

6851<em class="gene-name">

6852KMT2A</em>

6853 rearrangement.</li>

6854<li>

6855<em class="gene-name">

6856BCR</em>

6857::<em class="gene-name">

6858ABL1</em>

6859 rearrangement (before the use of tyrosine kinase inhibitors).</li>

6860<li>

6861Rearrangement of <em class="gene-name">

6862PDGFRB</em>

6863 (most commonly <em class="gene-name">

6864EBF1</em>

6865::<em class="gene-name">

6866PDGFRB</em>

6867), commonly associated with the <em class="gene-name">

6868BCR</em>

6869::<em class="gene-name">

6870ABL1</em>

6871like subtype.[<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

6872149</a>

6873,<a href="#cit/section_4.152">

6874152</a>

6875] These patients represent less than 1% of B-ALL cases in children but account for as much as 10% of induction failure cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

6876149</a>

6877] In one retrospective study, 43 of 49 patients (88%) with <em class="gene-name">

6878PDGFRB</em>

6879 fusions had end-induction MRD levels greater than 1%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.153">

6880153</a>

6881]</li>

6882</ul>

6883</div>

6884</li>

6885</ul>

6886</div>

6887<p id="_683" tabindex="-1">

6888In a large retrospective study, the OS rate of patients with induction failure was only 32%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

6889147</a>

6890] However, there was significant clinical and biological heterogeneity. A relatively favorable outcome was observed in patients with B-ALL between the ages of 1 and 5 years without adverse cytogenetics (<em class="gene-name">

6891KMT2A</em>

6892 rearrangement or <em class="gene-name">

6893BCR</em>

6894::<em class="gene-name">

6895ABL1</em>

6896). This group had a 10-year survival rate exceeding 50%, and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) in first remission was not associated with a survival advantage compared with chemotherapy alone for this subset. Patients with the poorest outcomes (10-year survival rate, &lt;20%) included those who were aged 14 to 18 years, or who had the <em class="gene-name">

6897BCR</em>

6898::<em class="gene-name">

6899ABL1</em>

6900 fusion or <em class="gene-name">

6901KMT2A</em>

6902 rearrangement. B-ALL patients younger than 6 years and T-ALL patients (regardless of age) appeared to have better outcomes if treated with allogeneic HSCT after achieving CR than those who received further treatment with chemotherapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

6903147</a>

6904] However, in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00408005">

6905AALL0434 (NCT00408005)</a>

6906 study, an advantage for HSCT in first CR for T-ALL patients with induction failure (defined as M3 marrow at end of induction) was not observed. In this study, T-ALL patients were assigned to receive nelarabine during several postinduction treatment phases and high-dose methotrexate during the first interim maintenance phase. The 5-year EFS rate of these patients was 53.1%, with no significant difference between those who proceeded to HSCT in first CR (n = 20) and those who did not (n = 23) (<em>

6907P</em>

6908 = .42).[<a href="#cit/section_4.119">

6909119</a>

6910]</p>

6911</section>

6912<section id="_2194">

6913<h5 id="_2194_toc">

6914Flow cytometry versus morphology</h5>

6915<p id="_2169" tabindex="-1">

6916MRD is now being integrated with morphological assessment into the response to induction therapy, on the basis of studies that showed that patients with MRD levels above 5%, despite morphological CR, had outcomes similar to patients with morphological induction failure.</p>

6917<div class="pdq-content-list">

6918<ol id="_2209">

6919<li>

6920In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00222612">

6921UKALL2003 (NCT00222612)</a>

6922 study, 59 of 3,113 patients (1.9%) had morphological induction failure.[<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

6923149</a>

6924]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6925<ul id="_2195">

6926<li>

6927The 5-year EFS rate was 51%, and the OS rate was 58%.</li>

6928<li>

69292.3% of patients had a morphological remission but had MRD of &#8805;5% measured by real-time quantitative IgH&#8211;T-cell receptor PCR. This group had a 5-year EFS rate of 47%, similar to those with morphological induction failure.</li>

6930<li>

6931The authors suggested that using both morphological and MRD criteria to define induction failure would more precisely identify patients with poor outcomes.</li>

6932</ul>

6933</div>

6934 </li>

6935<li>

6936A study of 9,350 patients enrolled on COG clinical trials between 2004 and 2014 compared characteristics of patients and their outcomes categorized by morphology (M1 vs. M2/M3) and MRD status assessed by flow cytometry (&lt;5% vs. &#8805;5%). Morphological remission (M1 status) was achieved for 98.6% of B-ALL patients and 93.8% of T-ALL patients at the end of induction therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.154">

6937154</a>

6938] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6939<ul id="_2171">

6940<li>

6941 Morphology and MRD were concordant in 97.4% of children. However, only 87.3% of T-ALL patients were M1 with MRD of &lt;5%, while 97.8% of B-ALL patients were in concordant remission.</li>

6942<li>

6943Approximately 20% of patients (40 of 202) with M2/M3 morphology had MRD of &lt;5%. B-ALL patients with M2/M3 morphology but MRD of &lt;5% had a 5-year OS rate of 72.7%, which was inferior to that of patients concordantly in remission (5-year OS rate, 93.8%) but superior to that of patients with M3 marrow (5-year OS rate, 43.4%).</li>

6944<li>

6945Among B-ALL and T-ALL patients with M1 marrow, 0.9% of B-ALL patients and 6.9% of T-ALL patients had MRD of &#8805;5%. Their outcome was compared with that of patients with M1 marrow and MRD of &lt;5% and are shown in <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2197">

6946Table 5</a>

6947 below.</li>

6948<li>

6949<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2197">

6950Table 5</a>

6951 shows that for children with B-ALL with M1 marrow and MRD of &#8805;5%, the 5-year EFS rate was significantly inferior to that of children concordantly in remission (59.1% vs. 87.1%) but was superior to that of children concordantly not in remission (M2 with MRD &#8805;5%: 5-year EFS rate, 39.1%). </li>

6952<li>

6953The impact on EFS for MRD of &#8805;5% for children with B-ALL in morphological remission was driven by NCI high-risk patients, as there was no significant difference in EFS between NCI standard-risk patients in morphological remission with or without MRD of &#8805;5%. </li>

6954<li>

6955Inferior EFS rates were also observed for patients with T-ALL with M1 marrow and MRD of &#8805;5% compared with those in concordant remission (87.6% vs. 80.3%). However, outcome for T-ALL patients not in remission (whether by morphology or MRD or both) was superior to that of comparable patients with B-ALL. </li>

6956<li>

6957Factors predictive of discordant MRD (&#8805;5%) for patients in morphological remission at end of induction included age 10 years and older, WBC count at presentation of 50,000/&#181;L or higher, neutral or unfavorable cytogenetics, and ETP ALL (for patients with T-ALL). </li>

6958</ul>

6959</div>

6960</li>

6961</ol>

6962</div>

6963<table id="_2197" class="table-default expandable-container">

6964<caption>

6966a</span>

6967</caption>

6968<colgroup>

6969<col width="5.52%">

6970<col width="24.40%">

6971<col width="16.56%">

6974<col width="13.19%">

6976</colgroup>

7036</td>

7133(n = 66) </td>

7153(n = 22 )</td>

7184<td>

718591.9% &#177; 1.3%

7186(n = 1,303) </td>

7191(n = 97)</td>
