719576.7% &#177; 12.3%

7196(n = 40)

7197</td>

7198</tr>

7199</tbody>

7200</table>

7201</section>

7202</section>

7203</section>

7204<section id="_537">

7205<h3 id="_537_toc">

7206Prognostic (Risk) Groups</h3>

7207<p id="_1582" tabindex="-1">

7208For decades, clinical trial groups studying childhood ALL have used risk classification schemes to assign patients to therapeutic regimens on the basis of their estimated risk of treatment failure. Initial risk classification systems used clinical factors such as age and presenting WBC count. Response-to-therapy measures were subsequently added, with some groups using early morphological bone marrow response (e.g., at day 8 or day 15) and with other groups using response of circulating leukemia cells to single-agent prednisone. Contemporary risk classification systems continue to use clinical factors such as age and presenting WBC count and incorporate cytogenetics and genomic lesions of leukemia cells at diagnosis (e.g., favorable and unfavorable translocations) and response to therapy based on detection of MRD at end of induction (and in some cases at later time points).[<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

7209137</a>

7210] The risk classification systems of the COG and the BFM groups are briefly described below.</p>

7211<section id="_605">

7212<h4 id="_605_toc">

7213Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) risk groups </h4>

7214<p id="_606" tabindex="-1">

7215In COG protocols, children with ALL are initially stratified into treatment groups (with varying degrees of risk of treatment failure) on the basis of a subset of prognostic factors, including the following:</p>

7216<div class="pdq-content-list">

7217<ul id="_624">

7218<li>

7219Age.</li>

7220<li>

7221WBC count at

7222diagnosis.</li>

7223<li>

7224Immunophenotype.</li>

7225<li>

7226Cytogenetics/genomic alterations.</li>

7227<li>

7228Presence of extramedullary disease.</li>

7229<li>

7230Down syndrome.</li>

7231<li>

7232Steroid pretreatment.</li>

7233</ul>

7234</div>

7235<p id="_625" tabindex="-1">

7236EFS rates exceed 85% in children meeting good-risk criteria (aged 1 to &lt;10 years, WBC count &lt;50,000/&#956;L, and precursor B-cell immunophenotype). In children meeting high-risk criteria, EFS rates are approximately 75%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

72374</a>

7238,<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

723955</a>

7240,<a href="#cit/section_4.144">

7241144</a>

7242,<a href="#cit/section_4.155">

7243155</a>

7244,<a href="#cit/section_4.156">

7245156</a>

7246] Additional factors, including cytogenetic abnormalities and measures of early response to therapy (e.g., MRD levels in peripheral blood on day 8 and in bone marrow samples at the end of induction), considered in conjunction with presenting age, WBC count, immunophenotype, the presence of extramedullary disease, and steroid pretreatment can identify patient groups for postinduction therapy with expected EFS

7247rates ranging from less than 40% to more than 95%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

72484</a>

7249,<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

7250130</a>

7251]</p>

7252<p id="_629" tabindex="-1">

7253 Patients who are at very high risk of treatment failure include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.157">

7254157</a>

7255-<a href="#cit/section_4.160">

7256160</a>

7257]</p>

7258<div class="pdq-content-list">

7259<ul id="_630">

7260<li>

7261Infants with <em class="gene-name">

7262KMT2A</em>

7263 rearrangements. </li>

7264<li>

7265Patients with hypodiploidy (&lt;44 chromosomes).</li>

7266<li>

7267Patients with initial induction failure.</li>

7268</ul>

7269</div>

7270</section>

7271<section id="_687">

7272<h4 id="_687_toc">

7273Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (BFM) risk groups </h4>

7274<p id="_698" tabindex="-1">

7275Since 2000, risk stratification on BFM protocols has been based on treatment response criteria, as well as biology. Treatment response is assessed primarily via MRD measurements at two time points, end-induction (time point 1, week 5) and end of the IB phase (similar to COG consolidation phase) at week 12 (time point 2). High MRD at both time points is defined as higher than 5 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

7276-4</span>

7277.</p>

7278<p id="_716" tabindex="-1">

7279The BFM defines 3 risk groups based on early response:[<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

7280132</a>

7281]</p>

7282<div class="pdq-content-list">

7283<ul id="_717">

7284<li>

7285<strong>

7286Standard risk:</strong>

7287 Patients who have negative MRD at both time points.</li>

7288<li>

7289<strong>

7290Intermediate risk:</strong>

7291 Patients who have high MRD at time point 1 and negative MRD at time point 2.</li>

7292<li>

7293<strong>

7294High risk:</strong>

7295 Patients with high MRD at time point 2. Patients with T-ALL with a poor response to the prednisone prophase are also considered high risk, regardless of subsequent MRD. </li>

7296</ul>

7297</div>

7298<p id="_691" tabindex="-1">

7299Biological factors used to stratify patients as high risk (regardless of MRD at either time point) include <em class="gene-name">

7300KMT2A::AFF1</em>

7301, <em class="gene-name">

7302TCF3::HLF</em>

7303, and hypodiploidy (&lt;45 chromosomes). Patients with <em class="gene-name">

7304IKZF1</em>

7305-plus status (<em class="gene-name">

7306IKZF1</em>

7307 deletions that co-occurred with deletions in <em class="gene-name">

7308CDKN2A</em>

7309, <em class="gene-name">

7310CDKN2B</em>

7311, <em class="gene-name">

7312PAX5</em>

7313, or <em class="gene-name">

7314PAR1</em>

7315 in the absence

7316of <em class="gene-name">

7317ERG</em>

7318 deletion) [<a href="#cit/section_4.161">

7319161</a>

7320] are considered high risk if they have high MRD at end-induction, regardless of end-consolidation MRD. Age, presenting leukocyte count, and CNS status at diagnosis do not factor into the current risk classification schema.</p>

7321</section>

7322<section id="_543">

7323<h4 id="_543_toc">

7324Prognostic (risk) groups under clinical evaluation</h4>

7325<div class="pdq-content-list">

7326<ol id="_2256">

7327<li>

7328COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03914625">

7329AALL1731 (NCT03914625)</a>

7330 standard-risk and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03959085">

7331AALL1732 (NCT03959085)</a>

7332 high-risk clinical trials: The COG classifies patients into six risk groups for patients with B-ALL (standard-risk favorable, standard-risk average, standard-risk high, high-risk favorable, high risk, and very high risk) on the basis of the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

7333<ul id="_692">

7334<li>

7335Age and presenting leukocyte count (using NCI risk-group criteria).[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

73363</a>

7337]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7338<ul id="_2179" class="list-dash">

7339<li>

7340NCI standard (low) risk: Includes children aged 1 year to &lt;10 years with WBC &lt;50,000/&#181;L at the time of diagnosis.</li>

7341<li>

7342NCI high risk: Includes children aged &#8805;10 years and/or children who have WBC &#8805;50,000/&#181;L at the time of diagnosis.</li>

7343</ul>

7344</div>

7345</li>

7346<li>

7347Extramedullary disease (presence or absence of CNS and/or testicular leukemia).<div class="pdq-content-list">

7348<ul id="_2180" class="list-dash">

7349<li>

7350CNS1: Absence of blasts on CSF cytospin preparation, regardless of the number of WBCs.</li>

7351<li>

7352CNS2: Presence of &lt;5 WBC/&#956;L in CSF and cytospin positive for blasts; or traumatic LP, &#8805;5 WBC/&#956;L, cytospin positive for blasts but negative by Steinherz/Bleyer algorithm.</li>

7353<li>

7354CNS3 is divided and defined as follows:<div class="pdq-content-list">

7355<ul id="_2181">

7356<li>

7357CNS3a: &lt;10 RBC/&#956;L; &#8805;5 WBC/&#956;L and cytospin positive for blasts.</li>

7358<li>

7359CNS3b: &#8805;10 RBC/&#956;L; &#8805;5 WBC/&#956;L and positive by Steinherz/Bleyer algorithm.</li>

7360<li>

7361CNS3c: Clinical signs of CNS leukemia (such as facial nerve palsy, brain/eye involvement or hypothalamic syndrome).</li>

7362</ul>

7363</div>

7364</li>

7365</ul>

7366</div>

7367</li>

7368<li>

7369Genomic alterations in leukemia cells.</li>

7370<li>

7371Day 8 peripheral blood MRD.</li>

7372<li>

7373Day 29 bone marrow morphological response and MRD.</li>

7374<li>

7375End of consolidation MRD.</li>

7376<li>

7377Steroid pretreatment.</li>

7378</ul>

7379</div>

7380<p id="_693" tabindex="-1">

7381Morphological assessment of early response in the bone marrow is no longer performed on days 8 and 15 of induction as part of risk stratification. Patients with T-cell phenotype are treated on separate trials and are not risk classified in this way.</p>

7382<p id="_545" tabindex="-1">

7383For patients with B-ALL, the definitions of favorable, unfavorable, and neutral cytogenetics are as follows:</p>

7384<div class="pdq-content-list">

7385<ul id="_546">

7386<li>

7387Favorable cytogenetic features include the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

7388<ul id="_2182" class="list-dash">

7389<li>

7390Hyperdiploidy with double trisomies of chromosomes 4 and 10 (double trisomy); or</li>

7391<li>

7392<em class="gene-name">

7393ETV6</em>

7394::<em class="gene-name">

7395RUNX1</em>

7396 fusion.</li>

7397</ul>

7398</div>

7399</li>

7400<li>

7401Unfavorable cytogenetic features include the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

7402<ul id="_2183" class="list-dash">

7403<li>

7404Hypodiploidy (&lt;44 chromosomes or DNA index &lt;0.81).</li>

7405<li>

7406<em class="gene-name">

7407KMT2A</em>

7408 rearrangements.</li>

7409<li>

7410t(17;19)(q21-q22;p13.3) or resultant <em class="gene-name">

7411TCF3</em>

7412::<em class="gene-name">

7413HLF</em>

7414 fusion transcript.</li>

7415<li>

7416Intrachromosomal amplification of chromosome 21 (iAMP21); and</li>

7417<li>

7418<em class="gene-name">

7419BCR</em>

7420::<em class="gene-name">

7421ABL1</em>

7422 (Ph+ or t(9;22)(q34;q11)). Patients with <em class="gene-name">

7423BCR</em>

7424::<em class="gene-name">

7425ABL1</em>

7426 ALL are treated on a separate clinical trial.</li>

7427</ul>

7428</div>

7429</li>

7430<li>

7431Neutral cytogenetics: Lacking favorable and unfavorable cytogenetic features.</li>

7432</ul>

7433</div>

7434<p id="_2184" tabindex="-1">

7435NCI standard-risk patients are divided into a highly favorable group (standard-risk favorable; 5-year DFS rate, &gt;95%), a group with favorable outcome (standard-risk average; 5-year DFS rate, 90%&#8211;95%), and a group with a 5-year DFS rate below 90% (standard-risk high). Patients classified as standard-risk high receive postinduction backbone chemotherapy as per high-risk B-ALL regimens with intensified consolidation, interim maintenance, and reinduction therapy. Criteria for these three groups are provided in <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2198">

7436Table 6</a>

7437, <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2199">

7438Table 7</a>

7439, and <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2200">

7440Table 8</a>

7441 below.</p>

7744Table 9</a>

7745. These patients have an EFS rate higher than 90% on past COG clinical trials for high-risk patients. </p>

7817<p id="_2186" tabindex="-1">

7819Table 10</a>

7820. NCI standard-risk patients are elevated to high-risk status based on steroid pretreatment and CNS and/or testicular involvement.</p>

8035&lt;0.01%</td>

8037</tbody>

8038</table>

8039<p id="_2187" tabindex="-1">

8040NCI high-risk patients with end-of-consolidation marrow MRD &#8805;0.01% are classified as very high risk and are eligible for a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell clinical trial in first remission (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03792633">

8041NCT03792633</a>

8042).</p>

8043<p id="_2188" tabindex="-1">

8044Patients with B-ALL and Down syndrome are classified into risk groups similar to other children, but Down syndrome patients classified as high risk receive a treatment regimen that is modified to reduce toxicity.</p>

8045</li>

8046<li>

8047<strong>

8048SJCRH Total 17 study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03117751">

8049NCT03117751</a>

8050)</strong>

8051 (Total Therapy XVII for Newly Diagnosed Patients With ALL and Lymphoma)<strong>

8052:</strong>

8053 The overarching objective of this study is to use novel precision medicine strategies based on inherited and leukemia-specific genomic features and targeted treatment approaches to improve the cure rate and quality of life of children with ALL and acute lymphoblastic lymphoma.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8054<p class="pdq-list-title">

8055Criteria for low risk (approximately 42% of patients).</p>

8056<ul id="_2173">

8057<li>

8058B-ALL with DNA index &#8805;1.16, <em class="gene-name">

8059ETV6</em>

8060::<em class="gene-name">

8061RUNX1</em>

8062 fusion, OR age 1 to 9.9 years and presenting WBC count &lt;50 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

80639</span>

8064/L.</li>

8065<li>

8066Patients must not have the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

8067<ul id="_2174" class="list-dash">

8068<li>

8069CNS3 status (&#8805;5 WBC/&#956;L of CSF with leukemic blasts or cranial nerve palsy).</li>

8070<li>

8071Overt testicular leukemia (evidenced by ultrasonography).</li>

8072<li>

8073Adverse genetic features: <em class="gene-name">

8074BCR</em>

8075::<em class="gene-name">

8076ABL1</em>

8077 fusion; <em class="gene-name">

8078TCF3</em>

8079::<em class="gene-name">

8080PBX1</em>

8081 fusion; rearranged <em class="gene-name">

8082KMT2A</em>

8083 (by FISH, PCR, and/or transcriptome or whole-genome sequencing); hypodiploidy (defined by &lt;0.95 DNA index, &lt;44 chromosomes, or genome-wide DNA copy-number alterations and gene expression); iAMP21; or <em class="gene-name">

8084MEF2D</em>

8085 fusion.</li>

8086<li>

8087Poor early response (&#8805;1% lymphoblasts on Day 15 of remission induction or &#8805;0.01% lymphoblasts on remission date [end of remission induction] by immunologic or molecular methods).</li>

8088</ul>

8089</div>

8090</li>

8091</ul>

8092</div>

8093<div class="pdq-content-list">

8094<p class="pdq-list-title">

8095Criteria for standard risk (approximately 48% of patients).</p>

8096<ul id="_2175">

8097<li>

8098Patients with T-ALL or B-ALL who do not meet the criteria for low-risk or high-risk ALL.</li>

8099</ul>

8100</div>

8101<div class="pdq-content-list">

8102<p class="pdq-list-title">

8103Criteria for high risk (approximately 10% of patients).</p>

8104<ul id="_2176">

8105<li>

8106MRD &#8805;1% at the end of remission induction.</li>

8107<li>

8108MRD &#8805;0.1% at the end of early intensification and inadequate decrease in MRD levels after one to two courses of consolidation treatment.</li>

8109<li>

8110Increasing MRD level at &#8805;0.01% after remission induction.</li>

8111<li>

8112Hypodiploid (defined by &lt;0.95 DNA index, &lt;44 chromosomes or genome-wide analysis) and MRD &#8805;0.01% at the end of remission induction.</li>

8113<li>

8114Re-emergence of leukemic lymphoblasts by MRD at &#8805;0.01% in patients previously MRD negative.</li>

8115<li>

8116Persistently detectable MRD at &#8805;0.01% after reinduction II (week 17 of continuation).</li>

8117</ul>

8118</div>

8119</li>

8120</ol>

8121</div>

8122</section>

8123</section>

8124<section id="_TrialSearch_22_sid_4">

8125<h3 id="_TrialSearch_22_sid_4_toc">

8126Current Clinical Trials</h3>

8127<p id="_TrialSearch_22_22" tabindex="-1">

8128Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8129advanced clinical trial search</a>

8130 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8131General information</a>

8132 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8133</section>

Leukemia 32 (6): 1370-1379, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29472723&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29472723&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8747[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8748</li>

8749<li id="section_4.155">

8750Moghrabi A, Levy DE, Asselin B, et al.: Results of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute ALL Consortium Protocol 95-01 for children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Blood 109 (3): 896-904, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17003366&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17003366&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8751[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8752</li>

8753<li id="section_4.156">

8754Veerman AJ, Kamps WA, van den Berg H, et al.: Dexamethasone-based therapy for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukaemia: results of the prospective Dutch Childhood Oncology Group (DCOG) protocol ALL-9 (1997-2004). Lancet Oncol 10 (10): 957-66, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19747876&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19747876&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8755[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8756</li>

8757<li id="section_4.157">

8758Kosaka Y, Koh K, Kinukawa N, et al.: Infant acute lymphoblastic leukemia with MLL gene rearrangements: outcome following intensive chemotherapy and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Blood 104 (12): 3527-34, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15297313&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15297313&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8759[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8760</li>

8761<li id="section_4.158">

8762Balduzzi A, Valsecchi MG, Uderzo C, et al.: Chemotherapy versus allogeneic transplantation for very-high-risk childhood acute lymphoblastic leukaemia in first complete remission: comparison by genetic randomisation in an international prospective study. Lancet 366 (9486): 635-42, 2005 Aug 20-26.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16112299&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16112299&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8763[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8764</li>

8765<li id="section_4.159">

8766Schrauder A, Reiter A, Gadner H, et al.: Superiority of allogeneic hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation compared with chemotherapy alone in high-risk childhood T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia: results from ALL-BFM 90 and 95. J Clin Oncol 24 (36): 5742-9, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17179108&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17179108&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8767[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8768</li>

8769<li id="section_4.160">

8770Ribera JM, Ortega JJ, Oriol A, et al.: Comparison of intensive chemotherapy, allogeneic, or autologous stem-cell transplantation as postremission treatment for children with very high risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia: PETHEMA ALL-93 Trial. J Clin Oncol 25 (1): 16-24, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17194902&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17194902&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8771[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8772</li>

8773<li id="section_4.161">

8774Stanulla M, Dagdan E, Zaliova M, et al.: IKZF1plus Defines a New Minimal Residual Disease-Dependent Very-Poor Prognostic Profile in Pediatric B-Cell Precursor Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia. J Clin Oncol 36 (12): 1240-1249, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29498923&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29498923&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8775[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8776</li>

8777</ol>

8778</div>

8779

8780 </section>

8781

8782

8783

8784 <section id="_565">

8785

8786 <h2>

8787Treatment Option Overview for Childhood ALL</h2>

8788

8789 <div id="_section_565" class="pdq-sections">

8790<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

8791<h6>

8792In This Section</h6>

8793<ul>

8794<li>

8795<a href="#_1320_toc">

8796Phases of Therapy</a>

8797</li>

8798<li>

8799<a href="#_1441_toc">

8800Sanctuary Sites<ul>

8801<li>

8802<a href="#_1442_toc">

8803Central nervous system (CNS)</a>

8804</li>

8805<li>

8806<a href="#_724_toc">

8807Testes</a>

8808</li>

8809</ul>

8810</a>

8811</li>

8812</ul>

8813</nav>

8814<section id="_1320">

8815<h3 id="_1320_toc">

8816Phases of Therapy</h3>

8817<p id="_568" tabindex="-1">

8818Treatment for children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is typically divided into the following phases:</p>

8819<div class="pdq-content-list">

8820<ol id="_642">

8821<li>

8822<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_732">

8823Remission induction chemotherapy</a>

8824 (at the time of diagnosis).</li>

8825<li>

8826<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_857">

8827Postinduction therapy</a>

8828 (after achieving complete remission).<div class="pdq-content-list">

8829<ul id="_1371">

8830<li>

8831<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1080">

8832Consolidation/intensification therapy</a>

8833.</li>

8834<li>

8835<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1092">

8836Maintenance therapy</a>

8837.</li>

8838</ul>

8839</div>

8840</li>

8841</ol>

8842</div>

8843</section>

8844<section id="_1441">

8845<h3 id="_1441_toc">

8846Sanctuary Sites</h3>

8847<p id="_1527" tabindex="-1">

8848Historically, certain extramedullary sites have been considered sanctuary sites (i.e., anatomic spaces that are poorly penetrated by many of the orally and intravenously administered chemotherapy agents typically used to treat ALL). The two most important sanctuary sites in childhood ALL are the central nervous system (CNS) and the testes. Successful treatment of ALL requires therapy that effectively addresses clinical or subclinical involvement of leukemia in these extramedullary sanctuary sites.</p>

8849<section id="_1442">

8850<h4 id="_1442_toc">

8851Central nervous system (CNS)</h4>

8852<p id="_1443" tabindex="-1">

8853At diagnosis, approximately 3% of patients have CNS3 disease (defined as cerebrospinal fluid specimen with &#8805;5 white blood cells/&#956;L with lymphoblasts and/or the presence of cranial nerve palsies). However, unless specific therapy is directed toward the CNS, most children will eventually develop overt CNS leukemia whether or not lymphoblasts were detected in the spinal fluid at initial diagnosis. CNS-directed treatments include intrathecal chemotherapy, CNS-directed systemic chemotherapy, and cranial radiation. Some or all of these treatments are included in current regimens for ALL. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_576">

8854CNS-Directed Therapy for Childhood ALL</a>

8855 section.</p>

8856</section>

8857<section id="_724">

8858<h4 id="_724_toc">

8859Testes</h4>

8860<p id="_725" tabindex="-1">

8861Overt testicular involvement at the time of diagnosis occurs in approximately 2% of males. In early ALL trials, testicular involvement at diagnosis was an adverse prognostic factor. With more aggressive initial therapy, however, the prognostic significance of initial testicular involvement is unclear.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

88621</a>

8863,<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

88642</a>

8865] The role of radiation therapy for testicular involvement is also unclear. A study from St. Jude Children's Research Hospital suggests that a good outcome can be achieved with aggressive conventional chemotherapy without radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

88661</a>

8867] The Children's Oncology Group has also adopted this strategy for boys with testicular involvement that resolves completely during induction chemotherapy.</p>

8868</section>

8869</section>

8870<h6 do-not-show="toc">

8871References</h6>

8872<ol>

8873<li id="section_5.1">

8874Hijiya N, Liu W, Sandlund JT, et al.: Overt testicular disease at diagnosis of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia: lack of therapeutic role of local irradiation. Leukemia 19 (8): 1399-403, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15973454&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15973454&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8875[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8876</li>

8877<li id="section_5.2">

8878Sirvent N, Suciu S, Bertrand Y, et al.: Overt testicular disease (OTD) at diagnosis is not associated with a poor prognosis in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia: results of the EORTC CLG Study 58881. Pediatr Blood Cancer 49 (3): 344-8, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16358303&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16358303&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8879[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8880</li>

8881</ol>

8882</div>

8883

8884 </section>

8885

8886

8887

8888 <section id="_1905">

8889

8890 <h2>

8891Special Considerations for the Treatment of Children With Cancer</h2>

8892

8893 <div id="_section_1905" class="pdq-sections">

8894<p id="_1906" tabindex="-1">

8895Because treatment of children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) entails complicated risk assignment and therapies and the need for intensive supportive care (e.g., transfusions; management of infectious complications; and emotional, financial, and developmental support), evaluation and treatment are best coordinated by a multidisciplinary team in cancer centers or hospitals with all of the necessary pediatric supportive care facilities.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

88961</a>

8897] A multidisciplinary team approach incorporates the skills of the following health care professionals and others to ensure that children receive treatment, supportive care, and rehabilitation that will achieve optimal survival and quality of life:</p>

8898<div class="pdq-content-list">

8899<ul id="_1907">

8900<li>

8901Primary care physicians.</li>

8902<li>

8903Pediatric medical oncologists/hematologists.</li>

8904<li>

8905Pediatric surgical subspecialists.</li>

8906<li>

8907Radiation oncologists. </li>

8908<li>

8909Pediatric intensivists.</li>

8910<li>

8911Rehabilitation specialists.</li>

8912<li>

8913Pediatric nurse specialists.</li>

8914<li>

8915Social workers.</li>

8916<li>

8917Child-life professionals.</li>

8918<li>

8919Psychologists.</li>

8920</ul>

8921</div>

8922<p id="_1908" tabindex="-1">

8923The American Academy of Pediatrics has outlined guidelines for cancer centers and their role in the treatment of pediatric patients with cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

89241</a>

8925] Treatment of childhood ALL typically involves chemotherapy given for 2 to 3 years. Because myelosuppression and generalized immunosuppression are anticipated consequences of leukemia and chemotherapy treatment, adequate facilities must be immediately available both for hematological support and for the treatment of infections and other complications throughout all phases of therapy. Approximately 1% to 3% of patients die during the remission induction phase, and another 1% to 3% die after having achieved complete remission from treatment-related complications.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

89262</a>

8927-<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

89286</a>

8929] It is important that the clinical centers and the specialists directing the patient&#8217;s care maintain contact with the referring physician in the community. Strong lines of communication optimize any urgent or interim care required when the child is at home.</p>

8930<p id="_1909" tabindex="-1">

8931Clinical trials are generally available for children with ALL, with specific protocols designed for children at standard (low) risk of treatment failure and for children at higher risk of treatment failure. Clinical trials for children with ALL are generally designed to compare standard therapy for a particular risk group with a potentially better treatment approach that may improve survival and/or diminish toxicities associated with the standard treatment regimen. Many of the therapeutic innovations that produced increased survival rates in children with ALL were established through clinical trials, and it is appropriate for children and adolescents with ALL to be offered participation in a clinical trial.</p>

8932<p id="_1910" tabindex="-1">

8933Risk-based treatment assignment is an important therapeutic strategy for

8934children with ALL. This approach allows

8935children who historically have a very good outcome to be treated with less intensive therapy and to be

8936spared more toxic treatments, while allowing children with a

8937historically lower probability of long-term survival to receive more intensive

8938therapy that may increase their chance of cure. For more information about a number of

8939clinical and laboratory features that have demonstrated prognostic value, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_22">

8940Risk-Based Treatment Assignment</a>

8941 section. </p>

8942<h6 do-not-show="toc">

8943References</h6>

8944<ol>

8945<li id="section_6.1">

8946American Academy of Pediatrics: Standards for pediatric cancer centers. Pediatrics 134 (2): 410-4, 2014. <a href="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410" title="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410">

8947Also available online</a>

8948. Last accessed May 19, 2023.</li>

8949<li id="section_6.2">

8950Rubnitz JE, Lensing S, Zhou Y, et al.: Death during induction therapy and first remission of acute leukemia in childhood: the St. Jude experience. Cancer 101 (7): 1677-84, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15378506&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15378506&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8951[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8952</li>

8953<li id="section_6.3">

8954Christensen MS, Heyman M, M&#246;tt&#246;nen M, et al.: Treatment-related death in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukaemia in the Nordic countries: 1992-2001. Br J Haematol 131 (1): 50-8, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16173962&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16173962&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8955[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8956</li>

8957<li id="section_6.4">

8958Vrooman LM, Stevenson KE, Supko JG, et al.: Postinduction dexamethasone and individualized dosing of Escherichia Coli L-asparaginase each improve outcome of children and adolescents with newly diagnosed acute lymphoblastic leukemia: results from a randomized study--Dana-Farber Cancer Institute ALL Consortium Protocol 00-01. J Clin Oncol 31 (9): 1202-10, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23358966&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23358966&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8959[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8960</li>

8961<li id="section_6.5">

8962Lund B, &#197;sberg A, Heyman M, et al.: Risk factors for treatment related mortality in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. Pediatr Blood Cancer 56 (4): 551-9, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21298739&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21298739&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8963[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8964</li>

8965<li id="section_6.6">

8966Alvarez EM, Malogolowkin M, Li Q, et al.: Decreased Early Mortality in Young Adult Patients With Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treated at Specialized Cancer Centers in California. J Oncol Pract 15 (4): e316-e327, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30849003&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30849003&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8967[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8968</li>

8969</ol>

8970</div>

8971

8972 </section>

8973

8974

8975

8976 <section id="_727">

8977

8978 <h2>

8979Treatment of Newly Diagnosed Childhood ALL</h2>

8980

8981 <div id="_section_727" class="pdq-sections">

8982<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

8983<h6>

8984In This Section</h6>

8985<ul>

8986<li>

8987<a href="#_728_toc">

8988Standard Induction Treatment Options for Newly Diagnosed ALL<ul>

8989<li>

8990<a href="#_732_toc">

8991Remission induction chemotherapy</a>

8992</li>

8993<li>

8994<a href="#_1389_toc">

8995Response to remission induction chemotherapy</a>

8996</li>

8997</ul>

8998</a>

8999</li>

9000<li>

9001<a href="#_857_toc">

9002Standard Postinduction Treatment Options for Childhood ALL<ul>

9003<li>

9004<a href="#_1080_toc">

9005Consolidation/intensification therapy</a>

9006</li>

9007<li>

9008<a href="#_1092_toc">

9009Maintenance therapy</a>

9010</li>

9011<li>

9012<a href="#_1106_toc">

9013Treatment options under clinical evaluation</a>

9014</li>

9015</ul>

9016</a>

9017</li>

9018<li>

9019<a href="#_TrialSearch_727_sid_7_toc">

9020Current Clinical Trials</a>

9021</li>

9022</ul>

9023</nav>

9024<section id="_728">

9025<h3 id="_728_toc">

9026Standard Induction Treatment Options for Newly Diagnosed ALL</h3>

9027<p id="_729" tabindex="-1">

9028Standard treatment options for newly diagnosed childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) include the following:</p>

9029<div class="pdq-content-list">

9030<ol id="_844">

9031<li>

9032Chemotherapy.</li>

9033</ol>

9034</div>

9035<section id="_732">

9036<h4 id="_732_toc">

9037Remission induction chemotherapy</h4>

9038<p id="_1528" tabindex="-1">

9039The goal of the first phase of therapy (remission induction) is to induce a complete remission (CR). This induction phase typically lasts 4 weeks. Overall, approximately 98% of patients with newly diagnosed B-ALL achieve CR by the end of this phase, with somewhat lower rates in infants and in noninfant patients with T-ALL or high presenting leukocyte counts.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

90401</a>

9041-<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

90425</a>

9043]</p>

9044<p id="_1325" tabindex="-1">

9045Induction chemotherapy typically consists of the following drugs, with or without an anthracycline (either doxorubicin or daunorubicin):</p>

9046<div class="pdq-content-list">

9047<ul id="_1326">

9048<li>

9049Vincristine.</li>

9050<li>

9051Corticosteroid (either prednisone or dexamethasone).</li>

9052<li>

9053Asparaginase.</li>

9054<li>

9055Intrathecal chemotherapy.</li>

9056</ul>

9057</div>

9058<p id="_1444" tabindex="-1">

9059The Children's Oncology Group (COG) protocols administer a three-drug induction (vincristine, corticosteroid, and pegaspargase) to National Cancer Institute (NCI) standard-risk B-ALL patients and a four-drug induction (vincristine, corticosteroid, and pegaspargase plus anthracycline) to NCI high-risk B-ALL and all T-ALL patients. Other groups use a four-drug induction for all patients.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

90601</a>

9061-<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

90623</a>

9063] </p>

9064<section id="_1385">

9065<h5 id="_1385_toc">

9066Corticosteroid therapy</h5>

9067<p id="_734" tabindex="-1">

9068Many current regimens use dexamethasone instead of prednisone during remission induction and later phases of therapy, although controversy exists as to whether dexamethasone benefits all subsets of patients. Some trials also suggest that dexamethasone during induction may be associated with more toxicity than prednisone, including higher rates of infection, myopathy, and behavioral changes.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

90691</a>

9070,<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

90716</a>

9072-<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

90738</a>

9074] The COG reported that dexamethasone during induction was associated with a higher risk of osteonecrosis in older children (aged &gt;10 years),[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

90758</a>

9076] although this finding has not been confirmed in other randomized studies.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

90771</a>

9078,<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

90797</a>

9080]</p>

9081<p id="_827" tabindex="-1">

9082Evidence (dexamethasone vs. prednisone during induction):</p>

9083<div class="pdq-content-list">

9084<ol id="_774">

9085<li>

9086The Children's Cancer Group conducted a randomized trial that compared dexamethasone and prednisone in standard-risk B-ALL patients receiving a three-drug induction without an anthracycline.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

90876</a>

9088] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9089<ul id="_1327">

9090<li>

9091Dexamethasone was associated with a superior event-free survival (EFS).</li>

9092<li>

9093Dexamethasone was associated with a higher frequency of reversible steroid myopathy and hyperglycemia. No significant differences in rates of infection during induction were observed between the two randomized arms.</li>

9094</ul>

9095</div>

9096</li>

9097<li>

9098Another randomized trial that included both standard-risk and high-risk patients was conducted by the United Kingdom Medical Research Council (MRC).[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

90997</a>

9100] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9101<ul id="_1328">

9102<li>

9103The trial demonstrated that dexamethasone was associated with a more favorable outcome than prednisolone in all patient subgroups.</li>

9104<li>

9105Patients who received dexamethasone had a significantly lower incidence of both central nervous system (CNS) and non-CNS relapses than did patients who received prednisolone.</li>

9106<li>

9107Dexamethasone was associated with a higher incidence of steroid-associated behavioral problems and myopathy, but an excess risk of osteonecrosis was not observed. There was no difference in induction death rates between the randomized groups.</li>

9108</ul>

9109</div>

9110</li>

9111<li>

9112The Associazione Italiana di Ematologia e Oncologia Pediatrica (AIEOP) <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00430118">

9113ALL-BFM-2000 (NCT00430118)</a>

9114 trial randomly assigned 3,720 patients to receive either dexamethasone (10 mg/m<span class="sup">

91152</span>

9116/d) or prednisone (60 mg/m<span class="sup">

91172</span>

9118/d) during multiagent remission induction (including an anthracycline for all patients) after a 7-day prednisone prophase.[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

91199</a>

9120]

9121<div class="pdq-content-list">

9122<ul id="_1830">

9123<li>

9124Dexamethasone was associated with higher incidence of life-threatening events (primarily infections), resulting in a significantly higher induction death rate (2.5% for dexamethasone vs. 0.9% for prednisone; <em>

9125P</em>

9126 = .00013).</li>

9127<li>

9128There was no difference in rates of osteonecrosis between the randomized groups.</li>

9129<li>

9130The 5-year cumulative incidence of relapse was significantly lower with dexamethasone (11% vs. 16%; <em>

9131P</em>

9132 &lt; .0001), resulting in superior 5-year EFS rates (84% for dexamethasone vs. 81% for prednisone, <em>

9133P</em>

9134 = .024) despite the increased induction death rate.</li>

9135<li>

9136No difference in overall survival (OS) was observed based on steroid randomization, although the study was not sufficiently powered to detect small differences in OS.</li>

9137<li>

9138In a predefined subgroup analysis, a survival benefit was observed with dexamethasone treatment in patients with T-ALL and a good response to the prednisone prophase (5-year OS rates, 91% with dexamethasone vs. 83% with prednisone, <em>

9139P</em>

9140 = .036).</li>

9141</ul>

9142</div>

9143</li>

9144<li>

9145The COG conducted a randomized trial of dexamethasone and prednisone in NCI high-risk B-ALL patients.[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

91468</a>

9147] Patients were randomly assigned to receive 14 days of dexamethasone or 28 days of prednisone during a four-drug induction (with an anthracycline). This trial also included a randomized comparison of high-dose and escalating-dose methotrexate during the interim maintenance phase.

9148<div class="pdq-content-list">

9149<ul id="_1863">

9150<li>

9151Dexamethasone was associated with a higher rate of infection, but there was no difference in the induction death rate when comparing dexamethasone and prednisone.</li>

9152<li>

9153For patients who were younger than 10 years at diagnosis, there was a significant interaction between the corticosteroid and methotrexate randomizations. However, the best outcome for this group of patients was observed in those who received both dexamethasone during induction and high-dose methotrexate during interim maintenance.</li>

9154<li>

9155The corticosteroid randomization was closed early for patients aged 10 years or older at diagnosis because of excessive rates of osteonecrosis in patients randomly assigned to dexamethasone. However, there was no EFS benefit associated with dexamethasone in these older patients (5-year EFS rates of 73.1% with dexamethasone and 73.9% with prednisone; <em>

9156P</em>

9157 = .78)

9158</li>

9159</ul>

9160</div>

9161</li>

9162</ol>

9163</div>

9164<p id="_1272" tabindex="-1">

9165The ratio of dexamethasone to prednisone dose used may influence outcome. Studies in which the dexamethasone to prednisone ratio was 1:5 to 1:7 have shown a better result for dexamethasone, while studies that used a 1:10 ratio have shown similar outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

916610</a>

9167] </p>

9168</section>

9169<section id="_1386">

9170<h5 id="_1386_toc">

9171Asparaginase</h5>

9172<p id="_736" tabindex="-1">

9173Several forms of asparaginase have been used in the treatment of

9174children with ALL, including the following:</p>

9175<div class="pdq-content-list">

9176<ul id="_1329">

9177<li>

9178<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1387">

9179Pegaspargase (PEG-asparaginase)</a>

9180.</li>

9181<li>

9182<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_2488">

9183Calaspargase pegol</a>

9184.</li>

9185<li>

9186<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1388">

9187Asparaginase Erwinia chrysanthemi (Erwinia L-asparaginase)</a>

9188.</li>

9189<li>

9190Native <em>

9191Escherichia coli</em>

9192 (<em>

9193E. coli</em>

9194) L-asparaginase (unavailable in the United States, but still available in other countries).</li>

9195</ul>

9196</div>

9197<section id="_1387">

9198<h6 id="_1387_toc">

9199Pegaspargase (PEG-asparaginase)</h6>

9200<p id="_1375" tabindex="-1">

9201Pegaspargase is a form of L-asparaginase in which the <em>

9202E. coli</em>

9203&#8211;derived enzyme is modified by the covalent attachment of polyethylene glycol. It is commonly used during both induction and postinduction phases of treatment in newly diagnosed patients treated in Western Europe. Pegaspargase is not available in the United States, but it is still available in other countries.</p>

9204<p id="_1530" tabindex="-1">

9205Pegaspargase may be given either intramuscularly (IM) or intravenously (IV).[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

920611</a>

9207] Pharmacokinetics and toxicity profiles are similar for IM and IV pegaspargase administration.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

920811</a>

9209] There is no evidence that IV administration of pegaspargase is more toxic than IM administration.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

921011</a>

9211-<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

921213</a>

9213]</p>

9214<p id="_1331" tabindex="-1">

9215Pegaspargase has a much longer serum half-life than native <em>

9216E. coli</em>

9217

9218L-asparaginase, producing prolonged asparagine depletion after a single injection.[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

921914</a>

9220] </p>

9221<p id="_1434" tabindex="-1">

9222Serum asparaginase enzyme activity levels of more than 0.1 IU/mL have been associated with serum asparagine depletion. Studies have shown that a single dose of pegaspargase given either IM or IV as part of multiagent induction results in serum enzyme activity of more than 0.1 IU/mL in nearly all patients for at least 2 to 3 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

922311</a>

9224,<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

922512</a>

9226,<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

922715</a>

9228,<a href="#cit/section_7.16">

922916</a>

9230] In one study of 54 NCI high-risk patients conducted by the COG, plasma asparaginase activity as low as 0.02 IU/mL was associated with serum asparagine depletion. Using that cutoff value, it was estimated that 96% of patients maintained the therapeutic effect (plasma asparagine depletion) for 22 to 29 days after a single pegaspargase dose of 2,500 IU/m<span class="sup">

92312</span>

9232.[<a href="#cit/section_7.17">

923317</a>

9234] In one randomized study, higher doses of pegaspargase (3,500 IU/m<span class="sup">

92352</span>

9236) did not improve outcome when compared with standard doses (2,500 IU/m<span class="sup">

92372</span>

9238).[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

923918</a>

9240][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9241Level of evidence A1</a>

9242]</p>

9243<p id="_2247" tabindex="-1">

9244In another study, doses of pegaspargase were reduced in an attempt to decrease toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

924519</a>

9246] While lower doses were successful in maintaining appropriate asparaginase levels of more than 0.1 IU/mL, the frequency of asparaginase-related toxicities was similar to the frequency of toxicities reported in previous studies that used higher doses of pegaspargase. This study did not report on the impact of lower doses of pegaspargase on EFS.

9247</p>

9248<p id="_776" tabindex="-1">

9249Evidence (use of pegaspargase versus native <em>

9250E. coli</em>

9251 L-asparaginase):</p>

9252<div class="pdq-content-list">

9253<ol id="_780">

9254<li>

9255A randomized comparison of IV pegaspargase versus IM native <em>

9256E. coli</em>

9257 asparaginase was conducted. Each agent was administered for a 30-week period after the achievement of CR.[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

925813</a>

9259][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9260Level of evidence A3</a>

9261]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9262<ul id="_1793">

9263<li>

9264Serum asparaginase activity (SAA) levels were significantly higher with IV pegaspargase and exceeded goal therapeutic levels (&gt;0.1 IU/mL) in nearly all patients throughout the 30-week period.</li>

9265<li>

9266There was no significant difference in EFS and OS between the randomized arms.</li>

9267<li>

9268There was no difference in rates of asparaginase-related toxicities, including hypersensitivity, pancreatitis, and thromboembolic complications.</li>

9269<li>

9270Similar outcome and similar rates of asparaginase-related toxicities were observed for both groups of patients.</li>

9271<li>

9272IV pegaspargase was associated with less treatment-related anxiety, as assessed by patient and parent surveys.</li>

9273</ul>

9274</div>

9275</li>

9276<li>

9277

9278 Another randomized trial of patients with standard-risk ALL assigned patients to receive either pegaspargase or native <em>

9279E. coli</em>

9280 asparaginase during induction and in each of two delayed intensification courses.[<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

928115</a>

9282]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9283<ul id="_1333">

9284<li>

9285A single dose of pegaspargase given in conjunction with vincristine and prednisone during induction therapy appeared to have similar activity and toxicity as nine doses of IM <em>

9286E. coli</em>

9287 L-asparaginase (3 times a week for 3 weeks).[<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

928815</a>

9289]</li>

9290<li>

9291 The use of pegaspargase was associated with more rapid blast clearance and a lower incidence of neutralizing antibodies.</li>

9292</ul>

9293</div>

9294</li>

9295</ol>

9296</div>

9297<p id="_737" tabindex="-1">

9298Patients with an allergic reaction to pegaspargase are typically switched to <em>

9299Erwinia</em>

9300 L-asparaginase. A COG analysis investigated the deleterious effect on disease-free survival (DFS) of early discontinuation of treatment with pegaspargase in patients with high-risk B-ALL. The study found that the adverse effect on outcome could be reversed with the use of <em>

9301Erwinia</em>

9302 L-asparaginase to complete the planned course of asparaginase therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

930320</a>

9304][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9305Level of evidence C2</a>

9306] Measurement of SAA levels after a mild or questionable reaction to pegaspargase may help to differentiate patients for whom the switch to <em>

9307Erwinia</em>

9308 is indicated (because of inadequate SAA) versus those for whom a change in preparation may not be necessary.[<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

930921</a>

9310,<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

931122</a>

9312]</p>

9313<p id="_2342" tabindex="-1">

9314Evidence (adverse prognostic impact of early discontinuation of pegaspargase or silent inactivation of asparaginase):</p>

9315<div class="pdq-content-list">

9316<ol id="_2343">

9317<li>

9318Several studies have identified a subset of patients who experience silent inactivation of asparaginase, which is defined as the absence of therapeutic SAA levels without overt allergy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

931923</a>

9320,<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

932124</a>

9322] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9323<ul id="_2351">

9324<li>

9325In a trial conducted by the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (DFCI) Consortium, 12% of patients who were initially treated with native <em>

9326E.coli</em>

9327 L-asparaginase demonstrated silent inactivation. These patients had a superior EFS if their asparaginase preparation was changed.[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

932824</a>

9329]</li>

9330<li>

9331Patients who were treated with pegaspargase appear to have lower levels of silent inactivation (&lt;10%).[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

933213</a>

9333,<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

933423</a>

9335,<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

933625</a>

9337]</li>

9338</ul>

9339</div>

9340 <p id="_2347" tabindex="-1">

9341Determination of the optimal frequency of pharmacokinetic monitoring for pegaspargase-treated patients, and whether such screening impacts outcome, awaits further investigation.</p>

9342</li>

9343<li>

9344A report from the COG included 8,196 patients with newly diagnosed B-ALL who were enrolled between 2004 to 2011.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

934520</a>

9346][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9347Level of evidence C2</a>

9348]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9349<ul id="_2348">

9350<li>

9351The cumulative incidence of pegaspargase discontinuation (because of toxicity) was 12.2% in NCI standard-risk patients and 25.4% in NCI high-risk patients.</li>

9352<li>

9353In multivariable analysis, NCI high-risk patients who discontinued pegaspargase early had inferior DFS (hazard ratio [HR], 1.5; <em>

9354P</em>

9355 = .002) than did those who received all prescribed doses. For NCI standard-risk patients, there was no impact of pegaspargase discontinuation on DFS, except in patients with slow-early response who received intensified postinduction therapy (HR, 1.7; <em>

9356P</em>

9357 = .03).</li>

9358<li>

9359NCI high-risk patients who discontinued pegaspargase but then switched to <em>

9360Erwinia</em>

9361 asparaginase and received all subsequent intended doses, did not have an increased risk of relapse (HR, 1.1; <em>

9362P</em>

9363 = .69).</li>

9364</ul>

9365</div>

9366 </li>

9367<li>

9368An analysis of 1,115 non&#8211;high-risk ALL patients from the Nordic Society of Pediatric Hematology and Oncology (NOPHO) ALL2008 protocol reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

936925</a>

9370]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9371<ul id="_2349">

9372<li>

9373255 patients received a truncated asparaginase course because of toxicity, and 46 patients had evidence of silent inactivation on therapeutic drug monitoring.</li>

9374<li>

9375The 7-year cumulative incidence of relapse was 11.1% in the 301 patients who received a truncated asparaginase course, compared with 6.7% in the remaining 814 patients who received the planned courses (HR, 1.73; <em>

9376P</em>

9377 = .03).</li>

9378<li>

9379In a Cox model, suboptimal asparaginase treatment (because of either truncated pegaspargase or silent inactivation) was significantly associated with a higher relapse risk (HR, 1.69; <em>

9380P</em>

9381 = 0.03).</li>

9382</ul>

9383</div>

9384</li>

9385</ol>

9386</div>

9387<section id="_2488">

9388<h6 id="_2488_toc">

9389Calaspargase pegol</h6>

9390<p id="_2152" tabindex="-1">

9391Calaspargase pegol is another formulation of pegylated asparaginase that is also available for the treatment of children and adolescents with ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

939226</a>

9393] This formulation is similar in structure to pegaspargase, except with a different linker between the L-asparaginase enzyme and the PEG moiety, resulting in a longer half-life.[<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

939427</a>

9395,<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

939628</a>

9397]</p>

9398<p id="_2489" tabindex="-1">

9399Evidence (calaspargase pegol vs. pegaspargase):</p>

9400<div class="pdq-content-list">

9401<ol id="_2490">

9402<li>

9403In a COG study, 165 patients with high-risk B-ALL were randomly assigned to receive either calaspargase pegol or pegaspargase during the induction phase of ALL therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

940427</a>

9405]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9406<ul id="_2491">

9407<li>

9408The mean half-life of calaspargase pegol was approximately 2.5 times longer than pegaspargase.</li>

9409<li>

9410The total systemic exposure to calaspargase pegol was greater than for pegaspargase.</li>

9411<li>

9412Twenty-five days after a dose of calaspargase pegol, 95% of patients maintained an asparaginase level higher than 0.1 IU/mL, compared with 28% of patients who received pegaspargase.</li>

9413<li>

9414Evidence of end-induction minimal residual disease (MRD) negativity was similar between the two drugs (74% and 72%).</li>

9415<li>

9416The toxicity profile of the two drugs was similar.</li>

9417</ul>

9418</div>

9419</li>

9420<li>

9421In a DFCI trial of calaspargase pegol in patients with newly diagnosed ALL, all patients received one dose of either calaspargase pegol or pegaspargase as part of induction therapy. After induction, 230 patients were randomly assigned to receive either calaspargase pegol every 3 weeks (10 doses) or pegaspargase every 2 weeks (15 doses).[<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

942228</a>

9423]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9424<ul id="_2492">

9425<li>

9426At day 25 after the induction dose, 88% of patients who received calaspargase pegol had an asparaginase level higher than 0.1 IU/mL, compared with 17% of patients who received pegaspargase.</li>

9427<li>

9428There was no difference in end-of-induction MRD.</li>

9429<li>

9430There was no difference in the frequency of toxicities (37%).</li>

9431<li>

9432The 5-year EFS rates were similar for calaspargase pegol and pegaspargase (88.1% vs. 84.9%).</li>

9433</ul>

9434</div>

9435</li>

9436</ol>

9437</div>

9438<p id="_2493" tabindex="-1">

9439Calaspargase pegol has only been approved for use in the United States for patients younger than 22 years.</p>

9440</section>

9441</section>

9442<section id="_1388">

9443<h6 id="_1388_toc">

9444Asparaginase <em>

9445Erwinia chrysanthemi</em>

9446 (<em>

9447Erwinia</em>

9448 L-asparaginase)</h6>

9449<p id="_1531" tabindex="-1">

9450<em>

9451Erwinia</em>

9452 L-asparaginase is typically used in patients who have experienced an allergy to native <em>

9453E. coli</em>

9454 or pegaspargase.</p>

9455<p id="_854" tabindex="-1">

9456The half-life of <em>

9457Erwinia</em>

9458 L-asparaginase (0.65 days) is much shorter than that of native <em>

9459E. coli</em>

9460 (1.2 days) or pegaspargase (5.7 days).[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

946114</a>

9462] If <em>

9463Erwinia </em>

9464L-asparaginase is used, the shorter half-life of the <em>

9465Erwinia </em>

9466preparation requires more frequent administration to achieve adequate asparagine depletion. </p>

9467<p id="_833" tabindex="-1">

9468Evidence (increased dose frequency of <em>

9469Erwinia</em>

9470 L-asparaginase needed to achieve goal therapeutic effect):</p>

9471<div class="pdq-content-list">

9472<ol id="_781">

9473<li>

9474A COG trial demonstrated that IM <em>

9475Erwinia</em>

9476 L-asparaginase given three times a week to patients with an allergy to pegaspargase leads to therapeutic serum asparaginase enzyme activity levels (defined as a level &#8805;0.1 IU/mL).[<a href="#cit/section_7.29">

947729</a>

9478]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9479<ul id="_2275">

9480<li>

9481 On this trial, 96% of children achieved a level of 0.1 IU/mL or more at 2 days after a dose of <em>

9482Erwinia</em>

9483 L-asparaginase and 85% did so at 3 days after a dose.</li>

9484</ul>

9485</div>

9486</li>

9487<li>

9488A trial of IV <em>

9489Erwinia</em>

9490 L-asparaginase given on a Monday-Wednesday-Friday schedule to patients with an allergy to pegaspargase demonstrated therapeutic serum asparaginase enzyme activity (defined as &#8805;0.1 IU/mL) in 83% of patients 48 hours after a dose but in only 43% of patients 72 hours after a dose.[<a href="#cit/section_7.30">

949130</a>

9492]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9493<ul id="_2276">

9494<li>

9495 If IV <em>

9496Erwinia</em>

9497 is given on a Monday-Wednesday-Friday schedule, the authors suggest that 72-hour nadir enzyme activity levels be monitored to ensure therapeutic levels.</li>

9498</ul>

9499</div>

9500</li>

9501</ol>

9502</div>

9503<p id="_2494" tabindex="-1">

9504A recombinant form of <em>

9505Erwinia</em>

9506 L-asparaginase, asparaginase erwinia chrysanthemi (recombinant)-rywn, was studied in a phase II/III COG trial. When it was given on a Monday (25 mg/m<span class="sup">

95072</span>

9508), Wednesday (25 mg/m<span class="sup">

95092</span>

9510), and Friday (50 mg/m<span class="sup">

95112</span>

9512) schedule for six doses, the proportion of patients who achieved asparaginase levels of 0.1 IU/mL or greater was 90% at 72 hours (44 of 49 patients) and 96% at 48 hours (47 of 49 patients). The safety profile was comparable with other forms of asparaginase.[<a href="#cit/section_7.31">

951331</a>

9514] The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved asparaginase erwinia chrysanthemi (recombinant)-rywn for IM use in children and adults with ALL.</p>

9515</section>

9516</section>

9517<section id="_1864">

9518<h5 id="_1864_toc">

9519Anthracycline use during induction</h5>

9520<p id="_1865" tabindex="-1">

9521The COG protocols administer a three-drug induction (vincristine, corticosteroid, and pegaspargase) to NCI standard-risk B-ALL patients and a four-drug induction (vincristine, corticosteroid, and pegaspargase plus an anthracycline) to NCI high-risk B-ALL and all T-ALL patients. Other groups use a four-drug induction for all patients.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

95221</a>

9523-<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

95243</a>

9525]</p>

9526<p id="_1893" tabindex="-1">

9527In induction regimens that include an anthracycline, either daunorubicin or doxorubicin are typically used. In a randomized trial comparing the two agents during induction, there were no differences in early response measures, including reduction in peripheral blood blast counts during the first week of therapy, day 15 marrow morphology, and end-induction MRD levels.[<a href="#cit/section_7.32">

952832</a>

9529][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810031&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9530Level of evidence B3</a>

9531] </p>

9532</section>

9533</section>

9534<section id="_1389">

9535<h4 id="_1389_toc">

9536Response to remission induction chemotherapy</h4>

9537<p id="_738" tabindex="-1">

9538 More than 95% of children with newly diagnosed ALL will achieve a CR within the first 4

9539weeks of treatment. Of those who fail to achieve CR within the first 4 weeks, approximately one-half will experience a toxic death during the induction phase (usually caused by infection) and the other half will have resistant disease (persistent morphological leukemia).[<a href="#cit/section_7.33">

954033</a>

9541-<a href="#cit/section_7.35">

954235</a>

9543]; [<a href="#cit/section_7.36">

954436</a>

9545][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9546Level of evidence C1</a>

9547] </p>

9548<p id="_2521" tabindex="-1">

9549Remission is classically defined as an end-induction bone marrow examination by routine microscopic cytomorphology with fewer than 5% lymphoblasts at the end of induction (M1). The Ponte de Legno consortium includes approximately 15 large national and international cooperative groups devoted to the study and treatment of childhood ALL. This group published a consensus definition of complete remission, as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_7.37">

955037</a>

9551]</p>

9552<div class="pdq-content-list">

9553<ul id="_2533">

9554<li>

9555Achievement of MRD levels of less than 1% and/or M1 cytomorphology. <div class="pdq-content-list">

9556<ul id="_2534" class="list-dash">

9557<li>

9558MRD is the gold standard and takes precedence over cytomorphology.</li>

9559<li>

9560MRD is determined by either flow cytometry or polymerase chain reaction techniques.</li>

9561</ul>

9562</div>

9563</li>

9564<li>

9565Resolution of extramedullary disease, assessed no earlier than the end of induction.</li>

9566</ul>

9567</div>

9568<p id="_1532" tabindex="-1">

9569Most patients with persistence of morphologically detectable leukemia at the end of the 4-week induction phase have a poor

9570prognosis and may benefit from an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) once CR is achieved.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

95714</a>

9572,<a href="#cit/section_7.38">

957338</a>

9574,<a href="#cit/section_7.39">

957539</a>

9576] In a large retrospective series, the 10-year OS rate for such patients was 32%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

957740</a>

9578] A trend for superior outcome with allogeneic HSCT compared with chemotherapy alone was observed in patients with T-cell phenotype (any age) and B-ALL patients older than 6 years. B-ALL patients who were aged 1 to 5 years at diagnosis and did not have any adverse cytogenetic abnormalities (<em class="gene-name">

9579KMT2A</em>

9580 rearrangement, <em class="gene-name">

9581BCR</em>

9582::<em class="gene-name">

9583ABL1</em>

9584) had a relatively favorable prognosis, without any advantage in outcome with the utilization of HSCT compared with chemotherapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

958540</a>

9586]</p>

9587<p id="_2496" tabindex="-1">

9588The incorporation of nelarabine may be of value for patients with T-ALL and have induction failure. The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00408005">

9589AALL0434 (NCT00408005)</a>

9590 study included 43 patients with more than 25% blasts in an end-induction bone marrow aspirate. Of these patients, 23 patients were nonrandomly assigned to therapy that included high-dose methotrexate and nelarabine as part of a multidrug regimen, and 20 patients underwent allogeneic transplant. The 5-year EFS rate was 53.1% (&#177; 9.4%) for the patients who received high-dose methotrexate and nelarabine. There was no difference in outcome for these two groups (HR, 0.66; 95% CI, 0.24&#8211;1.83; <em>

9591P</em>

9592 = .423).[<a href="#cit/section_7.41">

959341</a>

9594]</p>

9595<p id="_1335" tabindex="-1">

9596For patients who achieve CR, measures of the rapidity of blast clearance and MRD determinations have important prognostic significance, particularly the following:</p>

9597<div class="pdq-content-list">

9598<ul id="_1273">

9599<li>

9600The percentage of morphologically detectable marrow blasts at 7 and 14 days after starting multiagent remission induction therapy has been correlated with relapse risk,[<a href="#cit/section_7.42">

960142</a>

9602] and has been used in the past by the COG to risk-stratify patients. However, in multivariate analyses, when end-induction MRD is included, these early marrow findings lose their prognostic significance.[<a href="#cit/section_7.43">

960343</a>

9604,<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

960544</a>

9606]</li>

9607<li>

9608End-induction levels of submicroscopic MRD, assessed by multiparameter flow cytometry, polymerase chain reaction, or next-generation sequencing assays strongly correlates with long-term outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_7.43">

960943</a>

9610,<a href="#cit/section_7.45">

961145</a>

9612-<a href="#cit/section_7.48">

961348</a>

9614] Intensification of postinduction therapy for patients with high levels of end-induction MRD is a common component of most ALL treatment regimens. In a randomized trial conducted by the United Kingdom Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (UKALL) group, augmented postinduction therapy was shown to improve outcome for standard-risk and intermediate-risk patients with high end-induction MRD.[<a href="#cit/section_7.49">

961549</a>

9616]</li>

9617<li>

9618MRD levels earlier in induction (e.g., days 8 and 15) and at later postinduction time points (e.g., week 12 after starting therapy) have also been shown to have prognostic significance in both B-ALL and T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_7.43">

961943</a>

9620,<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

962144</a>

9622,<a href="#cit/section_7.47">

962347</a>

9624,<a href="#cit/section_7.50">

962550</a>

9626-<a href="#cit/section_7.53">

962753</a>

9628]</li>

9629<li>

9630A substantial majority of patients with a positive end-of-induction MRD will become MRD negative at the end of 4 to 8 weeks of consolidation therapy. In a COG study, patients with high-risk B-ALL who had a positive end-of-induction MRD but a negative end-of-consolidation MRD had a significantly improved DFS compared with patients who were MRD positive at end of consolidation (5-year DFS rate, 79.5% vs. 39.5%).[<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

963144</a>

9632]</li>

9633</ul>

9634</div>

9635<p id="_1336" tabindex="-1">

9636For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_526">

9637Response to initial treatment</a>

9638 section.</p>

9639<p id="_1435" tabindex="-1">

9640For specific information about CNS therapy to prevent CNS relapse in children with newly diagnosed ALL, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_576">

9641CNS-Directed Therapy for Childhood ALL</a>

9642 section.</p>

9643</section>

9644</section>

9645<section id="_857">

9646<h3 id="_857_toc">

9647Standard Postinduction Treatment Options for Childhood ALL</h3>

9648<p id="_1076" tabindex="-1">

9649Standard treatment options for consolidation/intensification and maintenance therapy (postinduction therapy) include the following:</p>

9650<div class="pdq-content-list">

9651<ol id="_1077">

9652<li>

9653Chemotherapy.</li>

9654</ol>

9655</div>

9656<p id="_1339" tabindex="-1">

9657CNS-directed therapy is provided during premaintenance chemotherapy by all groups. Some protocols (COG, St. Jude Children's Research Hospital [SJCRH], and DFCI) provide ongoing intrathecal chemotherapy during maintenance, while others (Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster [BFM]) do not. For specific information about CNS therapy to prevent CNS relapse in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who are receiving postinduction therapy, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_576">

9658CNS-Directed Therapy for Childhood ALL</a>

9659 section.</p>

9660<section id="_1080">

9661<h4 id="_1080_toc">

9662Consolidation/intensification therapy</h4>

9663<p id="_1081" tabindex="-1">

9664Once CR has been achieved, systemic treatment in conjunction with

9665CNS-directed therapy follows. The intensity of the

9666postinduction chemotherapy varies considerably depending on risk group assignment, but all patients receive some

9667form of intensification after the achievement of CR and before

9668beginning maintenance therapy.</p>

9669<p id="_1533" tabindex="-1">

9670The most commonly used intensification schema is the BFM backbone. This therapeutic backbone, first introduced by the BFM clinical trials group, includes the following:[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

96711</a>

9672]</p>

9673<div class="pdq-content-list">

9674<ol id="_1534">

9675<li>

9676An initial consolidation (referred to as induction IB) immediately after the initial induction phase. This phase includes intrathecal therapy, cyclophosphamide, low-dose cytarabine, and mercaptopurine.<p id="_2153" tabindex="-1">

9677An interim maintenance phase, which includes intrathecal therapy and four doses of high-dose methotrexate (typically 5 g/m<span class="sup">

96782</span>

9679) with leucovorin rescue.</p>

9680</li>

9681<li>

9682Reinduction (or delayed intensification), which typically includes agents and schedules similar to those used during the induction and initial consolidation phases.</li>

9683<li>

9684Maintenance, typically consisting of daily mercaptopurine (6-MP), weekly low-dose methotrexate, and sometimes, intermittent administration of vincristine and a corticosteroid, as well as continued intrathecal therapy.</li>

9685</ol>

9686</div>

9687<p id="_1535" tabindex="-1">

9688This backbone has been adopted by many groups, including the COG. Variation of this backbone includes the following: </p>

9689<div class="pdq-content-list">

9690<ul id="_1536">

9691<li>

9692Intensification for higher-risk patients by including additional doses of vincristine and pegaspargase, as well as repeated interim maintenance and delayed intensification phases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.54">

969354</a>

9694,<a href="#cit/section_7.55">

969555</a>

9696]</li>

9697<li>

9698The use of escalating doses of methotrexate (starting at a dose of 100 mg/m<span class="sup">

96992</span>

9700) without leucovorin rescue instead of or in addition to high-dose methotrexate during interim maintenance phases.</li>

9701<li>

9702 Elimination or truncation of some of the phases for lower-risk patients to minimize acute and long-term toxicity.</li>

9703</ul>

9704</div>

9705<p id="_1537" tabindex="-1">

9706Other clinical trial groups utilize a different therapeutic backbone during postinduction treatment phases, as follows: </p>

9707<div class="pdq-content-list">

9708<ul id="_1538">

9709<li>

9710DFCI: The DFCI ALL Consortium protocols include 30 weeks of pegaspargase therapy beginning at week 7 of therapy, given in conjunction with maintenance regimen (vincristine/dexamethasone pulses, weekly low-dose methotrexate, daily mercaptopurine).[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

97113</a>

9712] These protocols also do not include a delayed intensification phase, but high-risk patients receive additional doses of doxorubicin (instead of low-dose methotrexate) during the first six months of postinduction therapy.</li>

9713<li>

9714NOPHO: The NOPHO also emphasizes the use of pegaspargase during consolidation and intensification. In the ALL2008 trial, all patients received five doses of pegaspargase given every other week after induction. Patients then received an additional ten doses at 2-week intervals or three doses at 6-week intervals. Both regimens produced equally excellent survival rates, with reduced toxicity in the three-dose regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_7.56">

971556</a>

9716]</li>

9717<li>

9718SJCRH: SJCRH follows a BFM backbone but augments the reinduction and maintenance phases for some patients by including intensified dosing of pegaspargase, frequent vincristine/corticosteroid pulses, and rotating drug pairs during maintenance (mercaptopurine/methotrexate, cyclophosphamide/cytarabine, dexamethasone/vincristine).[<a href="#cit/section_7.57">

971957</a>

9720]</li>

9721</ul>

9722</div>

9723<section id="_1083">

9724<h5 id="_1083_toc">

9725Standard-risk ALL</h5>

9726<p id="_1084" tabindex="-1">

9727In children with low- and standard-risk B-ALL, there has been an attempt to limit

9728exposure to drugs such as anthracyclines and alkylating agents that may be

9729associated with an increased risk of late toxic effects.[<a href="#cit/section_7.58">

973058</a>

9731-<a href="#cit/section_7.60">

973260</a>

9733] The COG regimen for standard-risk B-ALL postinduction therapy can be delivered in the outpatient setting and has multiple favorable characteristics, including low-intensity 4-week consolidation, limited anthracycline (75 mg/m<span class="sup">

97342</span>

9735) and alkylator exposure (1 gm/m<span class="sup">

97362</span>

9737), only two doses of pegaspargase, and interim maintenance phases consisting of escalating doses of methotrexate (without leucovorin rescue) rather than high-dose IV methotrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_7.61">

973861</a>

9739][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9740Level of evidence B4</a>

9741] </p>

9742<p id="_2431" tabindex="-1">

9743Favorable outcomes for standard-risk patients with B-ALL were also reported in trials that used a limited number of courses of intermediate-dose or high-dose

9744methotrexate as consolidation followed by maintenance therapy (without a reinduction phase).[<a href="#cit/section_7.59">

974559</a>

9746,<a href="#cit/section_7.62">

974762</a>

9748,<a href="#cit/section_7.63">

974963</a>

9750] More specifically, a subset of patients with standard-risk B-ALL with favorable cytogenetics, no evidence of CNS or testicular disease at diagnosis, and rapid achievement of low levels of MRD, have been treated with exposure to no or low doses of anthracyclines and alkylating agents. The 5-year DFS rate was almost 99%, and the OS rate was 100%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.64">

975164</a>

9752] The DFCI ALL Consortium study used multiple doses of pegaspargase (30 weeks) as consolidation, without postinduction exposure to alkylating agents or anthracyclines.[<a href="#cit/section_7.65">

975365</a>

9754,<a href="#cit/section_7.66">

975566</a>

9756]</p>

9757<p id="_1680" tabindex="-1">

9758However, the prognostic impact of end-induction and/or consolidation MRD has influenced the treatment of patients originally diagnosed as NCI standard risk. Multiple studies have demonstrated that higher levels of end-induction MRD are associated with poorer prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_7.43">

975943</a>

9760,<a href="#cit/section_7.45">

976145</a>

9762,<a href="#cit/section_7.46">

976346</a>

9764,<a href="#cit/section_7.67">

976567</a>

9766,<a href="#cit/section_7.68">

976768</a>

9768] Augmenting therapy has been shown to improve the outcome in standard-risk patients with elevated MRD levels at the end of induction.[<a href="#cit/section_7.49">

976949</a>

9770] Patients with NCI standard-risk B-ALL with high-risk features (including increased end-of-induction MRD levels as well as CNS2 status at diagnosis, and/or unfavorable genetics) are treated with more intensified therapy. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_543">

9771Prognostic (risk) groups under clinical evaluation</a>

9772 section.</p>

9773<p id="_1119" tabindex="-1">

9774Evidence (intensification for standard-risk B-ALL):</p>

9775<div class="pdq-content-list">

9776<ol id="_1120">

9777<li>

9778Clinical trials conducted in the 1980s and early 1990s demonstrated that the use of

9779a delayed intensification phase improved outcome for children with standard-risk ALL treated with regimens using a BFM backbone.[<a href="#cit/section_7.69">

978069</a>

9781-<a href="#cit/section_7.71">

978271</a>

9783] The delayed intensification phase on such regimens, including those of the COG, consists of an 8-week phase of reinduction (including dexamethasone and an anthracycline) and reconsolidation containing cyclophosphamide, cytarabine, and 6-thioguanine given approximately 4 to 6 months after remission is achieved.[<a href="#cit/section_7.34">

978434</a>

9785,<a href="#cit/section_7.69">

978669</a>

9787,<a href="#cit/section_7.72">

978872</a>

9789]</li>

9790<li>

9791The former Children's Cancer Group (CCG) study (CCG-1991/<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005945">

9792COG-1991</a>

9793) for standard-risk ALL used dexamethasone in a three-drug induction phase and tested the utility of a second delayed intensification phase. This study also compared escalating IV methotrexate (without leucovorin rescue) in conjunction with vincristine versus a standard maintenance combination with oral methotrexate given during two interim maintenance phases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.73">

979473</a>

9795][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9796Level of evidence B1</a>

9797]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9798<ul id="_1247">

9799<li>

9800A second delayed intensification phase provided no benefit in patients who were rapid early responders (M1 or M2 marrow by day 14 of induction).</li>

9801<li>

9802Escalating IV methotrexate during the interim maintenance phases, compared with oral methotrexate during these phases, produced a significant improvement in EFS, which was because of a decreased incidence of isolated extramedullary relapses, particularly those involving the CNS.</li>

9803<li>
