9804Successful therapies for patients with standard-risk ALL that have decreased the use of drugs associated with long-term toxicities have focused on children with B-ALL, not T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_7.59">

980559</a>

9806,<a href="#cit/section_7.60">

980760</a>

9808,<a href="#cit/section_7.62">

980962</a>

9810,<a href="#cit/section_7.63">

981163</a>

9812,<a href="#cit/section_7.65">

981365</a>

9814,<a href="#cit/section_7.66">

981566</a>

9816] The COG, Dutch Children's Oncology Group (DCOG), DFCI, NOPHO, and other large cooperative groups have excluded patients with T-cell ALL from low and standard-risk therapies. Patients with NCI standard-risk features but a T-cell immunophenotype had an inferior EFS and OS compared with patients with NCI standard-risk B-ALL treated on the same regimens on CCG1952 and CCG1991.[<a href="#cit/section_7.74">

981774</a>

9818]</li>

9819</ul>

9820</div>

9821</li>

9822<li>

9823The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00103285">

9824AALL0331 (NCT00103285)</a>

9825 study stratified intensity of therapy for NCI standard-risk patients on the basis of biology and early response. Rapid early response was defined as less than 5% bone marrow blasts by day 15 based on local morphological interpretation and an M1 bone marrow with MRD levels of less than 0.1% at day 29. Standard-risk low patients were those with favorable biology (<em class="gene-name">

9826ETV6</em>

9827::<em class="gene-name">

9828RUNX1</em>

9829 or high hyperdiploidy with triple trisomy), CNS1 status, and a rapid early response. Standard-risk average patients were those lacking favorable or unfavorable biology who also had a rapid early response. Standard-risk high patients were those with slow early response and/or CNS3 status, or <em class="gene-name">

9830KMT2A</em>

9831-rearranged patients with rapid early response. All patients received a three-drug prednisone-based induction (no anthracycline). Standard-risk average patients were randomly assigned to either intensified consolidation (augmented BFM) or standard consolidation. Standard-risk high patients were nonrandomly assigned to the full augmented BFM therapy used for NCI high-risk patients, including two delayed intensification phases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.75">

983275</a>

9833]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9834<ul id="_2228">

9835<li>

9836The 6-year EFS rate for all patients was 89%, and the OS rate was 96%.</li>

9837<li>

9838For standard-risk low patients, this study evaluated the addition of four doses of pegaspargase (added in consolidation and interim maintenance phases) to standard therapy, which included two doses of pegaspargase (administered in induction and delayed intensification phases). Standard-risk low patients had highly favorable outcomes (6-year DFS and OS rates were 94.7% &#177; 0.6% and 98.7% &#177; 0.3%, respectively). The augmentation of standard-risk low therapy with additional pegaspargase did not improve outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_7.61">

983961</a>

9840][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9841Level of evidence B4</a>

9842]</li>

9843<li>

9844For standard-risk average patients, the augmented consolidation regimen did not improve rates of continuous complete remission (CCR) or OS. The 6-year rates of CCR and OS for the standard-risk average cohort were 88% to 89% and 95% to 96%, respectively. </li>

9845<li>

9846Standard-risk average patients with end-induction MRD levels of 0.01% to &lt;0.1% had an inferior outcome compared with those with MRD levels of &lt;0.01% (6-year CCR rates, 77% vs. 91%, respectively). Augmented consolidation was not associated with a better outcome in standard-risk average patients with higher levels of MRD. </li>

9847<li>

9848The standard-risk high cohort achieved a relatively favorable 6-year CCR rate of 86% and an OS rate of 93%.</li>

9849</ul>

9850</div>

9851</li>

9852<li>

9853In a randomized study conducted in the United Kingdom, children and young adults with ALL who lacked high-risk features (including adverse cytogenetics, and/or M3 marrow morphology at day 8 or day 15 of induction) were risk-stratified on the basis of MRD level at the end of induction (week 4) and at week 11 of therapy. Patients with undetectable MRD at week 4 (or with low MRD at week 4 and undetectable by week 11) were considered low risk, and were eligible to be randomly assigned to therapy with either one or two delayed intensification phases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.76">

985476</a>

9855][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9856Level of evidence B1</a>

9857]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9858<ul id="_1593">

9859<li>

9860There was no significant difference in EFS between patients who received one and those who received two delayed intensification phases.</li>

9861<li>

9862There was no significant difference in treatment-related deaths between the two arms; however, the second delayed intensification phase was associated with grade 3 or 4 toxic events in 17% of the 261 patients randomly assigned to that arm, and one patient experienced a treatment-related death during that phase.</li>

9863</ul>

9864</div>

9865</li>

9866<li>

9867In the AIEOP <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00430118">

9868ALL-BFM-2000 (NCT00430118)</a>

9869 trial, standard-risk patients (defined as those with undetectable MRD at days 33 and 78 and absence of high-risk cytogenetics) were randomly assigned to receive treatment with a single delayed-intensification phase of either standard intensity or reduced intensity (shorter duration, with reduced total dosages of dexamethasone, vincristine, doxorubicin, and cyclophosphamide).[<a href="#cit/section_7.77">

987077</a>

9871]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9872<ul id="_2026">

9873<li>

9874Reduced-intensity delayed intensification was associated with an inferior 8-year DFS rate (89% vs. 92%, <em>

9875P</em>

9876 = .04), resulting from an increased risk of relapse.</li>

9877<li>

9878In a subset analysis, for patients with the <em class="gene-name">

9879ETV6</em>

9880::<em class="gene-name">

9881RUNX1</em>

9882 fusion, no difference in outcome between the two treatment arms was observed (8-year DFS rate, approximately 94% for both arms).</li>

9883</ul>

9884</div>

9885</li>

9886<li>

9887Patients who are standard or intermediate risk at diagnosis, but have high levels of end-induction MRD, have been shown to have a poorer prognosis and should be treated as high-risk patients. The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00222612">

9888UKALL2003 (NCT00222612)</a>

9889 trial used augmented postinduction therapy (extra doses of pegaspargase and vincristine and an escalated-dose of IV methotrexate without leucovorin rescue) to treat standard- or intermediate-risk patients with high levels of end-induction MRD.[<a href="#cit/section_7.49">

989049</a>

9891][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9892Level of evidence B1</a>

9893]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9894<ul id="_1912">

9895<li>

9896Augmented postinduction therapy resulted in an increased EFS that was comparable to that of patients with low levels of end-induction MRD.</li>

9897</ul>

9898</div>

9899</li>

9900</ol>

9901</div>

9902</section>

9903<section id="_1086">

9904<h5 id="_1086_toc">

9905High-risk ALL</h5>

9906<p id="_1087" tabindex="-1">

9907In high-risk patients, a number of different approaches have been used with

9908comparable efficacy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.65">

990965</a>

9910,<a href="#cit/section_7.78">

991178</a>

9912]; [<a href="#cit/section_7.72">

991372</a>

9914][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9915Level of evidence B4</a>

9916] Treatment for high-risk patients

9917is generally more intensive than that for standard-risk patients and typically includes higher cumulative doses of multiple agents, including anthracyclines and/or alkylating agents. Higher doses of these agents increase the risk of both short-term and long-term toxicities, and many clinical trials have focused on reducing the side effects of these intensified regimens. </p>

9918<p id="_1121" tabindex="-1">

9919Evidence (intensification for high-risk ALL):</p>

9920<div class="pdq-content-list">

9921<ol id="_1122">

9922<li>

9923The former CCG developed an augmented BFM treatment regimen that included a second interim maintenance and delayed intensification phase. This regimen featured repeated courses of escalating-dose IV methotrexate (without leucovorin rescue) given with vincristine and pegaspargase during interim maintenance and additional vincristine and pegaspargase pulses during initial consolidation and delayed intensification. In the CCG-1882 trial, NCI high-risk patients with slow early response (M3 marrow on day 7 of induction) were randomly assigned to receive either standard- or augmented-BFM therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.54">

992454</a>

9925]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9926<ul id="_1124">

9927<li>

9928The augmented-therapy regimen in the CCG-1882 trial produced significantly better EFS and OS rates (75% and 78%) than did the standard CCG modified-BFM therapy (55% and 66.7%).</li>

9929<li>

9930There was a significantly higher incidence of osteonecrosis in patients older than 10 years who received the augmented therapy (which included two 21-day postinduction dexamethasone courses), compared with those who were treated on the standard arm (one 21-day postinduction dexamethasone course).[<a href="#cit/section_7.79">

993179</a>

9932]</li>

9933</ul>

9934</div>

9935</li>

9936<li>

9937In an Italian study, investigators showed that two applications of delayed intensification therapy (protocol II) significantly improved outcome for patients with a poor response to a prednisone prophase.[<a href="#cit/section_7.80">

993880</a>

9939]</li>

9940<li>

9941The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002812">

9942CCG-1961</a>

9943 study used a 2 &#215; 2 factorial design to compare both standard- versus augmented-intensity therapies and therapies of standard duration (one interim maintenance and delayed intensification phase) versus increased duration (two interim maintenance and delayed intensification phases) among NCI high-risk patients with a rapid early response. This trial also tested whether continuous versus alternate-week dexamethasone during delayed intensification phases affected rates of osteonecrosis.<div class="pdq-content-list">

9944<ul id="_1125">

9945<li>

9946Augmented therapy was associated with an improvement in EFS. There was no EFS benefit associated with the administration of the second interim maintenance and delayed intensification phases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.55">

994755</a>

9948,<a href="#cit/section_7.81">

994981</a>

9950][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9951Level of evidence A1</a>

9952]</li>

9953<li>

9954The cumulative incidence of osteonecrosis at 5 years was 9.9% for patients aged 10 to 15 years and 20.0% for patients aged 16 to 21 years, compared with 1.0% for patients aged 1 to 9 years (<em>

9955P</em>

9956 = .0001). For patients aged 10 to 21 years, alternate-week dosing of dexamethasone during delayed intensification phases was associated with a significantly lower cumulative incidence of osteonecrosis, compared with continuous dosing (8.7% vs. 17.0%, <em>

9957P</em>

9958 = .0005).[<a href="#cit/section_7.82">

995982</a>

9960][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9961Level of evidence A3</a>

9962] </li>

9963</ul>

9964</div>

9965</li>

9966<li>

9967In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075725">

9968AALL0232 (NCT00075725)</a>

9969 study (2004&#8211;2011), patients with high-risk B-ALL received an augmented BFM backbone with one interim maintenance and delayed intensification phase. Only patients with end-induction MRD greater than 0.1% or M2/M3 marrow at day 15 received two interim maintenance/delayed intensification phases. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either high-dose methotrexate or escalating dose IV methotrexate (Capizzi methotrexate) plus pegaspargase during the interim maintenance phase (the first phase only for those receiving two of these phases).[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

99708</a>

9971,<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

997244</a>

9973]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9974<ul id="_1771">

9975<li>

9976The methotrexate randomization was terminated early when planned interim monitoring indicated that high-dose methotrexate was associated with superior outcome. The 5-year EFS rate of patients randomly assigned to high-dose methotrexate was 79.6%, compared with 75% for those randomly assigned to the Capizzi methotrexate arm. High-dose methotrexate was also associated with a superior 5-year OS (<em>

9977P</em>

9978 = .025).[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

99798</a>

9980]</li>

9981<li>

9982Patients with MRD less than 0.01% at end of induction had a 5-year EFS rate of 87%, compared with 74% for those with MRD 0.01% to 0.1%. Those with MRD levels greater than 0.1% fared worse.[<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

998344</a>

9984] </li>

9985<li>

9986High-dose methotrexate was associated with a superior EFS rate in patients with end-induction MRD greater than 0.01% (high-dose methotrexate, 68%; Capizzi methotrexate, 58%; <em>

9987P</em>

9988 = .008).[<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

998944</a>

9990]</li>

9991</ul>

9992</div>

9993</li>

9994</ol>

9995</div>

9996<p id="_1866" tabindex="-1">

9997 Because treatment for high-risk ALL involves more intensive therapy, leading to a higher risk of acute and long-term toxicities, a number of clinical trials have tested interventions to prevent side effects without adversely impacting EFS. Interventions that have been investigated include the use of the cardioprotectant dexrazoxane to prevent anthracycline-related cardiac toxic effects and alternative scheduling of corticosteroids to reduce the risk of osteonecrosis.</p>

9998<p id="_1867" tabindex="-1">

9999 Evidence (cardioprotective effect of dexrazoxane):</p>

10000<div class="pdq-content-list">

10001<ol id="_1868">

10002<li>

10003In a DFCI ALL Consortium trial, children with high-risk ALL were randomly assigned to receive doxorubicin alone (30 mg/m<span class="sup">

100042</span>

10005/dose to a cumulative dose of 300 mg/m<span class="sup">

100062</span>

10007) or with dexrazoxane during the induction and intensification phases of multiagent chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.83">

1000883</a>

10009,<a href="#cit/section_7.84">

1001084</a>

10011]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10012<ul id="_1869">

10013<li>

10014The use of the cardioprotectant dexrazoxane before doxorubicin resulted in better left ventricular fractional shortening and improved end-systolic dimension Z-scores without any adverse effect on EFS or increase in

10015second malignancy risk, compared with the use of doxorubicin alone 5 years posttreatment.</li>

10016<li>

10017A greater long-term protective effect was noted in girls than in boys.</li>

10018</ul>

10019</div>

10020</li>

10021<li>

10022On the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01230983">

10023POG-9404</a>

10024 trial, patients with T-ALL were randomly assigned to receive dexrazoxane or not before each dose of doxorubicin (cumulative dose 360 mg/m<span class="sup">

100252</span>

10026).[<a href="#cit/section_7.85">

1002785</a>

10028]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10029<ul id="_1870">

10030<li>

10031There was no difference in EFS between patients with T-ALL who were treated with dexrazoxane and patients who were not treated with dexrazoxane (cumulative doxorubicin dose, 360 mg/m<span class="sup">

100322</span>

10033).</li>

10034<li>

10035Three years after initial diagnosis, left ventricular shortening fraction and left ventricular wall thickness were both significantly worse in patients who received doxorubicin alone than in patients who received dexrazoxane, indicating that dexrazoxane was cardioprotective. The frequency of grade 3 and 4 toxicities that occurred during therapy was similar between the randomized groups, and there was no difference in cumulative incidence of second malignant neoplasms. </li>

10036</ul>

10037</div>

10038</li>

10039</ol>

10040</div>

10041<p id="_1871" tabindex="-1">

10042Evidence (reducing risk of osteonecrosis):</p>

10043<div class="pdq-content-list">

10044<ol id="_1872">

10045<li>

10046In the CCG-1961 study, alternate-week dosing of dexamethasone during delayed intensification was studied with the goal of reducing the frequency of osteonecrosis.[<a href="#cit/section_7.82">

1004782</a>

10048] Patients with high-risk B-ALL and a rapid early morphological response to induction therapy were randomly assigned to receive either one or two delayed intensification phases. Patients randomly assigned to one delayed intensification phase received daily dosing of dexamethasone (21 consecutive days), while those randomly assigned to two delayed intensification phases received alternate-week dosing of dexamethasone (days 0&#8211;6 and 14&#8211;21) during each delayed intensification phase.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10049<ul id="_1873">

10050<li>

10051For patients aged 10 years or older at diagnosis, those who received two delayed intensification phases (alternate-week dosing of dexamethasone) had a significantly lower risk of symptomatic osteonecrosis (5-year cumulative incidence of 8.7%, compared with 17% for patients receiving one delayed intensification phase with continuous dexamethasone dosing; <em>

10052P</em>

10053 = .001).</li>

10054<li>

10055The greatest impact was seen in females aged 16 to 21 years, who showed the highest incidence of osteonecrosis with standard therapy containing continuous dexamethasone; the incidence of osteonecrosis with alternative-week dexamethasone was 5.6%, compared with 57.6% for those receiving continuous dosing.</li>

10056</ul>

10057</div>

10058</li>

10059</ol>

10060</div>

10061<p id="_1894" tabindex="-1">

10062For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1576">

10063Osteonecrosis</a>

10064 section.</p>

10065</section>

10066<section id="_1089">

10067<h5 id="_1089_toc">

10068Very high-risk ALL</h5>

10069<p id="_1090" tabindex="-1">

10070Approximately 10% to 20% of patients with ALL are classified as very high risk, including the following:[<a href="#cit/section_7.72">

1007172</a>

10072,<a href="#cit/section_7.86">

1007386</a>

10074] </p>

10075<div class="pdq-content-list">

10076<ul id="_1126">

10077<li>

10078Infants younger than 1 year, especially if there is a <em class="gene-name">

10079KMT2A</em>

10080 gene rearrangement present. For more information about infants with

10081ALL, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1152">

10082Infants With ALL</a>

10083 section.</li>

10084<li>

10085Patients with adverse cytogenetic abnormalities, including <em class="gene-name">

10086BCR</em>

10087::<em class="gene-name">

10088ABL1</em>

10089, <em class="gene-name">

10090TCF3</em>

10091::<em class="gene-name">

10092HLF</em>

10093, <em class="gene-name">

10094KMT2A</em>

10095 gene rearrangements, and low hypodiploidy (&lt;44 chromosomes).</li>

10096<li>

10097Patients who achieve CR but have a slow early response to initial therapy, including those with a high absolute blast count after a 7-day steroid prophase, and patients with high MRD levels at the end of induction (week 4) or later time points (e.g., week 12).</li>

10098<li>

10099Patients who have morphologically persistent disease after the first 4 weeks of therapy (induction failure), even if they later achieve CR.</li>

10100</ul>

10101</div>

10102<p id="_1127" tabindex="-1">

10103Patients with very high-risk features have been treated with multiple cycles of intensive chemotherapy during the consolidation phase (usually in addition to the typical BFM backbone intensification phases). These additional cycles often include agents not typically used in frontline ALL regimens for standard-risk and high-risk patients, such as high-dose cytarabine, ifosfamide, and etoposide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.72">

1010472</a>

10105] However, even with this intensified approach, reported long-term EFS rates range from 30% to 50% for some of these very high-risk subsets.[<a href="#cit/section_7.38">

1010638</a>

10107,<a href="#cit/section_7.72">

1010872</a>

10109] The DCOG reported the outcomes of 107 patients with very high-risk features who were treated with three to six intensive chemotherapy blocks in two consecutive trials. Sixty of these patients received an allogeneic HSCT in first CR. The 5-year EFS rate was 73%, and the OS rate was 79% for all patients. With this intensified treatment approach, the cumulative incidence of treatment-related mortality was 12.3%, which was similar to the cumulative incidence of relapse, at 13%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.87">

1011087</a>

10111]</p>

10112<p id="_1091" tabindex="-1">

10113On some clinical trials, very high-risk patients have also been considered candidates for allogeneic HSCT in first CR.[<a href="#cit/section_7.38">

1011438</a>

10115,<a href="#cit/section_7.88">

1011688</a>

10117-<a href="#cit/section_7.90">

1011890</a>

10119] However, there are limited data regarding the outcome of very high-risk patients treated with allogeneic HSCT in first CR. Controversy exists regarding which subpopulations could potentially benefit from HSCT. </p>

10120<p id="_1128" tabindex="-1">

10121Evidence (allogeneic HSCT in first remission for very high-risk patients):</p>

10122<div class="pdq-content-list">

10123<ol id="_1129">

10124<li>

10125In a European cooperative group study conducted between 1995 and 2000, very high-risk patients were defined as one of the following: morphologically persistent disease after a four-drug induction, <em class="gene-name">

10126BCR</em>

10127::<em class="gene-name">

10128ABL1</em>

10129 or <em class="gene-name">

10130KMT2A</em>

10131::<em class="gene-name">

10132AFF1</em>

10133 fusions, or poor response to prednisone prophase in patients with either T-cell phenotype or presenting white blood cells (WBC) &gt;100,000/&#956;L. These patients were assigned to receive either an allogeneic HSCT in first CR (based on the availability of a human lymphocyte antigen&#8211;matched related donor) or intensive chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.38">

1013438</a>

10135]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10136<ul id="_1130">

10137<li>

10138 Using an intent-to-treat analysis, patients assigned to allogeneic HSCT (on the basis of donor availability) had a superior 5-year DFS rate compared with patients assigned to intensive chemotherapy (57% &#177; 7% for transplant vs. 41% &#177; 3% for chemotherapy, <em>

10139P</em>

10140 = .02).</li>

10141<li>

10142There was no significant difference in OS rates (56% &#177; 6% for transplant vs. 50% &#177; 3% for chemotherapy; <em>

10143P</em>

10144 = .12). </li>

10145<li>

10146For patients with T-ALL and a poor response to prednisone prophase, both DFS and OS rates were significantly better with allogeneic HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_7.88">

1014788</a>

10148]</li>

10149</ul>

10150</div>

10151</li>

10152<li>

10153In a large retrospective series of patients with initial induction failure, the 10-year OS rate for patients with persistent leukemia was 32%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

1015440</a>

10155] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10156<ul id="_1541">

10157<li>

10158A trend for superior outcome with allogeneic HSCT, compared with chemotherapy alone, was observed in patients with T-cell phenotype (any age) and with B-ALL who were older than 6 years.</li>

10159<li>

10160Patients with B-ALL who were aged 1 to 5 years at diagnosis and did not have any adverse cytogenetic abnormalities (<em class="gene-name">

10161KMT2A</em>

10162 rearrangement, <em class="gene-name">

10163BCR</em>

10164::<em class="gene-name">

10165ABL1</em>

10166) had a relatively favorable prognosis, without any advantage in outcome with the utilization of HSCT compared with chemotherapy alone.</li>

10167</ul>

10168</div>

10169</li>

10170<li>

10171The AIEOP <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00430118">

10172ALL-BFM-2000 (NCT00430118)</a>

10173 study (2000&#8211;2006) classified patients as high risk if they met any of the following criteria: poor response to prednisone prophase, failure to achieve CR at the end of the first month of treatment, high MRD levels after induction IB (day 78 of therapy), and <em class="gene-name">

10174KMT2A</em>

10175::<em class="gene-name">

10176AFF1</em>

10177 fusion. These patients were allocated to allogeneic HSCT in first CR per protocol on the basis of donor availability and investigator preference.[<a href="#cit/section_7.91">

1017891</a>

10179][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10180Level of evidence B4</a>

10181]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10182<ul id="_1643">

10183<li>

10184The overall 5-year EFS rate of patients meeting high-risk criteria was 58.9%. </li>

10185<li>

10186The 5-year EFS rate was 74% for patients whose only high-risk feature was prednisone-poor response. There was no significant difference in DFS (<em>

10187P</em>

10188 = .31) or OS (<em>

10189P</em>

10190 = .91) when comparing HSCT and chemotherapy for patients with poor prednisone response in whom HSCT was allowed per protocol (those with T-ALL and/or WBC &#8805;100,000/mm<span class="sup">

101913</span>

10192).</li>

10193<li>

10194All other high-risk patients (i.e., those with initial induction failure, high day 78 MRD and/or <em class="gene-name">

10195KMT2A</em>

10196::<em class="gene-name">

10197AFF1</em>

10198 fusion) had EFS rates less than 50%. For these patients, there was no statistically significant difference in DFS between those who received HSCT (n = 66) and those who received chemotherapy only (n = 88), after adjusting for waiting time to HSCT (5.7 months).</li>

10199</ul>

10200</div>

10201</li>

10202<li>

10203On the NOPHO <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00819351">

10204ALL2008 (NCT00819351)</a>

10205 protocol, patients were allocated to HSCT in first CR if they had MRD levels of 5% or greater at the end of induction or MRD levels of 0.1% or greater at end of consolidation. All patients allocated to HSCT received at least three blocks of intensive chemotherapy before HSCT to reduce levels of MRD.[<a href="#cit/section_7.92">

1020692</a>

10207] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10208<ul id="_2292">

10209<li>

10210In the intent-to-treat analysis of 69 patients who met HSCT criteria (10 of whom did not undergo HSCT), the 5-year DFS rate was 78%.</li>

10211<li>

10212 Comparing the patients in this cohort who did and did not receive HSCT, receipt of HSCT was not significantly associated with survival (HR, 1.4; <em>

10213P</em>

10214 = .69).</li>

10215<li>

10216 For patients who underwent HSCT, superior outcomes (better DFS and lower cumulative incidence of relapse) were observed in patients who had nondetectable MRD before HSCT.</li>

10217</ul>

10218</div>

10219</li>

10220<li>

10221In the DCOG ALL-10 and ALL-11 trials, patients with very high-risk features received an intensified treatment regimen that included three high-dose chemotherapy blocks after consolidation. After the three blocks, 60 patients received an allogeneic HSCT, and 22 patients continued with a chemotherapy-only approach, which included three additional high-dose blocks. In these trials, very high-risk disease was defined by any of the following features: morphologically detectable disease at end of induction, high end-consolidation MRD (time point 2), t(4;11), or poor response to a prednisone prophase.[<a href="#cit/section_7.87">

1022287</a>

10223]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10224<ul id="_2568">

10225<li>

10226The 5-year EFS rate was 72.8% for all patients.</li>

10227<li>

10228In a landmark analysis of EFS from the end of the third high-dose chemotherapy block, no difference was observed in the outcomes of patients who received HSCT versus those who received chemotherapy only.</li>

10229</ul>

10230</div>

10231</li>

10232<li>

10233Two retrospective analyses investigated the role of HSCT in first CR for patients with hypodiploid ALL. The studies showed no clear evidence that HSCT improved outcomes when 1) transplanting all patients with hypodiploid ALL, or 2) transplanting hypodiploid patients deemed at high risk on the basis of high MRD after induction. The studies did not examine the strategy of HSCT for persistent MRD after consolidation, nor did they analyze the status of MRD at the time of HSCT. <div class="pdq-content-list">

10234<ol id="_2132" class="lower-alpha">

10235<li>

10236In a study of 306 hypodiploid patients from 16 ALL cooperative groups treated between 1997 and 2013, a subgroup of 228 patients (42 who underwent HSCT) with 44 or fewer chromosomes who achieved remission were analyzed.[<a href="#cit/section_7.93">

1023793</a>

10238][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10239Level of evidence C2</a>

10240] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10241<ul id="_2133">

10242<li>

10243Favorable prognostic factors included a chromosome number of 44 (compared with 43 or fewer), MRD less than 0.01% after induction, and treatment on an MRD-stratified protocol that intensified therapy for patients with higher MRD after induction. </li>

10244<li>

10245After correction for median time to transplant, patients with low MRD who underwent HSCT had a DFS rate of 73.6%, compared with a DFS rate of 70% for those treated with chemotherapy alone (<em>

10246P</em>

10247 = .81). Patients with higher MRD after induction who underwent HSCT had a DFS rate of 55.9%, compared with a DFS rate of 40.3% for those treated with chemotherapy (<em>

10248P</em>

10249 = .29).</li>

10250</ul>

10251</div>

10252</li>

10253<li>

10254The COG published an analysis of 113 evaluable patients with hypodiploid ALL who were treated between 2003 and 2011; 61 of those patients underwent HSCT in first CR.[<a href="#cit/section_7.94">

1025594</a>

10256][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10257Level of evidence C1</a>

10258] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10259<ul id="_2134">

10260<li>

10261The 5-year EFS rate was 57.4% for patients who underwent HSCT and 47.8% for patients in the chemotherapy cohorts (<em>

10262P</em>

10263 = .49). The OS rate was 66.2% for patients who underwent HSCT and 53.8% for patients in the chemotherapy cohorts (<em>

10264P</em>

10265 = .34).</li>

10266<li>

10267Patients with high MRD after induction (&#8805;0.01%) had a very poor EFS rate of 26.7% at 5 years, with no difference between the patients who received HSCT and the patients who received chemotherapy.</li>

10268</ul>

10269</div>

10270</li>

10271</ol>

10272</div>

10273</li>

10274</ol>

10275</div>

10276</section>

10277</section>

10278<section id="_1092">

10279<h4 id="_1092_toc">

10280Maintenance therapy</h4>

10281<section id="_1093">

10282<h5 id="_1093_toc">

10283Backbone of maintenance therapy</h5>

10284<p id="_1094" tabindex="-1">

10285The backbone of maintenance therapy in most protocols includes daily oral

10286mercaptopurine and weekly oral or parenteral methotrexate. On many protocols, intrathecal chemotherapy for CNS sanctuary therapy is

10287 continued during maintenance therapy. Also, vincristine/steroid pulses during maintenance are used by some groups but not others (see <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1099">

10288below</a>

10289). It is imperative to

10290carefully monitor children on maintenance therapy for both drug-related

10291toxicity and for compliance with the oral chemotherapy agents used during

10292maintenance therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.95">

1029395</a>

10294] A protocol conducted by the COG suggested there are significant differences in compliance with oral mercaptopurine regimens among various racial and socioeconomic groups and that level of adherence impacts relapse risk.[<a href="#cit/section_7.95">

1029595</a>

10296,<a href="#cit/section_7.96">

1029796</a>

10298] </p>

10299<p id="_2154" tabindex="-1">

10300In the past, clinical practice generally called for the administration of oral mercaptopurine in the evening, on the basis of evidence from older studies that this practice may improve EFS.[<a href="#cit/section_7.97">

1030197</a>

10302] However, in a study conducted by the NOPHO group, in which details of oral intake were prospectively captured, timing of mercaptopurine administration (nighttime vs. other times of day) was not of prognostic significance.[<a href="#cit/section_7.98">

1030398</a>

10304] In a COG study, taking mercaptopurine at varying times of day rather than consistently at nighttime was associated with higher rates of nonadherence. However, among adherent patients (i.e., those who took &gt;95% of prescribed doses), there was no association between timing of mercaptopurine ingestion and relapse risk.[<a href="#cit/section_7.99">

1030599</a>

10306]</p>

10307<p id="_1095" tabindex="-1">

10308Some patients may develop severe hematologic toxicity when

10309receiving conventional dosages of mercaptopurine because of an inherited

10310deficiency (homozygous mutant) of thiopurine S-methyltransferase, an enzyme that inactivates

10311mercaptopurine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.100">

10312100</a>

10313,<a href="#cit/section_7.101">

10314101</a>

10315] These patients are able to tolerate mercaptopurine only

10316in much lower dosages than those conventionally used.[<a href="#cit/section_7.100">

10317100</a>

10318,<a href="#cit/section_7.101">

10319101</a>

10320]

10321Patients who are heterozygous for the mutation generally tolerate

10322mercaptopurine without serious toxicity, but they do require more frequent dose

10323reductions for hematologic toxicity than do patients who are homozygous for the

10324normal allele.[<a href="#cit/section_7.100">

10325100</a>

10326] Polymorphisms of the <em class="gene-name">

10327NUDT15</em>

10328 gene, observed most frequently in East Asian and Hispanic patients, have also been linked to extreme sensitivity to the myelosuppressive effects of mercaptopurine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.102">

10329102</a>

10330-<a href="#cit/section_7.104">

10331104</a>

10332]</p>

10333<p id="_1131" tabindex="-1">

10334Evidence (maintenance therapy):</p>

10335<div class="pdq-content-list">

10336<ol id="_1132">

10337<li>

10338A meta-analysis of randomized trials compared thiopurines and found the following: <div class="pdq-content-list">

10339<ul id="_2257">

10340<li>

10341Thioguanine did not improve the overall EFS, although particular subgroups may benefit from its use.[<a href="#cit/section_7.105">

10342105</a>

10343]</li>

10344<li>

10345The use of continuous thioguanine instead of mercaptopurine during the maintenance phase is associated with an increased risk of hepatic complications, including veno-occlusive disease (sinusoidal obstruction syndrome) and portal hypertension.[<a href="#cit/section_7.106">

10346106</a>

10347-<a href="#cit/section_7.110">

10348110</a>

10349]</li>

10350<li>

10351Because of the increased toxicity of thioguanine, mercaptopurine remains the standard drug of choice.</li>

10352</ul>

10353</div>

10354</li>

10355<li>

10356In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01190930">

10357AALL0932 (NCT01190930)</a>

10358 trial, NCI standard-risk patients with average-risk features were randomly assigned to receive weekly oral methotrexate during maintenance at one of two starting doses: 20 mg/m<span class="sup">

103592</span>

10360 (standard) or 40 mg/m<span class="sup">

103612</span>

10362 (investigational).[<a href="#cit/section_7.111">

10363111</a>

10364][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10365Level of evidence A1</a>

10366]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10367<ul id="_2344">

10368<li>

10369There was no significant difference in 5-year DFS from the start of maintenance therapy between the two treatment arms (5-year DFS rate, 95.1% for patients who received the standard dose vs. 94.2% for patients who received the investigational dose; <em>

10370P</em>

10371 = .92), indicating no advantage for the higher dose of oral methotrexate.</li>

10372</ul>

10373</div>

10374</li>

10375<li>

10376An intensified maintenance regimen, consisting of rotating pairs of agents, including cyclophosphamide and epipodophyllotoxins along with more standard maintenance agents, has been evaluated in several clinical trials conducted by SJCRH and other groups.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

103772</a>

10378]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10379<ul id="_1451">

10380<li>

10381The intensified maintenance with rotating pairs of agents was associated with more episodes of febrile neutropenia [<a href="#cit/section_7.112">

10382112</a>

10383] and a higher risk of secondary acute myelogenous leukemia,[<a href="#cit/section_7.113">

10384113</a>

10385,<a href="#cit/section_7.114">

10386114</a>

10387] especially when epipodophyllotoxins were included.[<a href="#cit/section_7.112">

10388112</a>

10389]<p id="_1583" tabindex="-1">

10390On the basis of these findings, SJCRH modified the agents used in the rotating pair schedule during the maintenance phase. On the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00137111">

10391Total XV</a>

10392 study, standard-risk and high-risk patients received three rotating pairs (mercaptopurine plus methotrexate, cyclophosphamide plus cytarabine, and dexamethasone plus vincristine) throughout this treatment phase. Low-risk patients received more standard maintenance (without cyclophosphamide and cytarabine).[<a href="#cit/section_7.57">

1039357</a>

10394]</p>

10395</li>

10396<li>

10397A randomized study from Argentina demonstrated no benefit from this intensified approach compared with a more standard maintenance regimen for patients who receive induction and consolidation phases based on a BFM backbone.[<a href="#cit/section_7.112">

10398112</a>

10399]</li>

10400</ul>

10401</div>

10402</li>

10403</ol>

10404</div>

10405</section>

10406<section id="_1099">

10407<h5 id="_1099_toc">

10408Vincristine/corticosteroid pulses</h5>

10409<p id="_1100" tabindex="-1">

10410Pulses of vincristine and corticosteroid are often added to the

10411standard maintenance backbone, although the benefit of these pulses within the context of contemporary multiagent chemotherapy regimens remains controversial.</p>

10412<p id="_1134" tabindex="-1">

10413Evidence (vincristine/corticosteroid pulses):</p>

10414<div class="pdq-content-list">

10415<ol id="_1135">

10416<li>

10417A CCG randomized trial conducted in the 1980s demonstrated improved

10418outcome in patients who received monthly vincristine/prednisone pulses.[<a href="#cit/section_7.115">

10419115</a>

10420] </li>

10421<li>

10422A

10423meta-analysis combining data from six clinical trials from the same treatment era showed an EFS advantage for vincristine/prednisone pulses.[<a href="#cit/section_7.116">

10424116</a>

10425,<a href="#cit/section_7.117">

10426117</a>

10427] However, overall EFS from these trials was lower than is observed with more contemporary regimens.</li>

10428<li>

10429A systematic review of the impact of vincristine plus steroid pulses from more recent clinical trials raised the question of whether such pulses are of value in current ALL treatment, which includes more intensive early therapy and risk stratification incorporating early response (MRD) and biological factors.[<a href="#cit/section_7.117">

10430117</a>

10431]</li>

10432<li>

10433In a multicenter randomized trial in children with intermediate-risk ALL being treated on a BFM regimen, there was no benefit associated with the addition of six pulses of vincristine/dexamethasone during the continuation phase, although the pulses were administered less frequently than in other trials in which a benefit had been demonstrated.[<a href="#cit/section_7.118">

10434118</a>

10435]</li>

10436<li>

10437A small multicenter trial of average-risk patients demonstrated superior EFS in patients receiving vincristine plus corticosteroid pulses. In this study, there was no difference in outcome based on type of steroid (prednisone vs. dexamethasone).[<a href="#cit/section_7.119">

10438119</a>

10439][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10440Level of evidence A1</a>

10441] </li>

10442<li>

10443In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01190930">

10444AALL0932 (NCT01190930)</a>

10445 trial, standard-risk patients were randomly assigned during maintenance to receive vincristine/dexamethasone pulses every 4 weeks or every 12 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_7.111">

10446111</a>

10447][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10448Level of evidence A1</a>

10449] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10450<ul id="_2350">

10451<li>

10452For the randomly assigned standard-risk patients, the 5-year DFS rate from the start of maintenance was 94.6%. There was no significant difference between the every-4-week group and the every-12-week group.</li>

10453</ul>

10454</div>

10455</li>

10456<li>

10457The Chinese Children&#8217;s Cancer Group conducted a randomized noninferiority trial to determine whether vincristine/dexamethasone pulses could be omitted during the second year of maintenance therapy. One year after the initiation of therapy, 5,054 patients with non-<em class="gene-name">

10458BCR</em>

10459::<em class="gene-name">

10460ABL1</em>

10461 fusion&#8211;positive ALL (B-ALL and T-ALL, aged 0&#8211;18 years) were randomly assigned to receive either vincristine/dexamethasone pulses every 8 weeks (seven pulses total) or no pulses during the second year of maintenance chemotherapy. Noninferiority was defined by calculating the one-sided 95% upper confidence bound of the difference in EFS probability between arms to ensure that an EFS decrement of 5% or more was ruled out.[<a href="#cit/section_7.120">

10462120</a>

10463]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10464<ul id="_2432">

10465<li>

10466For low-risk patients (NCI standard-risk B-ALL with high hyperdiploidy or <em class="gene-name">

10467ETV6</em>

10468::<em class="gene-name">

10469RUNX1</em>

10470 and low end-induction MRD), the EFS difference between arms met the protocol definition of noninferiority, indicating that omission of vincristine/dexamethasone pulses during the second year of maintenance did not result in a decrement of EFS that was greater than 5%.</li>

10471<li>

10472For intermediate-risk and high-risk patients, the difference in 5-year EFS between arms did not meet the protocol definition of noninferiority (the 95% upper confidence bound for the difference was 0.055, which exceeded the preset noninferiority margin of 0.05); therefore, it could not be concluded that vincristine/dexamethasone pulses could be omitted in these patients without resulting in an EFS decrement exceeding 5%.</li>

10473</ul>

10474</div>

10475 </li>

10476</ol>

10477</div>

10478<p id="_1103" tabindex="-1">

10479For regimens that include vincristine/steroid pulses, a number of studies have addressed which steroid (dexamethasone or prednisone) should be used. From these studies, it appears that dexamethasone is associated with superior EFS, but also may lead to a greater frequency of steroid-associated complications, including bone toxicity and infections, especially in older children and adolescents.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

104806</a>

10481,<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

104827</a>

10483,<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

1048424</a>

10485,<a href="#cit/section_7.69">

1048669</a>

10487,<a href="#cit/section_7.121">

10488121</a>

10489] Compared with prednisone, dexamethasone has also been associated with a higher frequency of behavioral problems.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

104907</a>

10491] In a randomized study of 50 patients aged 3 to 16 years who received maintenance chemotherapy, concurrent administration of hydrocortisone (at physiological dosing) during dexamethasone pulses reduced the frequency of behavioral difficulties, emotional lability, and sleep disturbances.[<a href="#cit/section_7.122">

10492122</a>

10493]</p>

10494<p id="_1102" tabindex="-1">

10495 Evidence (dexamethasone vs. prednisone):</p>

10496<div class="pdq-content-list">

10497<ol id="_1136">

10498<li>

10499In a

10500CCG study, dexamethasone was compared with prednisone during the induction and maintenance phases for children aged 1 to

10501younger than 10 years with lower-risk ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

105026</a>

10503,<a href="#cit/section_7.69">

1050469</a>

10505]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10506<ul id="_1137">

10507<li>

10508Patients randomly assigned to receive dexamethasone had significantly fewer CNS relapses and a significantly better EFS rate.</li>

10509</ul>

10510</div>

10511</li>

10512<li>

10513In a MRC United Kingdom Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (UKALL) trial, dexamethasone was compared with prednisolone during the induction and maintenance phases in both standard-risk and high-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

105147</a>

10515]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10516<ul id="_1138">

10517<li>

10518 The EFS and incidence of both CNS and non-CNS relapses improved with the use of dexamethasone.</li>

10519<li>

10520Dexamethasone was associated with an increased risk of steroid-associated toxicities, including behavioral problems, myopathy, and osteopenia.</li>

10521</ul>

10522</div>

10523 </li>

10524<li>

10525In a DFCI ALL Consortium trial, patients were randomly assigned to receive either dexamethasone or prednisone during all postinduction treatment phases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

1052624</a>

10527]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10528<ul id="_1543">

10529<li>

10530Dexamethasone was associated with a superior EFS, but also with a higher frequency of infections (primarily episodes of bacteremia) and, in patients aged 10 years or older, an increased incidence of osteonecrosis and fracture.</li>

10531</ul>

10532</div>

10533</li>

10534</ol>

10535</div>

10536<p id="_1340" tabindex="-1">

10537The benefit of using dexamethasone in

10538children aged 10 to 18 years requires further investigation because of the increased risk of steroid-induced osteonecrosis in this age

10539group.[<a href="#cit/section_7.79">

1054079</a>

10541,<a href="#cit/section_7.121">

10542121</a>

10543]</p>

10544</section>

10545<section id="_1104">

10546<h5 id="_1104_toc">

10547Duration of maintenance therapy</h5>

10548<p id="_1105" tabindex="-1">

10549Maintenance chemotherapy generally continues for 2 to 3 years of continuous

10550CR. On some studies, boys are treated longer than girls.[<a href="#cit/section_7.69">

1055169</a>

10552] In other trials, there is no difference in the duration of treatment based on sex.[<a href="#cit/section_7.65">

1055365</a>

10554,<a href="#cit/section_7.72">

1055572</a>

10556] It is not clear whether longer duration of maintenance therapy reduces relapse in boys, especially in the context of current therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_7.72">

1055772</a>

10558][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10559Level of evidence B4</a>

10560] Extending the duration of maintenance therapy beyond 3 years

10561does not improve outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_7.116">

10562116</a>

10563]</p>

10564</section>

10565<section id="_1459">

10566<h5 id="_1459_toc">

10567Adherence to oral medications during maintenance therapy</h5>

10568<p id="_1460" tabindex="-1">

10569Nonadherence to treatment with mercaptopurine during maintenance therapy is associated with a significant risk of relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_7.95">

1057095</a>

10571] A risk model has been developed to predict which patients have a high risk of nonadherence.[<a href="#cit/section_7.123">

10572123</a>

10573]</p>

10574<p id="_1480" tabindex="-1">

10575Evidence (adherence to treatment):</p>

10576<div class="pdq-content-list">

10577<ol id="_1481">

10578<li>

10579The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00268528">

10580AALL03N1 (NCT00268528)</a>

10581 trial studied the impact of nonadherence to mercaptopurine during maintenance therapy in 327 children and adolescents (169 Hispanic patients and 158 non-Hispanic White patients).[<a href="#cit/section_7.95">

1058295</a>

10583]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10584<ul id="_1482">

10585<li>

10586A progressive increase in relapse was observed with decreasing adherence to mercaptopurine, with HRs ranging between 4.0% to 5.7% for adherence rates ranging from 94.9% to 90%, 89.9% to 85%, and less than 85%. After adjusting for other prognostic factors (including NCI risk group and chromosomal abnormalities), a progressive increase in relapse was observed with decreasing adherence to mercaptopurine. MRD data were unavailable in this study population, so they were not included in the analysis of prognostic factors.</li>

10587<li>

10588Adherence was significantly lower among Hispanic patients, patients older than 12 years, and patients from single-mother households. However, among adherent patients, Hispanic ethnicity remained an independent predictor of adverse outcome.</li>

10589</ul>

10590</div>

10591</li>

10592<li>

10593The AALL03N1 trial also included 71 Asian American patients and 68 African American patients, in addition to the non-Hispanic White and Hispanic patients described above.[<a href="#cit/section_7.96">

1059496</a>

10595]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10596<ul id="_1704">

10597<li>

10598Using an adherence rate of less than 90% to define nonadherence, 20.5% of the participants were nonadherers.</li>

10599<li>

10600An adherence rate of less than 90% was associated with increased relapse risk (HR, 3.9).</li>

10601<li>

10602Adherence rates were significantly lower in Asian American and African American patients than in non-Hispanic White patients.</li>

10603</ul>

10604</div>

10605 </li>

10606<li>

10607In a third publication from the AALL03N1 study, the following key observations were made:[<a href="#cit/section_7.124">

10608124</a>

10609]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10610<ul id="_1895">

10611<li>

10612Patients with mercaptopurine nonadherence (defined as mean adherence rate of &lt;95%) were at a 2.7-fold increased risk of relapse compared with adherers.</li>

10613<li>

10614Among adherers, high intra-individual variability in thioguanine levels (due to varying dose-intensity and drug treatment interruptions) was associated with increased risk of relapse.</li>

10615</ul>

10616</div>

10617</li>

10618<li>

10619The authors of the above studies also found that self-reporting was not a reliable measure of adherence, with 84% of patients overreporting compliance with taking mercaptopurine at least some of the time.[<a href="#cit/section_7.125">

10620125</a>

10621] The data suggest that additional measures of adherence besides self-reporting are needed.</li>

10622<li>

10623Another publication from the AALL03N1 study described mercaptopurine ingestion habits, red cell thioguanine nucleotide (TGN) levels, adherence, and relapse risk.[<a href="#cit/section_7.99">

1062499</a>

10625]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10626<ul id="_1979">

10627<li>

10628The findings showed that certain ingestion habits (e.g., taking with dairy and taking at varying times throughout the day) were associated with nonadherence. However, after adjusting for adherence and other prognostic factors, ingestion habits were not associated with relapse risk.</li>

10629<li>

10630For adherent patients, there was no association between TGN levels and ingestion habits.</li>

10631<li>

10632The authors concluded that commonly practiced restrictions surrounding mercaptopurine ingestion do not appear to impact outcome but may hinder adherence.</li>

10633</ul>

10634</div>

10635</li>

10636</ol>

10637</div>

10638</section>

10639</section>

10640<section id="_1106">

10641<h4 id="_1106_toc">

10642Treatment options under clinical evaluation</h4>

10643<p id="_1108" tabindex="-1">

10644Risk-based treatment assignment is a key therapeutic strategy utilized for

10645children with ALL, and protocols are designed for specific patient populations

10646that have varying degrees of risk of treatment failure. The <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_22">

10647Risk-Based Treatment Assignment</a>

10648 section of this summary describes the

10649clinical and laboratory features used for the initial stratification of

10650children with ALL into risk-based treatment groups.

10651</p>

10652<p id="_1107" tabindex="-1">

10653Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

10654NCI website</a>

10655. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

10656ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

10657.</p>

10658<p id="_1993" tabindex="-1">

10659The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

10660<section id="_1109">

10661<h5 id="_1109_toc">

10662COG studies for B-ALL</h5>

10663<section id="_1110">

10664<h6 id="_1110_toc">

10665Standard-risk ALL</h6>

10666<div class="pdq-content-list">

10667<ol id="_1248">

10668<li>

10669<strong>

10670<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03914625">

10671COG-AALL1731 (NCT03914625)</a>

10672</strong>

10673 (A Phase III Trial Investigating Blinatumomab in Combination with Chemotherapy in Patients with Newly Diagnosed Standard Risk or Down Syndrome B-ALL and the Treatment of Patients with Localized B-Lymphoblastic Lymphoma)<strong>

10674:</strong>

10675 This protocol is open for NCI standard-risk B-ALL non-Down syndrome patients and all B-ALL patients with Down syndrome (age &lt;31 years) regardless of presenting WBC. The protocol is testing whether the addition of the bispecific T-cell engaging antibody blinatumomab can improve outcome and whether reducing duration of treatment in boys (from 3 years from the start of interim maintenance 1 phase to 2 years from the start of that phase) will adversely impact DFS. <p id="_2155" tabindex="-1">

10676All patients receive a three-drug induction with dexamethasone (no anthracycline). After completion of induction, patients are classified into one of three groups on the basis of biology and early response measures:</p>

10677<div class="pdq-content-list">

10678<ul id="_2156">

10679<li>

10680Standard-risk favorable: Presence of either <em class="gene-name">

10681ETV6</em>

10682::<em class="gene-name">

10683RUNX1</em>

10684 or double trisomy (chromosomes 4 and 10), day 8 peripheral blood MRD of &lt;1% and day 29 marrow MRD of &lt;0.01%.</li>

10685<li>

10686Standard-risk average: Favorable biology but day 8 peripheral blood MRD of &gt;1% (but day 29 marrow MRD of &lt;0.01%); or presence of double trisomy and day 29 marrow MRD of &#8805;0.01% but &lt;0.1%; or neutral cytogenetics with day 29 marrow MRD of &lt;0.01%.</li>

10687<li>

10688Standard-risk high: Presence of <em class="gene-name">

10689ETV6</em>

10690::<em class="gene-name">

10691RUNX1</em>

10692 or neutral cytogenetics and day 29 marrow MRD of &#8805;0.01%; or presence of double trisomy and day 29 MRD of &#8805;0.1%; or presence of neutral cytogenetics and CNS2 at diagnosis, regardless of early response measures; or presence of unfavorable cytogenetics (iAMP21, <em class="gene-name">

10693KMT2A</em>

10694 rearrangement, hypodiploidy (&lt;44 chromosomes), or <em class="gene-name">

10695TCF3</em>

10696::<em class="gene-name">

10697HLF</em>

10698 (t(17;19)).</li>

10699</ul>

10700</div>

10701<p id="_2157" tabindex="-1">

10702Standard-risk favorable patients will be treated with standard therapy.</p>

10703<p id="_2158" tabindex="-1">

10704All standard-risk average patients will have MRD evaluated at day 29 of induction using high-throughput sequencing (HTS)-MRD assay. HTS-MRD undetectable patients will be treated with standard therapy, while patients with HTS-MRD detectable disease (or if HTS-MRD is indeterminate or unavailable), as well as those with double trisomies and day 29 marrow MRD of &#8805;0.01% to &lt;0.1% will be eligible to participate in a randomization of standard therapy or standard therapy plus the addition of two cycles of blinatumomab.</p>

10705<p id="_2159" tabindex="-1">

10706Standard-risk high patients will be treated with the augmented BFM (NCI high risk) backbone. Any patients with end-consolidation MRD of &gt;1% are removed from protocol therapy. Those with end-consolidation MRD of &lt;0.1% will be eligible to participate in a randomization of either the NCI high-risk backbone alone or this therapy plus two cycles of blinatumomab. Those with end-consolidation MRD of &#8805;0.1% and &lt;1% will be directly assigned to receive NCI high-risk backbone therapy plus two cycles of blinatumomab. </p>

10707<p id="_2160" tabindex="-1">

10708NCI standard-risk Down syndrome patients who meet definition of standard-risk average will be treated in the same way as non-Down syndrome standard-risk average patients, as detailed above. All other Down syndrome patients, including NCI high-risk Down syndrome patients, those with unfavorable biology, and those with high day 29 MRD will be considered Down syndrome-high, and will be nonrandomly assigned to receive two cycles of blinatumomab added to a deintensified chemotherapy regimen that omits intensive elements of the augmented BFM treatment backbone. Omitted elements include anthracyclines during induction and cyclophosphamide/cytarabine-based chemotherapy during the second half of delayed intensification.</p>

10709<p id="_2161" tabindex="-1">

10710All patients, regardless of risk group, will receive the same duration of therapy (2 years from the start of interim maintenance 1 phase). This represents a reduction in treatment duration by 1 year for boys compared with COG standard treatment.</p>

10711</li>

10712</ol>

10713</div>

10714</section>

10715<section id="_1114">

10716<h6 id="_1114_toc">

10717High-risk and very high-risk ALL</h6>

10718<div class="pdq-content-list">

10719<ol id="_1249">

10720<li>

10721<strong>

10722<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03959085">

10723COG-AALL1732 (NCT03959085)</a>

10724</strong>

10725 (A Phase III Randomized Trial of Inotuzumab Ozogamicin for Newly Diagnosed High-Risk B-ALL; Risk-Adapted Postinduction Therapy for High-Risk B-ALL, Mixed Phenotype Acute Leukemia [MPAL], and Disseminated B-Lymphoblastic Lymphoma)<strong>

10726:</strong>

10727 This protocol is open for patients with NCI high-risk non-Down syndrome ALL, any patient with MPAL, and patients with disseminated B-lymphoblastic lymphoma. Patients with NCI standard-risk B-ALL who had steroid pretreatment, CNS3 status, or testicular disease at diagnosis are also eligible for this study. <p id="_2258" tabindex="-1">

10728For patients with B-ALL, the protocol is testing whether the addition of two blocks of inotuzumab ozogamicin to a modified-BFM backbone will improve DFS and whether reducing duration of treatment in boys (from 3 years from the start of interim maintenance 1 phase to 2 years from the start of that phase) will adversely impact DFS. The study also aims to determine the EFS of patients with MPAL and disseminated B-lymphoblastic lymphoma who are treated with a standard high-risk ALL chemotherapy regimen.</p>

10729<p id="_2205" tabindex="-1">

10730All patients receive a four-drug induction (including prednisone and daunorubicin). After completion of induction, subsequent therapy depends on age, biology, and response to therapy.</p>

10731<div class="pdq-content-list">

10732<ul id="_2206">

10733<li>

10734High-risk favorable: Patients who are younger than 10 years with <em class="gene-name">

10735ETV6</em>

10736::<em class="gene-name">

10737RUNX1</em>

10738 fusions or high hyperdiploidy with trisomies of chromosomes 4 and 10 and who achieve an MRD of &lt;0.01% at end of induction will receive a modified-BFM regimen with one interim maintenance phase (high-dose methotrexate), and are not eligible for randomization.</li>

10739<li>

10740Other high-risk B-ALL patients who do not meet high-risk favorable criteria but who achieve an MRD of &lt;0.01% (for NCI high risk) or &lt;1% (for NCI standard risk) by the end of consolidation (EOC) will be eligible for randomization to modified-BFM therapy with or without two blocks of inotuzumab. Patients who are CD22 negative at diagnosis (or have unknown CD22 status) are not eligible to be randomized, and they are removed from protocol therapy.</li>

10741<li>

10742Patients with MPAL and disseminated B-lymphoblastic lymphoma will receive a standard high-risk modified-BFM backbone with two interim maintenance phases, but are not eligible for randomization.</li>

10743</ul>

10744</div>

10745<p id="_2207" tabindex="-1">

10746All patients will receive the same duration of therapy (2 years from the start of interim maintenance 1 phase). This represents a reduction in treatment duration by 1 year for boys, compared with standard treatment. NCI high-risk B-ALL patients with EOC MRD of &#8805;0.01% are removed from protocol therapy and are eligible to enroll on the COG-AALL1721 trial (see above). NCI standard-risk patients with EOC MRD of &#8805;1% are removed from protocol therapy and are not eligible for enrollment on the COG-AALL1721 trial.</p>

10747</li>

10748<li>

10749<strong>

10750<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03876769">

10751COG-AALL1721 (NCT03876769)</a>

10752</strong>

10753 (Study of Efficacy and Safety of Tisagenlecleucel in High-Risk B-ALL End-of-Consolidation MRD-Positive Patients)<strong>

10754:</strong>

10755 This protocol is open to patients with NCI high-risk B-ALL who are aged 1 to 25 years, were in morphological CR at end of induction and have end-consolidation MRD of &#8805;0.01%. The primary objective of the trial is to evaluate the efficacy of tisagenlecleucel (a CD19-directed chimeric antigen receptor [CAR] T cell) as definitive therapy in this patient population, specifically to determine whether the 5-year DFS rate with tisagenlecleucel therapy exceeds 55%.<p id="_2425" tabindex="-1">

10756Patients enrolled on this trial will undergo leukapheresis to collect autologous T cells, which will then be sent for manufacturing of tisagenlecleucel. While awaiting completion of manufacturing, patients will proceed with interim maintenance phase 1 (high-dose methotrexate); this phase may be interrupted as soon as product is available. Once available, patients will then receive lymphodepleting chemotherapy and infusion of tisagenlecleucel. No further anti-leukemic treatment is to be administered after tisagenlecleucel. Marrow samples will be obtained at regular intervals postinfusion, beginning at day 29 after tisagenlecleucel administration to assess disease status; tests of peripheral blood will also be sent to screen for evidence of B-cell aplasia. </p>

10757<p id="_2426" tabindex="-1">

10758Patients must have evidence of CD19-positivity at diagnosis to enroll on trial. Patients with M3 marrow at end of induction, M2/M3 marrow at end of consolidation, hypodiploidy (&lt;44 chromosomes), <em class="gene-name">

10759BCR</em>

10760::<em class="gene-name">

10761ABL1</em>

10762 ALL, or previous treatment with tyrosine kinase inhibitors are excluded from enrollment. </p>

10763</li>

10764<li>

10765<strong>

10766<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03007147">

10767AALL1631 (NCT03007147)</a>

10768</strong>

10769 (Imatinib Mesylate and Combination Chemotherapy in Treating Patients With Newly Diagnosed <em class="gene-name">

10770BCR</em>

10771::<em class="gene-name">

10772ABL1</em>

10773 [Ph+] ALL)<strong>

10774:</strong>

10775 AALL1631 is an international collaborative protocol conducted by the COG and the European EsPhALL group. Patients with <em class="gene-name">

10776BCR</em>

10777::<em class="gene-name">

10778ABL1</em>

10779-like ALL and ABL-class fusions (defined as those involving <em class="gene-name">

10780ABL1</em>

10781, <em class="gene-name">

10782ABL2</em>

10783, <em class="gene-name">

10784CSF1R</em>

10785, <em class="gene-name">

10786PDGFRB</em>

10787, or <em class="gene-name">

10788PDGFRA</em>

10789) are eligible to enroll. These patients enter the trial after completion of the first month of treatment (induction IA) and receive chemotherapy combined with imatinib (pretreatment using imatinib during induction IA is allowed). After the induction IB phase (weeks 10&#8211;12), MRD is assessed by immunoglobulin H/T-cell receptor (IgH-TCR) PCR, and patients are classified as either standard risk (MRD &lt;0.05%) or high risk (MRD &gt;0.05%). Standard-risk patients are randomly assigned to receive one of the following two cytotoxic chemotherapy backbones: <div class="pdq-content-list">

10790<ul id="_2392">

10791<li>

10792The EsPhALL backbone used in previous EsPhALL protocols and COG AALL1122; or</li>

10793<li>

10794A less-intensive regimen similar to those typically administered to non-<em class="gene-name">

10795BCR</em>

10796::<em class="gene-name">

10797ABL1</em>

10798, high-risk B-ALL patients on COG trials.</li>

10799</ul>

10800</div>

10801<p id="_2393" tabindex="-1">

10802Standard-risk patients on both arms will continue to receive imatinib until the completion of all planned chemotherapy (2 years of treatment). The objective of the standard-risk randomization is to determine whether the less-intensive chemotherapy backbone is associated with a similar DFS and lower rates of treatment-related morbidity and mortality compared with the standard therapy (EsPhALL chemotherapy backbone).</p>

10803<p id="_2394" tabindex="-1">

10804High-risk patients will proceed to HSCT after completion of three consolidation blocks of chemotherapy. Treatment with imatinib will restart after HSCT and be administered from day 56 until day 365. The aim is to test the feasibility of post-HSCT administration of imatinib and describe the outcomes of these patients.</p>

10805</li>

10806</ol>

10807</div>

10808</section>

10809</section>

10810<section id="_1075">

10811<h5 id="_1075_toc">

10812Other studies</h5>

10813<div class="pdq-content-list">

10814<ol id="_1139">

10815<li>

10816<strong>

10817<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03117751">

10818St. Jude Total 17 study (TOT17, NCT03117751)</a>

10819</strong>

10820 (Combination Chemotherapy in Treating Patients With ALL or Lymphoma)<strong>

10821:</strong>

10822 <p id="_2201" tabindex="-1">

10823This trial has the following four main objectives: </p>

10824<div class="pdq-content-list">

10825<ol id="_2202">

10826<li>

10827To improve the EFS of provisional standard-risk or high-risk patients with genetically or immunologically targetable lesions or MRD of &#8805;5% at day 15 or &#8805;1% at the end of remission induction, by the addition of molecular and immunotherapeutic approaches including tyrosine kinase inhibitors or CAR T cells/blinatumomab for refractory B-ALL patients, and the proteasome inhibitor bortezomib for those lacking targetable lesions.</li>

10828<li>

10829To improve overall treatment outcome of patients with T-ALL by optimizing pegaspargase and cyclophosphamide treatment, by the addition of new agents in patients with targetable genomic abnormalities (e.g., activated tyrosine kinases or <em class="gene-name">

10830JAK/STAT</em>

10831 mutations) or by the addition of bortezomib for those who have a poor early response to treatment but no targetable lesions, and by administering nelarabine to T-ALL patients with leukemia cells in cerebrospinal fluid at diagnosis or MRD of &#8805;0.01% at the end of induction.</li>

10832<li>

10833To examine in a randomized study design whether the administration of two doses of rituximab to children with B-ALL during early remission induction therapy decreases allergic reactions to pegaspargase.</li>

10834<li>

10835To determine in a randomized study design whether the incidence and/or severity of acute vincristine-induced peripheral neuropathy can be reduced by decreasing the dosage of vincristine in patients with the high-risk CEP72 TT genotype or by shortening the duration of vincristine therapy in patients with the CEP72 CC or CT genotype.</li>

10836</ol>

10837</div>

10838</li>

10839</ol>

10840</div>

10841</section>

10842</section>

10843</section>

10844<section id="_TrialSearch_727_sid_7">

10845<h3 id="_TrialSearch_727_sid_7_toc">

10846Current Clinical Trials</h3>

10847<p id="_TrialSearch_727_22" tabindex="-1">

10848Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

10849advanced clinical trial search</a>

10850 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

10851General information</a>

10852 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

10853</section>

Leukemia 25 (6): 953-9, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21372841&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21372841&amp;dopt=Abstract">

11275[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

11276</li>

11277<li id="section_7.106">

11278Broxson EH, Dole M, Wong R, et al.: Portal hypertension develops in a subset of children with standard risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia treated with oral 6-thioguanine during maintenance therapy. Pediatr Blood Cancer 44 (3): 226-31, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15503293&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15503293&amp;dopt=Abstract">

11279[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

11280</li>

11284</li>

11285<li id="section_7.108">

11286Vora A, Mitchell CD, Lennard L, et al.: Toxicity and efficacy of 6-thioguanine versus 6-mercaptopurine in childhood lymphoblastic leukaemia: a randomised trial. Lancet 368 (9544): 1339-48, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17046466&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17046466&amp;dopt=Abstract">

11287[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

11288</li>

11289<li id="section_7.109">

11290Jacobs SS, Stork LC, Bostrom BC, et al.: Substitution of oral and intravenous thioguanine for mercaptopurine in a treatment regimen for children with standard risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia: a collaborative Children's Oncology Group/National Cancer Institute pilot trial (CCG-1942). Pediatr Blood Cancer 49 (3): 250-5, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16856155&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16856155&amp;dopt=Abstract">

11291[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

11292</li>

11293<li id="section_7.110">

11294Stork LC, Matloub Y, Broxson E, et al.: Oral 6-mercaptopurine versus oral 6-thioguanine and veno-occlusive disease in children with standard-risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia: report of the Children's Oncology Group CCG-1952 clinical trial. 11295[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

11296</li>

11300</li>

11358</div>

11359

11360 </section>

11361

11362

11363

11364 <section id="_576">

11365

11366 <h2>

11367Central Nervous System (CNS)-Directed Therapy for Childhood ALL</h2>

11368

11369 <div id="_section_576" class="pdq-sections">

11370<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

11371<h6>

11372In This Section</h6>

11373<ul>

11374<li>

11375<a href="#_2259_toc">

11376Overview of CNS-Directed Treatment Regimens</a>

11377</li>

11378<li>

11379<a href="#_1376_toc">

11380Intrathecal Chemotherapy</a>

11381</li>

11382<li>

11383<a href="#_1377_toc">

11384CNS-Directed Systemic Chemotherapy</a>

11385</li>

11386<li>

11387<a href="#_1378_toc">

11388Cranial Radiation Therapy</a>

11389</li>

11390<li>

11391<a href="#_1379_toc">

11392CNS Therapy for Standard-risk Patients</a>

11393</li>

11394<li>

11395<a href="#_1380_toc">

11396CNS Therapy for High-risk and Very High-risk Patients

11397Without CNS Involvement<ul>

11398<li>

11399<a href="#_2304_toc">

11400Intrathecal chemotherapy</a>

11401</li>

11402<li>

11403<a href="#_2309_toc">

11404Cranial radiation therapy</a>

11405</li>

11406</ul>

11407</a>

11408</li>

11409<li>

11410<a href="#_1390_toc">

11411CNS Therapy for Patients With CNS3 Disease at Diagnosis</a>

11412</li>

11413<li>

11415CNS Therapy Options Under Clinical Evaluation</a>

11416</li>

11417<li>

11418<a href="#_1381_toc">

11419Toxicity of CNS-Directed Therapy<ul>

11420<li>

11421<a href="#_1382_toc">

11422Acute and subacute toxicities</a>

11423</li>

11424<li>

11430</li>
