11432</nav>

11433<section id="_2259">

11434<h3 id="_2259_toc">

11435Overview of CNS-Directed Treatment Regimens</h3>

11436<p id="_719" tabindex="-1">

11437At diagnosis, approximately 3% of patients have CNS3 disease (defined as cerebrospinal fluid [CSF] specimen with &#8805;5 white blood cells [WBC]/&#956;L with lymphoblasts and/or the presence of cranial nerve palsies). However, unless specific therapy is directed toward the CNS, most children will eventually develop overt CNS leukemia whether or not lymphoblasts were detected in the spinal fluid at initial diagnosis. Therefore, all children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) should receive systemic combination

11438chemotherapy together with some form of CNS prophylaxis.</p>

11439<p id="_741" tabindex="-1">

11440Because the CNS is a sanctuary site (i.e., an anatomical space that is poorly penetrated by many of the systemically administered chemotherapy agents typically used to treat ALL), specific CNS-directed therapies must be instituted early in treatment to eliminate clinically evident CNS disease at diagnosis and to prevent CNS relapse in all patients. Historically, survival rates for children with ALL improved dramatically after CNS-directed therapies were added to treatment regimens. </p>

11441<p id="_1546" tabindex="-1">

11442Standard treatment options for CNS-directed therapy include the following:</p>

11443<div class="pdq-content-list">

11444<ol id="_846">

11445<li>

11446 <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1376">

11447Intrathecal chemotherapy</a>

11448.</li>

11449<li>

11450<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1377">

11451CNS-directed systemic chemotherapy</a>

11452.</li>

11453<li>

11454<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1378">

11455Cranial radiation therapy</a>

11456.</li>

11457</ol>

11458</div>

11459<p id="_1575" tabindex="-1">

11460All of these treatment modalities have a role in the treatment and prevention of CNS leukemia. The combination of intrathecal chemotherapy plus CNS-directed systemic chemotherapy is standard. Cranial radiation is reserved for select situations.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

114611</a>

11462]</p>

11463<p id="_785" tabindex="-1">

11464The type of CNS-therapy that is used is based on a patient&#8217;s risk of CNS-relapse, with higher-risk patients receiving more intensive treatments. Data suggest that the following groups of patients are at increased risk of CNS relapse:</p>

11465<div class="pdq-content-list">

11466<ul id="_796">

11467<li>

11468Patients with 5 or more WBC/&#181;L and blasts in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) (CNS3), obtained at diagnosis. </li>

11469<li>

11470Patients with blasts in the CSF but fewer than 5 WBC/&#181;L (CNS2) may be at increased risk of CNS relapse,[<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

114712</a>

11472] although this risk appears to be nearly fully abrogated if they receive more doses of intrathecal chemotherapy, especially during the induction phase.[<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

114733</a>

11474]</li>

11475<li>

11476Patients with T-ALL, especially those with high presenting peripheral blood leukocyte counts.</li>

11477<li>

11478Patients who have a traumatic lumbar puncture showing blasts at the time of diagnosis may have an increased risk of CNS relapse. These patients receive more intensive CNS-directed therapy on some treatment protocols.[<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

114793</a>

11480,<a href="#cit/section_8.4">

114814</a>

11482]</li>

11483</ul>

11484</div>

11485<p id="_1299" tabindex="-1">

11486CNS-directed treatment regimens for newly diagnosed childhood ALL are presented in <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1300">

11487Table 11</a>

11488.</p>

11489<table id="_1300" class="table-default expandable-container">

11490<caption>

11491Table 11. CNS-Directed Treatment Regimens for Newly Diagnosed Childhood ALL</caption>

11492<colgroup>

11493<col width="28.51%">

11494<col width="9.63%">

11495<col width="61.84%">

11496</colgroup>

11497<THead>

11498<tr>

11499<th>

11500Disease Status</th>

11501<th colspan="2">

11502Standard Treatment Options</th>

11503</tr>

11504</THead>

11505<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

11506<tr>

11507<td colspan="3">

11508ALL = acute lymphoblastic leukemia; CNS = central nervous system; CNS3 = cerebrospinal fluid

11509

11510 with &#8805;5 white blood cells/&#181;L, cytospin positive for blasts, or cranial nerve palsies.</td>

11511</tr>

11512<tr>

11513<td colspan="3">

11514<span class="sup">

11515a</span>

11516The drug itself is not CNS-penetrant, but leads to cerebrospinal fluid asparagine depletion.</td>

11517</tr>

11518</TFoot>

11519<tbody>

11520<tr>

11521<td rowspan="8">

11522<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1379">

11523Standard-risk ALL</a>

11524</td>

11525<td colspan="2">

11526<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1376">

11528</td>

11529</tr>

11530<tr>

11535</tr>

11536<tr>

11541</tr>

11542<tr>

11543<td colspan="2">

11545CNS-directed systemic chemotherapy</a>

11546</td>

11547</tr>

11548<tr>

11549<td>

11550&#160;</td>

11551<td>

11552Dexamethasone</td>

11553</tr>

11554<tr>

11555<td>

11556&#160;</td>

11557<td>

11558L-asparaginase<span class="sup">

11559a</span>

11560</td>

11561</tr>

11562<tr>

11563<td>

11564&#160;</td>

11565<td>

11566High-dose methotrexate with leucovorin rescue</td>

11567</tr>

11568<tr>

11569<td>

11570&#160;</td>

11571<td>

11572Escalating-dose intravenous methotrexate (no leucovorin rescue)</td>

11573</tr>

11574<tr>

11575<td rowspan="8">

11576<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1380">

11577High-risk and very high-risk ALL</a>

11578</td>

11579<td colspan="2">

11580<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1376">

11581Intrathecal chemotherapy</a>

11582</td>

11583</tr>

11584<tr>

11585<td>

11586&#160;</td>

11587<td>

11588Methotrexate alone</td>

11589</tr>

11590<tr>

11591<td>

11592&#160;</td>

11593<td>

11594Methotrexate with cytarabine and hydrocortisone</td>

11595</tr>

11596<tr>

11597<td colspan="2">

11598<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1377">

11599CNS-directed systemic chemotherapy</a>

11600</td>

11601</tr>

11602<tr>

11603<td>

11604&#160;</td>

11605<td>

11606Dexamethasone</td>

11607</tr>

11608<tr>

11609<td>

11610&#160;</td>

11611<td>

11612L-asparaginase<span class="sup">

11613a</span>

11614</td>

11615</tr>

11616<tr>

11617<td>

11618&#160;</td>

11619<td>

11620High-dose methotrexate with leucovorin rescue</td>

11621</tr>

11622<tr>

11623<td colspan="2">

11624<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1378">

11625Cranial radiation therapy</a>

11626</td>

11627</tr>

11628</tbody>

11629</table>

11630<p id="_1322" tabindex="-1">

11631A major goal of current ALL clinical trials is to provide effective CNS therapy while minimizing neurological toxic effects and other late effects. </p>

11632</section>

11633<section id="_1376">

11634<h3 id="_1376_toc">

11635Intrathecal Chemotherapy</h3>

11636<p id="_742" tabindex="-1">

11637All therapeutic regimens for childhood ALL include intrathecal chemotherapy. Intrathecal chemotherapy is usually started at the beginning of induction, intensified during consolidation and, in many protocols, continued throughout the maintenance phase. </p>

11638<p id="_786" tabindex="-1">

11639Intrathecal chemotherapy typically consists of one of the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

116405</a>

11641]</p>

11642<div class="pdq-content-list">

11643<ol id="_787">

11644<li>

11645Methotrexate alone. </li>

11646<li>

11647Methotrexate with cytarabine and hydrocortisone (triple intrathecal chemotherapy).</li>

11648</ol>

11649</div>

11650<p id="_1431" tabindex="-1">

11651Unlike intrathecal cytarabine, intrathecal methotrexate has a significant systemic effect, which may contribute to prevention of marrow relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

116526</a>

11653]</p>

11654</section>

11655<section id="_1377">

11656<h3 id="_1377_toc">

11657CNS-Directed Systemic Chemotherapy</h3>

11658<p id="_743" tabindex="-1">

11659In addition to therapy delivered directly to the brain and spinal fluid, systemically administered agents are also an important component of effective CNS prophylaxis. The following systemically administered drugs provide some degree of CNS prophylaxis:</p>

11660<div class="pdq-content-list">

11661<ul id="_788">

11662<li>

11663Dexamethasone.</li>

11664<li>

11665L-asparaginase (does not penetrate into CSF itself, but leads to CSF asparagine depletion).[<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

116667</a>

11667]</li>

11668<li>

11669High-dose methotrexate with leucovorin rescue.</li>

11670<li>

11671Escalating dose intravenous (IV) methotrexate without leucovorin rescue.</li>

11672</ul>

11673</div>

11674<p id="_789" tabindex="-1">

11675Evidence (CNS-directed systemic chemotherapy):</p>

11676<div class="pdq-content-list">

11677<ol id="_790">

11678<li>

11679In a randomized Children's Cancer Group (CCG) study of standard-risk patients who all received the same dose and schedule of intrathecal methotrexate without cranial irradiation, oral dexamethasone was associated with a 50% decrease in the rate of CNS relapse compared with oral prednisone.[<a href="#cit/section_8.8">

116808</a>

11681]</li>

11682<li>

11683 In another standard-risk ALL trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005945">

11684COG-1991</a>

11685), escalating dose IV methotrexate without leucovorin rescue significantly reduced the CNS relapse rate compared with standard, low-dose, oral methotrexate given during each of two interim maintenance phases.[<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

116869</a>

11687]</li>

11688<li>

11689 In a randomized clinical trial conducted by the former Pediatric Oncology Group, T-ALL patients who received high-dose methotrexate experienced a significantly lower CNS relapse rate than did patients who did not receive high-dose methotrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_8.10">

1169010</a>

11691]</li>

11692</ol>

11693</div>

11694</section>

11695<section id="_1378">

11696<h3 id="_1378_toc">

11697Cranial Radiation Therapy</h3>

11698<p id="_841" tabindex="-1">

11699 The proportion of patients receiving cranial radiation therapy has decreased significantly over time. At present, most newly diagnosed children with ALL are treated without cranial radiation therapy. Many groups administer cranial radiation therapy only to those patients considered to be at highest risk of subsequent CNS relapse, such as those with documented CNS leukemia at diagnosis (as defined above) (&#8805;5 WBC/&#956;L with blasts; CNS3) and/or T-cell phenotype with high presenting WBC count.[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

1170011</a>

11701] Some centers do not use cranial irradiation for any patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1170212</a>

11703]</p>

11704<p id="_2512" tabindex="-1">

11705 In patients who do receive radiation therapy, the cranial radiation dose has been significantly reduced and administration of spinal irradiation is not standard.</p>

11706<p id="_1324" tabindex="-1">

11707Ongoing trials seek to determine whether radiation therapy can be eliminated from the treatment of all children with newly diagnosed ALL without compromising survival or leading to increased rate of toxicities from upfront and salvage therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1170812</a>

11709,<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

1171013</a>

11711] A meta-analysis of randomized trials of CNS-directed therapy has confirmed that radiation therapy can be replaced by intrathecal chemotherapy in most patients with newly diagnosed ALL. Additional systemic therapy may be required depending on the agents and intensity used.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

1171214</a>

11713]; [<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

117141</a>

11715][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11716Level of evidence B1</a>

11717]</p>

11718</section>

11719<section id="_1379">

11720<h3 id="_1379_toc">

11721CNS Therapy for Standard-risk Patients</h3>

11722<p id="_745" tabindex="-1">

11723Intrathecal chemotherapy without cranial radiation therapy, given in the context of appropriate systemic chemotherapy, results in CNS relapse rates of less than 5% for children with standard-risk ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1172412</a>

11725,<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

1172613</a>

11727,<a href="#cit/section_8.15">

1172815</a>

11729-<a href="#cit/section_8.18">

1173018</a>

11731] </p>

11732<p id="_1419" tabindex="-1">

11733The use of cranial radiation therapy is not a necessary component of CNS-directed therapy for these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.19">

1173419</a>

11735,<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

1173620</a>

11737] Some regimens use triple intrathecal chemotherapy (methotrexate, cytarabine, and hydrocortisone), while others use intrathecal methotrexate alone throughout therapy.</p>

11738<p id="_792" tabindex="-1">

11739Evidence (triple intrathecal chemotherapy vs. intrathecal methotrexate):</p>

11740<div class="pdq-content-list">

11741<ol id="_793">

11742<li>

11743The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002744">

11744CCG-1952</a>

11745 study for National Cancer Institute (NCI) standard-risk patients compared the relative efficacy and toxicity of triple intrathecal chemotherapy (methotrexate, cytarabine, and hydrocortisone) with methotrexate as the sole intrathecal agent in nonirradiated patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.21">

1174621</a>

11747]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11748<ol id="_1432" class="lower-alpha">

11749<li>

11750 There was no significant difference in either CNS or non-CNS toxicities.</li>

11751<li>

11752Although triple intrathecal chemotherapy was associated with a lower rate of isolated CNS relapse (3.4% &#177; 1.0% compared with 5.9% &#177; 1.2% for intrathecal methotrexate; <em>

11753P</em>

11754 = .004), there was no difference in event-free survival (EFS) rates.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11755<ul id="_1420">

11756<li>

11757The reduction in CNS relapse rate was especially notable in patients with CNS2 status at diagnosis (lymphoblasts seen in CSF cytospin, but with &lt;5 WBC/high-power field on CSF cell count). The isolated CNS relapse rate was 7.7% (&#177; 5.3%) for CNS2 patients who received triple intrathecal chemotherapy, compared with 23.0% (&#177; 9.5%) for those who received intrathecal methotrexate alone (<em>

11758P</em>

11759 = .04).</li>

11760<li>

11761There were more bone marrow relapses in the group that received the triple intrathecal chemotherapy, leading to a worse overall survival (OS) rate (90.3% &#177; 1.5%) compared with the intrathecal methotrexate group (94.4% &#177; 1.1%; <em>

11762P</em>

11763 = .01).</li>

11764<li>

11765When the analysis was restricted to patients with B-ALL and rapid early response (M1 marrow on day 14), there was no difference between triple and single intrathecal chemotherapy in terms of rates of CNS relapse, OS, or EFS rates. </li>

11766<li>

11767The findings of this trial need to be interpreted within the context of other therapy administered to patients. Dexamethasone, which has been associated with lower CNS relapse rates and improved EFS rates in standard-risk patients in other trials,[<a href="#cit/section_8.8">

117688</a>

11769,<a href="#cit/section_8.22">

1177022</a>

11771] was not used in CCG-1952 (prednisone was the only steroid administered to patients).[<a href="#cit/section_8.23">

1177223</a>

11773] It is not clear whether the results of the CCG-1952 trial are generalizable to protocols that include the use of dexamethasone and/or other CNS-directed systemic therapies.</li>

11774</ul>

11775</div>

11776</li>

11777<li>

11778In a follow-up study of neurocognitive functioning in the two groups, there were no clinically significant differences.[<a href="#cit/section_8.24">

1177924</a>

11780][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11781Level of evidence A3</a>

11782]</li>

11783</ol>

11784</div>

11785</li>

11786</ol>

11787</div>

11788</section>

11789<section id="_1380">

11790<h3 id="_1380_toc">

11791CNS Therapy for High-risk and Very High-risk Patients

11792Without CNS Involvement</h3>

11793<section id="_2304">

11794<h4 id="_2304_toc">

11795Intrathecal chemotherapy</h4>

11796<p id="_2305" tabindex="-1">

11797Approaches to intrathecal therapy have also been studied in high-risk patients.</p>

11798<p id="_2306" tabindex="-1">

11799Evidence (triple intrathecal chemotherapy vs. intrathecal methotrexate):</p>

11800<div class="pdq-content-list">

11801<ol id="_2307">

11802<li>

11803The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02883049">

11804AALL1131 (NCT02883049)</a>

11805 study for NCI high-risk patients and NCI standard-risk B-ALL patients with slow early response (defined by day 8 peripheral blood MRD and/or day 29 marrow MRD) randomly assigned patients aged 1 to 30 years to receive either postinduction intrathecal methotrexate or triple intrathecal chemotherapy (methotrexate, cytarabine, and hydrocortisone). Patients with CNS3 disease were not eligible, and patients on this trial did not receive cranial radiation. Postinduction intrathecal therapy was administered for a total of 21 to 26 doses. Neurocognitive assessments were performed in a subset of patients aged 6 to 12 years at initial diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.25">

1180625</a>

11807]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11808<ul id="_2308">

11809<li>

11810The 5-year postinduction disease-free survival (DFS) rates were 93.2% (&#177; 2.1%) for patients randomly assigned to intrathecal methotrexate and 90.6% (&#177; 2.3%) (<em>

11811P</em>

11812 = .85) for patients assigned to triple intrathecal chemotherapy.</li>

11813<li>

11814 The OS rates were 96.3% (&#177; 1.5%) for patients who received intrathecal methotrexate and 96.7% (&#177; 1.4%) (<em>

11815P</em>

11816 = .77) for patients who received triple intrathecal chemotherapy.</li>

11817<li>

11818There were no differences in the cumulative incidence of isolated bone marrow relapse, isolated CNS relapse, or combined bone marrow and CNS relapse between the two arms.</li>

11819<li>

11820There were no significant differences in neurological toxicities or in assessments of neurocognitive functioning during treatment for patients who received intrathecal methotrexate compared with patients who received triple intrathecal chemotherapy.</li>

11821</ul>

11822</div>

11823</li>

11824</ol>

11825</div>

11826</section>

11827<section id="_2309">

11828<h4 id="_2309_toc">

11829Cranial radiation therapy</h4>

11830<p id="_749" tabindex="-1">

11831Controversy exists as to whether high-risk and very high-risk patients should be treated with cranial radiation therapy, although there is a growing consensus that cranial radiation therapy may not be necessary for most of these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

1183214</a>

11833] Indications for cranial radiation therapy on some treatment regimens have included the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

1183411</a>

11835]</p>

11836<div class="pdq-content-list">

11837<ul id="_800">

11838<li>

11839Patients with T-cell phenotype and high initial WBC count.</li>

11840<li>

11841Patients with high-risk B-ALL and extremely high presenting leukocyte counts and/or adverse cytogenetic abnormalities.</li>

11842</ul>

11843</div>

11844<p id="_750" tabindex="-1">

11845Both the proportion of patients receiving radiation therapy and the dose of radiation administered have decreased over the last two decades. </p>

11846<p id="_801" tabindex="-1">

11847Evidence (cranial radiation therapy):</p>

11848<div class="pdq-content-list">

11849<ol id="_802">

11850<li>

11851In a trial conducted between 1990 and 1995, the Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (BFM) group demonstrated that a reduced dose of prophylactic radiation (12 Gy instead of 18 Gy) provided effective CNS prophylaxis in high-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.26">

1185226</a>

11853]</li>

11854<li>

11855 In the follow-up trial conducted by the BFM group between 1995 and 2000 (BFM-95), cranial radiation therapy was administered to approximately 20% of patients (compared with 70% on the previous trial), including patients with T-cell phenotype, a slow early response (as measured by peripheral blood blast count after a 1-week steroid prophase), and/or adverse cytogenetic abnormalities.[<a href="#cit/section_8.18">

1185618</a>

11857] <div class="pdq-content-list">

11858<ul id="_834">

11859<li>

11860While the rate of isolated CNS relapses was higher in the nonirradiated higher-risk patients compared with historical (irradiated) cohorts, their overall EFS rates were not significantly different.</li>

11861</ul>

11862</div>

11863</li>

11864<li>

11865Several groups, including the St. Jude Children's Research Hospital (SJCRH), the Dutch Childhood Oncology Group (DCOG), and the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC), have published results of trials that omitted cranial radiation therapy for all patients, including high-risk subsets.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1186612</a>

11867,<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

1186813</a>

11869,<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

1187027</a>

11871] Most of these trials have included at least four doses of high-dose methotrexate during postinduction consolidation and an increased frequency of intrathecal chemotherapy. The SJCRH and DCOG studies also included frequent vincristine/dexamethasone pulses and intensified dosing of pegaspargase,[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1187212</a>

11873,<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

1187413</a>

11875] while the EORTC trials included additional high-dose methotrexate and multiple doses of high-dose cytarabine during postinduction treatment phases for patients with CNS3 status (CSF

11876

11877 with &#8805;5 WBC/&#181;L and cytospin positive for blasts).[<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

1187827</a>

11879]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11880<ul id="_830">

11881<li>

11882The 5-year cumulative incidence of isolated CNS relapse on those trials was between 2% and 4%, although some patient subsets had a significantly higher rate of CNS relapse. On the SJCRH study, clinical features associated with a significantly higher risk of isolated CNS relapse included T-cell phenotype, the t(1;19) translocation, and the presence of blasts in the CSF at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1188312</a>

11884]</li>

11885<li>

11886The overall EFS rate was 85.6% for the SJCRH study and 81% for the DCOG study&#8212;both in line with outcomes achieved by contemporaneously conducted clinical trials on which some patients received prophylactic radiation therapy&#8212;but was lower on the EORTC trial (8-year EFS rate, 69.6%).[<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

1188727</a>

11888]</li>

11889<li>

11890On the SJCRH study, 33 of 498 patients (6.6%) in first remission with high-risk features (including 26 patients with high minimal residual disease [MRD], 6 with <em class="gene-name">

11891BCR</em>

11892::<em class="gene-name">

11893ABL1</em>

11894-positive ALL, and 1 with near haploidy) received an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant, which included total-body irradiation.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1189512</a>

11896]</li>

11897</ul>

11898</div>

11899</li>

11900<li>

11901In a meta-analysis of aggregated data from more than 16,000 patients treated between 1996 and 2007 by ten cooperative groups, the use of cranial radiation therapy did not appear to impact 5-year OS or cumulative incidence of any event.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

1190214</a>

11903]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11904<ul id="_1797">

11905<li>

11906In subgroup analyses of high-risk subsets, only those with CNS3 status at diagnosis appeared to benefit from cranial radiation, with a significantly lower rate of CNS relapses (isolated/any) in irradiated patients. However, even within this subgroup, OS rates were similar with or without the use of radiation therapy.</li>

11907<li>

11908This study suggests that cranial radiation therapy may not be an essential component of treatment, even for high-risk patients. However, interpretation is limited by the considerable variation in treatment administered to patients by the different cooperative groups.</li>

11909</ul>

11910</div>

11911</li>

11912<li>

11913The EORTC-58832 trial that was conducted between 1983 and 1989 included patients with medium-risk and high-risk ALL. Patients were randomly assigned to receive or not to receive cranial radiation after intensification and before maintenance therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.28">

1191428</a>

11915][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11916Level of evidence A1</a>

11917]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11918<ul id="_2341">

11919<li>

11920The 25-year EFS and OS rates in the two arms of the trial were similar: the EFS rate was 59.5% and the OS rate was 78.1% for patients who did not receive cranial radiation; the EFS rate was 60.5% and the OS rate was 78.5% for patients who received cranial radiation.</li>

11921<li>

11922 There was a dramatic decrease in the rate of late CNS adverse events in the patients who did not receive cranial radiation therapy.</li>

11923<li>

11924The incidence of second neoplasms was also decreased in patients who did not receive radiation (7.3%) compared with patients who did receive radiation (13%) (HR, 0.43). Meningiomas accounted for the increased incidence of second neoplasms in the cranial radiation group.</li>

11925</ul>

11926</div>

11927</li>

11928</ol>

11929</div>

11930</section>

11931</section>

11932<section id="_1390">

11933<h3 id="_1390_toc">

11934CNS Therapy for Patients With CNS3 Disease at Diagnosis</h3>

11935<p id="_752" tabindex="-1">

11936Therapy for ALL patients with clinically evident CNS disease (&#8805;5 WBC/high-power field with blasts on cytospin; cranial nerve palsies-CNS3) at diagnosis typically includes intrathecal chemotherapy and cranial radiation therapy (usual dose is 18 Gy).[<a href="#cit/section_8.18">

1193718</a>

11938,<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

1193920</a>

11940] Spinal radiation is no longer used. </p>

11941<p id="_804" tabindex="-1">

11942Evidence (cranial radiation therapy):</p>

11943<div class="pdq-content-list">

11944<ol id="_805">

11945<li>

11946The SJCRH, DCOG, and the EORTC have published results of trials that omitted cranial radiation therapy for all patients, including high-risk subsets.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1194712</a>

11948,<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

1194927</a>

11950] These trials have included at least four doses of high-dose methotrexate during postinduction consolidation and an increased frequency of intrathecal chemotherapy. The SJCRH study also included higher cumulative doses of anthracycline than on Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) trials, and frequent vincristine/dexamethasone pulses and intensified dosing of pegaspargase,[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1195112</a>

11952] while the EORTC trials included additional high-dose methotrexate and multiple doses of high-dose cytarabine, during postinduction treatment phases for CNS3 (CSF

11953

11954 with &#8805;5 WBC/&#181;L and cytospin positive for blasts) patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

1195527</a>

11956]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11957<ul id="_1423">

11958<li>

11959On the SJCRH <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00137111">

11960Total XV (TOTXV)</a>

11961 study, patients with CNS3 status (N = 9) were treated without cranial radiation therapy (observed 5-year EFS rate, 43% &#177; 23%; OS rate, 71% &#177; 22%).[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1196212</a>

11963] On this study, CNS leukemia at diagnosis (defined as CNS3 status or traumatic lumbar puncture with blasts) was an independent predictor of inferior EFS.</li>

11964<li>

11965On the DCOG-9 trial, the 5-year EFS rate of CNS3 patients (n = 21) treated without cranial radiation therapy was 67% (&#177; 10%).[<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

1196613</a>

11967]</li>

11968<li>

11969On the EORTC trial, the 8-year EFS rate of CNS3 patients (n = 49) treated without cranial radiation therapy was 68%. The cumulative incidence of isolated CNS relapse for those patients was 9.4%.[<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

1197027</a>

11971][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

11972Level of evidence B4</a>

11973]</li>

11974</ul>

11975</div>

11976</li>

11977<li>

11978A meta-analysis of aggregated data from more than 16,000 patients treated between 1996 and 2007 by ten cooperative groups evaluated whether the use of cranial radiation therapy affected outcome in high-risk patient subsets.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

1197914</a>

11980]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11981<ul id="_1879">

11982<li>

11983In subgroup analyses of high-risk subsets, only those with CNS3 status at diagnosis appeared to benefit from cranial radiation therapy, with a significantly lower rate of CNS relapses (isolated/any) in irradiated patients. However, even within this subgroup, OS rates were similar with or without the use of radiation therapy.</li>

11984</ul>

11985</div>

11986</li>

11987</ol>

11988</div>

11989<p id="_806" tabindex="-1">

11990 Larger prospective studies will be necessary to fully elucidate the safety of omitting cranial radiation therapy in CNS3 patients.</p>

11991</section>

11992<section id="_740">

11993<h3 id="_740_toc">

11994CNS Therapy Options Under Clinical Evaluation</h3>

11995<p id="_761" tabindex="-1">

11996Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

11997NCI website</a>

11998. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

11999ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

12000.</p>

12001<p id="_1994" tabindex="-1">

12002The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

12003<div class="pdq-content-list">

12004<ol id="_836">

12005<li>

12006<strong>

12007<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03117751">

12008SJCRH Total XVII study (TOT17; NCT03117751)</a>

12009</strong>

12010 (Combination Chemotherapy in Treating Patients With ALL or Lymphoma)<strong>

12011:</strong>

12012 Patients receive both intrathecal chemotherapy and high-dose methotrexate without radiation therapy. Certain patients with high-risk features receive intensified intrathecal therapy.</li>

12013</ol>

12014</div>

12015</section>

12016<section id="_1381">

12017<h3 id="_1381_toc">

12018Toxicity of CNS-Directed Therapy</h3>

12019<p id="_754" tabindex="-1">

12020Toxic effects of CNS-directed therapy for childhood ALL can be acute and subacute or late developing. For more information, see the <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_9">

12021Late Effects of the Central Nervous System</a>

12022 section in Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer.</p>

12023<section id="_1382">

12024<h4 id="_1382_toc">

12025Acute and subacute toxicities</h4>

12026<p id="_756" tabindex="-1">

12027The most common acute side effect associated with intrathecal chemotherapy alone is seizures. Up to 5% of nonirradiated patients

12028with ALL treated with frequent doses of intrathecal chemotherapy will have at least one seizure during therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1202912</a>

12030] Higher rates of seizure were observed with consolidation regimens that included 12 courses of intermediate-dose IV methotrexate (1 g/m<span class="sup">

120312</span>

12032) given every 2 weeks with intrathecal chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.29">

1203329</a>

12034] Intrathecal and high-dose IV methotrexate have also been associated with a stroke-like syndrome, which, in most cases, appears to be reversible.[<a href="#cit/section_8.30">

1203530</a>

12036]</p>

12037<p id="_807" tabindex="-1">

12038Patients with ALL

12039who develop seizures during the course of treatment and who receive anticonvulsant therapy should not receive phenobarbital or phenytoin as

12040anticonvulsant treatment, as these drugs may increase the clearance of some

12041chemotherapeutic drugs and adversely affect treatment outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_8.31">

1204231</a>

12043]</p>

12044</section>

12045<section id="_1383">

12046<h4 id="_1383_toc">

12047Late-developing toxicities</h4>

12048<p id="_1889" tabindex="-1">

12049Late effects associated with CNS-directed therapies include subsequent neoplasms, neuroendocrine disturbances, leukoencephalopathy, and neurocognitive impairments.</p>

12050<p id="_1890" tabindex="-1">

12051Subsequent neoplasms are observed primarily in survivors who received cranial radiation therapy. Meningiomas are the most commonly observed second neoplasm and are most often of low malignant potential. However, high-grade lesions can also occur. In a SJCRH retrospective study of more than 1,290 patients with ALL who had never relapsed, the 30-year cumulative incidence of a subsequent neoplasm occurring in the CNS was 3%. Excluding meningiomas, the 30-year cumulative incidence was 1.17%.[<a href="#cit/section_8.32">

1205232</a>

12053] Nearly all of these CNS subsequent neoplasms occurred in previously irradiated patients.</p>

12054<p id="_758" tabindex="-1">

12055Neurocognitive impairments, which can range in severity and functional consequences, have been documented in long-term ALL survivors treated both with and without radiation therapy. In general,

12056patients treated without cranial radiation therapy have less severe neurocognitive sequelae than irradiated patients, and the

12057deficits that do develop represent relatively modest declines in a limited

12058number of domains of neuropsychological functioning.[<a href="#cit/section_8.33">

1205933</a>

12060-<a href="#cit/section_8.36">

1206136</a>

12062] For patients who receive cranial radiation therapy, the frequency and severity of toxicities appear dose-related. Patients treated with 18 Gy of cranial radiation therapy appear to be at lower risk of severe impairments compared with those treated with doses of 24 Gy or higher. Younger age at diagnosis and female sex have been reported in many studies to be associated with a higher risk of neurocognitive late effects.[<a href="#cit/section_8.37">

1206337</a>

12064]</p>

12065<p id="_809" tabindex="-1">

12066Several studies have also evaluated the impact of other components of treatment on the development of late neurocognitive impairments. A comparison of neurocognitive outcomes of patients treated with methotrexate versus triple intrathecal chemotherapy showed no clinically meaningful difference.[<a href="#cit/section_8.24">

1206724</a>

12068][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12069Level of evidence C1</a>

12070] Controversy exists about whether patients who receive dexamethasone have a higher risk of neurocognitive disturbances.[<a href="#cit/section_8.38">

1207138</a>

12072]

12073In a SJCRH study of nonirradiated long-term survivors, treatment with dexamethasone was associated with increased risk of impairments in attention and executive function.[<a href="#cit/section_8.39">

1207439</a>

12075] Conversely, long-term neurocognitive testing in 92 children with a history of standard-risk ALL who had received either dexamethasone or prednisone during treatment did not demonstrate any meaningful differences in cognitive functioning based on corticosteroid randomization.[<a href="#cit/section_8.40">

1207640</a>

12077]</p>

12078<p id="_813" tabindex="-1">

12079Evidence (neurocognitive late effects of cranial radiation):</p>

12080<div class="pdq-content-list">

12081<ol id="_814">

12082<li>

12083A SJCRH study of 567 adult long-term survivors of childhood ALL underwent neurocognitive testing (mean time from diagnosis, 26 years).[<a href="#cit/section_8.39">

1208439</a>

12085] <div class="pdq-content-list">

12086<ul id="_1880">

12087<li>

12088Patients treated with 24 Gy of cranial radiation therapy showed the highest rates of impairment. Up to one-third of these patients demonstrated impairments (defined as test scores 2 or more standard deviations below age-adjusted national norms) in attention, memory, processing speed, and executive function.</li>

12089<li>

12090Significantly fewer patients who had received 18 Gy of cranial radiation therapy demonstrated severe impairments compared with those who had received 24 Gy. In general, there was no significant difference in rates of impairment between nonirradiated survivors and those who received 18 Gy of cranial radiation therapy. However, the 18-Gy group was at increased risk of academic problems.</li>

12091<li>

12092In addition to being dose-related, the neurocognitive impact of cranial radiation therapy was also dependent on age at diagnosis, with higher frequency of impairments in patients diagnosed at a younger age.</li>

12093</ul>

12094</div>

12095</li>

12096<li>

12097A study compared memory impairment in patients who received 18 Gy of cranial radiation therapy (n = 127) versus 24 Gy of cranial radiation therapy (n = 138).[<a href="#cit/section_8.41">

1209841</a>

12099]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12100<ul id="_1881">

12101<li>

12102Long-term survivors who received 24 Gy of cranial radiation therapy demonstrated significant impairments in immediate and delayed memory, compared with survivors who received 18 Gy.</li>

12103</ul>

12104</div>

12105</li>

12106<li>

12107 In a randomized trial comparing irradiated (at a dose of 18 Gy) and nonirradiated standard-risk ALL patients, the following was observed: [<a href="#cit/section_8.33">

1210833</a>

12109][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12110Level of evidence A3</a>

12111]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12112<ul id="_1913">

12113<li>

12114Cognitive function for both groups (assessed at a median of 6 years postdiagnosis) was in the average range, with only subtle differences noted between the groups in cognitive skills.</li>

12115</ul>

12116</div>

12117</li>

12118<li>

12119 In a randomized trial, hyperfractionated radiation therapy (at a dose of 18 Gy) did not decrease neurological late effects when compared with conventionally fractionated radiation therapy. Cognitive function for both groups was not significantly impaired.[<a href="#cit/section_8.42">

1212042</a>

12121]</li>

12122</ol>

12123</div>

12124<p id="_1882" tabindex="-1">

12125Evidence (neurocognitive late effects in nonirradiated patients):</p>

12126<div class="pdq-content-list">

12127<ol id="_1883">

12128<li>

12129In the SJCRH long-term follow-up study of 567 adult long-term survivors, some nonirradiated patients also demonstrated neurocognitive impairments.[<a href="#cit/section_8.39">

1213039</a>

12131]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12132<ul id="_1884">

12133<li>

12134The age-adjusted mean test scores for nonirradiated patients were very similar to that of expected national norms. However, approximately 15% of the nonirradiated survivors participating in this study demonstrated impairments in some domains, including attention, memory, processing speed, and executive function.</li>

12135<li>

12136Despite the impairments noted on neurocognitive testing, overall, the educational attainment and employment status of the tested ALL survivors were similar to age- and sex-adjusted expected proportions using census data for the U.S. population.</li>

12137</ul>

12138</div>

12139</li>

12140<li>

12141In a second study from SJCRH, patients enrolled on Total Study XV (which omitted cranial radiation therapy in all patients) underwent comprehensive neuropsychological assessments at induction, end of maintenance, and 2 years after completion of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.43">

1214243</a>

12143] <div class="pdq-content-list">

12144<ul id="_1885">

12145<li>

12146Neurocognitive function was largely age appropriate 2 years after completing therapy, without evidence of excess impairment on measures of intellectual functioning, academic abilities, learning, and memory. Problems with sustained attention were observed at an increased frequency in this population compared with normative expectations.</li>

12147<li>

12148High-risk patients who received more intensive CNS-directed chemotherapy (including high-dose methotrexate and more doses of intrathecal chemotherapy) were at greater risk of difficulties in attention, processing speed, and academics.</li>

12149</ul>

12150</div>

12151</li>

12152<li>

12153In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00437060">

12154AALL06N1 (NCT00437060)</a>

12155 trial, patients with high-risk B-ALL who had been enrolled in the AALL0232 trial received a neurocognitive evaluation. These patients had been randomly assigned to receive either high-dose methotrexate with leucovorin rescue or escalating-dose IV methotrexate with pegasparaginase during the interim maintenance phase of therapy in the AALL0232 trial. A neurocognitive evaluation, which included an assessment of intellectual function (estimated intelligence quotient [IQ]), working memory, and processing speed, was conducted after the completion of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.44">

1215644</a>

12157] <div class="pdq-content-list">

12158<ul id="_2482">

12159<li>

12160The method of methotrexate delivery was unrelated to differences in neurocognitive outcomes after controlling for ethnicity, race, age, gender, insurance status, and time off treatment.</li>

12161<li>

12162Survivors younger than 10 years at diagnosis had a statistically significantly lower estimated IQ and processing speed scores than older patients.</li>

12163<li>

12164Additionally, patients with public health insurance had significantly lower estimated IQ scores than participants with U.S. private or military insurance.</li>

12165</ul>

12166</div>

12167</li>

12168</ol>

12169</div>

12170</section>

12171</section>

12276Schrappe M, Reiter A, Ludwig WD, et al.: Improved outcome in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia despite reduced use of anthracyclines and cranial radiotherapy: results of trial ALL-BFM 90. German-Austrian-Swiss ALL-BFM Study Group. Blood 95 (11): 3310-22, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10828010&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10828010&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12277[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12278</li>

12279<li id="section_8.27">

12280Sirvent N, Suciu S, Rialland X, et al.: Prognostic significance of the initial cerebro-spinal fluid (CSF) involvement of children with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) treated without cranial irradiation: results of European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) Children Leukemia Group study 58881. Eur J Cancer 47 (2): 239-47, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21095115&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21095115&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12281[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12282</li>

12283<li id="section_8.28">

12284Piette C, Suciu S, Bertrand Y, et al.: Long-term outcome evaluation of medium/high risk acute lymphoblastic leukaemia children treated with or without cranial radiotherapy in the EORTC 58832 randomized study. Br J Haematol 189 (2): 351-362, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31837008&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31837008&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12285[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12286</li>

12287<li id="section_8.29">

12288Mahoney DH, Shuster JJ, Nitschke R, et al.: Acute neurotoxicity in children with B-precursor acute lymphoid leukemia: an association with intermediate-dose intravenous methotrexate and intrathecal triple therapy--a Pediatric Oncology Group study. J Clin Oncol 16 (5): 1712-22, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9586883&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9586883&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12289[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12290</li>

12291<li id="section_8.30">

12292Bhojwani D, Sabin ND, Pei D, et al.: Methotrexate-induced neurotoxicity and leukoencephalopathy in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia. J Clin Oncol 32 (9): 949-59, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24550419&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24550419&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12293[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12294</li>

12295<li id="section_8.31">

12296Relling MV, Pui CH, Sandlund JT, et al.: Adverse effect of anticonvulsants on efficacy of chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. Lancet 356 (9226): 285-90, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11071183&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11071183&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12297[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12298</li>

12299<li id="section_8.32">

12300Hijiya N, Hudson MM, Lensing S, et al.: Cumulative incidence of secondary neoplasms as a first event after childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia. JAMA 297 (11): 1207-15, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17374815&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17374815&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12301[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12302</li>

12303<li id="section_8.33">

12304Waber DP, Turek J, Catania L, et al.: Neuropsychological outcomes from a randomized trial of triple intrathecal chemotherapy compared with 18 Gy cranial radiation as CNS treatment in acute lymphoblastic leukemia: findings from Dana-Farber Cancer Institute ALL Consortium Protocol 95-01. J Clin Oncol 25 (31): 4914-21, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17971588&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17971588&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12305[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12306</li>

12307<li id="section_8.34">

12308Jansen NC, Kingma A, Schuitema A, et al.: Neuropsychological outcome in chemotherapy-only-treated children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. J Clin Oncol 26 (18): 3025-30, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18565888&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18565888&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12309[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12310</li>

12311<li id="section_8.35">

12312Espy KA, Moore IM, Kaufmann PM, et al.: Chemotherapeutic CNS prophylaxis and neuropsychologic change in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia: a prospective study. J Pediatr Psychol 26 (1): 1-9, 2001 Jan-Feb.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11145727&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11145727&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12313[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12314</li>

12315<li id="section_8.36">

12316Copeland DR, Moore BD, Francis DJ, et al.: Neuropsychologic effects of chemotherapy on children with cancer: a longitudinal study. J Clin Oncol 14 (10): 2826-35, 1996.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8874345&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8874345&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12317[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12318</li>

12319<li id="section_8.37">

12320von der Weid N, Mosimann I, Hirt A, et al.: Intellectual outcome in children and adolescents with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia treated with chemotherapy alone: age- and sex-related differences. Eur J Cancer 39 (3): 359-65, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12565989&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12565989&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12321[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12322</li>

12323<li id="section_8.38">

12324Waber DP, Carpentieri SC, Klar N, et al.: Cognitive sequelae in children treated for acute lymphoblastic leukemia with dexamethasone or prednisone. J Pediatr Hematol Oncol 22 (3): 206-13, 2000 May-Jun.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10864051&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10864051&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12325[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12326</li>

12327<li id="section_8.39">

12328Krull KR, Brinkman TM, Li C, et al.: Neurocognitive outcomes decades after treatment for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia: a report from the St Jude lifetime cohort study. J Clin Oncol 31 (35): 4407-15, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24190124&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24190124&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12329[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12330</li>

12331<li id="section_8.40">

12332Kadan-Lottick NS, Brouwers P, Breiger D, et al.: A comparison of neurocognitive functioning in children previously randomized to dexamethasone or prednisone in the treatment of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Blood 114 (9): 1746-52, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19546477&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19546477&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12333[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12334</li>

12335<li id="section_8.41">

12336Armstrong GT, Reddick WE, Petersen RC, et al.: Evaluation of memory impairment in aging adult survivors of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia treated with cranial radiotherapy. J Natl Cancer Inst 105 (12): 899-907, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23584394&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23584394&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12337[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12338</li>

12339<li id="section_8.42">

12340Waber DP, Silverman LB, Catania L, et al.: Outcomes of a randomized trial of hyperfractionated cranial radiation therapy for treatment of high-risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia: therapeutic efficacy and neurotoxicity. J Clin Oncol 22 (13): 2701-7, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15226337&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15226337&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12341[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12342</li>

12343<li id="section_8.43">

12344Jacola LM, Krull KR, Pui CH, et al.: Longitudinal Assessment of Neurocognitive Outcomes in Survivors of Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treated on a Contemporary Chemotherapy Protocol. J Clin Oncol 34 (11): 1239-47, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26858334&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26858334&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12345[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12346</li>

12347<li id="section_8.44">

12348Hardy KK, Embry L, Kairalla JA, et al.: Neurocognitive Functioning of Children Treated for High-Risk B-Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Randomly Assigned to Different Methotrexate and Corticosteroid Treatment Strategies: A Report From the Children's Oncology Group. J Clin Oncol 35 (23): 2700-2707, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28671857&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28671857&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12349[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12350</li>

12351</ol>

12352</div>

12353

12354 </section>

12355

12356

12357

12358 <section id="_1141">

12359

12360 <h2>

12361Postinduction Treatment for Specific ALL Subgroups</h2>

12362

12363 <div id="_section_1141" class="pdq-sections">

12364<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

12365<h6>

12366In This Section</h6>

12367<ul>

12368<li>

12369<a href="#_1142_toc">

12370T-ALL<ul>

12371<li>

12372<a href="#_1144_toc">

12373Treatment options for T-ALL</a>

12374</li>

12375<li>

12376<a href="#_1149_toc">

12377Treatment options under clinical evaluation for T-ALL</a>

12378</li>

12379<li>

12380<a href="#_TrialSearch_1142_sid_2_toc">

12382</li>

12384</a>

12385</li>

12386<li>

12387<a href="#_1152_toc">

12389<li>

12392KMT2A</em>

12414</li>

12417Treatment options under clinical evaluation for adolescent and young adult patients with ALL</a>

12418</li>

12419</ul>

12420</a>

12421</li>

12425<li>

12428</li>

12441ABL1</em>

12442-positive (Philadelphia Chromosome-positive) ALL<ul>

12443<li>

12446BCR</em>

12448ABL1</em>

12449-positive ALL</a>

12454BCR</em>

12456ABL1</em>
