12467</nav>

12468<section id="_1142">

12469<h3 id="_1142_toc">

12470T-ALL</h3>

12471<p id="_1143" tabindex="-1">

12472Historically, patients with T-acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) have had a worse prognosis than children with B-ALL. In a review of a large number of patients treated on Children's Oncology Group (COG) trials over a 15-year period, T-cell immunophenotype still proved to be a negative prognostic factor on multivariate analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

124731</a>

12474] However, with current treatment regimens, outcomes for children with T-ALL are now approaching those achieved for children with B-ALL. For example, the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (DFCI) ALL Consortium reported a 5-year event-free survival (EFS) rate of 81% and an overall survival (OS) rate of 90% for patients with T-ALL who were treated on two consecutive clinical trials between 2005 and 2015.[<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

124752</a>

12476] Another example is the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00408005">

12477AALL0434 (NCT00408005)</a>

12478 trial for T-ALL that resulted in a 5-year EFS rate of 83.8% and an OS rate of 89.5%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

124793</a>

12480]</p>

12481<section id="_1144">

12482<h4 id="_1144_toc">

12483Treatment options for T-ALL</h4>

12484<p id="_2260" tabindex="-1">

12485Treatment options for T-ALL include the following:</p>

12486<div class="pdq-content-list">

12487<ol id="_2261">

12488<li>

12489Chemotherapy with or without prophylactic cranial radiation therapy.</li>

12490</ol>

12491</div>

12492<p id="_2262" tabindex="-1">

12493Evidence (chemotherapy and prophylactic cranial radiation therapy):</p>

12494<div class="pdq-content-list">

12495<ol id="_1179">

12496<li>

12497Protocols of the former Pediatric Oncology Group (POG) treated children with T-ALL differently from children with B-ALL. On the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01230983">

12498POG-9404</a>

12499 protocol, patients with T-ALL were treated using a regimen based on the DFCI 87-001 protocol, which included multiple doses of L-asparaginase and doxorubicin during postinduction therapy, as well as prophylactic cranial radiation therapy. Patients were randomly assigned to either the high-dose methotrexate arm or the control arm.[<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

125004</a>

12501]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12502<ul id="_1180">

12503<li>

12504Patients randomly assigned to receive high-dose methotrexate achieved a superior outcome (10-year EFS rates were 78% with high-dose methotrexate vs. 68% for the control arm).[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

125055</a>

12506,<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

125076</a>

12508]</li>

12509</ul>

12510</div>

12511</li>

12512<li>

12513 In the POG-9404 study, patients were also randomly assigned to receive doxorubicin with or without dexrazoxane to determine the efficacy of dexrazoxane in preventing late cardiac mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

125147</a>

12515][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12516Level of evidence B1</a>

12517]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12518<ul id="_1858">

12519<li>

12520There was no difference in EFS between patients with T-ALL who were treated with dexrazoxane and patients who were not treated with dexrazoxane (cumulative doxorubicin dose, 360 mg/m<span class="sup">

125212</span>

12522).[<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

125237</a>

12524]</li>

12525<li>

12526The frequency of grade 3 and grade 4 toxicities that occurred during therapy was similar between the randomized groups, and there was no difference in cumulative incidence of second malignant neoplasms. Three years after initial diagnosis, left ventricular shortening fraction and left ventricular wall thickness were both significantly worse in patients who received doxorubicin alone than in patients who received dexrazoxane, indicating that dexrazoxane was cardioprotective.[<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

125277</a>

12528]</li>

12529<li>

12530With combined data from three COG trials that randomized dexrazoxane with doxorubicin therapy (P9404, P9425, and P9426) and had a median follow-up of 12.6 years, dexrazoxane did not appear to compromise long-term survival.[<a href="#cit/section_9.8">

125318</a>

12532][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12533Level of evidence A1</a>

12534]</li>

12535</ul>

12536</div>

12537</li>

12538<li>

12539On protocols of the former Children&#8217;s Cancer Group (CCG), children with T-ALL received the same treatment regimens as did children with B-ALL. Protocol and treatment assignment were based on the patients' clinical characteristics (e.g., age and white blood cell [WBC] count) and the disease response to initial therapy. Most children with T-ALL met National Cancer Institute (NCI) high-risk criteria.<div class="pdq-content-list">

12540<ul id="_1181">

12541<li>

12542Results from the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002812">

12543CCG-1961</a>

12544 trial for high-risk ALL, which included patients with T-ALL, showed that an augmented Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (BFM) regimen with a single delayed intensification course produced the best results for patients with morphological rapid response to initial induction therapy (estimated 5-year EFS rate, 83%).[<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

125459</a>

12546,<a href="#cit/section_9.10">

1254710</a>

12548] With this approach, patients with a presenting WBC count greater than 200,000 had similar outcomes to those with a WBC count of less than 200,000.[<a href="#cit/section_9.11">

1254911</a>

12550][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12551Level of evidence B1</a>

12552]</li>

12553<li>

12554Overall results from POG-9404 and CCG-1961 were similar, although POG-9404 used a higher cumulative dose of anthracyclines and cranial radiation therapy for every patient, while CCG-1961 used cranial radiation therapy only for patients with slow morphological response.[<a href="#cit/section_9.10">

1255510</a>

12556,<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

125575</a>

12558] </li>

12559<li>

12560Among children with NCI standard-risk T-ALL treated on the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002744">

12561CCG-1952</a>

12562, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005945">

12563COG-1991</a>

12564, and POG-9404 trials, the 7-year EFS rates were comparable with those of patients treated with the CCG regimens that used significantly less anthracycline in a less intensive chemotherapy backbone without the prophylactic cranial irradiation included in POG-9404.[<a href="#cit/section_9.12">

1256512</a>

12566] However, the patients with NCI standard-risk T-ALL had an inferior EFS and OS compared with patients with NCI standard-risk B-ALL treated with the same regimens on the CCG-1952 and COG-1991 trials.[<a href="#cit/section_9.12">

1256712</a>

12568]</li>

12569</ul>

12570</div>

12571</li>

12572<li>

12573In the COG, children with T-ALL are not treated on the same protocols as children with B-ALL. <div class="pdq-content-list">

12574<ol id="_2277" class="lower-alpha">

12575<li>

12576Pilot studies from the COG have demonstrated the feasibility of incorporating nelarabine (a nucleoside analog with demonstrated activity in patients with relapsed and refractory T-cell lymphoblastic disease) in the context of a BFM regimen for patients with newly diagnosed T-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_9.13">

1257713</a>

12578-<a href="#cit/section_9.15">

1257915</a>

12580]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12581<ul id="_2278">

12582<li>

12583The pilot study showed a 5-year EFS rate of 73% for all patients who received nelarabine and 69% for those patients with a slow early response.[<a href="#cit/section_9.16">

1258416</a>

12585]</li>

12586</ul>

12587</div>

12588</li>

12589<li>

12590The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00408005">

12591AALL0434 (NCT00408005)</a>

12592 trial enrolled 1,562 evaluable patients aged 1 to 31 years with T-ALL. Patients received an augmented BFM regimen and were randomly assigned to receive an interim maintenance phase with either high-dose methotrexate with leucovorin rescue or escalating-dose methotrexate without leucovorin but with pegaspargase.[<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

125933</a>

12594] Intermediate-risk and high-risk patients were also randomly assigned to receive either six courses of nelarabine during postinduction treatment or no nelarabine.[<a href="#cit/section_9.17">

1259517</a>

12596] Nearly all patients received either prophylactic (12 Gy) or therapeutic (18 Gy) cranial irradiation. Only 10% of patients considered to be low risk were not irradiated. Patients assigned to the escalating-dose methotrexate arm received cranial radiation therapy earlier than did patients assigned to the high-dose methotrexate arm (week 8 vs. week 26). Patients on the escalating-dose methotrexate arm also received two additional doses of pegaspargase. Results were as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

125973</a>

12598,<a href="#cit/section_9.17">

1259917</a>

12600]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12601<ul id="_2263">

12602<li>

12603 The overall 5-year EFS rate was 83.8%, and the OS rate was 89.5%. </li>

12604<li>

12605Results indicated a better disease-free survival (DFS) for patients who were randomly assigned to the escalating-dose methotrexate arm (5-year DFS rate, 91.5%) than for patients randomly assigned to the high-dose methotrexate arm (5-year DFS rate, 85.3%; <em>

12606P</em>

12607 = .005).</li>

12608<li>

12609For intermediate-risk and high-risk patients, treatment with nelarabine was associated with a superior outcome (5-year DFS rate, 88.2% with nelarabine vs. 82.1% without nelarabine; <em>

12610P</em>

12611 = .029). The 5-year cumulative incidence of central nervous system (CNS) relapse was significantly lower for patients treated with nelarabine (1.3% vs. 6.9% in the no-nelarabine arm).</li>

12612<li>

12613The best outcome for intermediate-risk and high-risk patients was observed in those randomly assigned to both the escalating-dose methotrexate and nelarabine arms (5-year DFS rate, 91.4%). The worst outcome was observed in patients randomly assigned to receive high-dose methotrexate and no nelarabine (5-year DFS rate, 78.1%).</li>

12614<li>

12615Patients with initial induction failure (M3 marrow at day 29, n = 43) were nonrandomly assigned to receive high-dose methotrexate and nelarabine; 20 of these patients were removed from the protocol therapy to undergo allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) in first complete remission (CR). The overall 5-year EFS rate for induction-failure patients was 53%, with no difference in outcomes between HSCT and chemotherapy.</li>

12616</ul>

12617</div>

12618</li>

12619<li>

12620In the successor COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02112916">

12621AALL1231 (NCT02112916)</a>

12622 trial for T-ALL, patients were randomly assigned to receive or not receive the proteasome inhibitor bortezomib during induction and delayed intensification phases. Patients with initial induction failure (M3 marrow at day 29) or high MRD (&#8805;0.1%) at end of consolidation were nonrandomly assigned to receive three additional intensified chemotherapy blocks postconsolidation. Other nonrandomized changes to treatment included the use of dexamethasone during induction (instead of prednisone) and omission of cranial radiation therapy for all but the very high-risk patients. Because the results of AALL0434 trial were not known at the time that AALL1231 opened, nelarabine was not included in the chemotherapy backbone. The trial was designed to enroll 1,200 patients but closed to accrual early (after 824 evaluable patients had enrolled) once the results of the nelarabine randomization on AALL0434 were released.[<a href="#cit/section_9.18">

1262318</a>

12624]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12625<ul id="_2502">

12626<li>

12627Comparing patients with T-ALL assigned to receive bortezomib versus patients who did not receive bortezomib, there was no difference in the 4-year EFS rate (82.9% vs. 81.5%; <em>

12628P</em>

12629 = .396) or the 5-year OS rate (87.9% vs. 88.3%; <em>

12630P</em>

12631 = .469).</li>

12632<li>

12633Subset analyses were performed comparing similar patients with T-ALL scheduled to receive 12 Gy cranial radiation therapy on the AALL0434 trial (90.8% of patients), but not on the AALL1231 trial (9.5% of patients). Excluding patients who received nelarabine (AALL0434) or bortezomib (AALL1231), the 4-year EFS (<em>

12634P</em>

12635 = .412), OS (<em>

12636P</em>

12637 = .600), cumulative incidence of CNS relapse (<em>

12638P</em>

12639 = .456), and overall relapse (<em>

12640P</em>

12641 = .836) rates were not significantly different between the studies, indicating that the omission of cranial radiation (in the context of the AALL1231 chemotherapy backbone) did not adversely impact outcome.</li>

12642<li>

12643While the 4-year EFS rates were similar between the AALL1231 and AALL0434 trials (<em>

12644P</em>

12645 = .131), the 4-year OS rate on the AALL1231 trial was inferior to that on the AALL0434 trial (87% vs. 90%, <em>

12646P</em>

12647 = .006). </li>

12648<li>

12649While the cumulative incidence of relapse was similar in both studies (<em>

12650P</em>

12651 = .562), there was a higher rate of treatment-related mortality on the AALL1231 trial, compared with the AALL0434 trial (6.1% vs. 2.0%). Rates of treatment-related mortality were higher on the AALL1231 trial during both induction (1.5% vs. 0.4%, <em>

12652P</em>

12653 = .002) and postinduction treatment phases (3.9% vs. 2.1%, <em>

12654P</em>

12655 = .008).</li>

12656<li>

12657Despite intensification of the chemotherapy backbone, outcome was poor for patients with T-ALL assigned to the very high-risk group (5.2% of patients). The 4-year EFS rate was 31.3% for patients on the no-bortezomib arm, compared with 7.8% for patients on the bortezomib arm (<em>

12658P</em>

12659 = .033).</li>

12660</ul>

12661</div>

12662</li>

12663</ol>

12664</div>

12665</li>

12666</ol>

12667</div>

12668<p id="_2264" tabindex="-1">

12669The use of prophylactic cranial radiation therapy in the treatment of patients with T-ALL is declining. Some groups, such as St. Jude Children's Research Hospital (SJCRH) and the Dutch Childhood Oncology Group (DCOG), do not use cranial radiation therapy in first-line treatment of ALL. Other groups, such as DFCI, COG, and BFM, are now limiting radiation therapy to patients with very high-risk features or CNS3 disease.</p>

12670</section>

12671<section id="_1149">

12672<h4 id="_1149_toc">

12673Treatment options under clinical evaluation for T-ALL</h4>

12674<p id="_1150" tabindex="-1">

12675Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

12676NCI website</a>

12677. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

12678ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

12679.</p>

12680</section>

12681<section id="_TrialSearch_1142_sid_2">

12682<h4 id="_TrialSearch_1142_sid_2_toc">

12683Current Clinical Trials</h4>

12684<p id="_TrialSearch_1142_22" tabindex="-1">

12685Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

12686advanced clinical trial search</a>

12687 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

12688General information</a>

12689 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

12690</section>

12691</section>

12692<section id="_1152">

12693<h3 id="_1152_toc">

12694Infants With ALL</h3>

12695<p id="_1153" tabindex="-1">

12696Infant ALL is uncommon, representing approximately 2% to 4% of cases of childhood ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_9.19">

1269719</a>

12698] Because of their distinctive biological characteristics and their high risk of

12699leukemia recurrence, infants with ALL are treated on protocols specifically

12700designed for this patient population. Common therapeutic themes of the intensive chemotherapy regimens used to treat infants with ALL are the inclusion of postinduction intensification courses with high doses of cytarabine and methotrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

1270120</a>

12702-<a href="#cit/section_9.23">

1270323</a>

12704]</p>

12705<p id="_1914" tabindex="-1">

12706Infants diagnosed within the first few months of life have a particularly poor outcome. In one study, patients diagnosed within 1 month of birth had a 2-year OS rate of 20%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.24">

1270724</a>

12708][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12709Level of evidence B4</a>

12710] In another study, the 5-year EFS rate for infants diagnosed at younger than 90 days was 16%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

1271122</a>

12712][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12713Level of evidence B4</a>

12714] </p>

12715<p id="_1391" tabindex="-1">

12716For infants with <em class="gene-name">

12717KMT2A</em>

12718 gene rearrangements, the EFS rates at 4 to 5 years continue to be in the 35% range.[<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

1271920</a>

12720-<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

1272122</a>

12722,<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

1272325</a>

12724,<a href="#cit/section_9.26">

1272526</a>

12726][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12727Level of evidence B4</a>

12728] Factors predicting poor outcome for infants with <em class="gene-name">

12729KMT2A</em>

12730 rearrangements include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

1273121</a>

12732,<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

1273322</a>

12734]; [<a href="#cit/section_9.27">

1273527</a>

12736][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12737Level of evidence C2</a>

12738]; [<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

1273928</a>

12740][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12741Level of evidence B4</a>

12742]</p>

12743<div class="pdq-content-list">

12744<ul id="_1184">

12745<li>

12746Younger age at diagnosis (&#8804;90&#8211;180 days).</li>

12747<li>

12748Extremely high presenting leukocyte count (&#8805;200,000&#8211;300,000/&#956;L).</li>

12749<li>

12750Poor early response, as reflected by a poor response to a prednisone prophase or high levels of minimal residual disease (MRD) at the end of induction and consolidation phases of treatment.</li>

12751</ul>

12752</div>

12753<p id="_2480" tabindex="-1">

12754In addition to having a significantly higher relapse rate than older children with ALL, infant patients more frequently present with a higher acuity. In a large retrospective study, infants with ALL were more likely to present with multisystem organ failure than noninfants (12% and 1%). Infants also had greater requirements for blood products, diuretics, supplemental oxygen, and mechanical ventilation during induction, compared with noninfants.[<a href="#cit/section_9.29">

1275529</a>

12756]</p>

12757<p id="_1710" tabindex="-1">

12758Infants are also at higher risk of developing treatment-related toxicity, especially infection. With current treatment approaches for this population, treatment-related mortality has been reported to occur in about 10% of infants, a rate that is much higher than the rate in older children with ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

1275921</a>

12760,<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

1276122</a>

12762] On the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00557193">

12763AALL0631 (NCT00557193)</a>

12764 trial, an intensified induction regimen resulted in an induction death rate of 15.4% (4 of 26 patients). The trial was subsequently amended to include a less-intensive induction and enhanced supportive care guidelines, resulting in a significantly lower induction death rate (1.6%; 2 of 123 patients) and significantly higher CR rate (94% vs. 68% with the previous, more intensified induction regimen).[<a href="#cit/section_9.30">

1276530</a>

12766]</p>

12767<section id="_1154">

12768<h4 id="_1154_toc">

12769Treatment options for infants with <em class="gene-name">

12770KMT2A</em>

12771 rearrangements</h4>

12772<p id="_1155" tabindex="-1">

12773Infants with <em class="gene-name">

12774KMT2A</em>

12775 gene rearrangements are generally treated on intensified chemotherapy regimens using agents not typically incorporated into frontline therapy for older children with ALL. However, despite these intensified approaches, EFS rates remain poor for these patients.</p>

12776<p id="_1186" tabindex="-1">

12777Evidence (intensified chemotherapy regimens for infants with <em class="gene-name">

12778KMT2A</em>

12779 rearrangements):</p>

12780<div class="pdq-content-list">

12781<ol id="_1187">

12782<li>

12783The international Interfant-99 trial used a cytarabine-intensive chemotherapy regimen, with increased exposure to both low- and high-dose cytarabine during the first few months of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

1278421</a>

12785]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12786<ul id="_2279">

12787<li>

12788The 5-year EFS rate was 37% for infants with <em class="gene-name">

12789KMT2A</em>

12790 rearrangements.</li>

12791</ul>

12792</div>

12793</li>

12794<li>

12795The COG tested intensification of therapy with a regimen that included multiple doses of high-dose methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and etoposide.[<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

1279620</a>

12797]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12798<ul id="_2280">

12799<li>

12800The 5-year EFS rate was 34% for infants with <em class="gene-name">

12801KMT2A</em>

12802 rearrangements.</li>

12803</ul>

12804</div>

12805</li>

12806<li>

12807On the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002756">

12808P9407 (NCT00002756)</a>

12809 trial, infants were treated with a shortened (46-week) intensive chemotherapy regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

1281022</a>

12811][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12812Level of evidence B4</a>

12813]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12814<ul id="_2281">

12815<li>

12816 The 5-year EFS rate was 36% for infants with <em class="gene-name">

12817KMT2A</em>

12818 rearrangements.</li>

12819</ul>

12820</div>

12821</li>

12822<li>

12823The international Interfant-06 study tested whether acute myeloid leukemia (AML)-style consolidation chemotherapy was superior to ALL-style chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

1282428</a>

12825][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12826Level of evidence B4</a>

12827] <div class="pdq-content-list">

12828<ul id="_2143">

12829<li>

12830The 6-year EFS rate was 46.1%, and the OS rate was 58.2%. These rates were not statistically different from the rates observed in the predecessor Interfant-99 protocol.</li>

12831<li>

12832For infants with <em class="gene-name">

12833KMT2A</em>

12834 rearrangements, the 6-year EFS rate was 36.4%, with no significant difference between the AML and ALL approach.</li>

12835<li>

12836In a subsequent analysis of the subset of <em class="gene-name">

12837KMT2A</em>

12838-rearranged patients in whom MRD was evaluated, both end-of-induction (EOI) and end-of-consolidation (EOC) MRD were strongly predictive of outcome. Patients who were EOI MRD positive, but became EOC MRD negative, had similar outcomes to those who were EOI MRD negative (6-year DFS rates, 65.7% and 72.0%, respectively). Patients with high EOC MRD had dismal outcomes (6-year DFS rate, 13.1%). Patients with negative EOI MRD had a higher 6-year DFS rate when treated with the ALL approach (78.2%) than did patients who were treated with the AML approach (45%). However, patients with high EOI MRD (&#8805;5 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

12839-4</span>

12840) who were treated with an AML approach had a superior 6-year DFS rate (45.9%) when compared with patients who were treated with the ALL approach (23.2%).[<a href="#cit/section_9.31">

1284131</a>

12842][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12843Level of evidence B1</a>

12844]</li>

12845</ul>

12846</div>

12847</li>

12848<li>

12849On the MLL-10 trial conducted by the Japanese Pediatric Leukemia/Lymphoma Study Group (JPLSG), infants with <em class="gene-name">

12850KMT2A</em>

12851 rearrangements were treated with an intensified chemotherapy backbone that included multiple phases using high-dose methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and high-dose cytarabine. Patients classified as high-risk on the basis of age and CNS status (75% of <em class="gene-name">

12852KMT2A</em>

12853-rearranged patients) were allocated to HSCT in first CR.[<a href="#cit/section_9.23">

1285423</a>

12855]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12856<ul id="_2323">

12857<li>

12858The 5-year EFS rate was 66%, and the 5-year OS rate was 82%.</li>

12859</ul>

12860</div>

12861</li>

12862<li>

12863In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00557193">

12864AALL0631 (NCT00557193)</a>

12865 trial, infants with <em class="gene-name">

12866KMT2A</em>

12867-rearranged ALL were assigned to receive an intensive chemotherapy regimen with or without lestaurtinib, an FLT3 inhibitor (administered during postinduction treatment phases).[<a href="#cit/section_9.26">

1286826</a>

12869]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12870<ul id="_2445">

12871<li>

12872 The overall 5-year EFS rate for all participants was 34%, and the 5-year OS rate was 41%. </li>

12873<li>

12874There was no difference in outcome between patients on the lestaurtinib arm versus those who received chemotherapy only. </li>

12875</ul>

12876</div>

12877<p id="_2446" tabindex="-1">

12878Exploratory studies were conducted to evaluate the impact of sufficient lestaurtinib blood levels to achieve FLT3 inhibition and to evaluate the impact of ex vivo sensitivity of leukemia cells to lestaurtinib.</p>

12879<div class="pdq-content-list">

12880<ul id="_2447">

12881<li>

12882Only 38% of lestaurtinib-treated patients demonstrated in vivo FLT3 inhibition. This subset of patients appeared to have a better outcome than other patients on the lestaurtinib arm, as did those whose blasts demonstrated ex vivo sensitivity to FLT3 inhibition.</li>

12883</ul>

12884</div>

12885</li>

12886</ol>

12887</div>

12888<p id="_1156" tabindex="-1">

12889The role of allogeneic HSCT during first remission in infants with <em class="gene-name">

12890KMT2A</em>

12891 gene rearrangements remains controversial. </p>

12892<p id="_1188" tabindex="-1">

12893Evidence (allogeneic HSCT in first remission for infants with <em class="gene-name">

12894KMT2A</em>

12895 rearrangements):</p>

12896<div class="pdq-content-list">

12897<ol id="_1189">

12898<li>

12899On a trial conducted by the JPLSG between 1998 and 2002, all infants with <em class="gene-name">

12900KMT2A</em>

12901 rearrangements were intended to proceed to allogeneic HSCT from the best available donor (related, unrelated, or umbilical cord) 3 to 5 months after diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_9.32">

1290232</a>

12903]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12904<ul id="_1190">

12905<li>

12906The 3-year EFS rate for all enrolled infants was 44%. This outcome resulted, in part, from the high frequency of early relapses, even with intensive chemotherapy. Of the 41 infants with <em class="gene-name">

12907KMT2A</em>

12908 rearrangements on that study who achieved CR, 11 infants (27%) relapsed before proceeding to transplant.</li>

12909</ul>

12910</div>

12911</li>

12912<li>

12913In a follow-up trial conducted by the JPLSG between 2011 and 2015, allocation to HSCT in first CR was restricted to the patients with <em class="gene-name">

12914KMT2A</em>

12915 rearrangements and classified as high risk (age &lt;6 months and/or CNS3 status at diagnosis).[<a href="#cit/section_9.23">

1291623</a>

12917]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12918<ul id="_2324">

12919<li>

12920 Of the 56 patients that were classified as high risk (75% of all <em class="gene-name">

12921KMT2A</em>

12922-rearranged patients enrolled on the trial), 49 achieved CR, and 38 underwent HSCT.</li>

12923<li>

12924 In an intent-to-treat analysis of all high-risk patients enrolled on the trial, the 5-year EFS rate was 56.6%.</li>

12925<li>

12926 For the subset of patients who also met Interfant-06 criteria for high risk (age &lt;6 months and WBC &gt;300,000/&#181;L or a prednisolone poor responder), the 5-year EFS rate was 45.2%.</li>

12927</ul>

12928</div>

12929</li>

12930<li>

12931 In a COG report that included 189 infants treated on CCG or POG infant ALL protocols between 1996 and 2000, there was no difference in EFS between patients who underwent HSCT in first CR and those who received chemotherapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.33">

1293233</a>

12933]</li>

12934<li>

12935The Interfant clinical trials group, after adjusting for waiting time to transplantation, also did not observe any difference in DFS in high-risk infants (defined by prednisone response) with <em class="gene-name">

12936KMT2A</em>

12937 rearrangements treated on the Interfant-99 trial with either allogeneic HSCT in first CR or chemotherapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

1293821</a>

12939]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12940<ul id="_1191">

12941<li>

12942 In a subset analysis from the same trial, allogeneic HSCT in first remission was associated with a significantly better DFS for infants with <em class="gene-name">

12943KMT2A</em>

12944 rearrangements who were younger than 6 months at diagnosis and had either a poor prednisone response at day 8 or leukocyte counts of at least 300,000/&#181;L.[<a href="#cit/section_9.34">

1294534</a>

12946] In this subset, HSCT in first remission was associated with a 64% reduction in the risk of failure resulting from relapse or death compared with chemotherapy alone.</li>

12947</ul>

12948</div>

12949</li>

12950<li>

12951On the Interfant-06 study, infants considered to be high risk (all of the following: <em class="gene-name">

12952KMT2A</em>

12953 rearrangements, age &lt;6 months, and WBC &#8805;300,000/&#956;L) were considered eligible for allogeneic HSCT in first CR.[<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

1295428</a>

12955][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

12956Level of evidence B4</a>

12957] <div class="pdq-content-list">

12958<ul id="_2144">

12959<li>

12960About one-half of the high-risk patients did not proceed to transplant in the first CR primarily because of early relapse.</li>

12961<li>

12962The 6-year EFS rate of the entire high-risk group was 21%.</li>

12963<li>

12964For the highly-selected population who underwent HSCT, the 4-year DFS rate was 44%.</li>

12965</ul>

12966</div>

12967</li>

12968</ol>

12969</div>

12970<p id="_2265" tabindex="-1">

12971For infants with ALL who undergo transplantation in first CR, outcomes appear to be similar with non&#8211;total-body irradiation (TBI) regimens and TBI-based regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_9.33">

1297233</a>

12973,<a href="#cit/section_9.35">

1297435</a>

12975]</p>

12976</section>

12977<section id="_1192">

12978<h4 id="_1192_toc">

12979Treatment options for infants without <em class="gene-name">

12980KMT2A</em>

12981 rearrangements</h4>

12982<p id="_1193" tabindex="-1">

12983The optimal treatment for infants without <em class="gene-name">

12984KMT2A</em>

12985 rearrangements also remains unclear, in part because of the paucity of data on the use of standard ALL regimens used in older children.</p>

12986<div class="pdq-content-list">

12987<ol id="_1194">

12988<li>

12989On the Interfant-99 trial, patients without <em class="gene-name">

12990KMT2A</em>

12991 rearrangements achieved a relatively favorable outcome with the cytarabine-intensive treatment regimen (4-year EFS rate, 74%).[<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

1299221</a>

12993]</li>

12994<li>

12995The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002756">

12996P9407 (NCT00002756)</a>

12997 trial of intensified chemotherapy reported a 5-year EFS rate of 70% in infants without the <em class="gene-name">

12998KMT2A</em>

12999 rearrangement.[<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

1300022</a>

13001][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13002Level of evidence B4</a>

13003]</li>

13004<li>

13005A favorable outcome for this subset of patients was obtained in a Japanese study using therapy comparable to that used to treat older children with ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

1300625</a>

13007] However, that study was limited by small numbers (n = 22) and a highly unusual sex distribution (91% males).</li>

13008<li>

13009On the Interfant-06 study, the 6-year EFS rate for infants without <em class="gene-name">

13010KMT2A</em>

13011 rearrangements was 73.9%, and the OS rate was 87.2%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.36">

1301236</a>

13013]; [<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

1301428</a>

13015][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13016Level of evidence B4</a>

13017]</li>

13018<li>

13019On the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00557193">

13020AALL0631 (NCT00557193)</a>

13021 study, infants without <em class="gene-name">

13022KMT2A</em>

13023 rearrangements received the same intensified chemotherapy backbone as those with the <em class="gene-name">

13024KMT2A</em>

13025 rearrangement.[<a href="#cit/section_9.37">

1302637</a>

13027]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13028<ul id="_2531">

13029<li>

13030The 5-year EFS rate was 87.3% (&#177; 4.7%), and the 5-year OS rate was 93.6% (&#177; 3.5%) for 64 infants without <em class="gene-name">

13031KMT2A</em>

13032 rearrangements.</li>

13033</ul>

13034</div>

13035</li>

13036</ol>

13037</div>

13038</section>

13039<section id="_1158">

13040<h4 id="_1158_toc">

13041Treatment options under clinical evaluation for infants with ALL</h4>

13042<p id="_1159" tabindex="-1">

13043Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

13044NCI website</a>

13045. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

13046ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

13047.</p>

13048</section>

13049</section>

13050<section id="_1161">

13051<h3 id="_1161_toc">

13052Adolescents and Young Adults With ALL</h3>

13053<p id="_1517" tabindex="-1">

13054Adolescents and young adults with ALL have been recognized as high risk for decades. Outcomes for this age group are inferior in almost all studies of treatment compared with children younger than 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_9.38">

1305538</a>

13056-<a href="#cit/section_9.40">

1305740</a>

13058] The reasons for this difference include more frequent presentation of adverse prognostic factors at diagnosis, including the following: </p>

13059<div class="pdq-content-list">

13060<ul id="_1518">

13061<li>

13062T-cell immunophenotype.</li>

13063<li>

13064<em class="gene-name">

13065BCR</em>

13066::<em class="gene-name">

13067ABL1</em>

13068 and <em class="gene-name">

13069BCR</em>

13070::<em class="gene-name">

13071ABL1</em>

13072-like disease.</li>

13073<li>

13074 Lower incidence of favorable cytogenetic abnormalities.</li>

13075</ul>

13076</div>

13077<p id="_1519" tabindex="-1">

13078In addition to more frequent adverse prognostic factors, patients in this age group have higher rates of treatment-related mortality [<a href="#cit/section_9.39">

1307939</a>

13080-<a href="#cit/section_9.42">

1308142</a>

13082] and nonadherence to therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.41">

1308341</a>

13084,<a href="#cit/section_9.43">

1308543</a>

13086]</p>

13087<section id="_1303">

13088<h4 id="_1303_toc">

13089Treatment options for adolescents and young adults with ALL</h4>

13090<p id="_1421" tabindex="-1">

13091Studies from the United States and France were among the first to identify the difference in outcome based on treatment regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_9.44">

1309244</a>

13093] Other studies have confirmed that older adolescent and young adult patients fare better on pediatric rather than adult regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_9.44">

1309444</a>

13095-<a href="#cit/section_9.52">

1309652</a>

13097]; [<a href="#cit/section_9.53">

1309853</a>

13099][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13100Level of evidence B4</a>

13101] These study results are summarized in <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1429">

13102Table 12</a>

13103.</p>

13104<p id="_1422" tabindex="-1">

13105Given the relatively favorable outcome that can be obtained in these patients with chemotherapy regimens used for high-risk pediatric ALL, there is no role for the routine use of allogeneic HSCT for adolescents and young adults with ALL in first remission.[<a href="#cit/section_9.40">

1310640</a>

13107]</p>

13108<p id="_1196" tabindex="-1">

13109Evidence (use of a pediatric treatment regimen for adolescents and young adults with ALL):</p>

13110<div class="pdq-content-list">

13111<ol id="_1197">

13112<li>

13113The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00558519">

13114CALGB-10403 (NCT00558519)</a>

13115 trial prospectively studied the feasibility and efficacy of using a pediatric treatment regimen (administered by medical oncologists) for adolescent and young adult patients with newly diagnosed ALL. Of the 318 patients enrolled, 295 were eligible and evaluable for response. The median age was 24 years (range, 17&#8211;39 years).[<a href="#cit/section_9.52">

1311652</a>

13117,<a href="#cit/section_9.54">

1311854</a>

13119] <div class="pdq-content-list">

13120<ul id="_2118">

13121<li>

13122Use of the pediatric regimen (from the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075725">

13123AALL0232</a>

13124 study, which included interim maintenance phases with escalating doses of methotrexate without leucovorin followed by asparaginase) was deemed safe, and the overall treatment-related mortality was 3%.</li>

13125<li>

13126The median EFS was 78.1 months, which is more than double the historical control of 30 months. The 3-year EFS rate was 59%, and the median OS was not reached. The estimated 3-year OS rate was 73%.</li>

13127<li>

13128Pretreatment risk factors associated with a worse outcome were obesity and the presence of the <em class="gene-name">

13129BCR</em>

13130::<em class="gene-name">

13131ABL1</em>

13132-like expression signature. Of the evaluable patients, 31% had a <em class="gene-name">

13133BCR</em>

13134::<em class="gene-name">

13135ABL1</em>

13136-like signature. These patients had a significantly worse outcome, with a 3-year EFS rate of 42%, compared with an EFS rate of 69% for patients without <em class="gene-name">

13137BCR</em>

13138::<em class="gene-name">

13139ABL1</em>

13140-like ALL (hazard ratio, 2.06; log-rank <em>

13141P</em>

13142 = .008).</li>

13143<li>

13144End-induction MRD was a significant predictor of outcome. In the subset of patients evaluable for MRD, 44% had absence of detectable end-induction MRD using an Ig-TCR PCR-MRD assay (sensitivity of detection of 1 in 10<span class="sup">

131454</span>

13146 to 10<span class="sup">

131475</span>

13148). These patients had a 3-year DFS rate of 85%, compared with a 3-year DFS rate of 54% for those with detectable end-induction MRD (<em>

13149P</em>

13150 = .001).</li>

13151<li>

13152In a study of patients aged 16 to 39 years, the outcomes of those who received postremission, standard, pediatric-inspired chemotherapy per the CALGB-10403 protocol were compared with the outcomes of patients who received myeloablative allogeneic HSCT. Patients who received chemotherapy had superior OS, DFS, and nonrelapse mortality rates.[<a href="#cit/section_9.55">

1315355</a>

13154][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13155Level of evidence B4</a>

13156]</li>

13157</ul>

13158</div>

13159</li>

13160<li>

13161Investigators reported on 197 patients aged 16 to 21 years treated on the CCG study (a pediatric ALL regimen) compared with 124 adolescents and young adults treated on the Cancer and Leukemia Group B (CALGB) study (an adult ALL regimen).[<a href="#cit/section_9.44">

1316244</a>

13163]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13164<ul id="_2282">

13165<li>

13166For the patients treated with a pediatric ALL regimen, the 7-year EFS rate was 63%.</li>

13167<li>

13168For the patients treated with an adult ALL regimen, the 7-year EFS rate was 34%.</li>

13169</ul>

13170</div>

13171</li>

13172<li>

13173In a Canadian population-based cohort study, the effect of adapting pediatric protocols for adolescent and young adult patients with ALL was determined over a 20-year period.[<a href="#cit/section_9.56">

1317456</a>

13175]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13176<ul id="_2145">

13177<li>

13178The 5-year EFS rate was 72% for adolescent and young adult patients treated at pediatric centers, compared with 56% for adolescent and young adult patients treated at adult centers (<em>

13179P</em>

13180 = .03).</li>

13181<li>

13182In the most recent period (2006&#8211;2011), the outcome of adolescent and young adult patients treated at adult centers with pediatric protocols was superior to those treated with adult protocols (EFS rate, 72% vs. 60%), but inferior to adolescent and young adult patients treated at pediatric centers (EFS rate, 81%; <em>

13183P</em>

13184 = .02).</li>

13185<li>

13186The authors conclude that besides protocol therapy, there may be other differences between adult and pediatric centers that may explain the disparate outcomes.</li>

13187</ul>

13188</div>

13189</li>

13190</ol>

13191</div>

13192<p id="_1165" tabindex="-1">

13193The reason that adolescents and young adults achieve superior outcomes with pediatric regimens is not known, although possible explanations include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.45">

1319445</a>

13195] </p>

13196<div class="pdq-content-list">

13197<ul id="_1275">

13198<li>

13199Treatment setting (i.e., site experience in treating ALL).</li>

13200<li>

13201Adherence to protocol therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.43">

1320243</a>

13203]</li>

13204<li>

13205The

13206components of protocol therapy.</li>

13207</ul>

13208</div>

13209<table id="_1429" class="table-default expandable-container">

13210<caption>

13211Table 12. Outcome According to Treatment Protocol for Adolescents and Young Adults with ALL </caption>

13212<colgroup>

13213<col width="25.00%">

13214<col width="25.00%">

13215<col width="25.00%">

13216<col width="25.00%">

13217</colgroup>

13218<THead>

13219<tr>

13220<th>

13221Site and Study Group</th>

13222<th>

13223Adolescent and Young Adult Patients (No.)</th>

13224<th>

13225Median age (y)</th>

13226<th>

13227Survival (%)</th>

13228</tr>

13229</THead>

13230<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

13234</tr>

13238Group for Lymphoblastic Acute Leukemia in Adults; MRC = Medical Research Council (United Kingdom); NOPHO = Nordic Society for Pediatric Hematology and Oncology; UKALL = United Kingdom Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia.</td>

13241<tbody>

1336158</a>

13362]</td>

13400]</td>
