1346960</a>

13470]</td>

13471<td>

13472229</td>

13473<td>

1347416&#8211;24</td>

13475<td>

1347672 EFS</td>

13477</tr>

13478</tbody>

13479</table>

13480<section id="_1576">

13481<h5 id="_1576_toc">

13482Osteonecrosis</h5>

13483<p id="_1577" tabindex="-1">

13484Adolescents with ALL appear to be at higher risk than younger children for developing therapy-related complications, including osteonecrosis, deep venous thromboses, and pancreatitis.[<a href="#cit/section_9.46">

1348546</a>

13486,<a href="#cit/section_9.61">

1348761</a>

13488,<a href="#cit/section_9.62">

1348962</a>

13490] Before the use of postinduction intensification for treatment of ALL, osteonecrosis was infrequent. The improvement in outcome for children and adolescents aged 10 years and older was accompanied by an increased incidence of osteonecrosis. </p>

13491<p id="_1578" tabindex="-1">

13492The weight-bearing joints are affected in 95% of patients who develop osteonecrosis and operative interventions were needed for management of symptoms and impaired mobility in more than 40% of cases. Most cases are diagnosed within the first 2 years of therapy and the symptoms are often recognized during maintenance. </p>

13493<p id="_1579" tabindex="-1">

13494Evidence (osteonecrosis):</p>

13495<div class="pdq-content-list">

13496<ol id="_1580">

13497<li>

13498In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002812">

13499CCG-1961</a>

13500 high-risk ALL study, alternate-week dosing of dexamethasone was compared with standard continuous dexamethasone during delayed intensification to determine whether the osteonecrosis risk could be reduced.[<a href="#cit/section_9.61">

1350161</a>

13502]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13503<ul id="_1581">

13504<li>

13505The median age at symptom onset was 16 years.</li>

13506<li>

13507The cumulative incidence was higher in adolescents and young adults aged 16 to 21 years (20% at 5 years) than in those aged 10 to 15 years (9.9%) or in patients aged 1 to 9 years (1%). </li>

13508<li>

13509Operative interventions were needed for management of symptoms and impaired mobility in more than 40% of cases.</li>

13510<li>

13511The use of alternate-week dosing of dexamethasone as compared with standard continuous dexamethasone during delayed intensification in CCG-1961 reduced the risk of osteonecrosis. The greatest impact was seen in females aged 16 to 21 years, who showed the highest incidence of osteonecrosis with standard therapy containing continuous dexamethasone; osteonecrosis was reduced with alternate-week dexamethasone postinduction (57.6% to 5.6%). </li>

13512</ul>

13513</div>

13514</li>

13515<li>

13516In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075725">

13517AALL0232 (NCT00075725)</a>

13518 high-risk ALL trial, patients were randomly assigned during induction to receive either 14 days of dexamethasone or 28 days of prednisone.[<a href="#cit/section_9.63">

1351963</a>

13520] <div class="pdq-content-list">

13521<ul id="_1861">

13522<li>

13523The incidence of osteonecrosis in patients older than 10 years who received dexamethasone was 24.3%, compared with an incidence of 15.9% in those who received prednisone (<em>

13524P</em>

13525 = .001).</li>

13526<li>

13527For patients aged 10 years and older, there was no difference in outcome between arms by corticosteroid (5-year EFS rate, 73.1% on the dexamethasone arm and 73.9% on the prednisone arm; <em>

13528P</em>

13529 = .78).</li>

13530</ul>

13531</div>

13532</li>

13533</ol>

13534</div>

13535</section>

13536</section>

13537<section id="_1167">

13538<h4 id="_1167_toc">

13539Treatment options under clinical evaluation for adolescent and young adult patients with ALL</h4>

13540<p id="_1168" tabindex="-1">

13541Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

13542NCI website</a>

13543. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

13544ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

13545.</p>

13546<p id="_1997" tabindex="-1">

13547The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

13548<div class="pdq-content-list">

13549<ol id="_1199">

13550<li>

13551<strong>

13552<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03150693">

13553A041501 (NCT03150693)</a>

13554</strong>

13555 (Inotuzumab Ozogamicin and Frontline Chemotherapy in Treating Young Adults With Newly Diagnosed B-cell ALL)<strong>

13556:</strong>

13557 This is a National Clinical Trials Network trial to further expand on the experience of using a pediatric-inspired chemotherapy backbone in young adults with ALL. Eligibility includes patients aged 18 to 39 years with newly diagnosed CD22-positive ALL. Patients who are in remission after induction will be randomly assigned to receive the pediatric backbone either with or without two courses of inotuzumab ozogamicin (a toxin-conjugated anti-CD22 monoclonal antibody) before starting consolidation therapy.</li>

13558<li>

13559<strong>

13560<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03876769">

13561COG-AALL1721 (NCT03876769)</a>

13562</strong>

13563 (Study of Efficacy and Safety of Tisagenlecleucel in High-Risk B-ALL End-of-Consolidation MRD-Positive Patients)<strong>

13564:</strong>

13565

13566The objective of the study is to evaluate the efficacy of CD19 chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy (tisagenlecleucel) in patients who are MRD positive at the end of consolidation by measuring 5-year EFS. Other objectives include assessing proportion of subjects who are disease free without allogeneic transplant at 1 year, OS, and proportion of subjects who achieve MRD-negative CR or CRI at 3 months after tisagenlecleucel.

13567</li>

13568<li>

13569<strong>

13570<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03959085">

13571COG-AALL1732 (NCT03959085)</a>

13572</strong>

13573 (A Phase III Randomized Trial of Inotuzumab Ozogamicin for Newly Diagnosed High-Risk B-ALL; Risk-Adapted Postinduction Therapy for High-Risk B-ALL, Mixed Phenotype Acute Leukemia [MPAL], and Disseminated B-Lymphoblastic Lymphoma)<strong>

13574:</strong>

13575 This protocol is open for patients younger than 25 years at diagnosis who meet any of the following diagnoses: NCI high-risk non-Down syndrome B-ALL, MPAL, and disseminated B-lymphoblastic lymphoma. For patients with B-ALL, the protocol is testing whether the addition of two blocks of inotuzumab ozogamicin to a modified-BFM backbone will improve DFS. For patients with MPAL and disseminated B-lymphoblastic lymphoma, the study aims to determine the EFS associated with treatment using a standard high-risk B-ALL modified-BFM backbone.</li>

13576</ol>

13577</div>

13578</section>

13579</section>

13580<section id="_2503">

13581<h3 id="_2503_toc">

13582Children With Down Syndrome</h3>

13583<p id="_2504" tabindex="-1">

13584Approximately 2% to 3% of childhood ALL cases occur in children with Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_9.64">

1358564</a>

13586-<a href="#cit/section_9.67">

1358767</a>

13588] ALL in pediatric patients with Down syndrome is characterized by a lower incidence of both favorable (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

13589ETV6</em>

13590::<em class="gene-name">

13591RUNX1</em>

13592 and high hyperdiploidy with favorable trisomies) and unfavorable (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

13593BCR</em>

13594::<em class="gene-name">

13595ABL1</em>

13596, <em class="gene-name">

13597KMT2A</em>

13598 rearrangements, low hypodiploidy, t(9;22)(q34;q11.2) or t(4;11)(q21;q23)) biology and a near absence of T-cell phenotype.[<a href="#cit/section_9.64">

1359964</a>

13600-<a href="#cit/section_9.66">

1360166</a>

13602,<a href="#cit/section_9.68">

1360368</a>

13604,<a href="#cit/section_9.69">

1360569</a>

13606]</p>

13607<p id="_2505" tabindex="-1">

13608Certain genomic abnormalities, such as <em class="gene-name">

13609IKZF1</em>

13610 deletions, <em class="gene-name">

13611CRLF2</em>

13612 aberrations, and <em class="gene-name">

13613JAK</em>

13614 mutations, are seen more frequently in ALL arising in children with Down syndrome than in those without Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_9.70">

1361570</a>

13616-<a href="#cit/section_9.74">

1361774</a>

13618] Studies of children with Down syndrome and ALL suggest that the presence of <em class="gene-name">

13619IKZF1</em>

13620 deletions (but not <em class="gene-name">

13621CRLF2</em>

13622 aberrations or <em class="gene-name">

13623JAK</em>

13624 mutations) is associated with an inferior prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_9.69">

1362569</a>

13626,<a href="#cit/section_9.74">

1362774</a>

13628,<a href="#cit/section_9.75">

1362975</a>

13630]</p>

13631<p id="_2506" tabindex="-1">

13632Patients with Down syndrome have an increased risk of developing toxicities from treatment, including infections, mucositis, and seizures. In some studies, outcomes of children with Down syndrome and ALL have been reported to be inferior,[<a href="#cit/section_9.64">

1363364</a>

13634,<a href="#cit/section_9.65">

1363565</a>

13636,<a href="#cit/section_9.76">

1363776</a>

13638-<a href="#cit/section_9.78">

1363978</a>

13640] although in other studies, patients with Down syndrome appeared to fare as well as those without Down syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_9.79">

1364179</a>

13642,<a href="#cit/section_9.80">

1364380</a>

13644] Inferior outcomes for patients with Down syndrome, when observed, are related to both an increased risk of relapse, as well as increased frequency of treatment-related mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_9.64">

1364564</a>

13646-<a href="#cit/section_9.66">

1364766</a>

13648,<a href="#cit/section_9.69">

1364969</a>

13650,<a href="#cit/section_9.76">

1365176</a>

13652,<a href="#cit/section_9.77">

1365377</a>

13654]</p>

13655<p id="_2507" tabindex="-1">

13656Because of the well-established increase in toxicity experienced by patients with Down syndrome, some ALL protocols (such as those of the COG) have de-intensified risk-based treatment for patients with Down syndrome and ALL to minimize exposure to the morbid components of therapy. While this treatment reduction strategy reduces the frequency and severity of toxicities, its impact on antileukemic outcomes is not yet known.</p>

13657<section id="_2513">

13658<h4 id="_2513_toc">

13659Treatment of children with Down syndrome</h4>

13660<p id="_2508" tabindex="-1">

13661Evidence (toxicity and outcome of patients with Down syndrome and ALL):</p>

13662<div class="pdq-content-list">

13663<ol id="_2509">

13664<li>

13665A large retrospective study that included 653 patients with Down syndrome and ALL who were treated between 1995 to 2004 reported the following results:[<a href="#cit/section_9.69">

1366669</a>

13667]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13668<ul id="_2510">

13669<li>

13670Patients with Down syndrome had lower CR rates (97% vs. 99%, <em>

13671P</em>

13672 &lt; .001), higher cumulative incidence of relapse rates (26% vs. 15%, <em>

13673P</em>

13674 &lt; .001), and higher treatment-related mortality rates (7.7% vs. 2.3%, <em>

13675P</em>

13676 &lt; .001), compared with patients without Down syndrome.</li>

13677<li>

13678For patients with Down syndrome and ALL, treatment-related mortality occurred at a higher rate during all phases of therapy, including maintenance. The rates of treatment-related mortality during induction was 2.8% and 4.9% during the remaining treatment phases after CR had been achieved. The most common cause of treatment-related mortality was infection.</li>

13679<li>

13680Among the patients with Down syndrome, age younger than 6 years, WBC count of less than 10,000/&#956;L, and the presence of the <em class="gene-name">

13681ETV6</em>

13682::<em class="gene-name">

13683RUNX1</em>

13684 fusion (observed in 8% of patients) were independent predictors of favorable EFS.</li>

13685</ul>

13686</div>

13687</li>

13688<li>

13689In a report of 2,811 children with ALL enrolled on the COG P9900 classification study, 80 patients (3%) had Down syndrome. Age, sex, WBC count, and risk group were similar between patients with and without Down syndrome, but a lower percentage of patients with Down syndrome had <em class="gene-name">

13690ETV6</em>

13691::<em class="gene-name">

13692RUNX1</em>

13693 (2.5% vs. 24%, <em>

13694P</em>

13695 &lt; .001) or trisomies 4 and 10 (7.7% vs. 24%, <em>

13696P</em>

13697 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_9.66">

1369866</a>

13699]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13700<ul id="_2514">

13701<li>

13702 The 5-year EFS and OS rates were inferior in children with Down syndrome: 69.9% versus 78.1% (<em>

13703P</em>

13704 = .078), and 85.8% versus 90.0% (<em>

13705P</em>

13706 = .033), respectively. </li>

13707<li>

13708However, when children with <em class="gene-name">

13709KMT2A</em>

13710 rearrangements, <em class="gene-name">

13711BCR</em>

13712::<em class="gene-name">

13713ABL1</em>

13714, <em class="gene-name">

13715ETV6</em>

13716::<em class="gene-name">

13717RUNX1</em>

13718, and trisomies 4 and 10 were excluded from the analysis, the EFS and OS rates were similar for children with and without Down syndrome (EFS rates, 68.0% [&#177; 9.3%] vs. 70.5% [&#177; 1.9%], <em>

13719P</em>

13720 = .817; OS rates, 86.7% [&#177; 6.7%] vs. 85.4% [&#177; 1.5%]; <em>

13721P</em>

13722 = .852).</li>

13723</ul>

13724</div>

13725</li>

13726<li>

13727In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005945">

13728CCG-1991 (NCT00005945)</a>

13729 study for children with standard-risk B-ALL (2000&#8211;2005), patients (including those with Down syndrome) were randomly assigned to receive an interim maintenance phase consisting of either escalating doses of intravenous methotrexate without leucovorin rescue or standard low-dose oral methotrexate given with vincristine, dexamethasone, and mercaptopurine.[<a href="#cit/section_9.80">

1373080</a>

13731]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13732<ul id="_2515">

13733<li>

13734 The 10-year EFS rates were 94.4% (&#177; 5.4%) for patients with Down syndrome randomly assigned to receive escalating-dose IV methotrexate (N = 31), versus 81.5% (&#177; 6.6%) for patients who received oral low-dose methotrexate (N = 44).</li>

13735<li>

13736 The mean total tolerated dose of methotrexate on the escalating IV arm was lower in patients with Down syndrome than patients without Down syndrome.</li>

13737<li>

13738 The incidence of mucositis was increased in patients with Down syndrome who received escalating-dose methotrexate, compared with patients without Down syndrome, but there was no increase in hepatic toxicity, infections, or treatment-related deaths.</li>

13739</ul>

13740</div>

13741</li>

13742<li>

13743On DFCI ALL Consortium protocols, children with Down syndrome receive the same risk-stratified therapy as other patients, without any dose reductions or modifications. An analysis of two consecutive trials conducted between 2000 to 2011 found the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.79">

1374479</a>

13745]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13746<ul id="_2516">

13747<li>

13748 The 5-year EFS and OS rates of patients with Down syndrome (N = 38) were similar to that of patients without Down syndrome (N = 1,248) (EFS rates, 91% vs. 84%; OS rates, 97% vs. 91%). </li>

13749<li>

13750All patients with Down syndrome achieved complete remission, and none of the patients experienced treatment-related mortality. </li>

13751<li>

13752Patients with Down syndrome had significantly higher rates of mucositis (52% vs. 12%, <em>

13753P</em>

13754 &lt; .001), non-CNS thrombosis (18% vs. 8%; <em>

13755P</em>

13756 = .036), and seizure (16% vs. 5%, <em>

13757P</em>

13758 = .010). Patients with Down syndrome also had a higher incidence of infections during all therapy phases.</li>

13759</ul>

13760</div>

13761</li>

13762</ol>

13763</div>

13764</section>

13765<section id="_2517">

13766<h4 id="_2517_toc">

13767Treatment options under clinical evaluation for children with Down syndrome and ALL</h4>

13768<p id="_1999" tabindex="-1">

13769Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

13770NCI website</a>

13771. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

13772ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

13773.</p>

13774<p id="_2518" tabindex="-1">

13775The following is an example of a national and/or institutional clinical trial that is currently being conducted:</p>

13776<div class="pdq-content-list">

13777<ul id="_2519">

13778<li>

13779<strong>

13780<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03914625">

13781COG-AALL1731 (NCT03914625)</a>

13782</strong>

13783 (A Phase III Trial Investigating Blinatumomab in Combination with Chemotherapy in Patients with Newly Diagnosed Standard Risk or Down Syndrome B-ALL and the Treatment of Patients with Localized B-Lymphoblastic Lymphoma)<strong>

13784:</strong>

13785 This study is testing whether the addition of blinatumomab to standard chemotherapy will improve DFS. All patients with Down syndrome (including adolescent and young adult patients aged &lt;31 years) are eligible to enroll. NCI standard-risk patients with Down syndrome who meet the definition of standard-risk average will be treated in the same way as patients without Down syndrome who are standard-risk average. These patients are eligible to participate in the blinatumomab randomization. All other patients with Down syndrome, including NCI high-risk patients with Down syndrome, those with unfavorable biology, and those with high day 29 MRD will be considered Down syndrome-high, and will be nonrandomly assigned to receive two cycles of blinatumomab added to a deintensified chemotherapy regimen that omits intensive elements of the augmented BFM treatment backbone. Omitted elements include anthracyclines during induction and cyclophosphamide/cytarabine-based chemotherapy during the second half of delayed intensification.</li>

13786</ul>

13787</div>

13788</section>

13789</section>

13790<section id="_1170">

13791<h3 id="_1170_toc">

13792<em class="gene-name">

13793BCR</em>

13794::<em class="gene-name">

13795ABL1</em>

13796-positive (Philadelphia Chromosome-positive) ALL</h3>

13797<p id="_1520" tabindex="-1">

13798<em class="gene-name">

13799BCR</em>

13800::<em class="gene-name">

13801ABL1</em>

13802-positive (Philadelphia chromosome&#8211;positive [Ph+]) ALL is seen in about 3% of pediatric ALL cases, increases in adolescence, and is seen in 15% to 25% of adults. In the past, this subtype of ALL has been recognized as extremely difficult to treat, and patients had a poor outcome. In 2000, an international pediatric leukemia group reported a 7-year EFS rate of 25%, with an OS rate of 36%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.81">

1380381</a>

13804] In 2010, the same group reported a 7-year EFS rate of 31% and an OS rate of 44% in patients with <em class="gene-name">

13805BCR</em>

13806::<em class="gene-name">

13807ABL1</em>

13808 ALL treated without tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs).[<a href="#cit/section_9.82">

1380982</a>

13810] Treatment of this subgroup has evolved, from an emphasis on aggressive chemotherapy, to bone marrow transplantation, and currently to combination therapy using chemotherapy plus a TKI.</p>

13811<section id="_1171">

13812<h4 id="_1171_toc">

13813Treatment options for patients with <em class="gene-name">

13814BCR</em>

13815::<em class="gene-name">

13816ABL1</em>

13817-positive ALL</h4>

13818<p id="_2164" tabindex="-1">

13819Standard therapy for patients with <em class="gene-name">

13820BCR</em>

13821::<em class="gene-name">

13822ABL1</em>

13823 ALL includes the use of a TKI (e.g., imatinib or dasatinib) in combination with cytotoxic chemotherapy, with or without allogeneic HSCT in first CR.</p>

13824<p id="_1174" tabindex="-1">

13825Imatinib mesylate is a selective inhibitor of the BCR::ABL1 protein kinase. Phase I and phase II studies of single-agent imatinib in children and adults with relapsed or refractory <em class="gene-name">

13826BCR</em>

13827::<em class="gene-name">

13828ABL1</em>

13829 ALL have demonstrated relatively high response rates, although these responses tended to be of short duration.[<a href="#cit/section_9.83">

1383083</a>

13831,<a href="#cit/section_9.84">

1383284</a>

13833] </p>

13834<p id="_1345" tabindex="-1">

13835Clinical trials in adults and children with <em class="gene-name">

13836BCR</em>

13837::<em class="gene-name">

13838ABL1</em>

13839 ALL have demonstrated the feasibility of administering imatinib mesylate in combination with multiagent chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.85">

1384085</a>

13841-<a href="#cit/section_9.87">

1384287</a>

13843] Patients with <em class="gene-name">

13844BCR</em>

13845::<em class="gene-name">

13846ABL1</em>

13847 ALL demonstrated a better outcome after HSCT if imatinib was given before or after transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_9.88">

1384888</a>

13849-<a href="#cit/section_9.92">

1385092</a>

13851] Clinical trials have also demonstrated that many pediatric patients with <em class="gene-name">

13852BCR</em>

13853::<em class="gene-name">

13854ABL1</em>

13855 ALL have a comparable EFS using chemotherapy and a TKI rather than transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_9.92">

1385692</a>

13857,<a href="#cit/section_9.93">

1385893</a>

13859]</p>

13860<p id="_2040" tabindex="-1">

13861Dasatinib, a second-generation TKI, has also been studied in the treatment of <em class="gene-name">

13862BCR</em>

13863::<em class="gene-name">

13864ABL1</em>

13865 ALL. Dasatinib has shown significant activity in the CNS, both in a mouse model and a series of patients with CNS-positive leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_9.94">

1386694</a>

13867] The results of a phase I trial of dasatinib in pediatric patients indicated that once-daily dosing was associated with an acceptable toxicity profile, with few nonhematologic grade 3 or grade 4 adverse events.[<a href="#cit/section_9.95">

1386895</a>

13869]</p>

13870<p id="_1201" tabindex="-1">

13871Evidence (TKI):</p>

13872<div class="pdq-content-list">

13873<ol id="_1202">

13874<li>

13875The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00022737">

13876COG-AALL0031</a>

13877 study evaluated whether imatinib mesylate could be incorporated into an intensive chemotherapy regimen for children with <em class="gene-name">

13878BCR</em>

13879::<em class="gene-name">

13880ABL1</em>

13881 ALL. Patients received imatinib mesylate in conjunction with chemotherapy during postinduction therapy. Some children proceeded to allogeneic HSCT after two cycles of consolidation chemotherapy with imatinib mesylate, while other patients received imatinib mesylate in combination with chemotherapy throughout all treatment phases.[<a href="#cit/section_9.87">

1388287</a>

13883,<a href="#cit/section_9.92">

1388492</a>

13885]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13886<ul id="_1203">

13887<li>

13888The 5-year DFS rate for the 25 patients who received intensive chemotherapy with continuous dosing of imatinib mesylate was 70% (&#177; 12%). These patients fared better than historical controls who were treated with chemotherapy alone (without imatinib mesylate), and at least as well as the other patients on the trial who underwent allogeneic transplantation. The 5-year DFS rate was 66% for patients who underwent sibling-donor transplant (n = 21) and 59% for those who underwent unrelated donor transplant (n = 13).</li>

13889<li>

13890Patients with additional cytogenetic abnormalities had worse outcomes (<em>

13891P</em>

13892 = .05).</li>

13893</ul>

13894</div>

13895</li>

13896<li>

13897The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00720109">

13898COG-AALL0622 (NCT00720109)</a>

13899 study tested the use of dasatinib (instead of imatinib) combined with a chemotherapy backbone similar to that used in the COG-AALL0031 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_9.96">

1390096</a>

13901][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13902Level of evidence B4</a>

13903] On this trial, dasatinib was started on day 15 of induction, while on the AALL0031 trial, imatinib was started postinduction.<div class="pdq-content-list">

13904<ul id="_2041">

13905<li>

13906Introduction of a TKI during induction on the AALL0631 trial resulted in better early response compared with the AALL0031 trial (no TKI during induction). The end-induction (day 29) CR rate was 98% (n = 59) on the AALL0622 trial, compared with 89% (n = 91) on the AALL0031 trial (<em>

13907P</em>

13908 = .01), and rates of low end-induction MRD (&lt;0.01%) were superior on the AALL0622 trial compared with the AALL0031 trial (59% vs. 25%; <em>

13909P</em>

13910 &lt; .001).</li>

13911<li>

13912Outcomes in the two trials were similar: the 5-year OS rates were 81% and 86%, and the 5-year DFS rates were 68% and 60% for AALL0031 and AALL0622, respectively.</li>

13913<li>

13914Excessive toxicity with dasatinib was not observed.</li>

13915<li>

13916In a subset analysis that included patients who had diagnostic banked samples available, the <em class="gene-name">

13917IKZF1</em>

13918 deletion was identified in 57% of patients and was associated with inferior EFS and OS.</li>

13919</ul>

13920</div>

13921</li>

13922<li>

13923The EsPhALL2004 trial tested whether imatinib (administered discontinuously) given in the context of intensive chemotherapy improved outcome for pediatric <em class="gene-name">

13924BCR</em>

13925::<em class="gene-name">

13926ABL1</em>

13927 ALL patients, most of whom (80%) received an allogeneic HSCT in first CR. Patients were classified as either good risk or poor risk on the basis of early response measures and remission status at the end of induction. Good-risk patients (n = 90) were randomly assigned to receive imatinib or no imatinib; poor-risk patients (n = 70) were directly assigned to treatment with imatinib. Interpretation of this study is limited because of the high noncompliance rate with randomized assignment in good-risk patients and early closure before reaching goal accrual because of the publication of the results of the COG AALL0031 trial on which imatinib had been given continuously with chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.93">

1392893</a>

13929]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13930<ul id="_1915">

13931<li>

13932 The overall DFS of patients treated on this trial appeared to be better than historical controls, and when analyzed as-treated (and not by intent-to-treat), good-risk patients who received imatinib had a superior DFS (4-year DFS rate was 75% for patients who received imatinib and 56% for patients who did not receive imatinib).[<a href="#cit/section_9.97">

1393397</a>

13934]</li>

13935</ul>

13936</div>

13937</li>

13938<li>

13939The subsequent <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00287105">

13940EsPhALL2010 (NCT00287105)</a>

13941 trial was a result of an amendment to the 2004 trial, which included earlier initiation of imatinib therapy at day 15 of induction and continuous dosing of imatinib until the end of therapy or 1 year after transplant. A subsequent amendment in the trial also changed the indication for HSCT in first CR to only the poor-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.98">

1394298</a>

13943] <div class="pdq-content-list">

13944<ul id="_2121">

13945<li>

13946 Earlier introduction of imatinib (during induction) resulted in an increased rate of CR to 97% at the end of induction (from 78% in the previous trial) and fewer patients being allocated to HSCT (38% on amended trial vs. 81% on initial trial).</li>

13947<li>

13948The EFS and OS rates were similar between the amended trial and the initial trial, even though significantly fewer patients received HSCT in first CR on the amended trial.</li>

13949<li>

13950The EsPhALL chemotherapy backbone combined with continuous dosing of imatinib was associated with a high rate of toxicity (primarily infections) and treatment-related mortality.</li>

13951</ul>

13952</div>

13953 </li>

13954<li>

13955The Chinese Children&#8217;s Cancer Group ALL-2015 trial randomly assigned 189 patients to receive either dasatinib or imatinib combined with a multiagent regimen based on SJCRH ALL protocols. On this trial, dasatinib was administered at a higher dose (80 mg/m<span class="sup">

139562</span>

13957 instead of 60 mg/m<span class="sup">

139582</span>

13959) and imatinib was administered at a lower dose (300 mg/m<span class="sup">

139602</span>

13961 instead of 340 mg/m<span class="sup">

139622</span>

13963) than they were administered on previous pediatric <em class="gene-name">

13964BCR</em>

13965::<em class="gene-name">

13966ABL1</em>

13967 ALL trials conducted by COG and EsPhALL.[<a href="#cit/section_9.99">

1396899</a>

13969][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

13970Level of evidence A1</a>

13971]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13972<ul id="_2293">

13973<li>

13974With a median follow-up of 26.4 months, the 4-year EFS and OS rates were 71% and 88.4%, respectively, for patients randomly assigned to receive dasatinib, compared with 48.9% and 69.2%, respectively, for patients randomly assigned to receive imatinib. </li>

13975<li>

13976Toxicity was similar between the two treatment arms.</li>

13977<li>

13978Caution is needed in interpreting these results because of the short median follow-up time and because the outcomes of patients who received imatinib on this trial were inferior to the outcomes of imatinib-treated patients reported in previous trials.</li>

13979</ul>

13980</div>

13981 </li>

13982</ol>

13983</div>

13984</section>

13985<section id="_1998">

13986<h4 id="_1998_toc">

13987Treatment options under clinical evaluation for <em class="gene-name">

13988BCR</em>

13989::<em class="gene-name">

13990ABL1</em>

13991 ALL</h4>

13992<p id="_2520" tabindex="-1">

13993Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

13994NCI website</a>

13995. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

13996ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

13997.</p>

13998<p id="_2000" tabindex="-1">

13999The following is an example of a national and/or institutional clinical trial that is currently being conducted:</p>

14000<div class="pdq-content-list">

14001<ol id="_2012">

14002<li>

14003<strong>

14004<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03007147">

14005AALL1631 (NCT03007147)</a>

14006</strong>

14007 (Imatinib Mesylate and Combination Chemotherapy in Treating Patients with Newly Diagnosed <em class="gene-name">

14008BCR</em>

14009::<em class="gene-name">

14010ABL1</em>

14011 ALL)<strong>

14012:</strong>

14013 AALL1631 is an international collaborative protocol conducted by the COG and the European EsPhALL group. Patients with <em class="gene-name">

14014BCR</em>

14015::<em class="gene-name">

14016ABL1</em>

14017 ALL enter the trial at day 15 of induction IA and begin daily imatinib at that time. After the induction IB phase (weeks 10&#8211;12), MRD is assessed by immunoglobulin H/T-cell receptor (IgH-TCR) PCR, and patients are classified as standard risk (MRD &lt;0.05%) or high risk (MRD &gt;0.05%). Standard-risk patients are randomly assigned to receive one of the following two cytotoxic chemotherapy backbones: <div class="pdq-content-list">

14018<ul id="_2013">

14019<li>

14020The EsPhALL backbone used in previous EsPhALL protocols and COG AALL1122; or</li>

14021<li>

14022A less-intensive regimen similar to those typically administered to non-<em class="gene-name">

14023BCR</em>

14024::<em class="gene-name">

14025ABL1</em>

14026 high-risk B-cell ALL patients on COG trials.</li>

14027</ul>

14028</div>

14029<p id="_2003" tabindex="-1">

14030 Standard-risk patients on both arms will continue to receive imatinib until the completion of all planned chemotherapy (2 years of treatment). The objective of the standard-risk randomization is to determine whether the less-intensive chemotherapy backbone is associated with a similar DFS but lower rates of treatment-related toxicity compared with the standard therapy (EsPhALL chemotherapy backbone).</p>

14031<p id="_2004" tabindex="-1">

14032High-risk patients (approximately 15%&#8211;20% of patients) will proceed to HSCT after completion of three consolidation blocks of chemotherapy. Imatinib will be restarted after HSCT and administered from day +56 until day +365 to test the feasibility of post-HSCT administration of this agent and describe the outcome of patients treated in this manner.</p>

14033</li>

14034</ol>

14035</div>

14036</section>

14037<section id="_TrialSearch_1170_sid_6">

14038<h4 id="_TrialSearch_1170_sid_6_toc">

14039Current Clinical Trials</h4>

14040<p id="_TrialSearch_1170_22" tabindex="-1">

14041Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

14042advanced clinical trial search</a>

14043 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

14044General information</a>

14045 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

14046</section>

14047</section>

J Hematol Oncol 7 (1): 32, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24726034&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24726034&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14357[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14358</li>

14359<li id="section_9.79">

14360Athale UH, Puligandla M, Stevenson KE, et al.: Outcome of children and adolescents with Down syndrome treated on Dana-Farber Cancer Institute Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Consortium protocols 00-001 and 05-001. Pediatr Blood Cancer 65 (10): e27256, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29878490&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29878490&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14361[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14362</li>

14363<li id="section_9.80">

14364Matloub Y, Rabin KR, Ji L, et al.: Excellent long-term survival of children with Down syndrome and standard-risk ALL: a report from the Children's Oncology Group. Blood Adv 3 (11): 1647-1656, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31160295&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31160295&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14365[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14366</li>

14444</div>

14445

14446 </section>

14447

14577</nav>

14578<section id="_1206">

14579<h3 id="_1206_toc">

14580Prognostic Factors After First Relapse of Childhood ALL</h3>

14581<p id="_1207" tabindex="-1">

14582The prognosis for a child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) whose disease

14583recurs depends on multiple factors.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

145841</a>

14585-<a href="#cit/section_10.14">

1458614</a>

14587]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.15">

1458815</a>

14589][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14590Level of evidence C2</a>

14591]</p>

14592<p id="_1558" tabindex="-1">

14593The following two important risk factors after first relapse of childhood ALL are key to determining prognosis and treatment approach:</p>

14594<div class="pdq-content-list">

14595<ul id="_1559">

14596<li>

14597<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1394">

14598Site of relapse</a>

14599.</li>

14600<li>

14601<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1393">

14602Time from diagnosis to relapse</a>

14603.</li>

14604</ul>

14605</div>

14606<p id="_1560" tabindex="-1">

14607Other prognostic factors include the following:</p>

14608<div class="pdq-content-list">

14609<ul id="_1208">

14610<li>

14611<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1392">

14612Patient characteristics</a>

14613 (e.g., age and peripheral blast count at time of relapse).</li>

14614<li>

14615<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1490">

14616Risk group classification at initial diagnosis</a>

14617.</li>

14618<li>

14619<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1488">

14620Response to reinduction therapy</a>

14621.</li>

14622<li>

14623<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1395">

14624Cytogenetics/genomic alterations</a>

14625.</li>

14626<li>

14627<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1396">

14628Immunophenotype</a>

14629.</li>

14630</ul>

14631</div>

14632<section id="_1394">

14633<h4 id="_1394_toc">

14634Site of relapse</h4>

14635<p id="_1210" tabindex="-1">

14636Patients who have isolated extramedullary relapse generally fare better than those who have relapse involving the marrow. In some studies, patients with combined marrow/extramedullary relapse had a better prognosis than did those with a marrow only relapse. However, other studies have not confirmed this finding.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

146375</a>

14638,<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

1463913</a>

14640,<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

1464116</a>

14642] </p>

14643</section>

14644<section id="_1393">

14645<h4 id="_1393_toc">

14646Time from diagnosis to relapse</h4>

14647<p id="_1209" tabindex="-1">

14648For patients with relapsed B-ALL, early relapses fare worse than later relapses, and marrow relapses fare worse than isolated extramedullary relapses. For example, survival rates range from less than 20% for patients with marrow relapses occurring within 18 months from diagnosis to higher than 60% for those whose relapses occur more than 36 months from diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

146495</a>

14650,<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

1465113</a>

14652,<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1465317</a>

14654] </p>

14655<p id="_1241" tabindex="-1">

14656For patients with isolated central nervous system (CNS) relapses, the overall survival (OS) rates are 40% to 50% for early relapse (&lt;18 months from diagnosis) and 75% to 80% for those with late relapses (&gt;18 months from diagnosis).[<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

1465713</a>

14658,<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1465918</a>

14660] No evidence exists that early detection of relapse by frequent surveillance (complete blood counts or bone marrow tests) in off-therapy patients improves outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_10.19">

1466119</a>

14662] </p>

14663</section>

14664<section id="_1392">

14665<h4 id="_1392_toc">

14666Patient characteristics</h4>

14667<p id="_1348" tabindex="-1">

14668Age 10 years and older at diagnosis and at relapse have been reported as independent predictors of poor outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

1466913</a>

14670,<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

1467116</a>

14672] A Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG) study further showed that although patients aged 10 to 15 years at initial diagnosis do worse than patients aged 1 to 9 years (3-year postrelapse survival rate, 35% vs. 48%), those older than age 15 years did much worse (3-year OS rate, 15%; <em>

14673P</em>

14674 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1467520</a>

14676]</p>

14677<p id="_2225" tabindex="-1">

14678For patients with B-ALL who were diagnosed at age 18 years or younger and experienced a late relapse, age was not a significant predictor of subsequent outcome when analyzed by quartiles. However, the outcome for patients aged 18 years and older at time of relapse was significantly inferior to the outcome for patients relapsing at age younger than 18 years (39.5% vs. 68.7%; <em>

14679P</em>

14680 = .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1468121</a>

14682]</p>

14683<p id="_1349" tabindex="-1">

14684The Berlin-Frankfurt-M&#252;nster (BFM) group has also reported that high peripheral blast counts (&gt;10,000/&#956;L) at the time of relapse were associated with inferior outcomes in patients with late marrow relapses.[<a href="#cit/section_10.10">

1468510</a>

14686]</p>

14687<p id="_1585" tabindex="-1">

14688Children with Down syndrome and ALL who relapse have generally had inferior outcomes resulting from increased induction deaths, treatment-related mortality, and relapse.</p>

14689<div class="pdq-content-list">

14690<ul id="_1916">

14691<li>

14692The BFM group showed that since 2000, improvements in supportive care have led to decreases in treatment-related mortality in children with Down syndrome, but the risk of relapse remains high.[<a href="#cit/section_10.22">

1469322</a>

14694]</li>

14695<li>

14696An analysis of data from the Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research (CIBMTR) on 27 patients with Down syndrome and ALL who underwent hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) between 2000 and 2009 substantiated this finding. They noted that with current transplant practices, hematopoietic recovery, graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), and transplant-related mortality were within the expected range compared with patients without Down syndrome. However, relapse was higher than expected (&gt;50%) and was the primary cause of treatment failure, leading to poor survival (disease-free survival [DFS] rate at 3 years, 24%).[<a href="#cit/section_10.23">

1469723</a>

14698][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14699Level of evidence C1</a>

14700]</li>

14701</ul>

14702</div>

14703</section>

14704<section id="_1490">

14705<h4 id="_1490_toc">

14706Risk group classification at initial diagnosis</h4>

14707<p id="_1491" tabindex="-1">

14708The COG reported that risk group classification at the time of initial diagnosis was prognostically significant after relapse. Patients who met National Cancer Institute (NCI) standard-risk criteria at initial diagnosis fared better after relapse than did NCI high-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

1470913</a>

14710]</p>

14711</section>

14712<section id="_1488">

14713<h4 id="_1488_toc">

14714Response to reinduction therapy</h4>

14715<p id="_1489" tabindex="-1">

14716Patients with marrow relapses who have persistent morphological disease at the end of the first month of reinduction therapy have an extremely poor prognosis, even if they subsequently achieve a second complete remission (CR).[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

1471724</a>

14718][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14719Level of evidence B4</a>

14720]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

1472125</a>

14722][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14723Level of evidence C1</a>

14724] Several studies have demonstrated that minimal residual disease (MRD) levels after the achievement of second CR are of prognostic significance in relapsed ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1472521</a>

14726,<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

1472724</a>

14728,<a href="#cit/section_10.26">

1472926</a>

14730-<a href="#cit/section_10.29">

1473129</a>

14732]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.30">

1473330</a>

14734,<a href="#cit/section_10.31">

1473531</a>

14736][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14737Level of evidence C2</a>

14738] High levels of MRD at the end of reinduction and at later time points have been correlated with an extremely high risk of subsequent relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1473921</a>

14740,<a href="#cit/section_10.29">

1474129</a>

14742]</p>

14743</section>

14744<section id="_1395">

14745<h4 id="_1395_toc">

14746Cytogenetics/genomic alterations</h4>

14747<p id="_1740" tabindex="-1">

14748Changes in mutation profiles from diagnosis to relapse have been identified by gene sequencing.[<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

1474932</a>

14750,<a href="#cit/section_10.33">

1475133</a>

14752] While oncogenic gene fusions (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

14753TCF3</em>

14754::<em class="gene-name">

14755PBX1</em>

14756, <em class="gene-name">

14757ETV6</em>

14758::<em class="gene-name">

14759RUNX1</em>

14760) are almost always observed between the time of initial diagnosis and relapse, single nucleotide variants and copy number variants may be present at diagnosis, but not at relapse, and vice versa.[<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

1476132</a>

14762,<a href="#cit/section_10.34">

1476334</a>

14764] For example, while <em class="gene-name">

14765RAS</em>

14766 family mutations are common at both diagnosis and relapse, the specific <em class="gene-name">

14767RAS</em>

14768 family mutations may change from diagnosis to relapse as specific leukemic subclones rise and fall during the course of treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

1476932</a>

14770] By contrast, relapse-specific mutations in <em class="gene-name">

14771NT5C2</em>

14772 (a gene involved in nucleotide metabolism) have been noted in as many as 45% of ALL cases with early relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

1477332</a>

14774,<a href="#cit/section_10.35">

1477535</a>

14776,<a href="#cit/section_10.36">

1477736</a>

14778]</p>

14779<p id="_1352" tabindex="-1">

14780<em class="gene-name">

14781TP53</em>

14782 alterations (mutations and/or copy number alterations) are observed in approximately 10% of patients with ALL at first relapse and have been associated with an increased likelihood of persistent leukemia after initial reinduction and poor event-free survival (EFS) rates.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1478321</a>

14784,<a href="#cit/section_10.37">

1478537</a>

14786] In one study, approximately one-half of the <em class="gene-name">

14787TP53</em>

14788 alterations were present at initial diagnosis and half were newly observed at time of relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.37">

1478937</a>

14790]</p>

14791<p id="_2226" tabindex="-1">

14792<em class="gene-name">

14793IKZF1</em>

14794 deletions have also been reported to be associated with a poor prognosis in patients with B-ALL in first bone marrow relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.38">

1479538</a>

14796] However, in a BFM study of patients with B-ALL who experienced a late first marrow relapse, <em class="gene-name">

14797IKZF1</em>

14798 deletions were not prognostically significant.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1479921</a>

14800]</p>

14801<p id="_1700" tabindex="-1">

14802RAS pathway mutations (<em class="gene-name">

14803KRAS</em>

14804, <em class="gene-name">

14805NRAS</em>

14806, <em class="gene-name">

14807FLT3</em>

14808, and <em class="gene-name">

14809PTPN11</em>

14810) are common at relapse in B-ALL patients, and they were found in approximately 40% of patients at first relapse in one study of 206 children.[<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

1481132</a>

14812,<a href="#cit/section_10.39">

1481339</a>

14814] As observed at diagnosis, the frequency of RAS pathway mutations at relapse differs by cytogenetic subtype (e.g., high frequency in hyperdiploid cases and low frequency in <em class="gene-name">

14815ETV6</em>

14816::<em class="gene-name">

14817RUNX1</em>

14818 cases). The presence of RAS pathway mutations at relapse was associated with early relapse. However, presence of RAS pathway mutations at relapse was not an independent predictor of outcome.</p>

14819<p id="_1564" tabindex="-1">

14820Patients with <em class="gene-name">

14821ETV6</em>

14822::<em class="gene-name">

14823RUNX1</em>

14824-positive ALL appear to have a relatively favorable prognosis at first relapse, consistent with the high percentage of such patients who relapse more than 36 months after diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.38">

1482538</a>

14826,<a href="#cit/section_10.40">

1482740</a>

14828]</p>

14829<div class="pdq-content-list">

14830<ul id="_1917">

14831<li>

14832In the ALL-REZ BFM 2002 (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00114348">

14833NCT00114348</a>

14834) study, an EFS rate of 84% (&#177; 7%) was observed for patients with <em class="gene-name">

14835ETV6</em>

14836::<em class="gene-name">

14837RUNX1</em>

14838 ALL with bone marrow relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.38">

1483938</a>

14840] In this study, 94% of patients with <em class="gene-name">

14841ETV6</em>

14842::<em class="gene-name">

14843RUNX1</em>

14844 had a duration of first remission that extended at least 6 months beyond completion of their primary treatment, and on multivariate analysis, time to relapse (and not the presence of <em class="gene-name">

14845ETV6</em>

14846::<em class="gene-name">

14847RUNX1</em>

14848) was an independent predictor of outcome.</li>

14849<li>

14850Similarly, the 5-year OS rate was 81% for patients with <em class="gene-name">

14851ETV6</em>

14852::<em class="gene-name">

14853RUNX1</em>

14854 enrolled on the French Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia Study Group (FRALLE) 93 trial who relapsed at any site more than 36 months after diagnosis. The presence of <em class="gene-name">

14855ETV6</em>

14856::<em class="gene-name">

14857RUNX1</em>

14858 was associated with a favorable survival outcome compared with other late relapsing patients.[<a href="#cit/section_10.40">

1485940</a>

14860] However, the 3-year OS rate was only 31% for patients with <em class="gene-name">

14861ETV6</em>

14862::<em class="gene-name">

14863RUNX1</em>

14864 who experienced an early relapse (&lt;36 months).</li>

14865</ul>

14866</div>

14867</section>

14868<section id="_1396">

14869<h4 id="_1396_toc">

14870Immunophenotype</h4>

14871<p id="_1354" tabindex="-1">

14872Immunophenotype is an important prognostic factor at relapse. Patients with T-ALL who experience a marrow relapse (isolated or combined) at any time during treatment or posttreatment are less likely to achieve a second remission and long-term EFS than are patients with B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

148735</a>

14874,<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

1487524</a>

14876]</p>

14877</section>

14878</section>

14879<section id="_1213">

14880<h3 id="_1213_toc">

14881Standard Treatment Options for First Bone Marrow Relapse of Childhood ALL</h3>

14882<p id="_1492" tabindex="-1">

14883Standard treatment options for first bone marrow relapse include the following:</p>

14884<div class="pdq-content-list">

14885<ol id="_1493">

14886<li>

14887<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1356">

14888Reinduction chemotherapy</a>

14889.</li>

14890<li>

14891<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1402">

14892Postreinduction therapy for patients achieving a second CR</a>

14893.</li>

14894</ol>

14895</div>

14896<section id="_1356">

14897<h4 id="_1356_toc">

14898Reinduction chemotherapy</h4>

14899<p id="_1215" tabindex="-1">

14900Initial treatment of relapse consists of reinduction therapy to achieve a second CR. Using either a four-drug reinduction regimen (similar to that administered to newly diagnosed high-risk patients) or an alternative regimen including high-dose methotrexate and high-dose cytarabine, approximately 85% of patients with a marrow relapse achieve a second CR at the end of the first month of treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

149015</a>

14902]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

1490324</a>

14904,<a href="#cit/section_10.41">

1490541</a>

14906][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14907Level of evidence B4</a>

14908] Patients with early marrow relapses have a lower rate of achieving a morphological second CR (approximately 70%) than do those with late marrow relapses (approximately 95%).[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

1490924</a>

14910,<a href="#cit/section_10.41">

1491141</a>

14912]</p>

14913<p id="_1277" tabindex="-1">

14914Evidence (reinduction chemotherapy):</p>

14915<div class="pdq-content-list">

14916<ol id="_1278">

14917<li>

14918A COG study used three blocks of intensive reinduction therapy with an initial four-drug combination that included doxorubicin followed by two intensive consolidation blocks before either HSCT or chemotherapy continuation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

1491924</a>

14920]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14921<ul id="_1566">

14922<li>

14923Second remission was achieved after block 1 in 68% of patients with early relapse (&lt;36 months from initial diagnosis) and in 96% of those with later relapse.</li>

14924<li>

14925Blocks 2 and 3 reduced MRD in 40 of 56 patients who were MRD positive after block 1.</li>

14926</ul>

14927</div>

14928</li>

14929<li>

14930A United Kingdom&#8211;based randomized trial of ALL patients in first relapse compared reinduction with a four-drug combination using idarubicin versus mitoxantrone.[<a href="#cit/section_10.42">

1493142</a>

14932][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14933Level of evidence A1</a>

14934] <div class="pdq-content-list">

14935<ul id="_1279">

14936<li>

14937There was no difference in second CR rates or end-reinduction MRD levels between the two study arms.</li>

14938<li>

14939A significant improvement in the OS rate in the mitoxantrone arm was reported (69% vs. 45%; <em>

14940P</em>

14941 = .007), which resulted from decreased relapse after transplantation.</li>

14942</ul>

14943</div>

14944<p id="_1461" tabindex="-1">

14945The potential benefit of mitoxantrone in relapsed ALL regimens requires further investigation.</p>

14946</li>

14947<li>

14948Investigators from the ALL-REZ BFM group used a six-drug reinduction approach, which included high-dose methotrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_10.43">

1494943</a>

14950]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14951<ul id="_2284">

14952<li>

14953 A randomized comparison of 1 g/m<span class="sup">

149542</span>

14955 of methotrexate delivered over 36 hours versus 5 g/m<span class="sup">

149562</span>

14957 of methotrexate delivered over 24 hours with reinduction showed no difference in outcome, but the 36-hour infusion was associated with a higher incidence of mucositis.</li>

14958</ul>

14959</div>

14960</li>

14961<li>

14962The combination of clofarabine, cyclophosphamide, and etoposide was reported to induce remission in 42% to 56% of patients with refractory or multiply relapsed disease.[<a href="#cit/section_10.44">

1496344</a>

14964,<a href="#cit/section_10.45">

1496545</a>

14966]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.46">

1496746</a>

14968][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14969Level of evidence B4</a>

14970]</li>

14971<li>

14972The combination of bortezomib plus vincristine, dexamethasone, pegaspargase, and doxorubicin has been reported to induce complete response (with or without platelet recovery) in 70% to 80% of multiply relapsed patients with B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_10.47">

1497347</a>

14974][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14975Level of evidence C1</a>

14976]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.48">

1497748</a>

14978][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

14979Level of evidence C3</a>

14980]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14981<ol id="_2312" class="lower-alpha">

14982<li>

14983This combination (using prednisone instead of dexamethasone) was tested in B-ALL patients with first relapse occurring less than 36 months from initial diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.49">

1498449</a>

14985]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14986<ul id="_2313">

14987<li>

14988The second CR rate was 68%, which was not significantly different from that observed on a predecessor trial using the same reinduction platform without bortezomib.</li>

14989<li>

14990In subset analyses, the addition of bortezomib to the four-drug reinduction platform did not result in significantly better second CR rates for patients with either very early relapses (&lt;18 months from diagnosis) or early relapses (18&#8211;36 months from diagnosis) when compared with historical controls.</li>

14991</ul>

14992</div>

14993</li>

14994</ol>

14995</div>

14996 </li>

14997</ol>

14998</div>

14999<p id="_1896" tabindex="-1">

15000Patients with relapsed T-ALL have much lower rates of achieving second CR with standard reinduction regimens than do patients with B-cell phenotype.[<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

1500124</a>

15002] Treatment of children with first relapse of T-ALL in the bone marrow with single-agent therapy using the T-cell selective agent, nelarabine, has resulted in response rates of approximately 50%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.50">

1500350</a>

15004] In a trial of 28 pediatric patients with relapsed or refractory T-ALL who were treated with single-agent nelarabine, the overall response rate (CR and CR without hematological recovery) was 39.3%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.51">

1500551</a>

15006] The combination of nelarabine, cyclophosphamide, and etoposide has also been used in patients with relapsed or refractory T-ALL, with response rates comparable to single-agent nelarabine.[<a href="#cit/section_10.52">

1500752</a>

15008]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.53">

1500953</a>

15010][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15011Level of evidence C3</a>

15012] In a phase I/II trial of this combination in patients with relapsed or refractory T-ALL and T-lymphoblastic lymphoma, the overall best response rate (CR + CR with incomplete platelet recovery + partial response) was 38% (8 of 21 patients). The T-ALL cohort had a response rate of 33% (4 of 12 patients), and the T-lymphoblastic lymphoma cohort had a response rate of 44% (4 of 9 patients).[<a href="#cit/section_10.53">

1501353</a>

15014][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15015Level of evidence C3</a>

15016] </p>

15017<p id="_2569" tabindex="-1">

15018The proteosome inhibitor bortezomib (in combination with chemotherapy) has also been evaluated in patients with relapsed T-ALL. In a phase II trial conducted by the COG, the combination of bortezomib plus vincristine, prednisone, pegaspargase, and doxorubicin resulted in a second CR rate of 68% in T-ALL patients in first relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.49">

1501949</a>

15020]</p>

15021<p id="_1855" tabindex="-1">

15022Reinduction failure is a poor prognostic factor, but subsequent attempts to obtain remission can be successful and lead to survival after HSCT, especially if MRD becomes low or nondetectable. For more information about MRD risk stratification, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1403">

15023Late-relapsing B-ALL</a>

15024 section. Approaches have traditionally included the use of drug combinations distinct from the first attempt at treatment. These regimens often contain newer agents under investigation in clinical trials. Although survival is progressively less likely after each attempt, two to four additional attempts are often pursued, with diminishing levels of success measured after each attempt.[<a href="#cit/section_10.54">

1502554</a>

15026] Because studies of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells, blinatumomab, and inotuzumab have been shown to lead to high rates of remission in multiply relapsed and chemotherapy-refractory B-ALL patients, trials testing these agents after initial relapse are underway. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1928">

15027Immunotherapeutic Approaches for Refractory ALL</a>

15028 section.</p>

15029</section>

15030<section id="_1402">

15031<h4 id="_1402_toc">

15032Postreinduction therapy for patients achieving a second complete remission </h4>

15033<section id="_1497">

15034<h5 id="_1497_toc">

15035Early-relapsing B-ALL</h5>

15036<p id="_1498" tabindex="-1">

15037For B-ALL patients with an early marrow relapse, allogeneic

15038transplant from an HLA-identical sibling or matched unrelated donor that is

15039performed in second remission has been reported in most studies to result in higher leukemia-free survival

15040(LFS) than a chemotherapy approach.[<a href="#cit/section_10.7">

150417</a>

15042,<a href="#cit/section_10.30">

1504330</a>

15044,<a href="#cit/section_10.55">

1504555</a>

15046-<a href="#cit/section_10.63">

1504763</a>

15048] However, even with transplantation, the survival rate for patients with early marrow relapse is less than 50%. One study analyzed 278 patients with early-relapsing B-ALL who were treated between 2001 and 2013 in trials conducted by either the ALL-REZ BFM or UK-ALL groups. The overall survival rate was 32.6%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.29">

1504929</a>

15050] More favorable outcomes were observed for patients with early-relapsed B-ALL who had low end-reinduction MRD, low pre-HSCT MRD, and those who experienced acute GVHD. For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1404">

15051Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation for First and Subsequent Bone Marrow Relapse</a>

15052 section.</p>

15053<p id="_2395" tabindex="-1">

15054After initial reinduction chemotherapy, the use of blinatumomab instead of intensive cytotoxic chemotherapy as pre-HSCT consolidation has been shown to be associated with superior outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_10.64">

1505564</a>

15056,<a href="#cit/section_10.65">

1505765</a>

15058]</p>

15059<p id="_2396" tabindex="-1">

15060Evidence (blinatumomab before HSCT in early-relapsing B-ALL):</p>

15061<div class="pdq-content-list">

15062<ol id="_2397">

15063<li>

15064In a randomized phase III trial conducted between 2015 and 2019, patients with early-relapsing B-ALL were randomly assigned to receive either one 28-day course of blinatumomab or a cycle of intensive cytotoxic chemotherapy as a third consolidation course before proceeding to HSCT. The study was intended to enroll 202 patients but was terminated early (after 108 patients enrolled) when the superiority of blinatumomab was demonstrated on the basis of a prespecified stopping rule.[<a href="#cit/section_10.64">

1506564</a>

15066] <div class="pdq-content-list">

15067<ul id="_2398">

15068<li>

15069The 24-month EFS rate was 66.2% for patients who received blinatumomab, compared with 27.1% for patients who received the intensive chemotherapy block (hazard ratio [HR], 0.33; <em>

15070P</em>

15071 &lt; .001). </li>

15072<li>

15073The 24-month cumulative incidence of relapse was significantly lower in patients who received blinatumomab than in patients who received intensive chemotherapy (24.9% vs. 70.8%; HR, 0.24).</li>

15074<li>

15075For patients with high MRD (&#8805;10<span class="sup">

15076-4</span>

15077) at the time randomized treatment began, more patients achieved MRD negativity with blinatumomab treatment than with intensive chemotherapy treatment (93% vs. 24%).</li>

15078</ul>

15079</div>

15080</li>

15081<li>

15082A COG phase III clinical trial compared two courses of blinatumomab with two blocks of intensive chemotherapy in patients with B-ALL in first relapse. Treatment randomization occurred after a single block of intensive reinduction chemotherapy. Eligible patients included those with early relapse or those with late relapse but MRD levels greater than 0.1% after reinduction chemotherapy. Study enrollment ended early because of loss of clinical equipoise, in favor of blinatumomab. This was determined by the study&#8217;s data and safety monitoring committee. Key findings from the trial include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_10.65">

1508365</a>

15084]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15085<ul id="_2399">

15086<li>

15087The 2-year DFS rate was 54.4% for patients who received blinatumomab versus 39.0% for patients who received chemotherapy (HR for disease progression or mortality, 0.70; 95% CI, 0.47&#8211;1.03).</li>

15088<li>

15089The 2-year OS rate was 71.3% for patients who received blinatumomab versus 58.4% for patients who received chemotherapy (HR for mortality, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.39&#8211;0.98).</li>

15090<li>

15091Negative MRD rates were higher for patients after one or two courses of blinatumomab (75% and 66%, respectively) than for patients after one or two courses of intensive chemotherapy (32% and 32%, respectively). </li>

15092<li>

15093Adverse event rates for toxicities such as sepsis, mucositis, and febrile neutropenia were much lower for patients who received blinatumomab than for patients who received intensive chemotherapy.</li>

15094</ul>

15095</div>

15096</li>

15097</ol>

15098</div>

15099</section>

15100<section id="_1403">

15101<h5 id="_1403_toc">

15102Late-relapsing B-ALL</h5>

15103<p id="_1219" tabindex="-1">

15104Previous studies of late marrow relapse in patients with B-ALL showed that a primary chemotherapy approach after achievement of second CR resulted in survival rates of approximately 50%, and it was not clear whether allogeneic transplantation was associated with a superior cure rate.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

151055</a>

15106,<a href="#cit/section_10.9">

151079</a>

15108,<a href="#cit/section_10.42">

1510942</a>

15110,<a href="#cit/section_10.66">

1511166</a>

15112-<a href="#cit/section_10.68">

1511368</a>

15114]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.69">

1511569</a>

15116][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15117Level of evidence C1</a>

15118] Subsequent data have shown that the presence of end-reinduction MRD identifies patients with a high risk of ensuing relapse if treated with chemotherapy alone (no HSCT) in second CR. A number of studies have shown that patients with a late marrow relapse who have high end-reinduction MRD have better outcomes if they receive an allogeneic HSCT in second CR after achieving low or nondetectable MRD status.[<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1511917</a>

15120,<a href="#cit/section_10.70">

1512170</a>

15122]</p>

15123<p id="_1287" tabindex="-1">

15124Evidence (MRD-based risk stratification for late-relapse of B-ALL):</p>

15125<div class="pdq-content-list">

15126<ol id="_1288">

15127<li>

15128 In BFM studies, patients are considered to be intermediate risk if they have a late isolated marrow relapse or an early or late combined marrow/extramedullary relapse. In the ALL-REZ BFM P95/96 study from this group, end-reinduction MRD (assessed by a polymerase chain reaction&#8211;based assay) significantly predicted outcomes of children with intermediate-risk relapsed B-ALL treated with chemotherapy alone in second CR (no HSCT).[<a href="#cit/section_10.28">

1512928</a>

15130]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15131<ul id="_1562">

15132<li>

15133Patients with low MRD (&lt;0.1%) had a 10-year EFS rate of 73%, while those with high MRD (&#8805;0.1%) had a 10-year EFS rate of 10%. On multivariate analysis, end-reinduction MRD was the strongest independent prognostic factor.</li>

15134</ul>

15135</div>

15136</li>

15137<li>

15138In a subsequent BFM study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00114348">

15139ALL-REZ BFM 2002 [NCT00114348]</a>

15140), patients with intermediate-risk relapse were allocated to allogeneic HSCT if they had high MRD at the end of the first month of treatment. Those who had low end-reinduction MRD were treated with chemotherapy only (no HSCT).[<a href="#cit/section_10.70">

1514170</a>

15142] <div class="pdq-content-list">

15143<ul id="_1637">

15144<li>

15145The EFS rate was 64% for patients with high end-reinduction MRD treated with allogeneic HSCT in second CR, which was significantly better than what had been observed on the previous P95/96 trial, during which such patients received chemotherapy without HSCT. The improvement in EFS was primarily because of a significantly lower risk of relapse in the cohort who underwent HSCT in second CR (cumulative incidence of relapse, 27% on the 2002 trial compared with 59% on the P95/96 trial).</li>

15146<li>

15147Patients with late marrow-involved relapses and low end-reinduction MRD, treated with chemotherapy only, had a 5-year EFS rate of 76%, confirming the results seen in the previous P95/96 trial. However, the chemotherapy-only strategy resulted in a significantly worse outcome for patients with early-combined relapses (marrow plus extramedullary site) and low end-reinduction MRD. The 5-year EFS rate was only 37% for these patients. Because of these data, patients with early-combined relapses are now considered high risk on BFM trials.</li>

15148<li>

15149For patients with late marrow-involved relapses and high end-reinduction MRD (defined as &#8805;0.1%), level of MRD was prognostically significant. The 10-year EFS rate was significantly worse for those with MRD levels of &#8805;1% compared with those with MRD levels of &#8805;0.1% to &lt;1% (56% vs. 74%, respectively; <em>

15150P</em>

15151 = .02). Conversely, for patients with low end-reinduction MRD (&lt;0.1%), there was no significant difference in EFS between those with very low MRD (&lt;0.01%) versus those with MRD levels between 0.01% and &lt;0.1%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1515221</a>

15153]</li>

15154</ul>

15155</div>

15156</li>

15157<li>

15158The United Kingdom ALLR3 trial assigned patients who relapsed more than 6 months after completion of front-line therapy to HSCT if their end-reinduction MRD was &#8805;0.01% or to chemotherapy for those with MRD of &lt;0.01%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1515917</a>

15160]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15161<ul id="_2147">

15162<li>

15163Of the 228 patients treated, 220 patients achieved CR; 127 patients were allocated to HSCT (high MRD) and 93 were allocated to chemotherapy (low or not evaluable MRD). The 5-year EFS rates were 72% for patients with low MRD versus 56% for patients with high MRD. The 5-year OS rates were 87% for low MRD and 64% for high end-reinduction MRD.</li>

15164<li>

15165On the basis of these data, investigators from the United Kingdom recommend HSCT for late-relapsing patients with B-ALL who have MRD of &#8805;0.01% after reinduction therapy and chemotherapy alone for those with end-reinduction MRD of &lt;0.01%.</li>

15166</ul>

15167</div>

15168</li>

15169<li>

15170The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00381680">

15171AALL0433 (NCT00381680)</a>

15172 trial included patients with intermediate-risk relapse of B-ALL (defined as late marrow-involved relapse occurring &gt;36 months from initial diagnosis, or very early isolated extramedullary relapse occurring &lt;18 months from initial diagnosis). Patients received three induction blocks, followed either by an intensive chemotherapy backbone (with radiation therapy for patients with CNS or testicular involvement) or allogeneic HSCT (if matched-sibling donors were available). The trial also included a randomized comparison of standard versus intensified vincristine dosing. Of the 271 eligible patients, 257 (95%) achieved second CR. Of these patients, 74 (29% of those in second CR) received HSCT, 47 of whom had matched-sibling donors and 27 of whom had other donors.[<a href="#cit/section_10.31">

1517331</a>

15174]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15175<ul id="_2433">

15176<li>

15177For all 271 eligible patients, the 3-year EFS and OS rates were 63.6% and 72.3%, respectively. </li>

15178<li>

15179For patients with late marrow-involved relapses (n = 242), the 3-year EFS and OS rates were 66.3% and 74.8%, respectively. </li>

15180<li>

15181For patients with late marrow relapses, MRD at the end of the first month of treatment (end-reinduction MRD) was a significant prognostic factor. For patients with end-reinduction MRD less than 0.1%, the 3-year EFS rate was 84.9%, versus 53.7% for those with MRD higher than 0.1%. </li>

15182<li>

15183Adjusting for median time to HSCT, patients who received HSCT had an improved 3-year DFS rate (<em>

15184P</em>

15185 = .03), but not OS rate (<em>

15186P</em>

15187 = .46), compared with patients who received chemotherapy alone. </li>

15188<li>

15189The vincristine randomization was stopped early because of excessive toxicity, particularly in older patients.</li>

15190</ul>

15191</div>

15192</li>

15193</ol>

15194</div>

15195</section>

15196<section id="_2428">

15197<h5 id="_2428_toc">

15198<em class="gene-name">

15199BCR</em>

15200::<em class="gene-name">

15201ABL1</em>

15202 (Philadelphia chromosome&#8211;positive [Ph+]) ALL</h5>

15203<p id="_2429" tabindex="-1">

15204There is limited information regarding the treatment of patients with relapsed <em class="gene-name">

15205BCR</em>

15206::<em class="gene-name">

15207ABL1</em>

15208 ALL in the era of tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs).</p>

15209<p id="_2479" tabindex="-1">

15210A French multi-institutional study reported on 27 children with relapsed <em class="gene-name">

15211BCR</em>

15212::<em class="gene-name">

15213ABL1</em>

15214 ALL (24 overt, 3 molecular) who had all been initially treated with a regimen that included imatinib.[<a href="#cit/section_10.71">

1521571</a>

15216][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15217Level of evidence C1</a>

15218] </p>

15219<div class="pdq-content-list">

15220<ul id="_2448">

15221<li>

15222Among patients treated with either an intensive or nonintensive induction regimen, 96% obtained a second CR. </li>

15223<li>

15224Approximately one-half of the patients received consolidation therapy, and 78% of the patients proceeded to allogeneic HSCT. </li>

15225<li>

15226At the time of relapse, the TKI was changed for 23 of the 26 (88%) patients, 15 of whom (58%) received dasatinib. The 4-year EFS rate was 60.9%, and the OS rate was 76.1%.</li>

15227</ul>

15228</div>

15229</section>

15230<section id="_1499">

15231<h5 id="_1499_toc">

15232T-ALL</h5>

15233<p id="_1500" tabindex="-1">

15234For patients with T-ALL who achieve remission after bone marrow relapse, outcomes with postreinduction chemotherapy alone have generally been poor,[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

152355</a>

15236] and these patients are usually treated with allogeneic HSCT in second CR, regardless of time to relapse. At 3 years, the OS rate after allogeneic transplant for T-ALL in second remission was reported to be 48%, and the DFS rate was 46%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.72">

1523772</a>

15238][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15239Level of evidence C1</a>

15240]</p>

15241</section>

15242</section>

15243</section>

15244<section id="_1501">

15245<h3 id="_1501_toc">

15246Treatment Options for Second and Subsequent Bone Marrow Relapse</h3>

15247<p id="_1502" tabindex="-1">

15248Although there are no studies directly comparing chemotherapy with HSCT for patients in third or subsequent CR, because cure with chemotherapy alone is rare, transplant has generally been considered a reasonable approach for those achieving remission. Long-term survival for ALL patients after a second relapse is particularly poor, in the range of less than 10% to 20%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.61">

1524961</a>

15250] One of the main reasons for this is failure to obtain a third remission. Numerous attempts at novel combination approaches have resulted in only about 40% of children in second relapse achieving remission.[<a href="#cit/section_10.73">

1525173</a>

15252] However, two studies that added bortezomib to standard reinduction agents in multiply relapsed or refractory patients have resulted in 70% to 80% CR rates.[<a href="#cit/section_10.47">

1525347</a>

15254][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15255Level of evidence C1</a>

15256]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.48">

1525748</a>

15258][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15259Level of evidence C3</a>

15260] </p>

15261<p id="_2570" tabindex="-1">

15262A phase I trial tested the combination of venetoclax (BCL2 inhibitor) and navitoclax (BCL2 and BCL-X<sub>

15263L</sub>
