15264 inhibitor) given along with standard chemotherapy (vincristine, dexamethasone, with/without pegaspargase) in adult and pediatric patients with multiply relapsed or refractory B-ALL or T-ALL. The combination was well tolerated in general (the major toxicity was prolonged myelosuppression) and CR was achieved in 60% of patients, 57% of whom had nondetectable MRD.[<a href="#cit/section_10.74">

1526574</a>

15266] </p>

15267<p id="_2571" tabindex="-1">

15268For multiply relapsed patients who achieve CR, HSCT has been shown to cure 20% to 35%, with failures occurring because of high rates of relapse and transplant-related mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_10.75">

1526975</a>

15270-<a href="#cit/section_10.79">

1527179</a>

15272][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15273Level of evidence C1</a>

15274]</p>

15275<p id="_2148" tabindex="-1">

15276Given the poor outcomes for multiply relapsed B-ALL patients who are treated with chemotherapy followed by HSCT, CAR T-cell therapy has come to be used as standard in this population and has resulted in high rates of remission and improved survival (although direct comparative trials are lacking). For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1932">

15277CAR T-cell therapy</a>

15278 section. </p>

15279<p id="_2430" tabindex="-1">

15280Immune therapies such as blinatumomab and inotuzumab have been used in this population and have improved rates of remission, which has then often led to cure when followed by HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_10.80">

1528180</a>

15282-<a href="#cit/section_10.84">

1528384</a>

15284] Comparative studies of immune and cell therapy approaches have yet to be performed in this population, so data to inform optimal approaches to first therapy or sequence of therapies are lacking. </p>

15285</section>

15286<section id="_1404">

15287<h3 id="_1404_toc">

15288Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation for First and Subsequent Bone Marrow Relapse</h3>

15289<section id="_1569">

15290<h4 id="_1569_toc">

15291Components of the transplantation process</h4>

15292<p id="_1503" tabindex="-1">

15293An expert panel review of indications for HSCT was published in 2012.[<a href="#cit/section_10.85">

1529485</a>

15295] Components of the transplant process that have been shown to be important in improving or predicting outcome of HSCT for children with ALL include the following:</p>

15296<div class="pdq-content-list">

15297<ol id="_1504">

15298<li>

15299<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1505">

15300Total-body irradiation (TBI)-containing transplant preparative regimens</a>

15301.</li>

15302<li>

15303<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1508">

15304MRD detection just before transplant</a>

15305.</li>

15306<li>

15307<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1711">

15308MRD detection posttransplant</a>

15309.</li>

15310<li>

15311<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1510">

15312Donor type and HLA match</a>

15313.</li>

15314<li>

15315<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1513">

15316Role of GVHD/graft-versus-leukemia (GVL) in ALL and immune modulation after transplant to prevent relapse</a>

15317.</li>

15318</ol>

15319</div>

15320<p id="_2367" tabindex="-1">

15321 An analysis from the CIBMTR examined pretransplant variables to create a model for predicting LFS posttransplant in pediatric patients (aged &lt;18 years). All patients were first transplant recipients who had myeloablative conditioning, and all stem cells sources were included. For patients with ALL, the predictors associated with lower LFS included age younger than 2 years, second CR or higher, MRD positivity (only in second CR, not in first CR), and presence of morphologically detectable disease at time of transplant. A scale was established to stratify patients on the basis of risk factors to predict survival. The 5-year LFS rate was 68% for the low-risk group, 51% for the intermediate-risk group, and 33% for the high-risk group.[<a href="#cit/section_10.86">

1532286</a>

15323] </p>

15324<section id="_1505">

15325<h5 id="_1505_toc">

15326TBI-containing transplant preparative regimens</h5>

15327<p id="_1506" tabindex="-1">

15328For patients proceeding to allogeneic HSCT, TBI appears to be an important component of the conditioning regimen. Several studies have indicated that TBI is associated with superior outcomes in patients with ALL compared with chemotherapy-only preparative regimens.</p>

15329<p id="_2369" tabindex="-1">

15330Evidence (TBI as part of the preparative regimen for ALL):</p>

15331<div class="pdq-content-list">

15332<ol id="_2370">

15333<li>

15334 Two registry studies and a small randomized trial showed that transplant conditioning regimens that included

15335TBI resulted in higher cure rates than chemotherapy-only

15336preparative regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_10.55">

1533755</a>

15338,<a href="#cit/section_10.87">

1533987</a>

15340,<a href="#cit/section_10.88">

1534188</a>

15342]</li>

15343<li>

15344 An international study (United States, Europe, and Australia) that combined data sets from prospective trials and single-center data showed that the use of non-TBI regimens was an independent risk factor for poor outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_10.72">

1534572</a>

15346,<a href="#cit/section_10.78">

1534778</a>

15348,<a href="#cit/section_10.89">

1534989</a>

15350]</li>

15351<li>

15352An international phase III trial conducted between 2013 and 2018 enrolled 417 pediatric patients aged 4 to 21 years with ALL. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either TBI (12 Gy) with etoposide or chemotherapy only (fludarabine, thiotepa, and busulfan or treosulfan) as a preparative regimen. All patients were in morphological CR at the time of transplant and received a 9/10 or 10/10 matched sibling donor (MSD) or unrelated matched donor (URD) transplant. The intent was to enroll 1,000 patients, but the study was closed to enrollment early when a futility early stopping rule was met, indicating that the chemotherapy-only preparative regimen was associated with an inferior outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_10.90">

1535390</a>

15354]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15355<ul id="_2371">

15356<li>

15357The 2-year OS rate was 91% for patients who received a TBI-containing regimen, compared with 75% for those who received a chemotherapy-only preparative regimen (<em>

15358P</em>

15359 &lt; .001).</li>

15360<li>

15361The 2-year EFS rate was also superior in patients who received TBI (86% vs. 58%, <em>

15362P</em>

15363 &lt; .001), primarily because of a lower cumulative incidence of relapse in the TBI cohort (2-year cumulative incidence of relapse, 12% for TBI patients vs. 33% for chemotherapy-only patients).</li>

15364<li>

15365In subgroup analysis, the TBI regimen was superior regardless of donor type (MSD vs. URD), immunophenotype (B-ALL vs. T-ALL), and whether transplant occurred in first CR or second CR.</li>

15366<li>

15367There was no difference in the rates of acute or chronic GVHD or frequency of grades 3 or 4 nonhematologic adverse events between the two randomized treatment arms.</li>

15368</ul>

15369</div>

15370</li>

15371</ol>

15372</div>

15373<p id="_2372" tabindex="-1">

15374Based on these data, TBI for all but the youngest children (age &lt;3 or 4 years) remains standard of care in most centers in North America and Europe.[<a href="#cit/section_10.72">

1537572</a>

15376,<a href="#cit/section_10.78">

1537778</a>

15378,<a href="#cit/section_10.89">

1537989</a>

15380,<a href="#cit/section_10.90">

1538190</a>

15382]</p>

15383<p id="_2266" tabindex="-1">

15384Fractionated TBI (total dose, 12&#8211;14 Gy) is often combined with cyclophosphamide, etoposide, thiotepa, or a combination of these agents. Study findings with these combinations have generally resulted in similar rates of survival,[<a href="#cit/section_10.91">

1538591</a>

15386-<a href="#cit/section_10.93">

1538793</a>

15388] although one study suggested that if cyclophosphamide is used without other chemotherapy drugs, a dose of TBI in the higher range may be necessary.[<a href="#cit/section_10.94">

1538994</a>

15390] Many standard regimens include cyclophosphamide with TBI dosing between 13.2 and 14 Gy. On the other hand, when cyclophosphamide and etoposide were used with TBI, doses above 12 Gy resulted in worse survival resulting from excessive toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_10.92">

1539192</a>

15392]</p>

15393<p id="_2267" tabindex="-1">

15394A secondary analysis of the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00382109">

15395ASCT0431 (NCT00382109)</a>

15396 HSCT trial showed that ALL patients treated with TBI that involved dose modulation of lung fields to less than 8 Gy had a survival advantage on multivariate analysis (hazard ratio [HR], 1.85; <em>

15397P</em>

15398 = .04). Transplant-related mortality trended higher for patients who received doses of 8 Gy and higher, but did not reach significance (HR, 1.78; <em>

15399P</em>

15400 = .21). Because lower doses were not associated with increased relapse and resulted in improved survival, dose modulation for lung fields to less than 8 Gy was included in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02883049">

15401AALL1331 (NCT02883049)</a>

15402 trial. Results from the AALL1331 study and other studies looking more precisely into pulmonary dose modulation for TBI are needed to clarify and explain this observation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.95">

1540395</a>

15404]</p>

15405</section>

15406<section id="_1508">

15407<h5 id="_1508_toc">

15408MRD detection just before transplant</h5>

15409<p id="_1509" tabindex="-1">

15410Remission status at the time of transplantation has long been known to be an important predictor of outcome, with patients not in CR at HSCT having very poor survival rates.[<a href="#cit/section_10.96">

1541196</a>

15412] Several studies have also demonstrated that the level of MRD at the time of transplant is a key risk factor in children with ALL in CR undergoing allogeneic HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_10.27">

1541327</a>

15414,<a href="#cit/section_10.97">

1541597</a>

15416-<a href="#cit/section_10.105">

15417105</a>

15418][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15419Level of evidence C1</a>

15420]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1542121</a>

15422,<a href="#cit/section_10.29">

1542329</a>

15424,<a href="#cit/section_10.89">

1542589</a>

15426,<a href="#cit/section_10.106">

15427106</a>

15428] Survival rates of patients who are MRD positive pretransplant have been reported between 20% and 47%, compared with 60% to 88% in patients who are MRD negative.</p>

15429<p id="_1568" tabindex="-1">

15430When patients received two to three cycles of chemotherapy in an attempt to achieve an MRD-negative remission, the benefit of further intensive therapy for achieving MRD negativity must be weighed against the potential for significant toxicity. In addition, there is not clear evidence showing that MRD positivity in a patient who has received multiple cycles of therapy is a biological disease marker for poor outcome that cannot be modified, or whether further intervention bringing such patients into an MRD negative remission will overcome this risk factor and improve survival. </p>

15431<div class="pdq-content-list">

15432<ul id="_1919">

15433<li>

15434In one report, 13 patients with ALL and high MRD at the time of planned transplant received an additional cycle of chemotherapy in an attempt to lower MRD before proceeding to HSCT. Ten of the 13 patients (77%) remained in CR post-HSCT, with no relapses observed in the eight patients who achieved low MRD after the additional chemotherapy cycle. In comparison, only 6 of 21 high-MRD patients (29%) who proceeded directly to HSCT without receiving additional pre-HSCT chemotherapy remained in CR.[<a href="#cit/section_10.98">

1543598</a>

15436]</li>

15437</ul>

15438</div>

15439</section>

15440<section id="_1711">

15441<h5 id="_1711_toc">

15442MRD detection posttransplant</h5>

15443<p id="_1741" tabindex="-1">

15444The presence of detectable MRD post-HSCT has been associated with an increased risk of subsequent relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.104">

15445104</a>

15446,<a href="#cit/section_10.107">

15447107</a>

15448-<a href="#cit/section_10.110">

15449110</a>

15450] For patients with MRD that is detectable pre-HSCT, the detection of any level of MRD post-HSCT puts that patient at very high risk of failure (&gt;90%).[<a href="#cit/section_10.89">

1545189</a>

15452] The accuracy of MRD for predicting relapse increases as time from HSCT elapses and relapse risk is higher for patients who have higher levels of MRD detected at any given time. One study showed higher sensitivity for predicting relapse using next-generation sequencing assays than with flow cytometry, especially early after HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_10.109">

15453109</a>

15454]</p>

15455</section>

15456<section id="_1510">

15457<h5 id="_1510_toc">

15458Donor type and HLA match</h5>

15459<p id="_1511" tabindex="-1">

15460Survival rates after matched unrelated donor and umbilical cord blood transplantation have improved significantly over the past decade and offer an outcome similar to that obtained with matched sibling donor transplants.[<a href="#cit/section_10.59">

1546159</a>

15462,<a href="#cit/section_10.111">

15463111</a>

15464-<a href="#cit/section_10.114">

15465114</a>

15466]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.115">

15467115</a>

15468,<a href="#cit/section_10.116">

15469116</a>

15470][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15471Level of evidence B4</a>

15472]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.117">

15473117</a>

15474][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15475Level of evidence C1</a>

15476]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.118">

15477118</a>

15478][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15479Level of evidence C2</a>

15480] Rates of clinically extensive GVHD and treatment-related mortality remain higher after unrelated donor transplantation compared with matched sibling donor transplants.[<a href="#cit/section_10.60">

1548160</a>

15482,<a href="#cit/section_10.75">

1548375</a>

15484,<a href="#cit/section_10.111">

15485111</a>

15486] However, there is some evidence that matched unrelated donor transplantation may yield a lower relapse rate. National Marrow Donor Program and CIBMTR analyses have demonstrated that rates of GVHD, treatment-related mortality, and OS have improved over time.[<a href="#cit/section_10.119">

15487119</a>

15488-<a href="#cit/section_10.121">

15489121</a>

15490]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.122">

15491122</a>

15492,<a href="#cit/section_10.123">

15493123</a>

15494][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15495Level of evidence C1</a>

15496] </p>

15497<p id="_1512" tabindex="-1">

15498Another CIBMTR study suggested that outcome after one- or two-antigen mismatched cord blood transplants may be equivalent to that for a matched family donor or a matched unrelated donor.[<a href="#cit/section_10.124">

15499124</a>

15500] In certain cases in which no suitable donor is found or an immediate transplant is considered crucial, a haploidentical transplant using large doses of stem cells may be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_10.125">

15501125</a>

15502,<a href="#cit/section_10.126">

15503126</a>

15504] Improved approaches to haploidentical HSCT using alpha-beta T-cell receptor (TCR)/CD19 depletion or posttransplant cyclophosphamide have shown survival rates that are similar to those in studies using other stem cell sources.[<a href="#cit/section_10.127">

15505127</a>

15506] A large multicenter trial from Italy showed similar outcomes using alpha-beta TCR/CD19&#8211;depleted haploidentical donors compared with matched unrelated donors, with lower rates of GVHD.[<a href="#cit/section_10.128">

15507128</a>

15508] A second multicenter trial using alpha-beta TCR/CD19&#8211;depleted killer immunoglobulin-like receptor (KIR)&#8211;favorable haploidentical donors showed survival outcomes comparable to all other stem cell sources, with lower rates of GVHD and transplant-related mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_10.129">

15509129</a>

15510]</p>

15511</section>

15512<section id="_1513">

15513<h5 id="_1513_toc">

15514Role of GVHD/GVL in ALL and immune modulation after transplant to prevent relapse</h5>

15515<p id="_1678" tabindex="-1">

15516Most studies of pediatric and young adult patients that address this issue suggest an effect of both acute and chronic GVHD in decreasing relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.111">

15517111</a>

15518,<a href="#cit/section_10.130">

15519130</a>

15520-<a href="#cit/section_10.133">

15521133</a>

15522]</p>

15523<div class="pdq-content-list">

15524<ul id="_1920">

15525<li>

15526In a COG trial of transplantation for children with ALL, grades I to III acute GVHD were associated with lower relapse risk (HR, 0.4; <em>

15527P</em>

15528 = .04) and better EFS (multivariate analysis, HR, 0.5; <em>

15529P</em>

15530 = .02). Any effect of grade IV acute GVHD in decreasing relapse risk was obscured by a marked increase in transplant-related mortality (HR, 6.4; <em>

15531P</em>

15532 = .003), while grades I to III acute GVHD had no statistically detectable effect on transplant-related mortality (HR, 0.6; <em>

15533P</em>

15534 = .42).[<a href="#cit/section_10.132">

15535132</a>

15536]</li>

15537<li>

15538 In a multivariate model, both pretransplant MRD and acute GVHD were independent predictors of relapse, with the lowest risk of relapse observed in patients with both low pretransplant MRD and grades I to III acute GVHD.[<a href="#cit/section_10.108">

15539108</a>

15540] For patients who did not develop acute GVHD by day 55 post-HSCT, nearly all relapses occurred between days 100 and 400 post-HSCT.</li>

15541</ul>

15542</div>

15543<p id="_1514" tabindex="-1">

15544To harness this GVL effect, a number of approaches to prevent relapse after transplantation have been studied, including withdrawal of immune suppression or donor lymphocyte infusion and targeted immunotherapies, such as monoclonal antibodies and natural killer cell therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.134">

15545134</a>

15546,<a href="#cit/section_10.135">

15547135</a>

15548] Trials in Europe and the United States have shown that patients defined as having a high risk of relapse based on increasing recipient chimerism (i.e., increased percentage of recipient DNA markers) can successfully undergo withdrawal of immune suppression without excessive toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_10.136">

15549136</a>

15550,<a href="#cit/section_10.137">

15551137</a>

15552]</p>

15553<div class="pdq-content-list">

15554<ul id="_1921">

15555<li>

15556One study showed that in 46 patients with increasing recipient chimerism, the 31 patients who underwent immune suppression withdrawal, donor lymphocyte infusion, or both therapies had a 3-year EFS rate of 37% versus 0% in the nonintervention group (<em>

15557P</em>

15558 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_10.138">

15559138</a>

15560]</li>

15561<li>

15562Other studies have shown better-than-expected rates of survival of pre-HSCT, MRD-positive patients when tapering of immunosuppression medication has occurred for MRD detected after HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_10.139">

15563139</a>

15564]</li>

15565<li>

15566A large international study showed a marked decrease in relapse in patients who experienced MRD-positive disease after HSCT and developed acute GHVD (HR, 0.29; <em>

15567P</em>

15568 &lt; .001), resulting in improved EFS (HR, 2.9; <em>

15569P</em>

15570 = .01). Acute GVHD significantly decreased relapse and improved EFS in both MRD-positive and MRD-negative patients. Chronic GVHD was also associated with less relapse in both MRD-positive and MRD-negative patients.[<a href="#cit/section_10.89">

1557189</a>

15572]</li>

15573</ul>

15574</div>

15575</section>

15576</section>

15577<section id="_1570">

15578<h4 id="_1570_toc">

15579Intrathecal medication after HSCT to prevent relapse</h4>

15580<p id="_1571" tabindex="-1">

15581The use of post-HSCT intrathecal chemotherapy chemoprophylaxis is controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_10.140">

15582140</a>

15583-<a href="#cit/section_10.143">

15584143</a>

15585]</p>

15586</section>

15587<section id="_1405">

15588<h4 id="_1405_toc">

15589Relapse after allogeneic HSCT for relapsed ALL</h4>

15590<p id="_1224" tabindex="-1">

15591For patients with B-ALL who relapse after allogeneic HSCT and can be successfully weaned from immune suppression and have no GVHD, tisagenlecleucel and other 4-1BB CAR T-cell approaches have resulted in EFS rates exceeding 50% at 12 months.[<a href="#cit/section_10.144">

15592144</a>

15593] For patients with T-ALL who relapse or for patients with B-ALL who are unable to undergo CAR T-cell therapy, a second ablative allogeneic HSCT may be feasible. However, many patients will be unable to undergo a second HSCT procedure because of failure to achieve remission, early toxic death, or severe organ toxicity related to salvage chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.145">

15594145</a>

15595] Among the highly selected group of patients able to undergo a second ablative allogeneic HSCT, approximately 10% to 30% will achieve long-term EFS.[<a href="#cit/section_10.145">

15596145</a>

15597-<a href="#cit/section_10.150">

15598150</a>

15599]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.79">

1560079</a>

15601,<a href="#cit/section_10.151">

15602151</a>

15603][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15604Level of evidence C1</a>

15605] Prognosis is more favorable in patients with longer duration of remission after the first HSCT and in patients with CR at the time of the second HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_10.147">

15606147</a>

15607,<a href="#cit/section_10.148">

15608148</a>

15609,<a href="#cit/section_10.152">

15610152</a>

15611] In addition, one study showed an improvement in survival after second HSCT if acute GVHD occurred, especially if it had not occurred after the first transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_10.153">

15612153</a>

15613] </p>

15614<p id="_1363" tabindex="-1">

15615Reduced-intensity approaches can also cure a percentage of patients when used as a second allogeneic transplant approach, but only if patients achieve a CR confirmed by flow cytometry.[<a href="#cit/section_10.154">

15616154</a>

15617][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15618Level of evidence B4</a>

15619] Donor leukocyte infusion has limited benefit for patients with ALL who relapse after allogeneic HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_10.155">

15620155</a>

15621]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.156">

15622156</a>

15623][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15624Level of evidence C1</a>

15625] </p>

15626<p id="_1291" tabindex="-1">

15627Whether a second allogeneic transplant is necessary to treat isolated CNS and testicular relapse after HSCT is unknown. A small series has shown survival in selected patients using chemotherapy alone or chemotherapy followed by a second transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_10.157">

15628157</a>

15629][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15630Level of evidence C1</a>

15631]</p>

15632</section>

15633</section>

15634<section id="_1928">

15635<h3 id="_1928_toc">

15636Immunotherapeutic Approaches for Relapsed or Refractory ALL</h3>

15637<p id="_1929" tabindex="-1">

15638Immunotherapeutic approaches for the treatment of relapsed or refractory ALL include monoclonal antibody therapy and CAR T-cell therapy.</p>

15639<section id="_1930">

15640<h4 id="_1930_toc">

15641Monoclonal antibody therapy</h4>

15642<p id="_1931" tabindex="-1">

15643The following two immunotherapeutic agents have been studied for the treatment of patients with relapsed or refractory B-ALL:</p>

15644<div class="pdq-content-list">

15645<ul id="_1952">

15646<li>

15647<strong>

15648Blinatumomab.</strong>

15649 Blinatumomab is a bispecific monoclonal antibody with one site for CD3 (T cells) and the other site for CD19 (present on most B-ALL cells). Thus, blinatumomab promotes the binding of the patient&#8217;s own cytotoxic T cells to B lymphoblasts, resulting in the tumor being killed.<p id="_2286" tabindex="-1">

15650 In a phase I/II trial of children younger than 18 years with relapsed/refractory B-ALL, 27 of 70 patients (39%) treated at the recommended phase II dose achieved a CR with single-agent blinatumomab; 52% of those achieving CR were MRD negative.[<a href="#cit/section_10.158">

15651158</a>

15652]</p>

15653</li>

15654<li>

15655<strong>

15656Inotuzumab.</strong>

15657 Inotuzumab is an anti-CD22 monoclonal antibody that is conjugated to calicheamicin.<p id="_2287" tabindex="-1">

15658 In trials of adult patients with relapsed/refractory B-ALL, CR was achieved in approximately 80% of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_10.159">

15659159</a>

15660,<a href="#cit/section_10.160">

15661160</a>

15662] </p>

15663<p id="_2522" tabindex="-1">

15664There have been two phase II trials of single-agent inotuzumab (both trials used 1.8 mg/m<span class="sup">

156652</span>

15666 total dose in the first course and 1.5 mg/m<span class="sup">

156672</span>

15668 in subsequent courses) used in the treatment of pediatric patients with relapsed (second or greater relapse) or refractory ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_10.84">

1566984</a>

15670]</p>

15671<div class="pdq-content-list">

15672<ul id="_2523">

15673<li>

15674In the COG phase II trial (N = 48), the overall response rate (ORR) (CR + CRi) was 58.3% after the first course, and 62.5% after two courses. Of those achieving complete response or complete response with incomplete count recovery, 70% were MRD negative (&lt;0.01%). Overall, inotuzumab was well tolerated, without any significant hepatoxicity or sinusoidal obstructive syndrome (SOS) during treatment. However, of 21 patients who subsequently went on to receive HSCT, 6 (28.6%) developed SOS.[<a href="#cit/section_10.84">

1567584</a>

15676]</li>

15677<li>

15678On a phase II trial conducted by the Innovative Therapies for Children With Cancer group (N = 28), the ORR was 81.5% (all responses occurring after the first cycle). Of the patients achieving a response, 81.8% achieved MRD negativity (&lt;0.01%), 59.1% after the first course, and the remaining patients after the second course. SOS was observed in seven (28%) patients, six after subsequent HSCT and one during inotuzumab therapy. There was no correlation between the extent of CD22 expression (mean fluorescence index or percentage of CD22 positive cells) and response. In a post-hoc analysis, combining patients from the phase I and phase II trials, the authors found that having a shorter interval between last dose of inotuzumab and undergoing HSCT was associated with a higher risk of developing SOS.[<a href="#cit/section_10.161">

15679161</a>

15680]</li>

15681</ul>

15682</div>

15683<p id="_2288" tabindex="-1">

15684Expert panel recommendations for the prevention of SOS associated with HSCT after inotuzumab include limiting inotuzumab to two courses, avoiding dual-alkylator HSCT regimens, avoiding hepatotoxic agents, and considering SOS prophylactic agents.[<a href="#cit/section_10.162">

15685162</a>

15686]</p>

15687</li>

15688<li>

15689<strong>

15690Rituximab or ofatumumab.</strong>

15691 These monoclonal antibodies target CD20, which is poorly expressed in younger children with ALL, but more common in teenagers and young adults. A number of studies have suggested benefit when adding one of these agents to reinduction chemotherapy in adults,[<a href="#cit/section_10.163">

15692163</a>

15693,<a href="#cit/section_10.164">

15694164</a>

15695] but very little data have been published in children.</li>

15696</ul>

15697</div>

15698</section>

15699<section id="_1932">

15700<h4 id="_1932_toc">

15701CAR T-cell therapy</h4>

15702<p id="_1933" tabindex="-1">

15703Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy is a therapeutic strategy for pediatric B-ALL patients with refractory disease or those in second or subsequent relapse. This treatment involves engineering T cells with a CAR that redirects T-cell specificity and function.[<a href="#cit/section_10.165">

15704165</a>

15705] One widely utilized target of CAR-modified T cells is the CD19 antigen expressed on almost all normal B cells and most B-cell malignancies. </p>

15706<section id="_2268">

15707<h5 id="_2268_toc">

15708Toxicities associated with CAR T-cell therapy</h5>

15709<p id="_2005" tabindex="-1">

15710Treatment with CAR T cells has been associated with cytokine release syndrome, which can be life-threatening.[<a href="#cit/section_10.166">

15711166</a>

15712,<a href="#cit/section_10.167">

15713167</a>

15714] Cytokine release syndrome presents as fever, headache, myalgias, hypotension, capillary leak, hypoxia, and renal dysfunction. Severe cytokine release syndrome has been effectively treated with tocilizumab, an anti&#8211;interleukin-6 receptor (IL-6R) antibody.[<a href="#cit/section_10.166">

15715166</a>

15716,<a href="#cit/section_10.168">

15717168</a>

15718] Long-term persistence of CAR T cells can lead to B-cell aplasia, necessitating immunoglobulin replacement.[<a href="#cit/section_10.166">

15719166</a>

15720]</p>

15721<p id="_2269" tabindex="-1">

15722Neurotoxicity, including aphasia, altered mental status, and seizures, has also been observed with CAR T-cell therapy, and the symptoms usually resolve spontaneously.[<a href="#cit/section_10.169">

15723169</a>

15724] CNS symptoms have not responded to IL-6R&#8211;targeting agents or other approaches.</p>

15725<p id="_2270" tabindex="-1">

15726Other CAR T-cell therapy side effects include coagulopathy, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)&#8211;like laboratory changes, and cardiac dysfunction. Between 20% and 40% of patients require treatment in the intensive care unit, mostly pressor support, with 10% to 20% of patients requiring intubation and/or dialysis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.165">

15727165</a>

15728,<a href="#cit/section_10.166">

15729166</a>

15730,<a href="#cit/section_10.170">

15731170</a>

15732,<a href="#cit/section_10.171">

15733171</a>

15734] </p>

15735<p id="_2400" tabindex="-1">

15736For an extensive discussion of CAR T-cell toxicities and approaches to mitigate these toxicities, see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/hp-stem-cell-transplant/car-t-cell-therapy">

15737Pediatric Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T-Cell Therapy</a>

15738.</p>

15739</section>

15740<section id="_2271">

15741<h5 id="_2271_toc">

15742CD19-targeted CAR T-cell therapy</h5>

15743<p id="_2006" tabindex="-1">

15744Several clinical trials of CAR T cells targeting CD19 in relapsed/refractory ALL have been conducted, with encouraging results. Published trials have involved the use of two types of costimulatory molecules, 4-1BB and CD28. CD28-based approaches have led to high rates of remission, but CAR T cells in these trials rarely persist longer than 1 to 2 months, necessitating HSCT for long-term survival.[<a href="#cit/section_10.172">

15745172</a>

15746] Many of the trials that used 4-1BB costimulation have resulted in persistence of CAR T cells for extended periods and long-term responses.[<a href="#cit/section_10.144">

15747144</a>

15748,<a href="#cit/section_10.170">

15749170</a>

15750]</p>

15751<p id="_2025" tabindex="-1">

15752Evidence (CD19-targeted CAR T-cell therapy):</p>

15753<div class="pdq-content-list">

15754<ol id="_1934">

15755<li>

15756In pilot clinical trials conducted at the Children&#8217;s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) and the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, 30 children and adults (25 of whom were aged 22 years or younger) with multiply relapsed or refractory CD19-positive ALL were given T cells transduced with CD19-directed 4-1BB CAR lentiviral vector.[<a href="#cit/section_10.166">

15757166</a>

15758][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15759Level of evidence C2</a>

15760]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15761<ul id="_1990">

15762<li>

15763 CR was obtained in 90% of patients, including 15 of 18 patients (83%) who had previously received allogeneic HSCT.</li>

15764<li>

15765The 6-month EFS rate was 67%, with most patients showing persistence of the CAR T cells and B-cell aplasia through 6 months.</li>

15766<li>

15767All 30 patients experienced some degree of cytokine release syndrome. Eight patients (27%) had severe symptoms requiring vasopressors and/or respiratory support. Cytokine release syndrome was effectively treated with tocilizumab.</li>

15768</ul>

15769</div>

15770</li>

15771<li>

15772A report of a phase I trial of 45 children and young adults with relapsed/refractory CD19-positive B-ALL who received 4-1BB&#8211;based lentiviral vector expanded CAR T cells showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_10.170">

15773170</a>

15774]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15775<ul id="_1982">

15776<li>

15777An overall remission rate of 89% for all patients enrolled using an intent-to-treat analysis.</li>

15778<li>

15779Improved long-term persistence of CAR T cells and B-cell aplasia in patients who: (1) received lymphodepleting strategies that contain fludarabine and cyclophosphamide, and (2) started the treatment with a higher percentage of cells expressing CD19, either on blasts or normal B cells.</li>

15780</ul>

15781</div>

15782</li>

15783<li>

15784A global phase II trial of the anti-CD19 4-1BB vector developed at the CHOP and the University of Pennsylvania led to U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval of tisagenlecleucel for children with multiply relapsed or refractory B-ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_10.144">

15785144</a>

15786]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15787<ul id="_2042">

15788<li>

15789Of 92 patients enrolled, 75 were infused with successfully manufactured CAR T cells. Eighty-one percent of infused patients had two measures noting CR within the first 3 months of infusion, and 100% of the remissions were MRD negative.</li>

15790<li>

15791The EFS rate of infused patients was 73% at 6 months and 50% at 12 months. The OS rate of infused patients was 90% at 6 months and 70% at 12 months.</li>

15792<li>

15793The CIBMTR performed a real-world analysis of 255 patients with ALL that largely duplicated the outcomes shown in the pivotal trials, with an initial CR rate of 85.5%. The 12-month duration of response rate was 69.9%, the EFS rate was 52.4%, and the OS rate was 77.2%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.173">

15794173</a>

15795]</li>

15796</ul>

15797</div>

15798</li>

15799<li>

15800A subsequent study from the University of Pennsylvania reported the 3-year updated results of the global phase II <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02435849">

15801ELIANA (NCT02435849)</a>

15802 trial that included 79 patients who were treated with tisagenlecleucel.[<a href="#cit/section_10.174">

15803174</a>

15804][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15805Level of evidence C2</a>

15806]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15807<ul id="_2537">

15808<li>

15809 The overall remission rate was 82% at 3 months.</li>

15810<li>

15811With a median follow-up of 38.8 months, the median duration of remission of the 66 patients with a complete response has not been reached. The estimated relapse-free survival (RFS) rate was 58% at 24 months and 52% at 36 months.</li>

15812<li>

15813Of the 32 patients in CR who received no additional therapy, the estimated RFS rate was 81% at 24 months and 76% at 36 months.</li>

15814</ul>

15815</div>

15816</li>

15817<li>

15818A report from the Pediatric Oncology Branch at the NCI described the use of a different CD19-targeted CAR T-cell product with a CD28 costimulatory domain that used a retroviral vector for gene transduction.[<a href="#cit/section_10.172">

15819172</a>

15820] <div class="pdq-content-list">

15821<ul id="_1991">

15822<li>

15823This CD19-CAR T-cell product induced complete responses in 70% of patients (14 of 20) (aged 1&#8211;30 years) with relapsed/refractory B-ALL.</li>

15824<li>

15825Persistence of CAR T cells in this study was 1 to 2 months, with recovery of normal B-cell lymphopoiesis in patients who achieved CR.</li>

15826<li>

15827In a subsequent follow-up study of 50 children and young adults who were treated with CD19-CAR T cells, 21 patients achieved an MRD-negative CR and received an allogeneic HSCT. In these 21 patients, the median OS was 70.2 months, and the 5-year EFS rate was 61.9%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.175">

15828175</a>

15829][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15830Level of evidence C2</a>

15831]</li>

15832</ul>

15833</div>

15834</li>

15835<li>

15836Another report described a multicenter trial of 25 children and young adults who were treated with anti-CD19, anti-CD28z CAR T cells. Investigators increased the dose of lymphodepleting cyclophosphamide during the trial and analyzed outcomes on the basis of low-dose and high-dose preconditioning, as well as the presence of MRD versus morphological evidence of disease before treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_10.176">

15837176</a>

15838][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

15839Level of evidence A1</a>

15840]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15841<ul id="_2224">

15842<li>

15843All toxicities were reversible, including 16% of patients with severe cytokine release syndrome and 28% of patients with severe neurotoxicity.</li>

15844<li>

15845The overall complete response rate was 75%, and 89% of patients in CR were MRD negative.</li>

15846<li>

15847The response rate was superior in the high-dose cyclophosphamide cohort than in the low-dose cohort (94% vs. 38%); the response rate was higher in the MRD cohort than in the morphological disease cohort (93% vs. 50%).</li>

15848<li>

15849Of 18 responding patients, 15 underwent consolidative HSCT.</li>

15850<li>

15851Improvement in OS only occurred in patients who received the higher dose of cyclophosphamide conditioning.</li>

15852</ul>

15853</div>

15854</li>

15855<li>

15856In an effort to overcome early loss of functional CD19-targeted CAR T cells, a humanized 4-1BB approach was tested in children and young adults with relapsed or refractory B-ALL or B-lymphoblastic lymphoma. Patients were treated in two cohorts: (1) patients without previous CAR T-cell exposure (CAR-na&#239;ve group) and (2) patients with previous CAR exposure who did not respond to more standard CARs, based on mouse-derived antibodies (re-treated group).[<a href="#cit/section_10.177">

15857177</a>

15858]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15859<ul id="_2401">

15860<li>

15861CR was achieved in 98% of CAR-na&#239;ve patients and 64% of re-treated patients.</li>

15862<li>

15863At 6 months, of those who responded, 27% of CAR-na&#239;ve patients and 48% of re-treated patients lost CAR persistence.</li>

15864<li>

15865For CAR-naive patients, the RFS rate was 84% (95% CI, 72%&#8211;97%) at 12 months and 74% (95% CI, 60%&#8211;90%) at 24 months.</li>

15866<li>

15867For the re-treatment cohort, the RFS rate was 74% (95% CI, 56%&#8211;97%) at 12 months and 58% (95% CI, 37%&#8211;90%) at 24 months.</li>

15868<li>

15869While these results appear favorable, they were not directly compared to currently approved CAR T cells.</li>

15870</ul>

15871</div>

15872</li>

15873</ol>

15874</div>

15875<section id="_2434">

15876<h6 id="_2434_toc">

15877Risk factors associated with CD19-targeted CAR T-cell failure</h6>

15878<p id="_2435" tabindex="-1">

15879Initial trials that used CAR T-cell therapy demonstrated that a very high proportion of patients with relapsed or refractory disease achieved CR, regardless of white blood cell count, cytogenetics,[<a href="#cit/section_10.178">

15880178</a>

15881] number of prior therapies, chemotherapy responsiveness, or other traditional factors associated with chemotherapy responsiveness. Subsequent studies have identified the following factors that are associated with poor long-term responses in patients who achieve initial CRs after CAR T-cell infusions:</p>

15882<div class="pdq-content-list">

15883<ol id="_2436">

15884<li>

15885Tumor burden at the time of CAR T-cell infusion.<div class="pdq-content-list">

15886<ol id="_2463" class="lower-alpha">

15887<li>

15888A single-center study assessed bone marrow blast percentage immediately before CAR T-cell infusion (after lymphodepleting chemotherapy). High tumor burden (HTB) was defined as 40% blasts or more, and low tumor burden (LTB) was defined as less than 40% blasts.[<a href="#cit/section_10.168">

15889168</a>

15890] <div class="pdq-content-list">

15891<ul id="_2468">

15892<li>

15893In the HTB cohort of patients (n = 15), the best ORR was 87%, and the MRD-negative CR rate was 80%.</li>

15894<li>

15895 In the LTB cohort of patients (n = 55), the best ORR was 100%, and all responders were MRD negative. </li>

15896<li>

15897Among HTB patients, the probability of continued remission was 49% (95% CI, 27%&#8211;88%) at 12 months and 39% (95% CI, 19%&#8211;82%) at 24 months.</li>

15898<li>

15899Among LTB patients, the probability of continued remission was 86% (95% CI, 77%&#8211;96%) at 12 months and 78% (95% CI, 67%&#8211;91%) at 24 months.</li>

15900</ul>

15901</div>

15902</li>

15903<li>

15904A study of 420 patients assessed the risk factors associated with long-term survival.[<a href="#cit/section_10.179">

15905179</a>

15906] <div class="pdq-content-list">

15907<ul id="_2469">

15908<li>

15909On multivariate analysis, a disease burden of 5% or higher, noted by bone marrow flow cytometry before starting lymphodepleting chemotherapy, was associated with a hazard ratio (HR) of 2.52 (95% CI, 1.86&#8211;3.41) for inferior EFS, compared with patients who had a lower disease burden.</li>

15910</ul>

15911</div>

15912</li>

15913<li>

15914In a study of 180 patients who received tisagenlecleucel infusions, univariate and multivariate analyses showed that high-disease burden (&gt;5% bone marrow blasts, CNS3 disease [defined as cerebrospinal fluid specimen with &#8805;5 white blood cells/&#956;L with lymphoblasts and/or the presence of cranial nerve palsies], or non-CNS extramedullary disease [EMD]) was associated with inferior outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_10.180">

15915180</a>

15916] <div class="pdq-content-list">

15917<ul id="_2470">

15918<li>

15919Patients with a high-disease burden had poorer outcomes (12-month OS rate, 58%; EFS rate, 31%) than patients with a low-disease burden (12-month OS rate, 85%; EFS rate, 70%) and patients with undetectable disease (12-month OS rate, 95%; EFS rate, 72%; <em>

15920P</em>

15921 &lt; .0001 for OS and EFS).</li>

15922</ul>

15923</div>

15924</li>

15925</ol>

15926</div>

15927</li>

15928<li>

15929Previous failure to respond to blinatumomab.<div class="pdq-content-list">

15930<ol id="_2464" class="lower-alpha">

15931<li>

15932In a study of 420 pediatric and young adult patients with ALL who were treated with CD19-targeted CAR T cells, the following results were reported:[<a href="#cit/section_10.179">

15933179</a>

15934]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15935<ul id="_2471">

15936<li>

15937Patients who had previously failed to respond to blinatumomab before CAR T-cell therapy had lower CR rates after CAR T-cell therapy (20 of 31, 64.5%) compared with previous responders to blinatumomab (39 of 42, 92.9%) or blinatumomab-na&#239;ve patients (317 of 339, 93.5%; <em>

15938P</em>

15939 &lt; .0001). </li>

15940<li>

15941Blinatumomab nonresponders had worse 6-month EFS rates (27.3%; 95% CI, 13.6%&#8211;43.0%) than blinatumomab responders (66.9%; 95% CI, 50.6%&#8211;78.9%; <em>

15942P</em>

15943 &lt; .0001) or blinatumomab-na&#239;ve patients (72.6%; 95% CI, 67.5%&#8211;77%; <em>

15944P</em>

15945 &lt; .0001).</li>

15946</ul>

15947</div>

15948</li>

15949</ol>

15950</div>

15951</li>

15952<li>

15953Persistent B-cell aplasia and next-generation sequencing of MRD (NGS-MRD).<div class="pdq-content-list">

15954<ol id="_2465" class="lower-alpha">

15955<li>

15956Early studies recognized that B-cell aplasia was a functional measurement of CD19-targeted CAR T-cell persistence, and that loss of B-cell aplasia within the first few months of treatment resulted in high rates of relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.166">

15957166</a>

15958] However, it is an imperfect measurement because CD19-negative relapse can occur despite persistent B-cell aplasia. NGS-MRD techniques rely on clonal rearrangements in the IgH or TCR sequences in lymphoblasts, which typically persist even when CD19 surface expression is lost.</li>

15959<li>

15960To define the risk of relapse, one study assessed B-cell aplasia and NGS-MRD in bone marrow over time in 143 patients who received tisagenlecleucel.[<a href="#cit/section_10.181">

15961181</a>

15962]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15963<ul id="_2472">

15964<li>

15965Multivariate analysis at day 28 showed independent associations of NGS-MRD greater than 0 (HR, 4.87; 95% CI, 2.18&#8211;10.8; <em>

15966P</em>

15967 &lt; .001) and loss of B-cell aplasia (HR, 3.33; 95% CI, 1.44&#8211;7.69; <em>

15968P</em>

15969 = .005) with relapse. </li>

15970<li>

15971By 3 months, the NGS-MRD HR increased to 12 (95% CI, 2.87&#8211;50; <em>

15972P</em>

15973 &lt; .001), whereas loss of B-cell aplasia was not independently predictive (HR, 1.27; 95% CI, 0.33&#8211;4.79; <em>

15974P</em>

15975 = .7). </li>

15976<li>

15977Early loss of B-cell aplasia was more predictive of relapse than a later loss of B-cell aplasia. </li>

15978<li>

15979Loss of B-cell aplasia in the first 6 months led to an EFS rate lower than 20%; however, patients who lost B-cell aplasia at 1 year had an EFS rate of 75%. </li>

15980<li>

15981Notably, NGS-MRD positivity occurring at any time after CAR T-cell therapy led to a very high risk of relapse.</li>

15982</ul>

15983</div>

15984</li>

15985</ol>

15986</div>

15987</li>

15988<li>

15989CNS disease and non-CNS EMD.<p id="_2524" tabindex="-1">

15990Although there are concerns that the treatment of patients with CNS disease could increase risk of neurotoxicity associated with CAR T-cell therapy, recent studies have shown that patients with CNS disease who undergo CAR T-cell therapy have similar outcomes to those without CNS disease, with no increase in severe immune effector cell associated neurotoxicity syndrome (ICANS).[<a href="#cit/section_10.182">

15991182</a>

15992,<a href="#cit/section_10.183">

15993183</a>

15994]</p>

15995<p id="_2525" tabindex="-1">

15996Evidence (CAR T-cell therapy for patients with CNS disease):</p>

15997<div class="pdq-content-list">

15998<ol id="_2485" class="lower-alpha">

15999<li>

16000Active CNS disease at relapse and/or infusion.<div class="pdq-content-list">

16001<ul id="_2535">

16002<li>

16003A single-center report analyzed 195 sequential patients treated with 4-1BB CD19-targeted CAR T cells, 66 of whom had CNS disease (43 with isolated CNS disease, 23 with combined bone marrow/CNS disease).[<a href="#cit/section_10.182">

16004182</a>

16005]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16006<ul id="_2526">

16007<li>

16008Overall, there was no difference in remission rates and progression-free survival rates with or without CNS disease.</li>

16009<li>

16010Patients with isolated CNS involvement had an RFS rate at 2 years of 66% (95% CI, 52%&#8211;82%), compared with 58% (95% CI, 50%&#8211;68%) for patients with bone marrow involvement (<em>

16011P</em>

16012 = .15).</li>

16013<li>

16014Ninety-eight percent of patients were treated before their infusion for their CNS disease and reached CNS1 or CNS2 status at the time of CAR T-cell treatment. Patients with symptomatic/progressive CNS disease were not treated until the disease was controlled and stable.</li>

16015</ul>

16016</div>

16017</li>

16018<li>

16019A retrospective report examined the outcomes of 184 patients who were treated with tisagenlecleucel at 15 U.S. institutions. In this series, patients were referred for CAR T-cell infusion for marrow-only disease (n = 129), CNS disease (n = 40; either isolated [n = 23] or combined marrow/CNS disease [n = 17]), and non-CNS EMD (n = 15; 6 patients with isolated EMD and 9 with marrow involvement). All but one patient with CNS disease received tisagenlecleucel after one or more relapses (none had previously underwent transplantation), whereas 29 of the marrow-only patients (22%) received infusions in first CR, 10 of whom (7.8%) had previously underwent transplantation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.183">

16020183</a>

16021]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16022<ul id="_2536">

16023<li>

16024In patients referred to receive tisagenlecleucel for CNS disease (n = 40), 31 (78%) were already CNS-negative at the time of infusion, and 88% (35 of 40) were in CR at day 28 after infusion. For patients with non-CNS EMD, 10 of 15 (66%) were in CR at day 28.</li>

16025<li>

16026The 12-month RFS rate was 59.4% for patients with marrow-only disease, 59.4% for patients with CNS disease (isolated or combined), and 50% for those with non-CNS EMD (isolated or combined) (<em>

16027P</em>

16028 = .92).</li>

16029<li>

16030In the CNS-disease cohort, there was no significant difference in 12-month RFS between patients with isolated CNS disease and those with combined CNS and marrow disease (<em>

16031P</em>

16032 = .63).</li>

16033<li>

16034Grade 3 or 4 neurotoxicity was observed in 3 of 40 patients (7.5%) in the CNS-disease cohort, compared with 9 of 129 patients (7%) with marrow-only disease. None of the patients with active CNS disease at the time of infusion experienced grade 3 or 4 neurotoxicity.</li>

16035</ul>

16036</div>

16037</li>

16038<li>

16039A second multicenter report reviewed 55 patients with relapses involving the CNS (isolated or combined with bone marrow) who were treated with either a CD28-based institutional CAR (n = 12) or tisagenlecleucel (4-1BB vector, n = 43).[<a href="#cit/section_10.184">

16040184</a>

16041]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16042<ul id="_2572">

16043<li>

16044Remission was achieved in 92% of children who received CD28-based CAR T cells and 93% of children who received 4-1BB&#8211;based CAR T cells.</li>

16045<li>

16046Of 11 children who received CD28-based CAR T cells and achieved a CR, 9 underwent HSCT. Seven of these nine patients survived relapse free.</li>

16047<li>

16048None of the 40 patients who were treated with the 4-1BB&#8211;based CAR T cells (tisagenlecleucel) and achieved a CR had a planned HSCT. Nineteen of these patients experienced relapses, 12 of whom had CNS relapses.</li>

16049<li>

16050Patients who received tisagenlecleucel for an isolated CNS relapse had a high incidence of subsequent CNS relapse (6 of 8 patients).</li>

16051</ul>

16052</div>

16053</li>

16054</ul>

16055</div>

16056</li>

16057<li>

16058For non-CNS EMD, available data are limited.<div class="pdq-content-list">

16059<ul id="_2487">

16060<li>

16061The report of 195 patients above compared CNS EMD, non-CNS EMD, and bone marrow&#8211;only disease. No differences in overall survival and RFS were noted between the groups.[<a href="#cit/section_10.182">

16062182</a>

16063]</li>

16064<li>

16065In contrast, a large retrospective analysis found that active EMD at infusion was independently associated with worse EFS (HR, 1.9; <em>

16066P</em>

16067 = .01).[<a href="#cit/section_10.179">

16068179</a>

16069]</li>

16070<li>

16071A separate analysis found that in 15 patients with non-CNS EMD, 10 achieved a CR, and 6 of the 10 patients subsequently relapsed. Consequently, only 4 of 15 patients remained event-free during the follow-up period.[<a href="#cit/section_10.183">

16072183</a>

16073]</li>

16074<li>

16075A retrospective analysis from the NCI identified limitations in eradication of non-CNS EMD with CAR T cells, despite concurrent marrow responses, highlighting the important role of positron emission tomography scans for monitoring.[<a href="#cit/section_10.185">

16076185</a>

16077]</li>

16078</ul>

16079</div>

16080</li>

16081</ol>

16082</div>

16083</li>

16084<li>

16085CAR T-cell dose.<div class="pdq-content-list">

16086<ol id="_2573" class="lower-alpha">

16087<li>

16088A retrospective multicenter study reviewed the doses of CD19-targeted CAR T cells (tisagenlecleucel) given per kilogram by quartiles and assessed patient outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_10.186">

16089186</a>

16090]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16091<ul id="_2574">

16092<li>

16093Patients who received the highest quartile dose had improved OS (HR, 0.22; 95% CI, 0.08&#8211;0.61), EFS (HR, 0.24; 95% CI, 0.12&#8211;0.49), and RFS (HR, 0.18; 95% CI, 0.07&#8211;0.49), compared with those who received the lowest quartile dose.</li>

16094<li>

16095Higher doses of CAR T cells were not associated with additional toxicities.</li>

16096<li>

16097A potential confounding factor was the significantly higher number of patients with favorable cytogenetics who received the highest quartile dose.</li>

16098<li>

16099Further research is warranted to elucidate the relationship between threshold dosing and post-CAR T-cell therapy outcomes for tisagenlecleucel.</li>

16100</ul>

16101</div>

16102</li>

16103</ol>

16104</div>

16105</li>

16106</ol>

16107</div>

16108</section>

16109<section id="_2440">

16110<h6 id="_2440_toc">

16111The role of consolidative HSCT after CD19-targeted CAR T-cell therapy for ALL</h6>

16112<p id="_2441" tabindex="-1">

16113Studies of second-generation CD19-targeted CAR T-cell approaches have shown that constructs using CD28-based costimulatory molecules result in a relatively short half-life of CAR T cells. This short half-life leads to very high rates of relapse unless HSCT is done soon after recovery from CAR T-cell toxicities. Therefore, treatments with CD28-targeted CAR T cells are considered bridging therapies, and HSCT is generally planned for eligible patients 4 to 8 weeks after the CAR T-cell procedure. Tisagenlecleucel and other CARs with 4-1BB costimulatory molecules have been shown to have significant levels of persistence, leading to long-term remission in 45% to 50% of patients without additional therapy. Up to 80% of relapses occur during the first year after CAR T-cell therapy and there is a window of deep remission. Because of this finding, some study groups have argued for planned HSCT during remission early after CAR T-cell infusion, either in all patients or in patients who have not had a previous HSCT. No randomized trials have addressed this issue, but some studies have addressed this question retrospectively.</p>

16114<p id="_2442" tabindex="-1">

16115Evidence (consolidative HSCT after CAR T-cell therapy):</p>

16116<div class="pdq-content-list">

16117<ol id="_2443">

16118<li>

16119CD28 CAR T-cell bridging approach.<div class="pdq-content-list">

16120<ol id="_2473" class="lower-alpha">

16121<li>

16122A study examined 50 children and young adults who were treated with CD28-based CD19 CAR T-cell therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.175">

16123175</a>

16124][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

16125Level of evidence C2</a>

16126]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16127<ul id="_2474">

16128<li>

16129Twenty-one patients achieved an MRD-negative CR and underwent an allogeneic HSCT. In these 21 patients, the median OS was 70.2 months, and the 5-year EFS rate was 61.9%.</li>

16130</ul>

16131</div>

16132</li>

16133</ol>

16134</div>

16135</li>

16136<li>

161374-1BB CARs with varying approaches to HSCT.<div class="pdq-content-list">

16138<ol id="_2475" class="lower-alpha">

16139<li>

16140A study of 50 patients eligible for HSCT after 4-1BB-based CAR T-cell therapy reported the following results (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02028455">

16141PLAT-02 [NCT02028455]</a>

16142 trial):[<a href="#cit/section_10.187">

16143187</a>

16144]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16145<ul id="_2476">

16146<li>

16147Patients who lost CAR T-cell function before 63 days after therapy had improved LFS if they underwent HSCT, compared with those who did not undergo HSCT (<em>

16148P</em>

16149 = .01).</li>

16150<li>

16151Patients with no prior history of HSCT had an improved LFS with a planned HSCT, with a trend toward significance (<em>

16152P</em>

16153 = .09). This benefit was not evident in the 34 patients with a history of prior HSCT (<em>

16154P</em>

16155 = .45).</li>

16156</ul>

16157</div>

16158</li>

16159</ol>

16160</div>

16161</li>

16162<li>

161634-1BB CARs followed by an intent to perform HSCT.<div class="pdq-content-list">

16164<ol id="_2477" class="lower-alpha">

16165<li>

16166In a study from China of 52 children who received either CD19- or CD22-targeted CAR T-cell therapy and underwent a planned HSCT at a median of 50 days after CAR T-cell infusion (range, 34&#8211;98 days; 48 MRD-negative and 4 MRD-positive patients at time of HSCT), the following results were reported:[<a href="#cit/section_10.188">

16167188</a>

16168]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16169<ul id="_2478">

16170<li>

16171The 1-year EFS rate was 73%, and the 1-year OS rate was 87.7%. </li>

16172<li>

16173Although the survival rate of patients eligible to proceed to HSCT in remission was high, the analysis did not include patients who had a previous HSCT, patients who did not achieve remission with CAR T-cell infusions, and patients who were not eligible for HSCT after CAR T-cell therapy.</li>

16174</ul>

16175</div>

16176</li>

16177</ol>

16178</div>

16179</li>

16180</ol>

16181</div>

16182</section>

16183</section>

16184<section id="_2272">

16185<h5 id="_2272_toc">

16186CD22-targeted CAR T-cell therapy</h5>

16187<p id="_2149" tabindex="-1">

16188 At least 50% of relapses after CD19-targeted CAR T-cell therapy have occurred because of antigen escape, which has been shown to be related to mutations in the CD19 protein that delete the binding sites used by CAR T-cell constructs.[<a href="#cit/section_10.189">

16189189</a>

16190] Salvage after antigen escape has been documented with cell and immune therapy approaches targeting a second lymphoid antigen, CD22. Studies looking specifically at inotuzumab rescue of CD19-negative relapse have not been published, but two groups have reported high rates of subsequent achievement of remission and survival, generally when CD22 CAR T-cell therapy is followed by HSCT therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.190">

16191190</a>

16192,<a href="#cit/section_10.191">

16193191</a>

16194]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.192">

16195192</a>

16196][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

16197Level of evidence C1</a>

16198]; [<a href="#cit/section_10.188">

16199188</a>

16200][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

16201Level of evidence C2</a>

16202] Because the CD22 antigen can be downregulated, there is concern about targeting CD22 alone for long-term CAR T-cell response; consequently, this approach is often paired with HSCT.</p>

16203<p id="_2150" tabindex="-1">

16204 Evidence (CD22-targeted CAR T-cell therapy):</p>

16205<div class="pdq-content-list">

16206<ol id="_2151">

16207<li>

16208Investigators at the NCI reported a phase I/II trial of 58 children and young adults treated with a CD22-targeted CAR T-cell approach.[<a href="#cit/section_10.193">

16209193</a>

16210][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

16211Level of evidence C2</a>

16212] <div class="pdq-content-list">

16213<ul id="_2291">

16214<li>

16215Of the 55 patients with ALL who were infused, 40 achieved CRs (73%); 88% of those patients achieved MRD-negative remissions.</li>

16216<li>

16217Although 86% of patients experienced cytokine release syndrome, 90% experienced grades 1 to 2 cytokine release syndrome. </li>

16218<li>

16219Thirty-three percent of patients experienced neurotoxicity, all of which were grades 1 or 2, except in one patient who experienced an intracranial hemorrhage. </li>

16220<li>

16221Thirty-eight percent of patients had an HLH/macrophage activation syndrome (MAS)&#8211;like syndrome that sometimes required management with anakinra.</li>

16222<li>

16223Patients who received CD22-targeted therapy with inotuzumab or CD22 CAR T-cell therapy before this therapy had lower rates of CD22 expression, were less likely to achieve remission, and had shorter duration of remission.</li>

16224<li>

16225Thirty of the 40 patients (75%) who achieved CRs relapsed; only patients who proceeded to HSCT had long-term remissions (14 patients proceeded to HSCT, 6 relapsed). The median RFS was 6 months for this group of patients who achieved CRs.</li>

16226</ul>

16227</div>

16228</li>

16229<li>

16230A Chinese group treated 34 patients who had failed previous CD19-targeted CAR T-cell therapy with CD22-targeted CAR T cells.[<a href="#cit/section_10.191">

16231191</a>

16232]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16233<ul id="_2274">

16234<li>

16235 CR occurred in 80% of the patients evaluable at day 30 (71% of all patients).</li>

16236<li>

16237 Seven patients received no further therapy, and three patients remained in remission at 5 to 13 months after therapy.</li>

16238<li>

16239 Eleven patients went on to HSCT, with a 1-year LFS rate of 72%.</li>

16240<li>

16241 This study demonstrated that long-term salvage of patients failing CD19-targeted CAR T cells can occur with CD22-targeted CAR T cells plus HSCT.</li>

16242</ul>

16243</div>

16244</li>

16245</ol>

16246</div>

16247</section>

16248</section>

16249</section>

16250<section id="_1408">

16251<h3 id="_1408_toc">

16252Treatment of Isolated Extramedullary Relapse</h3>

16253<p id="_1055" tabindex="-1">

16254With improved success in treating children with ALL, the incidence of

16255isolated extramedullary relapse has decreased. The incidence of isolated

16256CNS relapse is less than 5%, and testicular relapse is less than 1% to 2%.[<a href="#cit/section_10.194">

16257194</a>

16258-<a href="#cit/section_10.196">

16259196</a>

16260] As with bone marrow and mixed relapses, time from initial diagnosis to relapse is a key prognostic factor in isolated extramedullary relapses.[<a href="#cit/section_10.197">

16261197</a>

16262] In addition, age older than 6 years at relapse was noted in one study as an adverse prognostic factor for patients with an isolated extramedullary relapse, while a second study suggested age 10 years as a better cutoff.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

1626316</a>

16264,<a href="#cit/section_10.198">

16265198</a>

16266] Of note, in most children with isolated extramedullary relapses, submicroscopic marrow disease can be demonstrated using sensitive molecular techniques,[<a href="#cit/section_10.199">

16267199</a>

16268] and successful treatment strategies must effectively control both local and systemic disease. Patients with an isolated CNS relapse who show greater than 0.01% MRD in a morphologically normal marrow have a worse prognosis (5-year EFS rate, 30%) than do patients with either no MRD or MRD less than 0.01% (5-year EFS rate, 60%).[<a href="#cit/section_10.199">

16269199</a>

16270]</p>

16271<section id="_1409">

16272<h4 id="_1409_toc">

16273Isolated CNS relapse</h4>

16274<p id="_1364" tabindex="-1">

16275Standard treatment options for childhood ALL that has recurred in the CNS include the following:</p>

16276<div class="pdq-content-list">

16277<ol id="_1410">

16278<li>

16279Systemic and intrathecal chemotherapy.</li>

16280<li>

16281Cranial or craniospinal radiation.</li>

16282<li>

16283HSCT.</li>

16284<li>

16285CAR T-cell therapy for isolated CNS disease that is multiply relapsed.</li>

16286</ol>

16287</div>

16288<p id="_1227" tabindex="-1">

16289While

16290the prognosis for children with isolated CNS relapse had been quite poor in the

16291past, aggressive systemic and intrathecal therapy followed by cranial or craniospinal

16292radiation has improved the outlook, particularly for patients who did not

16293receive cranial radiation during their first remission.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1629418</a>

16295,<a href="#cit/section_10.197">

16296197</a>

16297,<a href="#cit/section_10.200">

16298200</a>

16299,<a href="#cit/section_10.201">

16300201</a>

16301]</p>

16302<p id="_1266" tabindex="-1">

16303Evidence (chemotherapy and radiation therapy):</p>

16304<div class="pdq-content-list">

16305<ol id="_1267">

16306<li>

16307 In a Pediatric Oncology Group (POG) study using this strategy, children

16308who had not previously received radiation therapy and whose initial remission was 18 months or longer had a 4-year EFS rate of approximately 80%,

16309compared with EFS rates of approximately 45% for children with CNS relapse within

1631018 months of diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.197">

16311197</a>

16312]</li>

16313<li>

16314 In a follow-up POG study, children who had not previously received radiation therapy and who had an initial remission of 18 months or more were treated with intensive systemic and intrathecal chemotherapy for 1 year followed by 18 Gy of cranial radiation only.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1631518</a>

16316] <div class="pdq-content-list">

16317<ul id="_2289">

16318<li>

16319The 4-year EFS rate was 78%. Children with an initial remission of less than 18 months also received the same chemotherapy but had craniospinal radiation (24 Gy cranial/15 Gy spinal) as in the first POG study and achieved a 4-year EFS rate of 52%.</li>

16320</ul>

16321</div>

16322</li>

16323<li>

16324The Children&#8217;s Oncology Group <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00096135">

16325AALL02P2 (NCT00096135)</a>

16326 study enrolled 118 eligible children with B-ALL and late isolated CNS relapse. Patients received intensified systemic therapy, triple intrathecal chemotherapy, and 12 Gy of cranial irradiation delivered at 12 months, with maintenance chemotherapy continuing until 104 weeks postdiagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.202">

16327202</a>

16328]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16329<ul id="_2368">

16330<li>

16331The 3-year EFS rate was 64.3% (&#177; 4.5%), and the OS rate was 79.6% (&#177; 3.8%).</li>

16332<li>

16333 Second relapses that included the CNS occurred in 46.1% of patients (18 of 39).</li>

16334<li>

16335Of the 112 patients who completed therapy, 78 received protocol-specified radiation therapy.</li>

16336<li>

16337 Study enrollment was closed after interim monitoring analysis showed inferior EFS compared with the POG 9412 study, in which patients received 18 Gy of cranial radiation. Thus, the lower dose of cranial radiation was deemed to be inadequate.</li>

16338</ul>

16339</div>

16340</li>

16341</ol>

16342</div>

16343<p id="_1228" tabindex="-1">

16344A number of case series describing HSCT in the treatment of isolated CNS relapse have been published.[<a href="#cit/section_10.203">

16345203</a>

16346,<a href="#cit/section_10.204">

16347204</a>

16348] Although some reports have suggested a possible role for HSCT for patients with isolated CNS disease with very early relapse and T-cell disease, there is less evidence for the need for HSCT in early isolated CNS relapse in B-cell disease, and no evidence in late relapse. In the COG AALL0433 study, patients with B-ALL and a very early isolated CNS relapse were treated with either intensive chemotherapy with cranial radiation or allogeneic HSCT after second CR was achieved, depending on availability of donors and physician decisions. A small number of patients proceeded to HSCT (n = 7), which was associated with more favorable DFS and OS, compared with patients who continued on chemotherapy and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.31">

1634931</a>

16350]</p>

16351<p id="_1268" tabindex="-1">

16352Evidence (HSCT):</p>

16353<div class="pdq-content-list">

16354<ol id="_1269">

16355<li>

16356A retrospective, registry-based study compared the outcome of patients treated with either HLA-matched sibling transplants or chemoradiation therapy as in the POG studies above.[<a href="#cit/section_10.205">

16357205</a>

16358][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

16359Level of evidence C2</a>

16360] This study included transplantation of both early (&lt;18 months from diagnosis) and late relapses.<div class="pdq-content-list">

16361<ul id="_1366">

16362<li>

16363The 8-year probabilities of LFS adjusted for age (58%) and duration of first remission (66%) were similar.</li>

16364<li>

16365Because of the relatively good outcome of patients with isolated CNS relapse more than 18 months from diagnosis who were treated with chemoradiation therapy alone (&gt;75%), transplantation is generally not recommended by the COG for this group.</li>

16366</ul>

16367</div>

16368</li>

16369<li>

16370The MRC ALLR3 trial tested intensive induction with mitoxantrone versus idarubicin in relapsed ALL patients, defining a superior outcome when mitoxantrone was used. A subanalysis of 80 patients entering the trial with isolated CNS relapse included 13 patients with very early relapse (defined as &lt;18 months from first diagnosis), 55 patients with early relapse (defined as &gt;18 months from initial diagnosis but within 6 months of being off therapy), and 12 patients with late relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

1637116</a>

16372][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

16373Level of evidence B4</a>

16374]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16375<ul id="_1829">

16376<li>

16377Patients with late relapse did very well with chemotherapy/cranial radiation therapy, with 11 of 12 patients surviving.</li>

16378<li>

16379Allogeneic HSCT was recommended for very early and early relapse. Sixty-six patients were alive and relapse free after the planned three induction courses. Fifty-four patients with early and very early isolated CNS relapse were eligible for protocol-recommended HSCT, and 39 patients (72%) received HSCT. Twenty-one percent of these patients relapsed, compared with a relapse rate of 71% in the group that did not receive HSCT.</li>

16380<li>

16381Of those eligible for transplant, treatment with mitoxantrone rather than idarubicin during reinduction was associated with a survival advantage (3-year progression-free survival rates, 61% vs. 21%; <em>

16382P</em>

16383 = .027). As in the larger trial, the major advantage from the mitoxantrone arm occurred in those who received HSCT. Small patient numbers in the very early group prohibited detailed analysis of this cohort, and rates of failure within the early group treated with chemotherapy/cranial radiation therapy were inferior to other published experiences, calling into question this chemotherapy approach for early isolated CNS relapse patients.</li>

16384</ul>

16385</div>

16386</li>

16387</ol>

16388</div>

16389<p id="_2527" tabindex="-1">

16390Evidence (CAR T-cell therapy for isolated CNS disease that is multiply relapsed):</p>

16391<p id="_2528" tabindex="-1">

16392CAR T cells have been shown to penetrate the CNS and lead to high rates of remission in patients with CNS disease with or without marrow involvement. A small number of studies have addressed the relationship of CNS involvement with CAR T-cell therapy outcomes.</p>

16393<div class="pdq-content-list">

16394<ol id="_2529">

16395<li>

16396A single-center study reported on 195 sequential patients treated with 4-1BB CD19-targeted CAR T cells, 66 of whom had CNS disease (43 with isolated CNS disease, 23 with combined BM/CNS disease).[<a href="#cit/section_10.182">

16397182</a>

16398]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16399<ul id="_2530">

16400<li>

16401Overall, there was no difference in remission rates and progression-free survival in patients with or without CNS disease.</li>

16402<li>

16403Of the patients with CNS disease, 79% were second or greater relapse.</li>

16404<li>

16405Patients with isolated CNS involvement had an RFS rate at 2 years of 66% (95% CI, 52%&#8211;82%), compared with 58% (95% CI, 50%&#8211;68%) for patients with bone marrow involvement (<em>

16406P</em>

16407 = .15).</li>

16408</ul>

16409</div>

16410</li>

16411</ol>

16412</div>

16413</section>

16414<section id="_1411">

16415<h4 id="_1411_toc">

16416Isolated testicular relapse</h4>

16417<p id="_1230" tabindex="-1">

16418The results of treatment of isolated testicular

16419relapse depend on the timing of the relapse. The 3-year EFS rate of boys with overt testicular relapse during therapy is approximately

1642040%; it is approximately 85% for boys with late testicular relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_10.206">

16421206</a>

16422] </p>

16423<p id="_1367" tabindex="-1">

16424Standard treatment options in North America for childhood ALL that has recurred in the testes include the following:</p>

16425<div class="pdq-content-list">

16426<ol id="_1368">

16427<li>

16428Chemotherapy.</li>

16429<li>

16430Radiation therapy.</li>

16431</ol>

16432</div>

16433<p id="_1270" tabindex="-1">

16434Standard approaches for treating isolated testicular relapse in North America include local radiation therapy along with intensive chemotherapy. In some European clinical trial groups, orchiectomy of the involved testicle is performed instead of radiation. Biopsy of the other testicle is performed at the time of relapse to determine if additional local control (surgical removal or radiation) is to be performed. A

16435study that looked at testicular biopsy at the end of frontline therapy failed to

16436demonstrate a survival benefit for patients with early detection of occult

16437disease.[<a href="#cit/section_10.207">

16438207</a>

16439]</p>

16440<p id="_2043" tabindex="-1">

16441There are limited clinical data concerning outcome without the use of radiation therapy or orchiectomy. Treatment protocols that have tested this approach have incorporated intensified dosing of chemotherapy agents (e.g., high-dose methotrexate) that may be able to achieve antileukemic levels in the testes.</p>

16442<p id="_1296" tabindex="-1">

16443Evidence (treatment of testicular relapse):</p>

16444<div class="pdq-content-list">

16445<ol id="_1271">

16446<li>

16447The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00096135">

16448COG AALL02P2 (NCT00096135)</a>

16449 trial tested whether radiation therapy could be eliminated for patients with late isolated testicular relapse (occurring more than 18 months from diagnosis).[<a href="#cit/section_10.208">

16450208</a>

16451] On this trial, testicular size was reassessed after the initial month of reinduction chemotherapy, which included high-dose methotrexate. If the testicle remained enlarged, biopsy was performed, and if positive, patients were to be treated with local radiation therapy. Those with testes that normalized in size or who had negative biopsies were to be treated without radiation therapy. Postinduction chemotherapy for all patients (whether or not they were irradiated) included multiple courses of high-dose methotrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_10.209">

16452209</a>

16453]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16454<ul id="_2044">

16455<li>

16456Of 40 patients enrolled, 26 had persistent testicular enlargement after reinduction. Testicular biopsy was positive in 12 of these 26 patients, 11 of whom received testicular radiation therapy; all other patients on the trial were treated without radiation.</li>

16457<li>

16458Participants who received testicular radiation therapy achieved a 5-year EFS rate of 73% versus 61% for those who did not receive radiation (<em>

16459P</em>

16460 = .6); the 5-year OS rate was 73% for those who received testicular radiation versus 71% (<em>

16461P</em>

16462 = .9) for those who did not receive testicular radiation.</li>

16463<li>

16464Thus, for patients with isolated testicular relapse achieving a favorable response after initial induction (documented by size reduction and/or biopsy), omission of testicular radiation therapy may be a feasible option.</li>

16465</ul>

16466</div>
