16467</li>

16468<li>

16469Dutch investigators treated five boys with a late testicular relapse with high-dose methotrexate during induction (12 g/m<span class="sup">

164702</span>

16471) and at regular intervals during the remainder of therapy (6 g/m<span class="sup">

164722</span>

16473) without testicular radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.208">

16474208</a>

16475]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16476<ul id="_2290">

16477<li>

16478 All five boys were long-term survivors.</li>

16479</ul>

16480</div>

16481</li>

16482<li>

16483 In a small series of boys who had an isolated testicular relapse after an HSCT for a prior systemic relapse of ALL, five of seven boys had extended EFS without a second HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_10.157">

16484157</a>

16485][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

16486Level of evidence C1</a>

16487]</li>

16488</ol>

16489</div>

16490</section>

16491</section>

16492<section id="_1231">

16493<h3 id="_1231_toc">

16494Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Relapsed Childhood ALL</h3>

16495<section id="_1233">

16496<h4 id="_1233_toc">

16497Trials for ALL in first relapse</h4>

16498<p id="_1638" tabindex="-1">

16499Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

16500NCI website</a>

16501. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

16502ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

16503.</p>

16504<p id="_2007" tabindex="-1">

16505The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

16506<div class="pdq-content-list">

16507<ol id="_1642">

16508<li>

16509<strong>

16510<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT04546399">

16511COG-AALL1821 (NCT04546399)</a>

16512</strong>

16513 (A Study to Compare Blinatumomab Alone to Blinatumomab With Nivolumab in Patients Diagnosed With First Relapse B-ALL)<strong>

16514:</strong>

16515 This protocol is testing the incorporation of immunotherapeutic therapies into the treatment of patients with B-ALL who are in first marrow relapse. Patients are stratified into three groups on the basis of age at time of study entry and timing of relapse from initial diagnosis.<div class="pdq-content-list">

16516<ul id="_2402">

16517<li>

16518Group 1 patients are either: (1) older than 18 years (regardless of timing of relapse) or (2) younger than 18 years with relapse occurring less than 24 months from initial diagnosis. These patients are randomly assigned to receive either blinatumomab alone or blinatumomab in combination with nivolumab (a checkpoint inhibitor), as reinduction for one or two cycles, followed by allogeneic HSCT. </li>

16519</ul>

16520</div>

16521<p id="_2403" tabindex="-1">

16522All patients who do not qualify for group 1 (i.e., those who are younger than 18 years with relapse occurring more than 24 months from initial diagnosis) receive a four-drug reinduction (vincristine, dexamethasone, doxorubicin, and pegaspargase) and are then classified as either group 2 or group 3. </p>

16523<div class="pdq-content-list">

16524<ul id="_2404">

16525<li>

16526Group 2 patients are younger than 18 years with either: (1) relapse occurring between 24 months and 36 months from diagnosis, regardless of end-reinduction MRD or (2) relapse occurring more than 36 months from diagnosis with MRD greater than 0.1% after four-drug reinduction. These patients are randomly assigned to receive either blinatumomab alone or blinatumomab in combination with nivolumab, as postinduction consolidation, before proceeding to allogeneic HSCT.</li>

16527<li>

16528Group 3 patients are younger than 18 years with relapse occurring more than 36 months from diagnosis and MRD less than 0.1% after four-drug reinduction and are not allocated to HSCT. These patients are randomly assigned to receive standard consolidation chemotherapy alternating with either three cycles of blinatumomab monotherapy or blinatumomab in combination with nivolumab, followed by maintenance therapy. </li>

16529</ul>

16530</div>

16531<p id="_2405" tabindex="-1">

16532Isolated extramedullary patients are not eligible for this trial.</p>

16533</li>

16534<li>

16535<strong>

16536<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02879643">

16537TACL 2012-002 (NCT02879643)</a>

16538</strong>

16539 (Vincristine Sulfate Liposome Injection in Combination with UKALL R3 Induction Chemotherapy for Children, Adolescents, and Young Adults with Relapsed ALL)<strong>

16540:</strong>

16541 This trial is assessing the safety and feasibility of vincristine sulfate liposome injection as replacement for standard vincristine in the UKALL R3 induction regimen in ALL patients (B-ALL or T-ALL) with first, second, or third relapse. Patients with either M2 (5%&#8211;24% blasts) or M3 (&gt;25% blasts) marrow involvement are eligible.</li>

16542</ol>

16543</div>

16544</section>

16545<section id="_1239">

16546<h4 id="_1239_toc">

16547Trials for ALL in second or subsequent relapse or refractory ALL</h4>

16548<p id="_1240" tabindex="-1">

16549Multiple clinical trials investigating new agents and new combinations of agents are available for children with second or subsequent relapsed or refractory ALL and should be considered. These trials are testing targeted treatments specific for ALL, including monoclonal antibody&#8211;based therapies and drugs that inhibit signal transduction pathways required for leukemia cell growth and survival. Multiple clinical trials investigating new agents, new combinations of agents, and immunotherapeutic approaches are available. For more information, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

16550ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

16551.</p>

16552</section>

16553<section id="_TrialSearch_1231_sid_9">

16554<h4 id="_TrialSearch_1231_sid_9_toc">

16555Current Clinical Trials</h4>

16556<p id="_TrialSearch_1231_22" tabindex="-1">

16557Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

16558advanced clinical trial search</a>

16559 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

16560General information</a>

16561 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

16562</section>

16563</section>

16591<li id="section_10.7">

Medical Research Council Working Party on Childhood Leukaemia. Br J Haematol 101 (1): 94-103, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9576189&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9576189&amp;dopt=Abstract">

16593[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

16594</li>

16595<li id="section_10.8">

16596Buchanan GR, Rivera GK, Pollock BH, et al.: Alternating drug pairs with or without periodic reinduction in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia in second bone marrow remission: a Pediatric Oncology Group Study. Cancer 88 (5): 1166-74, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10699908&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10699908&amp;dopt=Abstract">

16597[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

16598</li>

17372Hastings C, Chen Y, Devidas M, et al.: Late isolated central nervous system relapse in childhood B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia treated with intensified systemic therapy and delayed reduced dose cranial radiation: A report from the Children's Oncology Group study AALL02P2. 17373[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

17374</li>

17375<li id="section_10.203">

17376Yoshihara T, Morimoto A, Kuroda H, et al.: Allogeneic stem cell transplantation in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia after isolated central nervous system relapse: our experiences and review of the literature. Bone Marrow Transplant 37 (1): 25-31, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16247416&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16247416&amp;dopt=Abstract">

17377[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

17378</li>

17379<li id="section_10.204">

17380Harker-Murray PD, Thomas AJ, Wagner JE, et al.: Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation in children with relapsed acute lymphoblastic leukemia isolated to the central nervous system. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 14 (6): 685-92, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18489994&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18489994&amp;dopt=Abstract">

17381[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

17382</li>

17383<li id="section_10.205">

17384Eapen M, Zhang MJ, Devidas M, et al.: Outcomes after HLA-matched sibling transplantation or chemotherapy in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia in a second remission after an isolated central nervous system relapse: a collaborative study of the Children's Oncology Group and the Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research. Leukemia 22 (2): 281-6, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18033318&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18033318&amp;dopt=Abstract">

17385[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

17386</li>

17387<li id="section_10.206">

17388Wofford MM, Smith SD, Shuster JJ, et al.: Treatment of occult or late overt testicular relapse in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia: a Pediatric Oncology Group study. J Clin Oncol 10 (4): 624-30, 1992.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1548525&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1548525&amp;dopt=Abstract">

17389[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

17390</li>

17391<li id="section_10.207">

17392Trigg ME, Steinherz PG, Chappell R, et al.: Early testicular biopsy in males with acute lymphoblastic leukemia: lack of impact on subsequent event-free survival. J Pediatr Hematol Oncol 22 (1): 27-33, 2000 Jan-Feb.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10695818&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10695818&amp;dopt=Abstract">

17393[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

17394</li>

17395<li id="section_10.208">

17396van den Berg H, Langeveld NE, Veenhof CH, et al.: Treatment of isolated testicular recurrence of acute lymphoblastic leukemia without radiotherapy. Report from the Dutch Late Effects Study Group. Cancer 79 (11): 2257-62, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9179075&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9179075&amp;dopt=Abstract">

17397[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

17398</li>

17399<li id="section_10.209">

17400Barredo JC, Hastings C, Lu X, et al.: Isolated late testicular relapse of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia treated with intensive systemic chemotherapy and response-based testicular radiation: A Children's Oncology Group study. Pediatr Blood Cancer 65 (5): e26928, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29286562&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29286562&amp;dopt=Abstract">

17401[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

17402</li>

17403</ol>

17404</div>

17405

17406 </section>

17407

17408

17409

17410 <section id="_58">

17411

17412 <h2>

17413Changes to This Summary (09/07/2023)</h2>

17414

17415 <div id="_section_58" class="pdq-sections">

17416<p id="_1456" tabindex="-1">

17417The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as

17418new information becomes available. This section describes the latest

17419changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

17420<p id="_2577" tabindex="-1">

17421<strong>

17422<a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_727">

17423Treatment of Newly Diagnosed Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)</a>

17424</strong>

17425</p>

17426<p id="_2596" tabindex="-1">

17427Added <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_1375">

17428text</a>

17429 to state that pegaspargase is not available in the United States, but it is still available in other countries.</p>

17430<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

17431This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

17432PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

17433, which is

17434editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

17435the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

17436information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

17437maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

17438About This PDQ Summary</a>

17439 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

17440PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

17441 pages.

17442</p>

17443</div>

17444

17445 </section>

17446

17447

17448

17449 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

17450

17451 <h2>

17452About This PDQ Summary</h2>

17453

17454 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

17455<section id="_AboutThis_2">

17456<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

17457Purpose of This Summary</h3>

17458<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

17459This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the treatment of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

17460</section>

17461<section id="_AboutThis_4">

17462<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

17463Reviewers and Updates</h3>

17464<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

17465This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

17466PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

17467, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

17468<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

17469 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

17470<div class="pdq-content-list">

17471<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

17472<li>

17473be discussed at a meeting,</li>

17474<li>

17475be cited with text, or</li>

17476<li>

17477replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

17478</ul>

17479</div>

17480<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

17481Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

17482<p id="" tabindex="-1">

17483The lead reviewers for Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment are:</p>

17484<div class="pdq-content-list">

17485<ul id="">

17486<li>

17487William L. Carroll, MD (Laura and Isaac Perlmutter Cancer Center at NYU Langone)</li>

17488<li>

17489Alan Scott Gamis, MD, MPH (Children's Mercy Hospital)</li>

17490<li>

17491Michelle Hermiston, MD, PhD (University of California, San Francisco)</li>

17492<li>

17493Karen J. Marcus, MD, FACR (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute/Boston Children's Hospital)</li>

17494<li>

17495Jessica Pollard, MD (Dana-Farber/Boston Children's Cancer and Blood Disorders Center)</li>

17496<li>

17497Michael A. Pulsipher, MD (Children's Hospital Los Angeles)</li>

17498<li>

17499Rachel E. Rau, MD (Texas Medical Center)</li>

17500<li>

17501Arthur Kim Ritchey, MD (Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh of UPMC)</li>

17502<li>

17503Lewis B. Silverman, MD (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute/Boston Children's Hospital)</li>

17504<li>

17505Malcolm A. Smith, MD, PhD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

17506<li>

17507Sarah K. Tasian, MD (Children's Hospital of Philadelphia)</li>

17508</ul>

17509</div>

17510<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

17511Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

17512Email Us</a>

17513. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

17514</section>

17515<section id="_AboutThis_10">

17516<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

17517Levels of Evidence</h3>

17518<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

17519Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/treatment">

17520formal evidence ranking system</a>

17521 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

17522</section>

17523<section id="_AboutThis_12">

17524<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

17525Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

17526<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

17527PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

17528<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

17529The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

17530<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

17531PDQ&#174; Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board. PDQ Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq">

17532https://www.cancer.gov/types/leukemia/hp/child-all-treatment-pdq</a>

17533. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389206]</p>

17534<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

17535Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

17536Visuals Online</a>

17537, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

17538

17539</p>

17540</section>

17541<section id="_AboutThis_17">

17542<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

17543Disclaimer</h3>

17544<p id="_AboutThis_18" tabindex="-1">

17545Based on the strength of the available evidence, treatment options may be described as either &#8220;standard&#8221; or &#8220;under clinical evaluation.&#8221; These classifications should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

17546Managing Cancer Care</a>

17547 page.</p>

17548</section>

17549<section id="_AboutThis_20">

17550<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

17551Contact Us</h3>

17552<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

17553More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

17554Contact Us for Help</a>

17555 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

17556Email Us</a>

17557.</p>

17558</section>

17559</div>
